item.title: HOMEPAGE

To navigate, click on the right or left menu bars. Good luck! Check back regularly for updates-rb Theories and Models Health Assessment Nursing Research Pharmacology I Nursing Foundations Med-Surg I Med-Surg II OB Peds Pysch => in progress Pharmacology II (Nov) Community Health I (Dec) Community Health II (Jan) Leadership (Feb-Mar) Professional Issues in Nursing (Apr)

item.title: Antidepressants
item.description:
5 Main Types of Antidepressants MAOIs Isocarboxazid: (Marplan), Phenelzine: (Nardil), Tranylcypromine: (Parnate), Selegiline: (Emsam) DO NOT MIX WITH any other Antidepressants
TCAs Amitriptyline (Elavil), Clomipramine (Anafranil), Desipramine (Norpramin), Doxepin (Sinequan), Imipramine (Tofranil), Nortriptyline (Pamelor), Protriptyline (Vivactil), and Trimipramine (Surmontil)
SSRIs Fluoxetine (Prozac), Sertraline (Zoloft), Paroxetine (Paxil), Citalopram (Celexa), and Escitalopram (Lexapro)
SNRIs Venlafaxine (Effexor), Duloxetine (Cymbalta), Desvenlafaxine (Pristiq), Milnacipran (Savella), and Levomilnacipran (Fetzima)
Neurosteroid Antidepressants
see PsychopharmOrder of Use: First Line: SSRI Second Line: SNRI TCA - reserved for treatment-resistant depression after all else fails; avoid in elderly, ECG d/t cardiac risk, orthostatic hypotension Last Line - MAOI; atypical depression, strict dietary restrictions and drug interactions may Increase suicidal thots during first week especially 18-24 year olds notify provider for any suicidal thoughts; sudden change in mood clarify any new prescription worsening depression Slow Onset and SLOW taper off never stop abruptly Never MIX: SSRI + St. John's Wort
MAOI + any other Antidepressants => can lead to serotonin syndrome 2 week washout All Psych Drugs: decrease BP - falls risk weight Gain

item.title: Psychopharm
item.description:
updated 9/15 neurons => brain tissue n shit Neurotransmitters - key and lock system (neurotransmitter: key; receptor site: lock); then they are either: Reuptake: neurotransmitter is stored for reuse or broken down Inactivated => prevents continuous stimulation of receptors (Acetylcholinesterase, Monoamine Oxidases, Catechol-O-Methyltransferase) see => NeurotransmittersGenetics mental illnesss can be inheritable Neurobiology - functioning of bran impacts behavior example: twins with separate living environment can develop mental illness, addiction is passed down from parent to child Psychiatric Pharmacogenomic Testing study that seeks to understand how the genetics of an individual may impact the interaction on psychotropic mediccations can show severity of side effects Psychoimmunology studies impact of psychosocial stress on the body’s immune system relationship between stress and the immune system may be related to the presentation of some manifestations of mental illness Infection => viral infection possibly alters genetic composition in the central nervous system leading to the presentation of mental illnessNeuroplasticity brain’s ability to adapt synaptic connections, particularly in response to stress or learning or after experiencing an injury ability to establish new neuronal pathways or go through complete neuronal remapping in response to a stimulus may take weeks or months to reconfigure pathways Explains why: some manifestations of mental illness increase in severity over time, such as Major Depressive Disorder, and cannot be cured through a single dose of medication Explains why: pysch meds take weeks to take effect
Antidepressants
Antipsychotics
Anxiolytics
Mood Stabilizers
Sedative-Hypnotics
Herbal RemediesSerotonin Syndrome too much serotonin causes: too much SSRI, migrain/pain meds, LSD, ecstasy, combining antidepressants with St. John's wort Manifestations: restlessness, high BP, tachycardia, dilated pupils, muscle rigidity, sweating, loss of muscle coordinator Treatment: sedate with benzodiazepines, serotonin antagonist medications like cyproheptadine. Activation Syndrome can potentially happen when starting SSRI manifestations of irritability, anxiety, impulsivity, aggressiveness, and agitation High risk for suicidal ideations may develop within the first few hours of administration through the first few weeks Antidepressant Discontinuation Syndrome sudden discontinuation of the antidepressant medication difficulty sleeping, anxiety, depression, and flu-like symptoms rare: electric-shock-like sensations felt in their heads that can disrupt ADLs stopping MAOIs - psychosis may persist for weeks Lithium Toxicity anything greater than 1.5 mEq/L
Causes: dehydration, overdose, concurrent use with Loop Diuretics Manifestations: Early Toxicity 1.5 mEq/L poor coordination, confusion, and sedation GI discomfort, nausea, coarse tremors, vomiting, and diarrhea Treatment: withhold, consult provider Advanced => 2.0-2.5 seizures and stupor Extremely diluted urine, blurred vision, respiratory complications, tinnitus, and jerking motor movements Treatment: urea or mannitol to increase kidney excretion, gastric lavage Severe => greater than 2.5 mEq/L rapid deterioration -> comatose -> death treat: dialysis Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS)
initial exposure or abrupt continuation of Antipsychotics FGA => higher risk muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, vital sign instability (increased/decreased blood pressure and tachycardia), and elevated creatine kinase Nursing Intervention: monitoring fluid and electrolytes, initiating cooling measures, and placing the client on cardiac monitoring Treatment: dopaminergic agent, such as bromocriptine, or a skeletal muscle relaxing medication such as dantrolene Extrapyramidal Symptoms (EPS) effect of blocking dopamine transmission from the midbrain to the brainstem. Types: Akathisia: Restlessness, pacing, fidgeting Dystonia: Muscle stiffness, spasms, locked gaze Parkinsonism: Tremors, rigidity, slow movements, slumped posture, shuffling gait, drooling, tremors, and pill-rolling movements of the fingers Tardive dyskinesia: Involuntary movements of the face, tongue, and limbs Treatment: anticholinergic => diphenhydramine, benzotropine; or valbenazine Usually: B52 - benadryl, haldol, ativan Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale (AIMS) is an evidence-based assessment of the level of tardive dyskinesia based on abnormal movement. Agranulocytosis
caused by Antipsychotics => usually Clozaril / Clozipine (Atypical, or Second Gen Antipsychotics) Manifestations: flu-like, fatigue, sore throat, fatigue, fever, muscle aches very dangerous Alcohol Withdrawal prolonged CNS depressant => decreased GABA, increased, Gluatamate heart rate, increased blood pressure, nausea, vomiting, increased seizure risk, and hallucinations Treatment: benzodiazepine Opiate Withdrawal desensitized opiate receptor signaling large amounts of norepinephrine are released causing manifestations like muscle aches, goose flesh, GI discomfort, and sweating Life-threatening: nausea, vomitting, diarrhea -> dehydration, e- imbalance treat: methadone or buprenorphine (Suboxone => added naloxone) Detox Protocol Clinical Institute Withdrawal Assessment for Alcohol-Revised (CIWA-Ar) Clinical Opiate Withdrawal Scale (COWS) Steps: use appropriate scale - CIWA/COWS rate severity of withdrawal manifestations calculate sum of categories calculate med dose per orders administer meds

item.title: Lithium
item.description: class: Mood Stabilizers long-term treatment => Lithium Battery - duracell 0.6-1.2 mEq/L, toxicity happens after 1.5 mEq/L watch out for decreased renal function -> sets stage for toxicity (key: elderly) Creatinine 1.3, mL/hr, tinnitus LIT => note these Levels over 1.5 => toxic levels! Increasing Fluid & Sodium do not give lithium during dehydration and low sodium do not restrict water or sodium if a patient is vomiting or shitting like crazy, they are at increased risk for lit-tox report sodium less than 135 have patients drink 1-3L per day limit diuretics: coffee, colas, teas No anticholinergic meds Toxic Signs report excessive urination and extreme thirst neuromuscular excitability (ataxia, tingling) Hold the NSAIDs - Ibuprofen, NSAIDs (decrease renal blood flow) Alters sodium transport in nerve and muscle cells Influences reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine Stabilizes neuronal firing and reduces excitability Bipolar disorder treatment and maintenance Reduces mania and prevents recurrence of mood episodes GI upset, nausea, diarrhea Polyuria, polydipsia Fine hand tremor Weight gain Mild cognitive slowing dry mouth, thirst => do NOT report, ask them to suck a candy Lithium toxicity: coarse tremor, ataxia, confusion, seizures, coma Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus Hypothyroidism, goiter Arrhythmias, bradycardia Renal impairment Severe renal impairment Pregnancy (especially 1st trimester, risk of Ebstein anomaly) Dehydration or sodium depletion Concurrent use with diuretics or ACE inhibitors (raises toxicity risk) Monitor serum lithium levels (0.6–1.2 mEq/L therapeutic, >1.5 toxic) Assess renal and thyroid function regularly Maintain consistent fluid and sodium intake Monitor for signs of toxicity Ensure adherence, long-term therapy often required Diuretics (esp. thiazides) increase lithium levels ACE inhibitors and ARBs increase lithium levels NSAIDs increase lithium levels Caffeine decreases lithium levels Take medication at the same time daily Stay hydrated and maintain normal salt intake Do not stop abruptly without medical supervision Report symptoms of toxicity immediately (severe tremor, vomiting, confusion) Avoid NSAIDs unless approved by provider Regular blood tests are required to monitor levels updated 9/20

item.title: Carbamezapine
item.description: Mood Stabilizers and Seizures treatment for trigeminal myalgia (neuropathic pain) Leukopenia - watch out for infections, report fevers and sore throat! accidental pregnancy - oral contraceptives will not be effec last updated 9/20

item.title: Antipsychotics
item.description: First is Stiff, Second is Soft (First = EPS, Second = metabolic, DM2) First Generation => block dopamine receptors Second Generation => lesser degree of blocking dopamine receptors, inhibit serotonin reuptake Third Generation => regulate dopamine transmission Common Adverse Effects: anticholinergic: dry mouth, constipation, blurred vision, orthostatic hypotension Increased Breast tissue, decreased sex drive, irregular menstruation Nursing Interventions: hard candies - dry mouth encourage fiber, water, sugarless gum fall precautions Extrapyramidal Symptoms (EPS) involuntary movements that can occur as a side effect Akathisia: Restlessness, pacing, fidgeting Dystonia: Muscle stiffness, spasms Parkinsonism: Tremors, rigidity, slow movements Tardive dyskinesia: Involuntary movements of the face, tongue, and limbs Treatment: diphenhydramine Think of the spectrum of dopamine: Parkinsons ---- Homeostasis ---- Psychosis not enough dope ------------------- too much dope

item.title: Second Gen Antipsychotics
item.description: weight gain hypersalivation sedation agranular cytosis low immunity low WBC, Leukopenia high infection risk! CloZAPine ZAPS WBC! sore throat, fever, flu-like symptoms Immediately report to HCP Dementia - do not give for these patients (remove from Dementia) brand name: Geodon Watch out for: hypotension widened QT intervals monitor BP, ECG ZiprasiDONE - you are DONE if you have prolonged QT, and low BPpart of Antipsychotics updated 9/20

item.title: Haloperidol
item.description:
indication: schizophrenia, tourette's usually given with Benziodiazepine to control aggressive behavior EPS: extrapyramidal symptoms -> not life threatening dystonia spasm muscle contractions, usually of neck, face, tongue Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS) - life threatening high fever diaphoresis change in mental status muscle rigidity tremors Hold Haloperidol Assess Patient Notify Provider don't do anything else before doing the above
part of Antipsychotics updated 9/20

item.title: Benziodiazepine
item.description: ends in "-lam" and "-pam" Midazolam, AlprazoLAM, MedazoLAM TemazePAM, ClonazePAM acts fast - within minutes addictive - not safe for long term use for anxiety, seizure, alcohol withdrawal, sedation increases GABA => decreases neuron activity, induces sleep GABA in GRANDMA -> keeps everyone calm everything is low and slow: HR, BP, RR sedation -> suppression of ABC take at bedtime don't skip doses taper off -> do not abruptly stop do not take alcohol - increase sedation (depressant) flumazenil

item.title: Buspirone
item.description: not a sedative => you can drive the BUS in BUSpirone slow and really easy to quit atypical antianxiolytic no depressing effect 2-4 weeks for full effect ADVANTAGE: no withdrawal symptoms, no tolerance, no sedation you can still drive not for acute attacks not a PRN med! part of Anxiolytics

item.title: Anxiolytics
item.description:
Anxiolytics > Benzodiazepines
Anxiolytics > Buspirone
Anxiolytic and sedative hypnotic agents (see Benziodiazepine) Common examples include lorazepam, diazepam, alprazolam, midazolam, clonazepam Potential for abuse: causes release of dopamine => feeling of rewarded FALL RISK usually ends with "-pam" Diazepam – Valium. Lorazepam – Ativan. Alprazolam – Xanax. Clonazepam – Klonopin. Chlordiazepoxide – Librium. Oxazepam – Serax. Temazepam – Restoril. Midazolam – Versed. Triazolam – Halcion. Flurazepam – Dalmane. Estazolam – ProSom. Clorazepate – Tranxene.Mechanism of Action Enhance effect of gamma aminobutyric acid (GABA) at GABA A receptor Increase frequency of chloride channel opening Produce neuronal hyperpolarization and CNS depression Therapeutic Use Anxiety disorders Acute stress reactions Insomnia short term management Seizure disorders including status epilepticus Muscle relaxation in spasticity Alcohol withdrawal symptoms Preoperative sedation Side Effects Drowsiness fatigue Dizziness lightheadedness Impaired coordination and balance Memory impairment and confusion Blurred vision Gastrointestinal upset Adverse Effects Respiratory depression especially with other CNS depressants Dependence and tolerance with prolonged use Withdrawal symptoms if abruptly discontinued Paradoxical reactions such as agitation or aggression Overdose leading to coma hypotension respiratory failure note: flumazenil => for overdoseContraindications Hypersensitivity to benzodiazepines Severe respiratory insufficiency or sleep apnea Severe hepatic impairment Acute narrow angle glaucoma Pregnancy and breastfeeding due to risk of fetal harm Nursing Considerations Falls risk => especially caution with elderly due to fall risk and delirium Assess baseline anxiety level sleep pattern or seizure activity Monitor respiratory status and level of consciousness Use lowest effective dose for shortest duration Taper gradually to prevent withdrawal Keep flumazenil available as antidote for overdose Drug Interactions Potentiation with alcohol opioids antihistamines barbiturates CYP3A4 inhibitors such as ketoconazole or grapefruit juice increase drug levels Smoking and rifampin decrease effectiveness Enhanced sedation with antidepressants or antipsychotics Important Patient Education Avoid alcohol and other sedatives Do not drive or operate heavy machinery until drug effects are known Take medication exactly as prescribed do not double doses Do not stop suddenly taper required to avoid withdrawal Report mood changes unusual behavior or breathing problems Use for short term relief not long term management unless specifically directed You can drive the bus, in buspirone => it's not sedating
see BuspironeMechanism of Action Partial agonist at serotonin 5 HT1A receptors Moderate affinity for dopamine D2 receptors Does not affect GABA receptors Therapeutic Use Generalized anxiety disorder Alternative to benzodiazepines for long term anxiety management Off label use in depression augmentation Side Effects Dizziness lightheadedness Headache Nausea Nervousness Restlessness Fatigue Adverse Effects Serotonin syndrome if combined with other serotonergic agents Extrapyramidal symptoms rare Tachycardia or palpitations Allergic reactions Contraindications Hypersensitivity to buspirone Concurrent use with MAOIs within 14 days due to hypertensive reaction Severe hepatic or renal impairment Nursing Considerations Assess baseline anxiety and monitor therapeutic response Takes 2 to 4 weeks for full effect unlike benzodiazepines Not useful for acute anxiety or panic attacks Monitor for signs of serotonin syndrome with SSRIs or SNRIs Safe profile with minimal sedation or abuse potential Drug Interactions Avoid MAOIs due to risk of hypertensive crisis Grapefruit juice increases serum levels Increased risk of serotonin syndrome with SSRIs SNRIs triptans CYP3A4 inhibitors raise drug levels while inducers reduce effectiveness Important Patient Education Take consistently either with or without food May take several weeks for full benefit Do not use for immediate anxiety relief Avoid alcohol and grapefruit juice Report unusual movements chest pain or mood changes Low risk of dependence compared to benzodiazepines

item.title: Nursing Process - Phsych Nursing
item.description: updated ADPIE: Assessment Analysis (previously "Diagnosis") Planning Implementation Evaluation Clinical Judgement Action Model (CJAM): RAP-GAE Recognize cues - gather patient data Analyze Cues - link and organize cues, recognize patterns, look for relationships Prioritize Hypotheses - evaluate and rank potential problems based on cues Generate Solutions - develop/identify nursing interventions Take Action - implement by highest priority Evaluate - compare observed vs expected outcomes, assess effectiveness must be S.M.A.R.T goals Conditions that can Mimic a Mental Illness: THINCMED T – Tumors H – Hormones I – Infection or infectious diseases such as uremia or sepsis N – Nutritional deficits C – CNS disturbances such as neurological conditions or head injury M – Miscellaneous medical conditions E – Electrolyte disturbances or environmental toxins D – Drugs and substances use or polypharmacy Family Assessment Device (FAD) assess family functioning, specifically to determine how the roles of the family work in the family dynamics Mental Status Exam - Mini-Mental Status Exam - takes 10 minutes; language, memory, attention, orientation, visuospatial proficiency Min-Cog - 5 minutes => everything the MMSE does except attention and orientation MoCA - Montreal Cgonitive ASsessment - 10 minutes, attention, language, memory, orioentation, executive function ACE-R / Addenbrooke's Cognitive Exam (revised) - 20 min, assess executive functioning, oritentation, language, visuospatial proficiency, memoryMental Health Assessment Cues:When patients don't like to take meds -> reinforce that benefits outweigh the risks
item.guid: Psych/ii. Relationship Building/Nursing Process - Phsych Nursing.md

item.title: MAOIs
item.description:
updated 9/20 Monoamine oxidase inhibitors Antidepressants, panic disorder, social disorder Key drugs: phenelzine, selegiline, isocarboxazid also: tranylcypromine Key points: MAOI M - massive HTN crisis, headache A - avoid tyramine (alcohol, cheese, meat, dried fruits, fermented food, chocolate); start diet 2 weeks, continue 2 weeks after stopping O - OTC drugs => HTN crisis, avoid: calcium, antacids, acetaminophen, NSAIDs
O - avoid other Antidepressants -> serotonin syndrome; fully taper off -> 2 weeks I - Increased suicide risk Irreversibly inhibit monoamine oxidase enzyme Prevent breakdown of serotonin, norepinephrine, dopamine Increase levels of monoamines in synaptic cleft Major depressive disorder treatment resistant cases Atypical depression with hypersomnia and hyperphagia Anxiety disorders such as social anxiety disorder Parkinson disease with selegiline Orthostatic hypotension Weight gain Sexual dysfunction Insomnia Edema Tremors Hypertensive crisis with tyramine rich foods or sympathomimetic drugs Serotonin syndrome if combined with SSRIs SNRIs or TCAs Hepatotoxicity rare Severe headache, palpitations, chest pain in hypertensive crisis Concurrent use with SSRIs, SNRIs, TCAs, or other MAOIs Use with meperidine or dextromethorphan Cardiovascular disease or uncontrolled hypertension Pheochromocytoma History of liver disease Monitor blood pressure regularly Assess dietary intake for tyramine containing foods: smoked meats, red wine, beer, aged cheeses, chocolate, avocado, and soy products like tofu Educate about delayed onset of therapeutic effect Monitor for signs of serotonin syndrome Ensure 2 week washout when switching antidepressant classes Selegiline transdermal patch may reduce dietary restrictions at low doses Tyramine containing foods such as aged cheese cured meats red wine cause hypertensive crisis Sympathomimetic drugs like pseudoephedrine cause severe hypertension SSRIs SNRIs TCAs and certain opioids increase risk of serotonin syndrome Antihypertensives may cause additive hypotension Avoid foods high in tyramine Report severe headache chest pain or palpitations immediately Allow at least 2 week washout before starting new antidepressant Take medication consistently do not stop abruptly Avoid over the counter cold medications unless approved Inform all healthcare providers about MAOI use

item.title: Neurosteroid Antidepressants
item.description: Neurosteroid Antidepressants Allopregnanolone analogs Examples include brexanolone zuranolone Positive allosteric modulators of GABA A receptors Enhance inhibitory neurotransmission Restore balance between excitatory and inhibitory signaling in brain Brexanolone used for postpartum depression Zuranolone approved for major depressive disorder and postpartum depression Considered for patients not responding to traditional antidepressants Dizziness Sedation or somnolence Headache Nausea Fatigue Dry mouth Excessive sedation and sudden loss of consciousness with brexanolone Respiratory depression at high doses Suicidal ideation Dependence potential not well established but monitored Hypersensitivity to drug Caution with concurrent CNS depressants Severe hepatic impairment for some formulations Not recommended in patients with history of loss of consciousness with sedative drugs Brexanolone requires continuous IV infusion over 60 hours in certified healthcare facility Monitor oxygen saturation and level of consciousness during infusion Assess depression severity and suicidal ideation Educate patient about risk of sedation and need for monitoring Evaluate therapeutic response especially in postpartum patients Zuranolone is oral and can be given outpatient with less monitoring but still requires suicide risk screening CNS depressants like alcohol benzodiazepines opioids enhance sedation Strong CYP3A4 inhibitors increase serum levels CYP3A4 inducers decrease drug effectiveness Brexanolone infusion requires hospital stay with continuous monitoring Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery until drug effects are known Report excessive drowsiness fainting or breathing difficulties Adhere to dosing schedule for zuranolone if prescribed orally Inform provider of all other medications and supplements Not a first line antidepressant but effective for specific cases like postpartum depression

item.title: SNRIs
item.description: Serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors Second line Antidepressants after SSRIs most popular: Duloxetine Examples: venlafaxine, desvenlafaxine, duloxetine, levomilnacipran Note: patient refusal of this med is common, if so, educate them! Inhibit reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine at presynaptic neuron Increase levels of both neurotransmitters in synaptic cleft Minimal effect on dopamine Major depressive disorder Generalized anxiety disorder Panic disorder and social anxiety disorder Neuropathic pain and fibromyalgia with duloxetine Chronic musculoskeletal pain Stress urinary incontinence off label Unique Side Effect: Appetite Suppression Nausea, vomiting Insomnia or sedation Dizziness, headache Sweating Sexual dysfunction Dry mouth, constipation Hypertension and tachycardia due to norepinephrine reuptake inhibition Increased risk of suicidal ideation especially in adolescents Serotonin syndrome with serotonergic drugs Hepatotoxicity with duloxetine Withdrawal symptoms if abruptly discontinued Concurrent use with MAOIs or within 14 day washout Uncontrolled hypertension Hepatic impairment with duloxetine Known hypersensitivity Monitor blood pressure and heart rate regularly Assess liver function especially with duloxetine Watch for serotonin syndrome symptoms Educate about gradual tapering to avoid withdrawal Evaluate mood and suicide risk especially at therapy initiation Assess pain control in patients treated for neuropathic pain MAOIs increase risk of hypertensive crisis and serotonin syndrome SSRIs TCAs triptans increase risk of serotonin syndrome NSAIDs anticoagulants increase bleeding risk CYP inhibitors or inducers alter drug levels Take medication consistently at same time each day May take several weeks for full effect Do not stop abruptly taper required Report sustained elevated blood pressure palpitations or liver symptoms such as jaundice Avoid alcohol to reduce liver stress Inform provider about all medications and supplements

item.title: SSRIs
item.description:
Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors -> keeping more around, serotonin is good! First line Antidepressants, PTSD Examples include fluoxetine, sertraline, paroxetine ,citalopram, escitalopram fluvoxamine takes 2-4 weeks to reach full effect Inhibit reuptake of serotonin at presynaptic neuron Increase serotonin levels in synaptic cleft Minimal effect on norepinephrine or dopamine Major depressive disorder Anxiety disorders including generalized anxiety disorder panic disorder and social anxiety Obsessive compulsive disorder Post traumatic stress disorder Premenstrual dysphoric disorder Bulimia nervosa with fluoxetine Nausea diarrhea or gastrointestinal upset Headache Insomnia or somnolence => it is not a sedative Sexual dysfunction decreased libido anorgasmia Weight changes gain or loss depending on drug Tremor Increased risk of suicidal ideation especially in adolescents Serotonin syndrome when combined with serotonergic agents aka serotonin overdose
never mix with St Johns wort, MAOIs, tramadol SRI = Sweaty hot fever, Rigid muscles, restlessness, agitation, Increased HR Hyponatremia due to SIADH especially in elderly QT prolongation with citalopram at high doses Withdrawal symptoms if abruptly discontinued dizziness irritability flu like symptoms
Concurrent use with MAOIs or within 14 days washout Known hypersensitivity Caution in seizure disorders Caution with prolonged QT interval especially with citalopram Monitor mood and suicidal thoughts especially early in treatment Assess for therapeutic effect after 2 to 4 weeks Monitor sodium levels in elderly or those on diuretics Avoid abrupt discontinuation taper gradually Watch for signs of serotonin syndrome such as agitation hyperreflexia diaphoresis fever Educate that full therapeutic benefit may take 4 to 6 weeks
DO NOT TAKE with St. John's Wort (see Herbal Remedies) MAOIs and SNRIs increase risk of serotonin syndrome Warfarin NSAIDs and aspirin increase bleeding risk CYP450 interactions fluoxetine and paroxetine inhibit metabolism of other drugs Triptans increase risk of serotonin syndrome Take at same time daily May take weeks for full effect Do not stop abruptly taper required Report suicidal thoughts severe agitation or signs of serotonin syndrome Avoid alcohol or sedating drugs Inform provider of all medications and supplements

item.title: TCAs
item.description: Tricyclic Antidepressants First generation antidepressants Examples include amitriptyline & imipramine (Amy trips = sedative effect) others: nortriptyline, clomipramine, desipramine doxepin Inhibit reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin Increase synaptic concentration of monoamines Block muscarinic histamine and alpha adrenergic receptors causing side effects Major depressive disorder Anxiety disorders including panic disorder and OCD Chronic neuropathic pain and fibromyalgia Migraine prophylaxis Insomnia in low doses Anticholinergic effects dry mouth blurred vision constipation urinary retention Sedation and drowsiness Weight gain Orthostatic hypotension Sexual dysfunction Cardiac conduction abnormalities, prolonged QT interval arrhythmias CNS toxicity confusion hallucinations seizures in overdose High lethality in overdose due to arrhythmias and seizures Serotonin syndrome when combined with serotonergic agents Recent myocardial infarction or heart block History of seizures Concurrent use with MAOIs Severe liver disease Hypersensitivity to TCAs Key: wear sunglasses, chew gum, use fiber for constipation Obtain baseline ECG especially in older adults Monitor for orthostatic hypotension and fall risk Assess for suicidal ideation especially at therapy initiation Educate on slow onset of therapeutic effect 2 to 4 weeks Taper gradually to avoid withdrawal symptoms Use caution in elderly due to strong anticholinergic burden MAOIs increase risk of hypertensive crisis or serotonin syndrome Alcohol antihistamines opioids cause additive CNS depression SSRIs can increase TCA levels via CYP inhibition Anticholinergic drugs increase risk of toxicity Report palpitations dizziness fainting or chest pain immediately Avoid alcohol and other sedatives Change positions slowly to reduce dizziness Take medication consistently do not stop suddenly Overdose can be fatal keep out of reach of children Therapeutic effects may take several weeks

item.title: i. Foundational Concepts
item.description: Historical Perspective increased need for psych services after WWII National Mental Health Act of 1946 - Truman, establishment of National Institute of Mental Health 1950s - use of pharm, chlorpromazine for aggression & psychosis 1960s - JFK Mental Retardation Facilities, Community Mental Health Center Constructions act Contemporary Perspective use of asylums movement that limits institutionalization - focus on community-based care Healthy People 2030 - focus on multiple aspects of care - prevention, screening - goal => improve quality of life for those with mental illness Increase in primary Care Mental Health - the foundation for emotions, thinking, communication, learning, resilience, and self-esteem. Ability to complete ADLMental Illness - health conditions involving changes in emotion, thinking or behavior (or a combination of these). Mental illnesses are associated with distress and/or problems functioning in social, work, or family activities." Mental Health Disorder - a diagnostic term for a group of mental illness manifestations.Mental Health Continuum - range of mental health functioning with adaptive (wellness, health coping) on one end of the spectrum and maladaptive (illness, unhealthy coping, or an inability to cope) on the other end of the spectrum. Excelling - highest level of well being, in that a person has fulfillment in life and the ability for personal success. Motivations for goal achievement, rational thoughts, ability to foster social relationships, and the ability to resolve stress. Thriving - may experience stressors but can resolve those stressors. The nurse should look for plans or actions to process stress and the ability to foster social activity. Surviving - not a state of distress, but it is a state in which problems that may need action can be recognized. It may be described as the person feeling on edge. The nurse should look for nervousness, irritability, distraction, or withdrawnness. Struggling - may feel worthlessness, worried often, and that life is misery, but not all hope is lost. The nurse should look for poor performance in academic or occupational settings and dysfunctions in sleep and appetite. Crisis - severe symptoms and needs assistance. The nurse should anticipate a high level of worry, low mood, dysfunction in sleep, and irrational thinking. Continuum of Care (Wellness-Illness Model) - views an individual’s mental health across three general areas, well-being, neutrality, and disability Well Being - healthy Neutrality - ability to learn is diminished, no manifestation of illness, able to function, complete ADL Disability - mental illness, difficulty functioning Diathesis-Stress Model - two part theory, explains mental how mental illness develops Diathesis - individual's genetic or biological predisposition for developing an illness (family hx) Stress - change in environment (physical or emotional) => infection, job change, etc Social Determinants of Health - direct impact on well being; psychological distress are caused by a multitude of factors, such as discrimination, prejudice, and exposure to violence experienced by individuals based on their age, gender identity, sexual orientation, race, or ethnicity.5 Main Groups of SODH Life course - exposure to physical, environmental, and socioeconomic events at critical stages throughout one’s life Most critical stage: where rapid growth and neurological development typically occur Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs) = Traumatic or negative events such as physical or emotional abuse and neglect, sexual abuse, and a dysfunctional homelife that increase the risk for depression, anxiety, behavior, and substance use disorders. Protective Factors: social support systems, health screenings, and mental health resources, Households - Income, access to resources like food and water, parental mental and physical health, social support, and maternal care Lack of insurance coverage - huge factor in decrease seeking care Community - built and natural environment, neighborhood security, and the degree to which individuals participate in community events. Local services - schools, social services, health-related services, family services, age-related services (youth and older adults), and access to clean air and water. Country-level factors - human rights, access to health care, housing needs, policies for education access, governance, and inequality. Poverty = children who are poor have higher risk Pollution Disasters, war Protective Factors: national policies, cyberbullying, etc Delay in seeking health - cased by stigma, bias Stigma negative attitude or discredit against an individual or an identifiable group in which the individual or group is labeled as being different. can be thru media -> public stigma employer can negative attitude toward mental illness unemployment rate of people with M.I. - higher 3 Types of Stigma Public - negative attitude toward those who have a mental illness; this can be expressed in discriminatory attitudes or actions. Self-Stigma - negative view or internalized shame regarding their condition. Institutional - governmental policies or organizations limit opportunities for those with mental illness; this can be both intentional and unintentional. Bias stigma leads to bias stereotypes, prejudice, or even discrimination against a group of people that, in comparison to another group, is unfair example of stereotype: depression = desire to self-harm, attention seeking Explicit Bias - Intentionally displaying behaviors of discrimination toward someone. Implicit Bias - bias occurs outside of one’s conscious awareness.Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition, Text Revision (DSM-5-TR) principal diagnostic tool for defining and diagnosing mental health conditions. Conditions are continuously monitored and can be graded based on severity and absence or presence of certain features. Does not include treatment! tool to assist providers in using common diagnostic language to describe clients with mental health disorder WHO International Classification of Disease (ICD) - coding system utilized by member nations of the WHO to provide a common language around the description of illnesses.DSM5 - includes criteria for diagnosis lack of health insurance => leads to decrease in seeking care for M.I. clients have the right to humane treatment - consent and confidentiality, refuse treatment JAB-FN => Just Always Be Fair & Nice => Justice, Autonomy, Beneficience, Fidelity, NonmaleficenceNursing Code of Ethics: Ethical Principals Beneficence - providers act for doing good, and preventing harm Autonomy - ability to make rational decisions related to their care. Nonmaleficence - do no harm Justice - Fair and equal care and treatment for all Considerations: balance autonomy and client safety => can present as ethical dilemmas nurses may limit choices in order to keep patient safe Involuntary Hold - admitted against their willRight to self-determination - allows a client to refuse treatment, medzHIPAA - Health Insurance Portability Accountability Act => need consent to release infoDuty to Warn - healthcare providers responsiblity when another patient threatens another; must reportMistreatment - nurses are required to protect vulnerable individuals, children, elderly, disabled for maltreatment/abuseCultural Humility - practice of trying to appreciate and respect another individual’s culture and the role it plays in the individual’s life and health practicesHolistic Practices - acupuncture, massage therapy, natural erbs, specific diet, etc

item.title: Valproic Acid
item.description: Anticonvulsant, Mood Stabilizers Enhances GABA, blocks sodium and calcium channels Used for seizures, bipolar disorder, migraine prophylaxis Generalized seizures: tonic-clonic, absence, myoclonic Focal seizures Bipolar disorder (mania) Migraine prevention Pregnancy (teratogenic: neural tube defects) Liver disease, mitochondrial disorders Known hypersensitivity High protein binding Hepatic metabolism (CYP450 interactions minimal) Narrow therapeutic index: 50–100 mcg/mL target level GI upset: nausea, vomiting, anorexia Weight gain, tremor, alopecia Thrombocytopenia, bruising Hepatotoxicity (black box warning) => watch out for liver damage Pancreatitis (rare, life-threatening) Neural tube defects in pregnancy Monitor liver function tests, CBC, drug levels Monitor for jaundice, abdominal pain, bruising, bleeding Educate patient on contraceptive use (teratogenic) Do not abruptly discontinue (risk of seizures) Give with food to reduce GI upset Increases levels of lamotrigine (risk of SJS) Aspirin and warfarin ↑ free drug (protein binding displacement) CNS depressants may have additive effect

item.title: Barbiturates
item.description: also a sedative ending in "-barbital" lasts longer in the body takes longer to get OUT of the body high risk for toxicity: RR, HR, death => common question, priority patient! you went to the BAR, now you are sleepy, you are now behind BARs for a long time

item.title: Mood Stabilizers
item.description:
relieve manifestations of mood dysregulation found in disorders like Bipolar Disorder Drug Classes
Lithium
Anticonvulsants (carbamazepine, Valproic Acid)
2nd Gen Antipsychotics -> Ariprazole (see Antipsychotics) controversial, compared to valproic acid regulating reuptake of monoamine neurotransmitters prevents relapse into a manic or major depressive episode ref range: 0.6-1.2 Common Adverse Effects: diarrhea, nausea, increased thirst, and fine hand tremors Weight gain - extended use Nursing Considerations: must monitor blood levels EVERY 1-2 weeks until therapeutic level is maintained check blood levels (every few days-weeks depending on protocol) Toxic: greater than 1.5 mEq/L
monitor CMP => kidney metabolism encourage water intake to excrete lithium: 1-2 liters per day DO NOT mix with NSAIDs DO NOT mix with MAOIs (Phenelzine, Selegiline) inhibit kindling process => cascading effect that causes seizure to be more severe, frequent increase GABA => more inhibited neurological effect monitor blood serum - 12 hrs after the last dose Common Adverse Effects: sedation dry mouth Weight GAIN - valproic acid Weight LOSS - topiramate, lamogtrigine

item.title: ii. Legal n Ethical Shit
item.description: A psychotherapeutic-based treatment focused on modifying or controlling the immediate environment in which the client is living. Focus includes social and physical settings with the purpose of promoting health and healing. more humane care to clients than asylums trauma-informed - most pysch patients have traumatic past reduces inappropriate behavior milieau = environment mental health facility should be structured in ways that provide an ongoing therapeutic environment encourages self-awareness and self- management basically everything that is good standard of care for nurses Components of Milieu: Physical: healing space => safe and prevention injury, low stim, privacy, home-like restraints - balance with dignity; least restrictive promote interactions - chairs must be conversation-like instead of line Psychosocial: creating healing culture implement therapeutic social environment idea: each client owns their behavior and is responsible for their choices planned structure - predictability is good post schedule and client rights on spaces More components of Physical Milieu: Safety & injury prevention → self/other-directed, suicide risk Staff observation levels → safety, ongoing assessment Environmental stimulation → noise, light, interactions Adjust placement → room/unit changes based on sensitivity or need Art, color, design → match clinical needs, avoid overstimulation (abstract art → confusion, anxiety, anger, depression) Provide stimulation → sensory enhancement for dementia clients Ensure privacy → dedicated spaces Restraints/seclusion → balance dignity, independence, least restrictive goal Consider cognition/physical needs → signage, wheelchair/walker accessibility basis for determining intentions, motives, and actions by a particular group or within society. consideration of cultural norms, personal morals or values, and values of the profession Mental Healthcare Act of 2017 - protects the rights of patients who have mental illnesses, provides mental health pros with ethical and legal responsibilities for patients autonomy nonmaleficence - do not harm beneficence - removing harmful conditions to benefit the client or others. example: providing meds to reduce agitation, or remove objects that could pose harm fidelity - keeping promises veracity - Dealing truthfully with clients and others during professional interactions. justice - speak and be heard in a group session confidentiality informed consent involuntary admission Code Of Ethics for Nurses - outlined by the American Nurses Association articulates the ethical values, duties, and standards expected of a nurse in all areas of their practice​​​​​​​. Capacity - ability or inability to make decisions about proposed medical treatments or aspects of their health care.Competence only determined by a JUDGE thru a court hearing ability to understand information, use reasonable thought processes, communicate their wishes can understand the consequences of their decisions. Parity - equal coverage for mental and physical health in accessibility to health insurance.Federal government: Regulates health systems and providers. Protects the rights of the individual. Provides funding for services. Supports research and innovation. Establishes and enforces a minimum standard of mental health care. State Government: Establishes specific standards and regulations for mental health treatment. Provides oversight of mental health care within the state. Addresses issues related to treatment facilities, medical records, and standards, including involuntary treatment. Expands on federal government programs, funding, research, and protection standards. Types of Admission: Voluntary Admission client requests evaluation or admission to a mental health facility needs consent form must be assessed within 72 hours => then DC or continue admission Involuntary Admission - assisted inpatient treatment. severe mental illness, danger to self and others, unable to meet basic self-care illness prevents them from recognizing the need to seek care usually needs 2 providers to submit justification Emergency Hold: must determine to DC within 72 hours (in most states) => when without court order If evaluation determines patient meets criteria for commitment => court hearing - patient provided legal counsel Emergency Admission - temporary admission imminent danger to themselves or others usually detained by law enforcement Client Bill of Rights - in place despite being involuntarily admittedExceptions to Confidentiality and Privacy: danger to themselves danger to others leave facility against medical advice suspicion of abuse (including neglect, battery, murder) Duty To warn - notify individuals who are being threatened by a client supersedes upholding the client’s right to (Tarasoff)Informed Consent - can apply to legal representative if client is incompetent description f treatment benefits, adverse effects risks consequence of not receiving treatment alternatives if available signed form - if applicable by state nurse to serve as witness Implied Consent - can never be used if a patient's legal representative refuses treatmentCapacity vs Competency Capacity ability to provide informed consent often assumed by provider; if needed => use cognition assessment tool ability to understand information, use reasonable thought processes ability to: communicate their wishes, and understand the consequences of their decisions. Competency can only be determined in court of law during hearing health care providers cannot determine this! cognitive processes are intact and able to make decisions based on their personal motives if incompetent, a legal surrogate, guardian is assigned Psychiatric Advanced Directives (PAD) legal tool that allows patient to outline their wishes prior to a mental health crisis underutilized - need further education laws vary by state Tort violation of a patient's protected rights; breach of duty of the nurse intentional or unintentional Unintentional Tort - one example is negligence (standard of care not provided) Intentional Tort - examples include assault, battery (e.g. shaking a patient to awaken them), false imprisonment (restraints without lawful reason) patients should always be supervised during: seclusion/restraint left in a prone or supine position check q15 minutes Document always - include who was consulted, what was done, who was notified False Imprisonment - confinement of a patient when there is no legal reason to do so; use of restraints/seclusionOrder of Interventions (least to most restrictive): de-escalation timeout seclusion physical/chemical restraint De-escalation Strategies Use verbal communication that is clear and calm. body language of staff is nonthreatening. Approach the client with respect by being supportive of their issue or concern. Respond to client issues or concerns creating a sense of trust. Set clear limits or boundaries. low-stim environment Seclusion vs Timeout Timeout - to separate from a situation, allowing them time to think, calm down, prepare to end the behavior that, and reengage with others with a more composed presence and controlled behaviorSeclusion vs Restraint next step from timeout seclusion - last intervention before restraint Chemical Restraints - associated with increased risk of harm, skin breakdown, falls, deterioration of mental status last resort (along with physical restraints)! examples: antipsychoitcs/neuroleptics, anxiolytics, mood stabilizers, sedatives Documentations: order patient behavior leading up to indication that least restrictive/de-escalation techniques were attempted type of restraints interventions while restrained ongoing monitoring every 15 minutes - behavior, circulation, skin check Debriefing - to improve quality of future responsesPsychiatrist - diagnose medical and psychiatric illnesses, prescribe meds, give treatment orders, provide talk therapy, may specialize in children/adolescents Psychologist - assess brain function and provide talk therapies Social Worker/LCSW - create treatment goals, address long-term needs, provide psychotherapy Occupational Therapist - assess skills and provide rehabilitation Social Worker - provide social support such as housing, finances, and insurance Counselor/Therapist - use therapeutic techniques to reduce symptoms (e.g., drama or art therapy) Psychiatric Pharmacist - manage medications for mental health care Right to Treatment - right to emergency treatment regardless of their ability to pay Right to Refuse Treatment provider can deny treatment: risks outweigh benefits also includes right to second opinion no surprises act - costs are told upfront Client Bill of Rights: To be treated with consideration and respectful care. To make an advance directive and appoint someone to make health care decisions. To obtain current and understandable information regarding their care, treatment, and potential health outcomes. To refuse a recommended treatment, including medications. To privacy and confidentiality, including communication and records. To be informed of charges and policies. To review their medical records. To refuse inclusion in medical research studies. To receive reasonable continuity of care. To be informed of business relationships facilities or providers have that may influence care. When on conservationaship - no right to refuse treatment OSHA Workplace Violence - act or threat of physical violence, harassment, intimidation, or other threatening or disruptive behavior As nurses become more burnt out, compassion takes a plummet next module iii EBP n shitz
item.guid: Psych/i. Foundations/ii. Legal n Ethical Shit.md

item.title: Building Relationships n Shit
item.description: Social Roles: Occupational and TherapeuticOccupational Roles: nurse serves as educator, facilitator, manager home health care managers - promotes wellness and functioning in a client’s home as a health care setting. Therapeutic Roles: using nurse-patient relationship to build trust help identifying factors that aggravate or alleviate symptoms, coordinating spiritual leaders, encouraging emotional expression, or reinforcing cognitive-behavioral techniques. shorter frequent interactions are BETTER than occasional, longer ones Phases of Therapeutic Relationship: (Peplau) Pre-interaction - recognize need of the client, perform self evaluation of own beliefs and behavior before engaging with patient Orientation - collects data, assesses knowledge, and works with the client to develop mutual goals; inform client of multiple teams working with them => establish nurse-client relationship, identify barriers to wellness Working - the nurse and client have established a mutual level of trust and comfort and develop progress toward established goals. Termination - resolution phase, goals have been met, new goals developed; ensure continuity of care (e.g. community resource referrals) Boundary blurring - when boundaries become unclear, avoidTransference / Countertransference Transference - client to redirect their previously-experienced feelings or emotions toward the nurse. "you are leaving me just like my father" Countertransference - unconscious effort on behalf of the nurse to redirect their previously experienced feelings or emotions toward the client. "the client needs something, they never stop" "they remind me of my grand mother" Nurse must redirect to avoid, if not possible speak to supervisor Nonverbal Communication Incongruence - when facial expression doesn't match patient's mood; certain meds can cause this Therapeutic Communication: body position, body language, eye contact, touch, silence, and intuition SOLER => acrnonym for therapeutic nonverbal comms S - sit squarely to the patient (directly in front = too confrontational, slight angle is good) O - open posture L - lean forward E - eye contact R - relaxSURETY Sit at an angle Uncross arms and legs Relax Eye Contact Touch Your IntuitionOARS => therapeutic communication mnemonic Open-ended Affirmations => positive reinforcement, praise Reflections Summaries Open-Ended Statements => always allow the client to elaborate in their own words avoid using "would you", "can you" -> use "tell me more" or some shit like that Reflective Statements: Simple Reflection - to clarify client emotions or statements - kinda like parroting Complex Reflection - infers client emotion or thoughts in an effort to portray engagement and clarity.Summaries - restate major key concepts, way to move on to the next phaseBarrier to Therapeutic Communication: not doing self-evaluation of countertransference and bias Conducting The Interview: Socratic Questioning - using a series of open-ended, probing questions to help individuals explore their thoughts Active Listening Transtheoretical Model of Change => tbh not sure if it's worth it to studyLevels of Prevention: Primary - prevent the onset of disease (vaccines, education, lifestyle changes) Secondary - catch disease early (screenings, checkups, early detection tests) Tertiary - reduce the impact and complications of existing diseases Therapeutic Window - when interventions are most effective; maximize this6 Attributes for Culturally Competent Care: Awareness Knowledge Sensitivity Skill Proficiency - recognize lack of knowledge Dynamicity Leininger's Transcultural Theory considers the client’s social, spiritual, psychological, and physiological perspectives basically a whole-body approach embrace DEI type of shit use smart phones to engage patients and family telehealth 4 Processes to Follow to Utilize MOTIVATIONAL INTERVIEWING Engage - allows the client to share their perspective on what is important in their life. Focus - avoid "expert trap" => prescribing information or advice without the consent, solicitation, or consultation of the client. Evoke - use client's own motivation to make necessary behavior change Plan - should be S.M.A.R.T
item.guid: Psych/ii. Relationship Building/Building Relationships n Shit.md

item.title: 09-17 Case Study Day
item.description:
email: esevilla@nu.edu 34yo male hx: substance abuse UDS: + thc, etoh voluntary c/c "i want to die" presents to hositapl broke up with gf of 2 years feeling off for 2 weeks CSSRS - screening tool for SI, Columbia-Suicide Severity Rating Scale 1-5 scale: 1 seeking health, 5 very suicidal standardized way to communicate with other nurses in regards to care Questions to ask? Things to look out for? Is the patient DTS - danger to self? Yes, but need to ask more questions "what does anxiety and depression mean to you?" give benadryl, instead of haldol takeaway: need to determine trigger 28yo female no psych hx UDS: + THC 72 hold c/c: "i don't need to be here, you're holding me against my will" brought by friend to the ED: acting strange list last night people are spying on her, according to patient threatened a man because she thought she was being followed If you were writing the hold, what criteria would you use? ans: DTO Other questions to ask? Mood or Thought Disorder - thought disorder Patient becomes increasingly agitated during assessment yelling, cursing, demanding to leave, destroying property De-escalate? - yes try it Hands on? - yes, because she already destroyed property IMs? intramusculars - yes - faster than PO medz PRN meds: thorazine for agitation Ativan anxiety which would you pick? - none of them, all of them are PO
Escalation cycle infographic — Seattle Children’s 25yo male BIB police from trolley station acting erratic, attempting to charge officers and was tazed Day1: receives 3 I'm meds for agitation over the course of 16 hours Day 2: received patient on AM shift received I'm at 0100 but was not effective, been up since noon the previous day on assessment: patient is friendly thought process: tangential (jumping from topic to topic) speech: pressured (pushes the teeth through lips) mood - irritable, labile (low impulse control) affect: blunted => positive or negative of schizophrenia? ans: negative Appearance: disheveled, malodorous Oriented to name only "i want to go bacj to where I died last time" Scheduled meds: 20 ng PO zyprexa QHS => what to think of this dose? PRN: Vistaril 50 mg PO q4h PRN anxiety => insight: there is no med for agitation answer: no Patient did not sleep the whole night appears energetic, walking into toher patients rooms, causing distress to other patients what other options do we have? In the end: patient was put in seclusion given ativan at 1300, patient assualt staff, code called. patient given emergency 5250 (Haldol, Ativan, Benadryl) What changes are expected to see? zyprexa increased to 30mg PO QHS no PRNs added 45yo male, received on day2 cc: suicidal ideations detoxing on alcohol, lost his job, financial burdens, descrines self as alcoholic, drinks 6 pack a day BAC 300, but oriented to name, place, time, situation. Last drink was 0900 yesterday CIWA - Clinical Institute Withdrawal Assessment for Alcohol => maybe every hour 8 below is mild withdrawal, actual score is 4 delirium and tremors = deadly patient complaints of: diarrhea, nausea, sensitivity to light, irritability, runny nose, akathisia (uncontrolled urge to move) actual CIWA score is probably higher Meds: ativan 2mg PO TID, vitamin b 1tab PO daily, abilify 10 mg PO daily PRN: ativan 2mg PO q2h, CIWA > 8 2 hrs later: patient is complaining of same discomforts. CIWA is now probably higher Take away: staff is not fond of this patient, but still as a nurse, treat the patient same demographic as previous use COWS scale patient is asking for sobuxone, nurse gives it but 2 hours later, patient is complaining of runny nose, diarrhea, tachycardia, N/V. What happened? takeaway: must wait for all withdrawal symptoms to manifest before giving suboxone => wait until they have diarrhea Missle - Haldol Rocket Launcher - Risperidone Pistol - Zyprexa (Olanzapine)

item.title: 09-03 Clinical Orientation
item.description: Per Sevilla: Sim days start at 0900 strictly on Case study days, roll call will not start until 1000 5150 - 72 hours, criteriaL DTS (danger to self), DTO (danger to others), GD (Grave Disability - kinda like failure to thrive) 5250 - 14 day hold first opportunity for patient to prove that they do not need to be there court will see evidence for and against the hold 5350 - 30 day hold only for grave disability mood stabilizers and antidepressants take 2-3 weeks to work usually doctors may pursue conservatorship Conservatorship - temporary vs permanentRiese - court hearing to determine if a person has the ability to take their medication AI definition: A Riese hold is actually a Capacity Hearing, named after the court case Riese v. St. Mary's Hospital (1987), that determines if a patient on a mental health hold in California has the legal capacity to refuse psychiatric medication. If the court finds the patient lacks capacity, the facility can administer medication that the patient would otherwise refuse. This hearing ensures involuntary patients can refuse treatment if they have the mental capacity to make informed decisions about it. Escalation Curve - calm => trigger => agitation, acceleratiomn, peak => de-escalation caused by lack of control Psych nursing - eliminate triggers Mental Status Exam observe how the patient: looks, talks, acts, behaves ACE Scoring - Adverse Childhood ExperiencesTotal possible score: 0-10 Psychosis - distortion in reality Mood Disorder - inability to cope with emotions Main category: psychosis vs mood disorder!Grave Disability - unable to care for themselves, no ADL Schizophrenia Antipsychotics - aka Dopamine Receptor 2 Antagonist; block dopamine receptors side effects: EPS, tardive dyskinesia 1st gen, weight gain 2nd gen Common drugs: haldol, zyprexia, risperdal, thorazine MMD - major depressive Disorder SIGECAPPS -- sleep, interest, guilt, energy, concentration, appetite, psychomotor retardation, SI two blue weeks common medz: SSRI - keep certain neurotransmitters in the sunapse longer Bipolar Disorder DIGFAST - distractibility, irritability, grandiosity, flight od ideas, activity inc, sleep dec, talkativity inc Schizo-affective Disorder Tardive Dyskenisia vs EPSMental Health First Aid - can be one 8 hour day in person vs two 4 hour online sessions AA or NA - can be online Med Presentation - will be assigned by clinical instructor during post conference; brochure needed Final Care Plan - due by the end of hospital rotationClinical Hour Tracker Sheet father joes - write instructor approved mental1 - needs to be signed by staff AA/NA - can attend one hour - will count as 3 hours

item.title: iii EBP n shitz
item.description: updated 9/17 Literature REviews - conclusions derived from comparisons of the results of multiple peer-reviewed studies that were conducted on the same topic. Qualitative Studies - narrative in nature, as the researchers and the participants discuss or explain their primary reasons, attitudes and motivations” Quantitative Studies - use numerical data to evaluate outcomes. Mixed Methods - combine qualitative studies, which explore experiences and quantitative designs, which enumerate findings. Continuum of Professional Boundaries: Under-involvement Therapeutic Relationship/ Over-involvement MLP = Medical Legal Partnership interprofessional model working to reduce # of patients with MI related to SDOH tenet: training, the merging of healthcare and legal services for this cause, and advocacy at the federal and state levels SMI - Serious Mental Illness => defined by the degree of dysfunction it may in ADLs lower life expectancy usually accompanied by medical comorbidities lower QOL goal: improve QOL, manage medical comorbidities Professional Stigma - care provided to SMI patients is lesser quality d/t stigma Goal: attend educational sessions, know SMI life experiences, develop relationship Daily Living Issues => Housing, Unemployment inability to get/maintain job Approaches: Housing First - focus on getting stable living first before getting job Treatment First - establish job first prior to getting housing Caveat - getting a job means getting disenrolled from medicaid, job makes it difficult to get treatment Supported Housing - community-based program that provides housing and community-based treatment and support services to assist clients to integrate into the community and live independentlySocial Ecological Model (SE) - Individual, Interpersonal, Organizational, Community and Policy/SystemHarm Reduction Model - recovery as a process and an outcome incorporating abstinence in its treatment for clients who have substance use disorderCommon Treatment Issues: Medication Adherence Solutions: Mobile Assessment and Treatment for Schizo (MATS) - mobile phone, reminder meds, FOCUS Relapse - use phone apps too to manage Community Programs: psychotherapy medications assertive community treatment (ACT) involves an interprofessional team of health care workers (nurses, psychiatrists, social workers, and case managers) supporting a client appropriate for VERY serious patients supported employment supported housing ADPIE => per ati: AAPIEAssessment Analysis Planning Implementation EvaluationAdverse Childhood Experiences traumatic events essential to unlocking sources of a client’s condition and disorders later in life correlation between high risk behavior Trauma-informed care - approach that allows the client to feel safe because the nurse is actively listening, accepting, and operating within a framework of compassionHolistic Nursing - provides the nurse the opportunity to care for the client as a wholeCommon Issues to deal with Holistic nursing: dental health eye health sexual/reproductive health cardiovascular health higher rates of tobacco use substance use obesity Working Alliance - relationship between client and provider or nurse, or other member of the health care team who is foundational to the effectiveness of the client’s care. recovery is becoming more relevant Recovery Model shifting the focus from the management of symptoms to life goals and individualizing services for individual client needs opposite of medical model: goal is symptom free promotes increased self-esteem and affirms a positive contribution to society understand that patient will not be symptom free recovery does not equal COMPLETE independence Rehabilitation Model Development of independence: intellectual, spiritual, physical, and psychological similar to recovery as they promote independence

item.title: Sedative-Hypnotics
item.description: to treat sleep-wake disorder insomnia use only after nonpharmacological interventions do not work Drug Classes: Benzodiazepine (see Anxiolytics > Benzodiazepines) Non-Benzodiazepine Hypnotics Therapeutic use: act on the benzodiazepine receptor site of the GABA receptor fewer side effects than Benzodiazepines Examples" Zolpidem (Ambien), Zaleplon, Eszopiclone used for short term only! Serious Side Effects: amnesia, sleep walking, hallucinations, SI Melatonin Receptor Agonist for difficulty FALLING asleep example: Rameleon Side Effects: headache, fatigue, dizziness, and nausea Serious Side Effects: amnesia, sleep walking, hallucinations, SI (same as nonbenzos) Nurse Teaching: avoid other CNS depressants - alcohol do not operate vehicle remind: short term use only encourage good sleep hygiene

item.title: Exam Coverage

item.title: Stress
item.description: Stress biological and psychological response to a perceived or experienced stressor can be positive or maladaptive survival response - affects a lot of systems Chronic Stress - repeated exposure, no opportunity for recovery Categories: Psychological - loss of self-esteem, grief, fear, cognitive, loss of personal security Physiological - injury, heat/cold, illness, pain, substance abuse, etcPathophysiology of Stress amygdala sends "distress call" to hypothalamus, which releases CRH -> pituitary release adrenocorticotropin hormone (ACTH) Adrenal gland -> cortisol, epinephrine Fight-or-Flight Response -> can be fight, faint, flight, freeze, fawnGeneral Adaptation Syndrome - GAS when an event or stressor threatens the body and activates a three-stage response Stages of Gas: Alarm Stage aka, alarm stage => Fight-Flight-Freeze-Faint-or-Fawn initial, brief, and adaptive response sympathetic nervous system is activated: shock, then counter shock shock -> decrease in blood pressure, temperature, muscle tone, and a loss of bodily fluid countershock -> increased sympathetic nervous system (SNS) activity -> "fight response" increased HR, BP RR, heighted cognitive processes, senses, glucose, endurance, decreased digestion (nonessential) Resistance Stage aka adaptation stage => body attempts to adapt to the stressor the stressor diminishes, the individual can return to homeostasis Exhaustion Stage body has depleted its resources and can no longer adapt to the stressor tissues and organs are depleted, and the result can lead to illness, disease, or death Levels of Anxiety Mild Triggered by stressor Increased awareness, hypervigilance peak problem-solving ability Tension-relieving behaviors: nail-biting, foot-tapping, fidgeting restlessness Moderate Stress unresolved or perceived strongly Narrowed perception field, decreased concentration Limited learning ability, still problem-solves Sympathetic activation → ↑vitals Still has ability to learn and practice coping skills Severe Ongoing or threatening stress Distorted perception, focus on single detail Minimal problem-solving, feels no solution Symptoms: somatic complaints, impending doom, withdrawal, loud speech, nausea Panic Unable to process environment Disorganized, irrational, dissociation Fight-flight-fawn-faint-freeze responses Possible hallucinations, delusions Counterpoint: stress -> depletion of energy and the breakdown of resilience mechanisms -> erosion of health Good stress or bad stress? research says stress is neither good or bad Eustress -> positive stress response to a challenging but beneficial task that results in development growth, mastery, or a sense of fulfillment. Viewing stress as positive - good adaptation Acute Stress sudden exposure to adverse stressor can last for short period or a long time, depending on individual Chronic Stress prolonged exposure can lead to: eating disorders, mood disorders, and substance use disorders, as well as physical diseases such as hypertension, heart disease, obesity, metabolic syndrome, arthritis, and type 2 diabetes. Response to stress: Acute Stress - ↑ reaction time, ↑ energy, hyperawareness, ↑HR Chronic Stress - anxiety, ↑ infection, insomnia, depressionToxic Stress result of a prolonged or chronic stress response system body learns that experiencing fear, stressors, or trauma is normal biological and neurological changes to brain and body example: chronic stress since childhood, chronic neglect, exposure to violence, economic hardship, caregiver substance abuse referred to as ACEs -> adverse childhood experience Mediators => either Individual or EnvironmentalIndividual Factors: Perceptions & Attitudes hardiness and resilience lack of control, low self-esteem, low self-confidence, and a sense of hopelessness Temperament & Personality temperament - energy level, emotional responsiveness, demeanor, mood, response tempo, behavioral inhibition, and willingness to explore personality traits - characteristics drawn from a pattern of behaviors, attitudes, feelings, and habits. Genetics/Neurodevelopment - health condition, gender, prenatal care, age Lifestyle modifiable habits that can be related to individual choices and patterns of behaviors use of drugs and alcohol, smoking, physical activity, sleep, and eating Personality Traits: Neuroticism vs. Emotional Stability Extroversion vs. Introversion Openness to Experience vs. Closeness to Experiences Conscientiousness vs. Lack of Direction Agreeableness vs. AntagonismHardiness -> based on a positive self-perception and attitudes of hopefulnessEnvironmental Factors: Environment & Setting Safe, secure, and positive school or work environments are considered protective environmental factors high stress: pollution, abuse, or crime Cultural connection to one's culture is a form of social support, protective factor cause of stress: adapting to new cultures => language, discrimination, stereotypes Support System: family & community Safe, supportive, and secure early relationships can help individuals self-regulate Risk factor: lack of parental support and parent-child bonding ages of 18 and 23 => decreased social interactions -> loneliness, stress Spirituality & Religion offer positive influence, feeling of community, develop resilience Coping - learning to adjust to the stress or stressor while trying to keep themselves in a state of mental and physical equilibrium Holmes-Rahe Social Readjustment Scale measures positive and negative life events and assigns a value to certain stressors can provide insight into client’s experience of stress and risk for developing an illness each life event => assign point Coping Styles: Problem-focused - adaptive Emotion-Focused - adaptive; reduces negative emotions Avoidant Coping - cognitive and behavioral efforts directed toward diminishing, ignoring, or denying stressful situations in an effort to avoid dealing with the stressor crucial to maintain emotional homeostasis continuum from adaptive to maladaptive Adaptive Defense Mechanisms (aka, mature defenses) do not distort the situation/reality help accept situation, even if not comfortable found in individuals with healthy, mature functioning => aware of the stressor; use stress-management technique may be conscious or unconscious Maladaptive Defense Mechanisms based on avoiding, negating, or distorting reality to provide relief from the stressor common among individuals whose emotions and impulsivity outperform reasoning conscious or unconscious effort often seen in children and may be considered normal for children based on their emotional development prolong, avoid, or complicate stressors, potentially developing into symptoms of mental illness Adjusting expectations Avoids disappointment, reduces stress Consider multiple outcomes Biofeedback Biosensors monitor physiological responses physical and mental exercises to help control their specific automatic physical body functions, such as heart rate, blood pressure, and temperature. Clinician assists with interpretation Goal: awareness + self-regulation Deep breathing Slow, deliberate breaths improve gas exchange ↓heart rate, ↓BP, relaxation Refocuses stress, ↑breathing awareness Types: figure-eight, dragon, square Positive self-talk & reduce self-blame Encourage kindness, not doubt or blame Physical + mental health benefits Guided imagery Deep breathing + imagining calm scene Engage senses in imagined environment Guided verbally or via audio Mindfulness meditation Focus on present moment, thoughts, sensations Accept without judgment Recognize feelings, let them go

item.title: iv. Nursing Shit
item.description:
iv. Theories
iv. Therapies be familiar with and assisnt patient with interventions and teaching the nurse will NOT perform therapy RN will collect initial assessment data, documenting, evaluating manifestations, progression Recognize and report warning signs for suicide: wanting to die withdrawing from family/friends giving away possessions discussing death frequently with others reporting feeling of pain - emotionally or physically PCE - positive childhood experiencesPromote positive mental health => enhance well-being of individualPrimary Prevention - targeting at risk populations, high risk factors Secondary Prevention - early detection or screening, provide education r/t treatment, build relationship Tertiary Prevention - reduce the disabling effects of mental illness, such as helping the client develop positive adaptive coping skills

item.title: Neurotransmitters
item.description:
=> part of Psychopharmacology excitatory neurotransmitter => emotional responses, complex movements, and cognition pleasure and reward from behaviors affected by stress
Schizophrenia - too much dopamine (hallucinations), not enough (withdrawal) => can be both Deficiency → Parkinson’s disease, depression, attention deficits Excess → schizophrenia, mania inhibitory neurotransmitter emotional regulations, sexual behaviors, temperature regulation, sleep, and pain management Dysregulated => contributes to anxiety, depression, and psychotic disorders Antidepressant meds - block reuptake of serotonin in pre-synaptic neuron to improve neurotransmission in post-synaptic excitatory; stress response, learning, sleep, mood, memory, and attention. low levels = anxiety, social withdrawal, depression, and memory loss history of trauma - high levels Deficiency → depression, low energy, poor focus Excess → anxiety, hypertension, hyperarousal Excess during opiate withdrawal => muscle aches, goose flesh, pupil dilation, GI discomfort (diarrhea) neuromodulation mediate the effects of alertness and wakefulness regulation of gastric secretions, allergic response, and cardiac stimulation Histamine antagonist => side effects of sedation and weight gain Major inhibitory neurotransmitter in CNS Reduces neuronal excitability, promotes calm Deficiency → anxiety, seizures, insomnia Excess → sedation, impaired memory Drugs: benzodiazepine, barbiturates, alcohol ↑ GABA choto mate kudasai, needs some glutamate to learn Major excitatory neurotransmitter in CNS Involved in learning, memory, neuroplasticity Excess → excitotoxicity, seizures, neurodegeneration (Alzheimer’s, ALS, stroke) Deficiency → cognitive impairment, psychosis Drugs: NMDA receptor antagonists (ketamine, memantine) Note: increased Gluamate during alcohol withdrawal causes elevated HR Functions: muscle contraction (unique), autonomic nervous system, attention, learning, memory Regulates sleep-wake-cycle Deficiency → Alzheimer’s disease, myasthenia gravis Excess → cholinergic crisis (salivation, lacrimation, diarrhea, bradycardia) Drugs: anticholinergics (atropine), cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, neostigmine)
