item.title: v. Continuum of Treatment
item.description: Mental Health state of well being, can realize own abilities, cope with normal stress of life, live fruitfully and all that shit can handle stress of everyday life as opposed to patient with mental illness - no ability to cope Mental Health Continuum => range of mental well-being, with excellent mental health at one end and poor mental health, or mental illness, at the other end. everyone falls somewhere in the continuum! 5 Zones of Mental Health Continuum => can fluctuate; not goal-oriented - descriptive only Excelling - peak, top performance; e.g. marriage, promotion Thriving - can cope with regular stress, no long-term concerns; normal level performance Surviving - increased stress & disruption, high risk of regressing => must practice coping mechanisms Struggling - anxiety, depression, poor concentration, struggling with work; need professional help in managing (meds, hospitalization, counseling, therapy) In Crisis - state of emergency, need immediate health; suicidal, severe anxiety/depression, social isolation, lack of self-care. High risk for SI. Needs inpatient treatment, intensive mental health care. Self-Check Tool: Healthy happy and satisfied with life; emotionally balanced, healthy coping, normal mood fluctuations consistent performance, healthy sleep, self-confidence evident, comfortable in relationships Reacting - (Common and Reversible Stress) acute stress from life events, requires self-care and social support coping difficulty but daily living intact => FORGETFULLNESS irritability, impatience, nervousness, sadness, worry, procrastination forgetfulness, intrusive thoughts sleep problems, social withdrawal Injured (Significant Functional Impairment) requires professional care => prolonged distress, poor coping, impaired ADL Anger, anxiety, prolonged sadness, hopelessness, worthlessness, decreased performance Ill (Clinical Disorder, Severe Impairment) emergency! needs professional treatment inability to cope with stress, extreme thot and behavior changes severe anxiety, panic attacks, deep depression, fatigue, disturbed reality suicidal ideation Types of Mental Health Care Settings: Inpatient → severe dysfunction, safety risk, intense care, 24/7 supervision Outpatient/Community-Based → nonacute needs, med management, therapy, support Community-Based Care & Treatment => for nonacute needs Primary Care Provider → first contact, monitors overall health, prescribes/monitors meds, refers to therapy Outpatient Mental Health Clinic → psychiatrist, psychologist, APRNs, therapists, med management, ongoing care Case Management → nurse/social worker, coordinates meds, appointments, transport, collaborates with team Home-Based Services → nurse/social worker visits, med support, monitoring; includes ACT (Assertive Community Treatment) model (inpatient-level care at home, improves quality of life) Telehealth / Telepsychiatry → virtual visits, med management, effective as in-person Mobile Crisis Teams → emergency care onsite at client’s location Day Treatment → outpatient center, mental health + job training, nonresidential Family Services → caregiver tools and support Peer Services → support from trained peers with lived experience Inpatient Mental Health Services Crisis Stabilization Unit → short-term, emergent monitoring, few hours–days (Prof says 24 units max) Community-Based Hospital Facility → psych unit in hospital, short-term, days–weeks State Hospital Facility → serious illness, court-ordered, months–years, often criminal justice involvement Transitional/Respite Unit → post-hospital, prevents readmission, short-term 2–4 weeks Long-Term Care Facility → chronic illness, ADL support, often indefinite stay Substance Use Disorder Treatment Centers → detox, acute residential, MAT (methadone, buprenorphine, naltrexone), psychosocial + peer support Specialty Care & Treatment Military Veteran Care → VA programs, crisis care, PTSD, MST Pediatric/Adolescent Care → child/teen focused, inpatient or specialty facilities, PMHS trained providers Geriatric Care → older adult needs, long-term programs, government resources Forensic Care → clients with criminal convictions, rehab + safety balance, diversion programs prevent incarceration, court-ordered care MH is a public health issue Focus of PH Model: promoting mental health well-being preventing mental disorders improving access to community mental health services providing support throughout the disease process supporting recovery, lowering the incidences of death, disease, and disability among those with mental illnesses 2 Categories of mental illness: AMI - any mental illness SMI - serious mental illness - severe functional impairment, resulting in possible permanent disability. National Mental Health Act of 1946 - more resources into research, mental illness; education/research programsCommunity Mental Health Act (CMHA) - called for comprehensive community health centers to offer services to people with mental illness who were deinstitutionalized.Underserved populations at Risk for M.I.: densely populated lower-income communities => drugs, violence, crime rural areas - lack of access elderly non white veterans homeless Causes of At-Risk status: SDOH ACE - adverse childhood events Geographical settings - rural areas, poor marginalization - racism and shit Incarcerated - high rates of MI1963 Community Mental Health Act unintentionally worsened houselessness by releasing individuals without ensuring housingLevels of Prevention: Primary prevention aims to prevent mental illness through client and environmental support, education, and stressor reduction. Secondary prevention minimizes early symptoms through screenings, early intervention, and managing minor issues like anxiety. Tertiary prevention reduces long-term disability, focusing on treatment, management, and helping clients function in society. MTSS - Multitiered System of Support promotion - universal care for everyone prevention - targeted individualized - intensive Barriers to Mental Health Care: Lack of available treatment options or providers Inadequate transportation, childcare, or unable to take time off work. Held belief that mental health treatment “does not work” High level of mental health stigma in cultural or ethnic group Racism, bias, and discrimination in treatment settings Language barriers or lack of providers who speak languages other than English Lack of adequate health insurance coverage Sub-Headers: accessibility - rural areas lack of culturally competent care affordability availability of care and treatment - not enough providers How to reduce disparities: Provide culturally sensitive client-centered care Increase workforce diversity Improve awareness of disparities related to mental health care and treatment Promote cultural and language competence Provide education during nursing school on the Social Determinates of Health and Mental Health Advocate for system and legislative changes to reduce disparities

item.title: iv. Therapies
item.description: based on freud help a client to express any repressed emotions, bringing unconscious thoughts to the conscious mind transference - when the client develops feelings toward the therapist or health care worker in a way that mimics a relationship that was significant in their childhood Countertransference - therapist or health care worker unconsciously has feelings toward the client that reminds them of an individual in their past. It can be positive or negative. type of psychotherapy that focuses on modifying a client’s maladaptive behavior patterns and responses, and instead utilizing adaptative behaviors. Maladaptive Behavior - Behaviors that prevent an individual from coping with new or difficult circumstances, problems, or environments. address current issues (from the past) remove negative thought process therapist will often identify the thoughts an individual has that enhance or contribute to one’s anxiety premise: mental health problem is based in part on faulty thinking or unhealthy thoughts, related feelings, and learned patterns of behaviors. learn better ways of coping (new ways of thinking) that will lead to better patterns of living (behaviors). helping the individual recognize the thought patterns that created their current situation and reevaluate them in light of the current situation and apply new behaviors examples of who can benefit: depression, anxiety, eating disorders, tourette's aka psychotherapy promote the client’s well-being and assist or eliminate a client’s symptoms so they can continue with daily life aka psychosocial therapy groups are formed based on a specific diagnosis to best assist group members. members often act as a support network and guide their peers toward ways to improve coping skills and adapt to life changes varies by age: i.e. play therapy for kids can be traditional or nontraditional can be related to divorce, the death of a family member, communication problems, substance use, interpersonal conflicts, or behavioral problems, potentially among children form of psychotherapy in which the environment is controlled to assist the client in preventing self-destructive or maladaptive behaviors. pharmacology brain-stimulating activities: vagus nerve stim, repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation, magnetic seizure therapy, deep brain sim, ECT, etc virtual video conference, telephone, or even online chat for those who do not have the ability to leave home, live in areas where therapy is not close, or even those who cannot meet the schedule of most therapists. yoga, exercise, etc dietics

item.title: iv. Theories
item.description: freud id, superego, ego Id - instant gratification Superego - concerned with morals and following rules; "ideal self", "conscience" Ego - rational, realistic part of the personality that mediates between the id's impulses and the superego's moral demands human behavior is influenced by childhood experiences behavior is based on childhood experiences; part of an individual’s conscious awareness and unconscious memories experiences shape an individual’s personality. interpersonal relationships and social experiences assist in shaping an individual’s self. Three Types of Self: => based on social assessment The Good Me The Bad Me The NOT me - unknown, or the part of an individual that is often repressed anxiety is there when there is negative feedback Peplau’s Interpersonal Relations Model defines the nurse-client relationship as occurring in four distinct, overlapping phases Stages: Pre-interaction - nurse reviews data, anticipates concerns Orientation - nurse explains their role; pt expresses needs, sense of belonging, etc Working - work together to achieve goals Termination - nurse and client achieved goals, end of relationship Behaviorism - focused on observed behaviors (as opposed to unconscious mental state) John Watson Classical Conditioning (Pavlov) - associative learning, focuses on unconscious memory Operant Conditioning (B.F. Skinner) - behavior followed by positive consequences is likely to be repeated, and behavior followed by negative consequences is less likely to be repeated. human behaviors are influenced by an individual’s thought process Social cognitive theory is a form of cognitive therapy in which an individual models behaviors observed by others (e.g. peer pressure) Humanism - individual is studied or viewed as a whole Maslow, Rogers, Bugental "people are innately good" Mental or social illness causes deviations from this core concept Rogers - individuals perceive the world based on their own experiences, which are then reflected in their personality and behaviors to meet self-actualization. Bugental - humans are a single entity and cannot be broken down into parts begin with child development and progress throughout the lifespan with distinct stages describing behavioral differences Piaget - human intelligence is based on one’s biological ability to adapt to one’s environment; intelligence advances with age Erikson - each stage has specific tasks or goals to be plotted out and achieved so that resolution can occur see Developmental Theories based on Lawrence Kohlberg’s stages not tied to a specific age group, but rather to levels that can often be noted at specific ages *Preconventional Level (self-interest, obedience, avoid punishment)* Stage 1: Obedience and Punishment – morality based on avoiding punishment, rules seen as fixed Stage 2: Instrumental Relativist Orientation – right action based on self-interest, fair exchange or “you scratch my back, I’ll scratch yours” *Conventional Level (conformity, social order)* Stage 3: Interpersonal Relationships – morality defined by approval, “good boy/good girl” orientation, pleasing others Stage 4: Law and Order – respect for authority, duty, following laws to maintain society *Postconventional Level (abstract reasoning, universal principles)* Stage 5: Social Contract and Individual Rights – laws as social contracts, can be changed for the greater good, recognition of differing values Stage 6: Universal Ethical Principles – "golden rule"; morality based on internal principles of justice and equality, may conflict with laws provides an explanation of mental health disorders as a malfunction within the body offers insight into how the brain’s anatomy, genomics, psychopharmacology, and neurotransmitters influence mental health

item.title: Developmental Theories
item.description: "TAGIR" = trust, autonomy, guilt, industry, role confusion Infancy (0-12 months) - Trust vs Mistrust sense of trust with caregiver realize that they are separate beings from caregivers learns to tolerate small frustration and trusts in delayed gratification Toddler (1-3) - Autonomy Versus Shame and Doubt give up dependence and assert own sense of control self mastery: move from dependence to autonomy favorite response: "no" - negativism is normal quick changes from happy to crying and screaming Preschooler (3-6) - Initiative vs Guilt likes to please parents begins to plan activities, make up games acts out the roles of other people develops: sexual identity, conscience feels remorse when makes wrong choice or behaves badly School-age (6-12) - Industry vs Inferiority Developing self-worth and cognitive/social skills Thru involvement in home, school, and community activities satisfaction from achieving success in developing new skills = self worth if expectations are too high => inferiority Needs support and encouragement from important people in life Adolescent (11-20) - Identity vs Confusion Early (10-13) focus on bodily changes frequent mood changes strives to master skills w/in peer group define boundaries with parents struggles to separate from parents while still desiring dependence Middle (14-16) need for acceptance by peer group at highest level interested in attracting opposite gender conflict w/ parents Late (17-20) more secure with body image; matured sexual identity ability to understand implications of behavior and decisions Process of emancipation from family almost complete Adulthood (18-65+) Young Adulthood( 18-40) - Intimacy vs Isolation Middle Adulthood (40-65) - Generativity vs Stagnation** Late Adulthood (65+) - Integrity vs Despair Did I live a meaningful life? Do I have enough retirement? Positive: wisdom, acceptance Negative: regret, despair Sensorimotor Stage (Birth – 2 years) Learns through senses and motor actions Develops object permanence (around 8 months) Begins goal-directed behavior Stranger anxiety may develop Preoperational Stage - Preconceptual phase(2 – 4 years) Egocentric thinking dominates magical thinking - own thoughts are all-powerful Uses symbols, language, and pretend play Lacks concept of conservation Thinking is intuitive, not logical Preoperational - Intuitive Phase (4-7) able to classify and relate objects Has intuitive thought processes; knows if something is right or wrong, though cannot state why Tolerates others’ differences but does not understand them very curious about facts May begin to question parents’ values Centering - the tendency of young children to focus on only one aspect of a situation or object, while disregarding other relevant features Concrete Operational Stage (7 – 11 years) Develops logical thinking about concrete events Understands conservation, reversibility, classification, and seriation Less egocentric, more empathetic Difficulty with abstract or hypothetical concepts Formal Operational Stage (12 years – adulthood) Early (10-13) - Limited abstract thought process - Egocentrically thinking - Eager to apply limited abstract process to different situations and to peer groups Middle (14-16) - risky behaviors increase - more involved with society/politics Late (17-20) - established abstract thinking - critical thinking - less risky bejaviors - develops realistic goals and career plans

item.title: Nephrotic Syndrome - final
item.description: Kidney disorder causing massive protein loss in urine Characterized by proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia Nephrotic Syndrome => Nasty Protein Loss Most common in children ages 2–7, especially males Damage to glomerular basement membrane increases permeability to proteins Loss of albumin leads to decreased oncotic pressure → edema Liver compensates by increasing lipoprotein synthesis → hyperlipidemia Loss of immunoglobulins and clotting factors increases infection and clot risk 4 S => Triggers: stress sickness smoking sun exposure Minimal change disease (most common in children) => idiopathic Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis Membranous nephropathy Secondary to infections, lupus, diabetes, NSAIDs Age 2–7 years Recent viral illness Allergies or immunizations Autoimmune conditions Genetic predisposition Massive edema (periorbital, progressing to whole body) => Nursing tip: important to provide thorough skin care to prevent infection (ATI) Weight gain with low urine output Frothy or foamy urine (proteinuria) Hypoalbuminemia Hyperlipidemia Normal or slightly elevated BP Fatigue, anorexia, pallor Infection (peritonitis, sepsis) Thromboembolism (DVT, PE) Hypovolemia AKI Relapse or steroid resistance Urinalysis: 3+ or 4+ protein, microscopic hematuria Low serum albumin, low total protein Elevated cholesterol and triglycerides Renal biopsy if atypical presentation Normal complement levels (differentiates from APSGN) Corticosteroids (prednisone is first-line) Diuretics for severe edema Albumin IV followed by furosemide in severe hypoalbuminemia Statins if hyperlipidemia is prolonged Immunosuppressants for steroid-resistant cases Antibiotics if infection present Daily weights and strict I&Os Monitor edema and urine output Prevent skin breakdown Monitor for signs of infection or thromboembolism Promote quiet activities during steroid therapy Administer meds and monitor for side effects (e.g., Cushingoid from steroids) Importance of med adherence, especially steroids Recognize relapse signs: weight gain, edema, decreased urine Avoid exposure to infections; may be immunocompromise Low-sodium, adequate protein diet Monitor weight and urine at home Report signs of blood clots or infection NAILS = Nephrosis, Albumin low, Increased lipids, Lipiduria, Swelling HEPOn = Hypoalbuminemia, Edema, Proteinuria, hyperlipidemia

item.title: Osteogenesis Imperfecta
item.description: brittle bone disease take blood pressure manually to avoid over-tightening the cuff reposition frequently lift infant/child under broadest areas of the body signature manifestation: blue coloring of the sclera

item.title: Rheumatic Fever
item.description: Inflammatory autoimmune reaction after untreated Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcal pharyngitis Affects heart, joints, skin, CNS Mnemonic: "J♥NES" (Joints, ♥ Carditis, Nodules, Erythema marginatum, Sydenham chorea) Group A strep pharyngitis (Streptococcus pyogenes) Untreated or partially treated strep throat Molecular mimicry: antibodies to strep M protein cross-react with host tissues (heart, joints, CNS) Immune-mediated inflammation damages connective tissue, especially valves Recent untreated strep throat Age 5–15 years Overcrowded living conditions, low socioeconomic status Migratory polyarthritis Carditis (tachycardia, new murmurs, pericardial rub) Subcutaneous nodules over bony prominences Erythema marginatum (non-pruritic rash with serpiginous borders) Sydenham chorea (involuntary movements, emotional lability) Fever, malaise, elevated ESR/CRP Rheumatic heart disease (valvular stenosis/regurgitation, especially mitral) Heart failure Recurrence with repeated strep infections Jones Criteria: 2 major or 1 major + 2 minor + evidence of preceding strep infection Evidence: positive throat culture, rapid antigen test, elevated ASO titer ECG: prolonged PR interval Echocardiogram: valvular involvement Penicillin (benzathine penicillin G IM single dose or oral for 10 days) to eradicate strep Anti-inflammatory: aspirin or NSAIDs for arthritis Corticosteroids for severe carditis Bed rest during acute phase Secondary prophylaxis: monthly benzathine penicillin G IM for 5–10 years or longer if carditis present Monitor for new murmurs, signs of HF Manage fever and joint pain Strict adherence to antibiotic regimen Monitor for aspirin toxicity (tinnitus, bleeding) in children—consider Reye’s risk Educate on infection prevention and prompt sore throat evaluation Importance of completing antibiotics for strep throat Recognizing early signs of recurrence Long-term prophylaxis adherence Avoid strenuous activity during acute carditis Maintain regular follow-up with cardiology if heart involved

item.title: Hip Dysplasia
item.description: DDH Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip a condition where the ball & socket joint of the hip does not form properly leads to hip instability that can result in FULL dislocation of the hip joint head of the femur pops out of the hip socket making the affected leg shorter as the femur head gets- displaced. DDH typically presents at the time of birth or present in the first few years of age breech birth large infant family hx 0-12 weeks => extra gluteal folds instability, clicking sensation 12+ weeks - limited hip abduction, shortened legs walking years: Trendelenburg sign => pelvic tilt Pavlik Harness => like a jumper for infants only HCP can adjust do not take off - must be 100% of the day on dress child under the strap diapers under the strap no powders, lotions Spica Cast - cast applied from the chest to the thighs or knees

item.title: Pediculosis Capitis
item.description: lice do not share hats, combs put items on sealed airtight bag

item.title: Tinea
item.description: ringworm tinea pedis - athlete's foot tinea corporis - body ringworm treat with Griseofulvin - takes months to treat; apply after high fat meal do not share items tinea ring = its a ringworm thing

item.title: Immz to avoid in Immunocompromised Patients
item.description: MVR => "mover"MMR Varicella Rotavirus

item.title: Intussusception
item.description: 1 part of the intestines slides inside another part of the intestines, sort of like a telescope currant jelly stool no projectile vomiting - do not confuse with Hirschsprung's Disease

item.title: Hirschsprung's Disease
item.description: condition in infants that affects the large intestine (colon) causes problems with passing stool due to the missing nerve cells in the colon, which leads to bowel obstruction as the anal sphincter is unable to relax and coupled with no peristalsis (meaning no movement of the intestines) no BM or meconium distended abdomen refusing to feed green bile fever foul smelling diarrhea surgery to bypass affected colon

item.title: Tracheoesophageal Fistula & Esophageal Atresia
item.description: Tracheoesophageal Fistula (TEF) is an abnormal connection between the esophagus and the trachea, resulting in high risk for aspiration during feedings! Esophageal Atresia (EA) is when the esophagus is divided into 2 segments without connecting to one another. Both of these conditions (TEF & EA) often occur together.

item.title: Cleft Palate & Lip
item.description: huge risk for aspiration smoking alcohol anticonvulsants Lip - 3-6 months Palate - 12 months or earlier no objects in mouth: straws, Elevate after feeding Upright during feeding Elbow restraints - per policy burp often point bottle down and away during feeding slow feeding

item.title: Cleft Palate & Lip(1)
item.description: huge risk for aspiration smoking alcohol anticonvulsants Lip - 3-6 months Palate - 12 months or earlier no objects in mouth: straws, Elevate after feeding Upright during feeding Elbow restraints - per policy burp often point bottle down and away during feeding slow feeding

item.title: Pyloric Stenosis
item.description: projectile vomiting can lead to Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis => lower sphincter of the stomach becomes enlarged, preventing food from entering the small intestine leads to severe dehydration & constant hunger Note difference: Pyloric Stenosis => lower sphincter, Achalasia => motility problem in pre-stomach area projectile vomiting after feeding abdominal distention hunger poor weight gain Surgery

item.title: Achalasia
item.description: motility disorder that inhibits formula or milk from going down limited esophageal peristalsis and nonrelaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES).

item.title: PKU
item.description: Autosomal recessive metabolic disorder causing deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase Leads to accumulation of phenylalanine and deficiency of tyrosine Mnemonic: "PKU = Phenyl Kills the Upbrain" (untreated → intellectual disability) Mutation in PAH gene → phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency Rarely: defect in tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) metabolism Inability to convert phenylalanine → tyrosine Excess phenylalanine → neurotoxicity, impaired myelin formation Tyrosine becomes essential amino acid Autosomal recessive inheritance (both parents carriers) Northern European ancestry more common Family history of PKU Normal at birth, symptoms develop without dietary restriction Intellectual disability, seizures, hyperactivity Hypopigmentation (fair skin, light hair, blue eyes) Musty/mousy body odor (due to phenylacetate) Eczema, behavioral problems Severe irreversible intellectual disability if untreated Psychiatric disorders Maternal PKU → microcephaly, congenital heart defects in fetus Newborn screening (Guthrie bacterial inhibition assay or tandem mass spectrometry) Elevated phenylalanine levels (>20 mg/dL) Genetic testing for PAH mutations Lifelong low-phenylalanine diet (avoid meat, dairy, nuts, aspartame) Special phenylalanine-free formula (e.g., Lofenalac) Tyrosine supplementation Sapropterin (BH4 cofactor) for responsive cases Ensure newborn screening is done before discharge Educate parents on strict dietary adherence Monitor phenylalanine blood levels regularly Collaborate with dietitian for meal planning Monitor growth, development, and neurobehavioral status Avoid high-protein foods and aspartame => even peanut butter Tyrosine supplementation is essential Strict diet before and during pregnancy for women with PKU Regular follow-up for lifelong management Inform all healthcare providers of PKU diagnosis

item.title: Neuroblastoma
item.description: A malignant tumor of the sympathetic nervous system, originating from neural crest cells.1 It is the most common extracranial solid tumor in children. Neuroblastoma = Nervous Baby Tumor Exact cause is unknown. It is thought to be a genetic mutation in the developing neural crest cells, which normally form the sympathetic nervous system. Most cases are sporadic, but a small percentage can be familial. Arises from immature neuroblasts in the adrenal glands (most common site), chest, neck, or spinal cord. The tumor secretes catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine), leading to various symptoms. Can metastasize early and widely to bone, bone marrow, liver, skin, and lymph nodes. Clinical Pearl: High levels of catecholamine metabolites (HVA and VMA) in urine are a key diagnostic marker Age: Occurs most often in infants and young children, with over half of cases diagnosed before the age of 2. Genetics: A small number of cases are hereditary. Abdominal Mass: A firm, irregular mass in the abdomen that can cross the midline. Unlike Wilms' tumor, it's often irregular. Metastasis: Bone pain or limp (bone metastasis) Periorbital ecchymosis ("raccoon eyes") and proptosis (orbital metastasis). Hepatomegaly (liver metastasis). Skin nodules (dermal metastasis). Catecholamine-related symptoms: Hypertension, flushing, and sweating Diarrhea (due to vasoactive intestinal peptide secretion) Other: Anorexia, weight loss, irritability, and fever. Metastatic disease. Spinal cord compression leading to paralysis. Bone marrow suppression from tumor infiltration or chemotherapy. Tumor-related syndromes like opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome ("dancing eyes and feet") Urine Catecholamine Metabolites: Elevated levels of homovanillic acid (HVA) and vanillylmandelic acid (VMA).9 This is a hallmark test. Biopsy: Confirms the diagnosis and staging.10 Imaging: Ultrasound, CT, or MRI to locate the primary tumor and assess for spread. Bone Marrow Aspiration/Biopsy: To check for bone marrow involvement. MIBG Scan: A nuclear medicine scan that uses a radioactive tracer taken up by neuroblastoma cells to detect primary and metastatic disease. Surgery: To remove the primary tumor. Chemotherapy: The main treatment for advanced disease. Radiation Therapy: Used for high-risk tumors or to treat specific sites of metastasis (e.g., bone pain, spinal cord compression) Stem Cell Transplant: For high-risk disease. Immunotherapy: A newer approach using antibodies to target neuroblastoma cells. NCLEX Tip: The hallmark of neuroblastoma is elevated urine HVA and VMA levels. Monitor for signs and symptoms of catecholamine excess (e.g., hypertension, tachycardia). Provide meticulous skin care due to risk of skin breakdown and pain from bone lesions. Monitor for and manage side effects of chemotherapy, including nausea, vomiting, and myelosuppression (risk of infection, bleeding, and anemia). Neuroblastoma is NOT palpated, but unlike Wilms' tumor, a sign isn't posted to avoid it, as the tumor is often already metastatic and palpation won't change the prognosis. However, gentle handling is always a good practice. Provide comprehensive pain management, especially for bone pain. Explain the disease process and the importance of adhering to the complex treatment plan. Educate parents on monitoring for signs of infection (fever, chills) due to immunosuppression from chemotherapy. Advise on nutrition and hydration, as children may have a poor appetite. Teach parents how to manage pain and administer medications at home. Emphasize the importance of follow-up appointments and long-term monitoring.

item.title: Wilm's Tumor
item.description: One kidney chills, the other’s got Wilms => one side only kidney cells do not develop to maturity Malignant renal tumor in children, usually unilateral Peak onset age 3–4 years, rarely crosses midline Also called nephroblastoma Genetic mutations (WT1 gene on chromosome 11) Associated with syndromes like WAGR, Beckwith-Wiedemann, Denys-Drash Family history of Wilm’s tumor WAGR syndrome: Wilm’s tumor, Aniridia, Genitourinary anomalies, Retardation Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome Denys-Drash syndrome Male sex, African descent Painless abdominal mass Hematuria Hypertension due to renin secretion Fever, fatigue, weight loss Abdominal pain, constipation Anemia Metastasis (lungs most common) Kidney failure Bowel obstruction Recurrence Chemo or radiation side effects Abdominal ultrasound (first-line) CT or MRI for staging Chest X-ray for metastasis CBC, urinalysis Biopsy usually avoided pre-op to prevent rupture Surgical nephrectomy Chemotherapy Radiation therapy (based on stage) Long-term surveillance Do not palpate abdomen to avoid tumor rupture Monitor blood pressure and kidney function Assess for signs of infection or chemo complications Maintain strict I&Os Provide emotional support Educate family on diagnosis and treatment plan Avoid abdominal trauma Adhere to follow-up imaging and labs Recognize signs of recurrence or complications Monitor BP at home if instructed Importance of medication and chemo adherence Consider genetic counseling

item.title: Primitive Reflexes
item.description: Primitive Reflexes disappear over months Except: Moro - disappears at 12 months Persistent primitive reflexes - abnormalProtective Reflexes that Persists: Neck Righting Parachute (sideways and forward, backward)

item.title: Acute Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis
item.description: Immune-mediated kidney inflammation after streptococcal infection Most common in children 5–12 years old Follows untreated strep throat or impetigo by 1–3 weeks Immune complexes from Group A beta-hemolytic strep deposit in glomeruli Triggers inflammation and obstruction of glomerular capillaries Leads to decreased GFR, sodium/water retention, and hematuria Recent Group A strep infection (pharyngitis, skin infection) Latent period: 1–2 weeks after throat infection, 3–6 weeks after skin infection Recent untreated strep infection Children (especially boys) Low socioeconomic status Overcrowded living conditions Hematuria (tea or cola-colored urine) Periorbital and facial edema (especially in morning) Hypertension Oliguria Proteinuria Fever, malaise Possible flank or abdominal pain High K, Na / low Ca Hypertensive encephalopathy Acute kidney injury Pulmonary edema Electrolyte imbalances Chronic glomerulonephritis (rare) Throat culture or ASO titer (positive for recent strep) Urinalysis: hematuria, proteinuria, RBC casts Elevated BUN and creatinine Decreased serum C3 complement Kidney biopsy rarely needed Supportive care: rest, fluid and sodium restriction Antihypertensives for elevated BP Diuretics for edema Antibiotics (penicillin) if strep infection still present Dialysis if severe renal impairment Monitor vital signs, especially BP Daily weight and strict I&Os Assess for edema and respiratory distress Enforce fluid and sodium restrictions Monitor labs: BUN, creatinine, electrolytes, UA Educate on completing antibiotics for strep Complete all prescribed antibiotics Avoid NSAIDs (nephrotoxic) Monitor for changes in urine output or color Restrict salt and fluids as instructed Limit activity during acute phase Follow up for BP and kidney function monitoring

item.title: Growth Rates
item.description: Per ATI: Weight - double by 6 months Weight - triple by 12 months Weight - quadruple by 30 months

item.title: Myelomingocele
item.description: The most severe form of spina bifida, a type of neural tube defect (NTD). It involves a sac-like protrusion on the back containing meninges, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), and a portion of the spinal cord and nerves. Results in permanent neurological damage below the level of the lesion. Failure of the embryonic neural tube to close completely during the first month of pregnancy (around day 28). The exact cause is a multifactorial combination of genetic predisposition and environmental factors. Incomplete closure of the posterior vertebral arch allows the spinal cord and meninges to herniate through the opening. The exposed neural tissue is underdeveloped and damaged, leading to a loss of motor and sensory function distal to the defect. Often associated with Chiari II malformation, where the brainstem and cerebellum are pulled downward, obstructing CSF flow and causing hydrocephalus. Folic acid deficiency before and during pregnancy is the most significant risk factor. Family history of neural tube defects. Maternal use of certain medications (e.g., valproic acid, carbamazepine). Maternal diabetes or obesity. Maternal fever or hyperthermia in early pregnancy. Visible sac-like lesion on the spine, most commonly in the lumbosacral region. The sac may be thin and prone to rupture. Paralysis or weakness of the lower extremities (flaccid paralysis). Lack of sensation below the level of the lesion. Neurogenic bladder and bowel: Incontinence, retention, and constipation due to lack of nerve control. Orthopedic issues: Clubfoot, hip dysplasia, and scoliosis are common. Hydrocephalus: Present in about 80-90% of infants, evidenced by a rapidly increasing head circumference and bulging fontanelles. Common: neurogenic bladder =>always assess for bladder distention and incomplete emptying Hydrocephalus: Requires placement of a ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt. Infection: High risk of meningitis if the sac ruptures. Tethered Cord Syndrome: Scar tissue forms and attaches the spinal cord to surrounding structures, causing progressive neurological deterioration. Chronic kidney disease from recurrent UTIs and urinary retention. Latex Allergy: Extremely common due to frequent exposure during surgeries and catheterizations. Assume every child with spina bifida has a latex allergy. 🤧 Prenatal: Elevated maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) screen, confirmed by fetal ultrasound and amniocentesis (which shows high levels of alpha-fetoprotein). Postnatal: Obvious physical defect at birth. An MRI or CT scan is used to assess the extent of spinal cord involvement and to check for hydrocephalus. Immediate Pre-operative Care: Protect the sac! The infant is placed in a radiant warmer to remain unclothed. Position the infant prone (on their stomach) to prevent pressure on the sac. Cover the sac with a sterile, moist, non-adherent dressing to prevent drying and rupture. Keep the area free of contamination from urine and feces (use a protective drape). Surgery: Surgical closure of the back lesion is typically performed within 24-72 hours of birth to reduce the risk of infection. Ventriculoperitoneal (VP) Shunt: A shunt is surgically placed to treat hydrocephalus by draining excess CSF from the brain's ventricles to the abdominal cavity. Lifelong Management: Requires a multidisciplinary team (neurosurgery, urology, orthopedics, PT/OT). Includes clean intermittent catheterization (CIC) for bladder management and a bowel program. NCLEX Tip: The absolute priority for a newborn with a myelomeningocele is to protect the sac from injury and infection. Pre-op Mnemonic - SAC: Sterile Dressing: Cover with a sterile, saline-soaked, non-adherent dressing. Change it regularly (q2-4h) to keep it moist. Asepsis: Use strict sterile technique. Monitor for signs of infection (fever, irritability, lethargy). Contamination Prevention: Position infant prone with hips slightly flexed to keep urine and stool away from the lesion. Post-op Care: Monitor vital signs, intake/output, pain, and the surgical incision for signs of infection or CSF leakage. Continue prone positioning until cleared by the surgeon. Hydrocephalus Monitoring: Measure head circumference daily. Assess fontanelles for bulging and monitor for signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP) like a high-pitched cry, vomiting, and sunsetting eyes. Latex Precautions: Ensure a latex-free environment for all care. Use non-latex gloves, catheters, and supplies. Teach parents how to perform clean intermittent catheterization (CIC) and manage a bowel regimen. Educate on the signs and symptoms of a VP shunt malfunction: headache, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, swelling along the shunt track, and changes in behavior or school performance. Explain the importance of a latex-free environment and provide a list of common latex-containing products (e.g., balloons, rubber toys). Instruct on proper skin care and positioning to prevent pressure injuries, especially on areas with no sensation. Encourage range-of-motion exercises to prevent contractures. Connect the family with the Spina Bifida Association and other community support resources. ❤️

item.title: Pheochromocytoma
item.description: Rare catecholamine-secreting tumor from adrenal medulla chromaffin cells causing episodic or sustained hypertension Pheochromies are homies with high BPs Usually benign adrenal medulla tumor Can be extra-adrenal (paraganglioma) Associated with genetic syndromes: MEN2, von Hippel–Lindau, NF1 Family history of pheochromocytoma or related syndromes Age 30–50 most common, but can occur in children Genetic mutations in RET, VHL, NF1 genes Excess secretion of epinephrine, norepinephrine, ± dopamine → overstimulation of adrenergic receptors → episodic sympathetic surges Classic triad: episodic headache, diaphoresis, palpitations Hypertension (episodic or persistent) Tremor, anxiety, pallor, abdominal or chest pain, weight loss Attacks triggered by stress, surgery, certain meds, position changes Surgical removal (adrenalectomy) definitive Pre-op: alpha-blockade (phenoxybenzamine) for 7–14 days → beta-blockade after adequate alpha control Volume expansion pre-op to prevent hypotension post-tumor removal Monitor BP and heart rate closely Manage pre-op alpha and beta blockade Educate about avoiding triggers Post-op: watch for hypotension, hypoglycemia, arrhythmias Provide calm, low-stimulation environment to reduce catecholamine surges Plasma free metanephrines or 24-hr urine catecholamines/metanephrines MRI or CT abdomen to localize tumor MIBG scan if extra-adrenal suspected Hypertensive crisis Stroke, myocardial infarction, arrhythmias Multi-organ damage from prolonged catecholamine excess

item.title: VP Shunt
item.description: Surgical device that diverts excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from brain ventricles to another body cavity (commonly peritoneum) to relieve intracranial pressure in conditions like hydrocephalus Used to treat hydrocephalus from congenital malformations, tumors, meningitis, intraventricular hemorrhage, traumatic brain injury Increased infection risk in neonates and immunocompromised Blockage risk higher with history of intraventricular hemorrhage or high CSF protein content CSF overproduction or impaired absorption → ventricular dilation → increased ICP → VP shunt diverts CSF via catheter and valve to peritoneal cavity for absorption Signs of shunt malfunction: headache, nausea, vomiting, irritability, bulging fontanelle, altered LOC, vision changes Signs of shunt infection: fever, redness/tenderness along shunt tract, abdominal pain, peritonitis signs, meningitis symptoms Surgical placement of shunt system Revision or replacement if malfunction or infection occurs Antibiotics for shunt infection Temporary external ventricular drain if urgent removal needed Monitor neuro status and ICP signs Assess shunt site for redness, swelling, leakage Monitor for abdominal distension or pain Strict aseptic technique with any handling Educate caregivers on infection/malfunction signs Post-op: position patient flat initially, gradually elevate HOB as ordered CT or MRI brain to assess ventricle size Shunt series X-rays to check continuity CSF culture if infection suspected Ultrasound in infants to monitor ventricles Infection Mechanical failure/blockage Over-drainage (subdural hematoma, slit ventricle syndrome) Peritonitis Catheter migration

item.title: Precautions Types
item.description: MTV: Measles Tuberculosis Varicella - chickenpox PIMP: Pertussis Influenza Meningitis Pneumonia

item.title: Hemophilia 1
item.description: X-linked recessive bleeding disorder Deficiency of clotting factor VIII (Hemophilia A) or factor IX (Hemophilia B / Christmas disease) Leads to prolonged bleeding due to impaired clot formation Mutation in F8 or F9 gene leads to reduced or absent clotting factor Coagulation cascade is disrupted, especially *intrinsic pathway Results in ineffective fibrin clot formation → excessive bleeding Genetic mutation on X chromosome Mostly inherited; can be spontaneous mutation Females are carriers, males typically affected Family history of hemophilia Male sex Carriers passing gene to male offspring Prolonged bleeding, even with minor trauma Hemarthrosis (joint bleeding – knees, elbows) Bruising, hematomas Prolonged aPTT, normal PT and platelets Bleeding after procedures (circumcision, tooth extraction) Hematuria, GI bleeding, intracranial hemorrhage (severe cases) Joint deformities from recurrent hemarthrosis Compartment syndrome Intracranial hemorrhage Transfusion-related infections (if untreated with plasma-derived products) Development of inhibitors (antibodies to clotting factors) Prolonged aPTT Normal PT, bleeding time, and platelet count Factor VIII or IX assay to confirm type Genetic testing for carriers Factor replacement therapy (recombinant preferred) Hemophilia A: factor VIII Hemophilia B: factor IX Desmopressin (DDAVP) for mild Hemophilia A Antifibrinolytics (e.g., aminocaproic acid) Avoid NSAIDs and aspirin Administer factor before procedures or activity Monitor for signs of bleeding (joints, urine, stool, neuro status) Apply pressure after injections or blood draws Use soft toothbrushes and electric razors Avoid IM injections; use smallest gauge for venipuncture Assess for joint swelling, pain, or decreased ROM Importance of routine factor replacement Recognize early signs of bleeding (joint stiffness, HA, bruising) Avoid contact sports and trauma Medic alert bracelet Safe environment: pad furniture, use protective gear Vaccinate for hepatitis A and B (risk from blood products)

item.title: Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome
item.description: Acute condition causing triad of hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury => H.A.T. Leading cause of acute renal failure in children Often triggered by E. coli O157:H7 infection (toxin-mediated) Shiga toxin damages endothelial lining of small vessels, especially in kidneys Leads to platelet activation, microthrombi, and RBC fragmentation (schistocytes) Glomerular injury reduces filtration → acute renal failure Most commonly E. coli O157:H7 (undercooked beef, unpasteurized juice, petting zoos) Less commonly Shigella, Salmonella, pneumonia, or genetic forms Children <5 years old Recent diarrheal illness, especially bloody Exposure to contaminated food or water Contact with infected animals or individuals Profuse diarrhea (often bloody), followed by: Pallor, fatigue, irritability (anemia) Oliguria or anuria Petechiae, purpura, or bruising (thrombocytopenia) Hypertension Edema Seizures or altered mental status (severe cases) Acute kidney injury or failure Hypertension Neurologic involvement (seizures, coma) Pancreatitis, cardiomyopathy Chronic kidney disease CBC: low Hgb, low platelets, schistocytes on smear Elevated BUN and creatinine Urinalysis: hematuria, proteinuria Stool culture for E. coli O157:H7 or Shiga toxin Coombs test negative (non-immune hemolysis) Supportive care is key IV fluids to maintain perfusion Dialysis if renal failure or fluid overload Blood transfusions for severe anemia Avoid antibiotics and antidiarrheals (worsen toxin release) Monitor electrolytes, BP, and fluid balance Monitor urine output, daily weight, and BP Strict I&Os and fluid/electrolyte management Seizure precautions if CNS involvement Assess for bleeding and neurologic changes Prepare for dialysis if needed Maintain contact precautions for diarrhea Avoid undercooked meat and unpasteurized foods Proper hand hygiene, especially after animal contact Report signs of decreased urine, bleeding, or behavior changes Long-term follow-up for renal function if needed Educate on avoiding NSAIDs (nephrotoxic) Mnemonic HUS = Hemolysis, Uremia, Small platelets Triad = Anemia + Thrombocytopenia + AKI

item.title: Mononucleosis
item.description: Viral infection caused by Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) Affects lymphoid tissue and B cells Known as "kissing disease" due to transmission via saliva Common in teens and young adults EBV infects epithelial cells of oropharynx and salivary glands Virus spreads to B lymphocytes and causes proliferation Cytotoxic T cells respond, causing lymphoid tissue hyperplasia Results in enlarged lymph nodes, spleen, and liver Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV), a herpesvirus Transmitted through saliva, less commonly through blood or semen Adolescents and young adults (15–25 years) Close contact activities (kissing, sharing drinks) Immunocompromised individuals Fever Sore throat with exudative pharyngitis Fatigue (can last weeks to months) Enlarged cervical lymph nodes Splenomegaly and hepatomegaly Headache, malaise, body aches Rash (especially if given ampicillin/amoxicillin) Splenic rupture (medical emergency) Hepatitis Hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia Guillain-Barré syndrome (rare) Chronic EBV infection Positive Monospot test (heterophile antibody test) => rapid blood test used to detect infectious mononucleosis Elevated atypical lymphocytes on CBC Elevated LFTs and mild leukocytosis EBV-specific antibody testing (for confirmation) Supportive care: rest, fluids, antipyretics, analgesics Corticosteroids for airway obstruction or severe symptoms Avoid ampicillin/amoxicillin to prevent rash No antivirals typically needed unless complications arise Monitor for signs of splenic rupture (sudden LUQ pain, hypotension) Encourage rest and hydration Soft diet if painful swallowing Educate on avoiding contact sports for 4–6 weeks Monitor airway in cases of tonsillar hypertrophy Use droplet precautions if hospitalized with active symptoms Avoid kissing and sharing utensils while symptomatic Rest and increase fluid intake No contact sports or heavy lifting until cleared (risk of splenic rupture) Symptom relief with OTC meds like acetaminophen Fatigue may last weeks; gradual return to activities Seek care for severe abdominal pain or breathing difficulty

item.title: Eyes and Sensory
item.description: most common eye disorder: refractive errors ROP: retinopathy of prematurity Conjunctivitis - can be viral, allergic, bacterial (purulent, mucoid, green eye boogers) Viral or Allergic - water, mucoid Allergic - watery or stringy Treatment: rinse with water, hand washing, educate Eyelid Disorders Chalazion - benign (non-cancerous) bump on the eyelid caused by a blockage in a Meibomian gland. These glands produce an oily substance that lubricates the eye. self resolving per book Stye / Hordeolum - painful, red lump on the eyelid, usually caused by a bacterial infection; tx: abx, warm compress Blepharitis - redness, itching, and crusting around the eyelashes. note: no pain involved. Treatment: abx Refractive Errors - know which one is farsighted/nearsighted treatment Strabismus - misalignment of the eye, crosses after 4 months =? follow-up extropia exophthalmos Amblyopia Nystagmus - twitching eye Glaucoma - autosomal receptive disorder, incest, obstruction of aqueous humor, increased intraoptical pressure, Cataracts - clouding of natural lens, surgery - implant or contact lens, contacts until old enough for surgery Otitis Media AOM OM with Effisusion Otitis Externa Risk Factors: Eustachian tube dysfunction rucurrent URI daycare attendance previous epdispode smoking in household oral abx Hearing Acuity & Hearing Loss Types: conductive - transmission of sound thru middle ear is disrupted sensorineural - damage to hair cells in cochlea or along the auditory pathway Mixed - both conductive and sensori if identified => begin early intervention ASAP (speech therapy, audiology, etc)

item.title: Congenital Heart Diseases
item.description:
this is a general note for CHDs Disorders with decreased pulmonary blood flow => R-L Patho: Right-to-left shunt: deoxygenated blood bypasses lungs and enters systemic circulation Obstruction or narrowing (e.g., pulmonary stenosis) increases right-sided pressure Hypoxemia and cyanosis due to poor oxygenation Body compensates via polycythemia, clubbing Loud murmur may be present due to turbulent flow Examples: Tetralogy of Fallot
Tricuspid Atresia Pulmonary Artesia Disorders with increased pulmonary blood flow => L-R Patho: Left-to-right shunt: oxygenated blood recirculates through lungs Increased volume to pulmonary vessels → pulmonary hypertension Pulmonary Hypertension => forces the right side of the heart to work harder to pump blood through the lungs, and can lead to right-sided heart failure over time Pulmonary edema and respiratory distress common Risk of right heart failure over time Frequent infections due to fluid overload in lungs Examples
Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA)
Atrial Septal Defect (ASD)
Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD)
Atrioventricular Septal Defect (AVSD) Obstructive disorders Patho: narrowing of major vessel peripheral circulation or blood flow to lungs is affected Examples
Coarctation of the Aorta - narrowing of the aorta
Aortic Stenosis Pulmonary Stenosis Mixed disorders Patho: Mixing of well-oxygenated pulmonary venous blood with poorly oxygenated systemic venous blood Mixed blood enters systemic circulation → lower arterial oxygen saturation Often leads to cyanosis, decreased cardiac output, and heart failure Typically ductal-dependent, requiring PGE1 and surgical intervention Not responsive to O2 treatment Often no murmur Tires out easily => need to conserve energy; poor weight gain Examples: Transposition of the Great Vessels (TGV) aorta and pulmonary artery are switched => NOT COMPATIBLE WITH LIFE, immediate surgery Aorta arises from RV and pulmonary artery from LV → parallel circulations Oxygenated and deoxygenated blood only mix via ASD, VSD, or PDA Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR) - Pulmonary veins drain into right atrium instead of left atrium Truncus Arteriosus - both ventricles eject blood into the same artery → complete mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood Hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) Underdeveloped LV, aortic valve, and ascending aorta Systemic circulation sustained by PDA, with mixing at atrial level (ASD) Without intervention, results in shock and death as ductus closes Uncategorized Hypoplastic Left Heart Syndrome - cyanotic congenital heart defect that is ductal-dependent and classified as a single-ventricle physiology.

item.title: Cardiomyopathy
item.description:
A group of diseases that affect the heart muscle, impairing its ability to pump blood effectively. Can lead to heart failure, arrhythmias, and sudden cardiac death. no cure. Once heart muscle is altered, that is permanent. Classification: Dilated (DCM) - most common enlargement of the ventricles with reduced systolic function and decreased EF Causes: Idiopathic, ischemic heart disease, alcohol abuse, viral infections, toxins, genetic mutations symptoms: chest discomfort, peripheral edema, exponentially increasing levels of fatigue as the condition progresses, and exertional dyspnea. Hypertrophic (HCM) thickened ventricular walls, most commonly affecting the interventricular septum, leading to diastolic dysfunction. causes: Genetic mutations symptoms: fatigue, syncopal episodes, chest discomfort or palpitations, exhaustion, and dyspnea Restrictive (RCM) Stiffened ventricular walls due to fibrosis or infiltration, leading to impaired diastolic filling while systolic function is preserved poor prognosis; least common causes: Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis, radiation therapy, idiopathic. symptoms: similar to HF with DCM/HCM Arrhythmogenic (ACM) Fibrofatty replacement of the right ventricular myocardium, leading to arrhythmias and structural changes Causes: Genetic mutations (autosomal dominant), familial symptoms: ascites, increased JVD, and lethal dysrhythmias, VFib, VTach, including manifestations of other CMs Fluid overload: Diuretics and vasodilators
Heart Failure meds: ACEi, ARBs, BB, CCB, Diuretic DCM or RCM: heart transplant, LVAD (left ventricular assist device): can be permanent or temporary fix until transplant Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD): Prevents sudden cardiac death. Pacemaker: Helps regulate heart rhythm. septal myectomy - remove portions of hypertrophied ventricular septum alcohol septal ablation Lifestyle fluid restriction: 2L/day sodium restriction Lifestyle Echocardiogram BNP/NT-proBNP levels (heart failure markers) Troponin (I and T)- indicates myocardial injury genetic testing (for familial cases) MRI - detailed imaging CXR - cardiomegaly, pulmonary congestion ECG

item.title: Acute Rheumatic Fever
item.description: autoimmune inflammatory reaction to Group A Streptococcus (GAS) pharyngitis occurs 2–4 weeks post-infection can lead to rheumatic heart disease (valvular damage) MAJOR CRITERIA: JONES Joints HEart - carditis, valve damage Nodules Erythema Marginatum - painless rash Sydenham Chorea - flinching movement disorder Minor Criteria - PEACE Previous Rheumatic Fever ECG with PR prolongation Arthralgia CRP and ESR elevated Elevated Temp molecular mimicry: antibodies against GAS cross-react with host tissues targets: heart, joints, skin, CNS* affects all heart layers (pancarditis), esp. mitral valve chronic inflammation → valve fibrosis (mitral > aortic) fever, fatigue, malaise migratory polyarthritis (large joints, resolves without damage) carditis (new murmur, pericardial rub, tachycardia, CHF signs) chorea (Sydenham’s chorea): involuntary jerky movements, emotional lability erythema marginatum: serpiginous, non-pruritic rash subcutaneous nodules over bony surfaces history of sore throat or positive GAS culture clinical diagnosis based on Jones criteria + evidence of recent strep Jones Criteria (Revised):* Major: carditis, polyarthritis, chorea, erythema marginatum, subcutaneous nodules Minor: fever, ↑ ESR/CRP, arthralgia, prolonged PR interval need 2 major or 1 major + 2 minor + strep evidence labs: ↑ ESR, CRP, ASO titer, anti-DNase B throat culture or rapid strep test EKG: PR prolongation echo: valve involvement post-infection autoimmune response to Strep pyogenes (GAS) more common in children 5–15 years recent untreated or inadequately treated strep pharyngitis poor access to medical care overcrowded living conditions history of prior ARF penicillin to eradicate strep (IM benzathine or oral) NSAIDs for arthritis and fever steroids if severe carditis valve repair/replacement for chronic RHD long-term antibiotic prophylaxis (monthly IM penicillin for years) ensure completion of full antibiotic course monitor for cardiac symptoms (murmurs, dyspnea, edema) manage joint pain and chorea symptoms kkk educate family on importance of strep throat treatment support compliance with secondary prophylaxis can lead to chronic rheumatic heart disease (RHD) progressive valve stenosis/regurgitation (esp. mitral) recurrent episodes worsen heart damage rheumatic heart disease, heart failure, arrhythmias* permanent valve damage → need for surgery recurrence with future GAS infections

item.title: Peds-Heart Failure
item.description:
see Heart Failure
usually results from Congenital Heart Diseases edema periorbital edema - usually in younger patients dependent edema - for older patients

item.title: Tricuspid Atresia
item.description: part of Congenital Heart Diseases valve between the right atrium and right ventricle fails to develop deoxygenated blood mixes with oxygenated blood in the left atrium d/t patent foramen ovale (PFO) Blood in RA must cross ASD or PFO to LA From LA → LV → Part goes to aorta (systemic) Part goes through VSD or PDA to pulmonary artery Oxygenated & deoxygenated blood mix in LV → cyanosis Pulmonary flow depends on VSD size or PDA patency System is volume-loaded → risk of CHF if pulmonary flow too high Cyanosis (within hours–days after birth) Tachypnea poor feeding => baby will have weak suck poor weight gain => FTT Murmur (from VSD or shunt flow) Lethargy Clubbing over time CHF symptoms Pulmonary Edema Polycythemia - more RBC production loud murmur => patent PDA Absent tricuspid valve Hypoplastic RV ASD or PFO = RA to LA shunting VSD and/or PDA = LV to pulmonary artery flow Mostly sporadic May be linked to congenital syndromes (e.g. heterotaxy) Maternal diabetes Alcohol/drug use Viral teratogens (rubella, CMV) Genetic or chromosomal disorders Prostaglandin E1 to maintain PDA until surgery NOTE: PDA must be kept open! Surgical palliation (staged): BT shunt → ↑ pulm flow (neonatal) Glenn procedure: SVC → pulm artery (6–9 mo) Fontan procedure: IVC → pulm artery (2–3 yrs) Oxygen only if indicated (can worsen shunting) => usually not helpful Continuous SpO2 and cardiac monitoring Administer PGE1 as ordered Monitor for tet spells or worsening cyanosis Cluster care, support oral feeds (may need gavage) Educate family: surgical plan, infection prevention Monitor for post-op arrhythmias or heart failure Chronic hypoxemia → neuro delays Post-Fontan: protein-losing enteropathy, ascites Arrhythmias Stroke (from polycythemia or shunts) Heart failure

item.title: Pulmonary Stenosis
item.description: Congenital or acquired narrowing at or near the pulmonary valve Obstructs blood flow from right ventricle to pulmonary artery* Most common site is valvular Narrowed valve causes increased RV pressure Leads to right ventricular hypertrophy Severe cases reduce pulmonary blood flow, causing cyanosis In neonates, may be ductal-dependent for oxygenation Long-term pressure overload → RV failure Echocardiogram confirms site and pressure gradient ECG shows RV hypertrophy or right axis deviation CXR may show post-stenotic dilation of PA or RV enlargement Murmur: harsh systolic ejection murmur at left upper sternal border, +/- click Cardiac cath for hemodynamic data or intervention Asymptomatic if mild Murmur detected on routine exam decreased blood flow: diminished pulses Moderate/severe: dyspnea, fatigue, chest pain Cyanosis in critical PS Signs of RV failure: hepatomegaly, peripheral edema Poor feeding in neonates Most commonly congenital Genetic syndromes (e.g., Noonan) Acquired (rare): rheumatic disease, carcinoid syndrome Family history of CHD Genetic syndromes Maternal rubella or teratogen exposure Balloon valvuloplasty (first-line if valvular) Surgical repair for sub/supravalvular or complex cases Prostaglandin E1 if ductal-dependent neonate Monitor for re-stenosis or pulmonary regurgitation post-repair Monitor SpO2, HR, murmur intensity, perfusion Anticipate/prepare for PGE1 in ductal-dependent cases Post-cath monitoring: bleeding, arrhythmias, perfusion Support feeding and minimize energy expenditure Educate family: procedure expectations, follow-up needs RV failure Cyanosis Arrhythmias Recurrent stenosis Pulmonary valve insufficiency

item.title: Coarctation of the Aorta
item.description: Congenital narrowing of the aortic lumen, usually near the ductus arteriosus Causes obstructed blood flow to lower body Classified as pre-ductal (infantile) or post-ductal (adult-type) Narrowed aorta → ↑ afterload on LV → LV hypertrophy Blood flow to upper body = ↑ pressure Blood flow to lower body = ↓ pressure In infants: ductus arteriosus closure removes alternate route → acute ↓ perfusion In adults: collaterals may form (intercostal arteries), masking symptoms Can cause CHF, acidosis, and shock in infants if severe Echocardiogram = confirms anatomy 4-limb blood pressures: upper extremity HTN + lower extremity hypotension Pulse check: bounding upper pulses, weak/absent femoral pulses CXR: rib notching (adults), cardiomegaly (infants) ECG: LVH MRI/CT angio for surgical planning high BP proximal, low BP distal high BP in arms low BP in lower extremities Infants (severe cases): Poor feeding, lethargy Pale, cool lower extremities Shock-like state when ductus closes Older children/adults: HTN (arms), HA, epistaxis Leg cramps, cold feet Systolic murmur (left infraclavicular/back) Congenital, often isolated May occur with other heart defects: Bicuspid aortic valve, VSD Associated with Turner syndrome Genetic syndromes (Turner, Williams) Family history of CHD Infants: Prostaglandin E1 to keep ductus open Surgical repair (resection with anastomosis or patch) -> within 1st year of life Older children/adults: Balloon angioplasty +/- stent Lifelong cardiology follow-up Treat residual HTN Monitor BP in all four limbs Check femoral pulses regularly Administer PGE1 if indicated Pre/post-op care: monitor for HTN, bleeding, neuro checks Educate on long-term BP monitoring Screen siblings if familial HTN, even after repair Aortic aneurysm, dissection Re-coarctation (especially in neonates) Stroke, endocarditis LV failure if untreated

item.title: Resp - Ricci
item.description: infants - obligate nose breathers, sinuses not developed newborns - very small passages, more prone to obstruction throat - increased risk for airway obstruction trachea - smaller lumen smaller # of alveoli => higher risk of hypoxemia higher metabolic rate - higher resp rate, higher o2 demand Pharyngitis - sore throat bacterial: streptococcus => treat with abx, change toothbrush Viral Bronchiolitis - RSV clear runny nose, pharyngitis, low-grade fever, cough, wheeze, signs of respiratory distress at risk: prevention: synergys vaccine, hand washing treatment: prevention: Epistaxis pinch nose

item.title: Epiglottitis
item.description: swelling of airway do not visualize the airway do not leave child unattended do not place in a supine position provide 100% O2 in least invasiv matter ensure tracheostomy tray and emegency equipment ready

item.title: Cystic Fibrosis
item.description: Autosomal recessive disorder caused by CFTR gene mutation Affects chloride transport across epithelial cells Leads to thick, sticky mucus in lungs, pancreas, GI tract, and reproductive organs decreased pancreatic enzymes Defective CFTR protein disrupts chloride and sodium transport Results in dehydrated, viscous secretions Mucus obstructs airways and ducts, promoting infection and inflammation Progressive damage to lungs and other organs Persistent cough with thick sputum Recurrent respiratory infections Wheezing, dyspnea, clubbing Failure to thrive, poor weight gain despite appetite Steatorrhea, greasy/foul-smelling stools Meconium ileus in newborns Nasal polyps, sinusitis Male infertility Newborn screening via immunoreactive trypsinogen (IRT) Sweat chloride test >60 mEq/L is diagnostic Genetic testing for CFTR mutations Chest x-ray or CT shows hyperinflation, bronchiectasis Pulmonary function test shows obstructive pattern Airway clearance techniques (CPT, vest therapy) Mucolytics like dornase alfa Inhaled bronchodilators and hypertonic saline Inhaled and systemic antibiotics (e.g., tobramycin) Pancreatic enzyme replacement => every meal and every snack High-calorie, high-protein diet with fat-soluble vitamins (ADEK) burning calories fast CFTR modulators (ivacaftor, lumacaftor, tezacaftor, elexacaftor) Lung transplant in end-stage disease Encourage and assist with airway clearance Monitor respiratory and nutritional status Administer prescribed enzymes and medications Educate on infection prevention and treatment adherence Provide psychosocial support to patient and family Promote vaccinations, especially influenza and pneumococcal SEPARATE ROOMS FOR EACH CF patient => each CF patient has unique colonized bacteria Mutation in CFTR gene on chromosome 7 Autosomal recessive inheritance Family history of cystic fibrosis Northern European ancestry Respiratory: mucus plugging, infection, bronchiectasis GI: pancreatic insufficiency, malabsorption, bowel obstruction Reproductive: infertility (especially in males) Endocrine: CF-related diabetes Hepatobiliary: biliary cirrhosis, portal hypertension Chronic respiratory failure Pneumothorax Hemoptysis CF-related diabetes Liver disease Osteoporosis Infertility

item.title: Infectious Mononucleosis
item.description: cauused by Epstein-Barr Virus aka kissing disease => transmitted by close contact, cups, etc tonsils have patches of grey exudate, tender cervical lymph nodes can last up to 6 weeks Epstein-Barr splenomegaly => no contact sports! fatigue jaundice - liver involvement supportive care bed rest if fatigue or fever Mono spot EBV titers

item.title: Endocarditis
item.description: Inflammation of the endocardium, typically affecting the heart valves, caused by infection (infective endocarditis) or, rarely, non-infectious processes. endo = inner, itis = inflammation. endocarditis = inflammation of the inner heart Infectious: Bacteria (Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus viridans, Enterococcus), fungi (Candida, Aspergillus), less commonly viruses. most common type mold or bacterial vegetation on the valves more common on L side (aortic and mitral/bi valve) Non-Infectious: Autoimmune conditions (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus – Libman-Sacks endocarditis), malignancies. Prosthetic heart valves Congenital heart defects Rheumatic heart disease History of endocarditis IV drug use Poor dental hygiene or invasive dental procedures => strep throat (how creator of muppets died) Indwelling catheters or central lines Immunosuppression (e.g., HIV, chemotherapy). CLOT mnemonic Clots in heart and body Lung fluids - crackles & spleen enlarged d/t heart failure & infection Ovearheated - fever Too little oxygen = signs of heart failure General Symptoms: Fever, fatigue, night sweats, malaise, weight loss. Cardiac Symptoms: New or changing heart murmur, signs of heart failure (demand>output) Peripheral Signs: Petechiae (small red spots on skin or mucosa) Splinter hemorrhages (linear streaks under nails) Janeway lesions (painless, flat red spots on palms/soles) Osler nodes (painful nodules on fingers/toes) Roth spots (retinal hemorrhages with pale centers). Complications: Embolic events (e.g., stroke, pulmonary embolism), abscess formation, septicemia. IV antibiotics for 4-6 weeks (based on blood culture results). Antifungals if fungal endocarditis is confirmed. Surgical Intervention: Valve repair or replacement if extensive damage, persistent infection, or complications (e.g., heart failure, abscess). Monitor for signs of embolic events (neurological changes, limb ischemia). Assess for heart failure (dyspnea, edema, fatigue). Administer antibiotics on schedule and monitor for side effects. Educate on completing full antibiotic course. Encourage proper dental hygiene to prevent recurrence. Monitor for fever and new murmurs, indicating treatment failure. Blood Cultures: Positive in most cases, with at least two sets needed before antibiotics. Echocardiography: Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) or transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) to detect vegetations, valve damage, or abscess. Labs: Elevated inflammatory markers (CRP, ESR), leukocytosis, anemia. ECG: May show conduction abnormalities or arrhythmias. Other Tests: Imaging to detect embolic complications (e.g., CT for stroke, pulmonary embolism). #nursing #medsurg #cardiovascular #endocarditis

item.title: Peds-Hypertension
item.description: Acceptable BP values are based on gender, age, and height Children aged 1–13 years: Normal BP: <90th percentile for gender, age, and height Elevated BP: 90th–95th percentile or ≥130/80 (whichever is lower) Stage 1 Hypertension: ≥95th percentile or less than 95th percentile + 12 mm Hg (whichever is lower) Stage 2 Hypertension: ≥95th percentile + 12 mm Hg or ≥140/90 (whichever is lower) Adolescents aged ≥13 years: Normal BP: <120/80 Elevated BP: 120–129 systolic with diastolic <80 Stage 1 Hypertension: 130/80 to 139/89 Stage 2 Hypertension: ≥140/90

item.title: Peds-Cardiomyopathy
item.description: see Cardiomyopathy

item.title: Kawasaki
item.description: acute vasculitis of small and medium vessels, especially coronary arteries most common in children <5 years, especially of Asian descent leading cause of acquired heart disease in children in developed countries unknown trigger (possibly viral or environmental) → immune activation widespread inflammation of blood vessels, especially coronary arteries phases: acute, subacute, convalescent can lead to coronary artery aneurysms or thrombosis if untreated Diagnosis: fever ≥5 days plus ≥4 of the following CREAM features C → Conjunctivitis (bilateral, non-purulent) R → Rash (polymorphous, non-vesicular) E → Extremity changes (erythema, swelling, peeling of hands/feet) A → Adenopathy (cervical lymph node >1.5 cm, usually unilateral) M → Mucosal changes (strawberry tongue, cracked lips, red oral mucosa) other signs: irritability, desquamation, cardiac involvement (tachycardia, gallop, murmur) clinical diagnosis (no single confirmatory test) echocardiogram: baseline and follow-ups to monitor coronary arteries labs: ↑ ESR, CRP, WBC, platelets (late), LFTs; normocytic anemia sterile pyuria, hyponatremia, hypoalbuminemia possible unknown etiology suspected immune reaction in genetically susceptible host age <5 years Asian ethnicity (esp. Japanese) male sex possible seasonal pattern (winter-spring) IVIG (within 10 days of fever onset) to reduce coronary risk high-dose aspirin (anti-inflammatory dose) → low-dose for antiplatelet corticosteroids if IVIG-resistant or high-risk features monitor coronary artery dimensions on echo vaccines (esp. live) delayed ~11 months post-IVIG monitor cardiac status: HR, BP, perfusion administer IVIG safely (monitor for allergic reaction) monitor aspirin therapy: bleeding, Reye’s syndrome precautions educate parents on follow-up echoes, infection precautions post-IVIG promote hydration, comfort during febrile phase vasculitis can affect coronary arteries → aneurysms, thrombosis myocarditis, pericarditis, valvulitis long-term risk of coronary artery disease coronary artery aneurysm (25% untreated cases) MI, arrhythmia, sudden death IVIG resistance, recurrence (rare)

item.title: Infective Endocarditis
item.description: see Endocarditis

item.title: Dyslipidemia
item.description: abnormal lipid levels in blood: ↑ LDL, ↑ triglycerides, ↓ HDL, or ↑ total cholesterol can be primary (genetic) or secondary (lifestyle/underlying disease) increases long-term risk for atherosclerosis, coronary artery disease imbalance between lipoprotein production and clearance LDL deposits in vessel walls → plaque formation → vascular inflammation HDL clears cholesterol; low levels reduce protective effect triglycerides may also contribute to endothelial damage usually asymptomatic in children severe hyperlipidemia: xanthomas, xanthelasmas, lipemia retinalis may be detected during routine screening or family history workup fasting lipid panel is gold standard (≥12-hour fast) evaluate: total cholesterol, LDL, HDL, triglycerides non-fasting panel acceptable for initial screening labs to rule out secondary causes: TSH, liver function, glucose, renal labs Primary (genetic): familial hypercholesterolemia (FH), familial combined hyperlipidemia Secondary: obesity, sedentary lifestyle, diabetes, hypothyroidism, nephrotic syndrome, liver disease, medications (e.g. steroids, isotretinoin) family history of premature cardiovascular disease BMI >95th percentile, metabolic syndrome sedentary lifestyle, poor diet diabetes mellitus, hypertension Blood cholesterol level of 240 mg/dL or higher lifestyle modification first-line: diet (low saturated fat), exercise, weight loss statins for children ≥10 yrs with high LDL despite lifestyle changes or with high risk omega-3s, fibrates, ezetimibe may be considered in select cases manage secondary causes if present educate family on heart-healthy diet (e.g., DASH, Mediterranean) promote physical activity: 1 hr/day moderate to vigorous coordinate fasting blood draw, reinforce med compliance if on statin monitor for side effects: myalgias, elevated liver enzymes screen siblings or parents if familial if untreated: early atherosclerosis, MI, stroke, PAD psychological impact (esp. in children/teens on chronic therapy) coronary artery disease, stroke, fatty liver, pancreatitis (in hypertriglyceridemia) potential statin side effects: myopathy, hepatotoxicity

item.title: Patent Ductus Arteriosus
item.description: persistent opening between aorta and pulmonary artery after birth normal in fetal circulation; should close within hours to days postnatally failure to close leads to left-to-right shunt aortic pressure > pulmonary artery pressure → oxygenated blood flows into lungs ↑ pulmonary blood flow → pulmonary congestion, ↑ workload on LV large PDA can lead to CHF, pulmonary hypertension chronic flow can reverse (Eisenmenger) → cyanosis in lower extremities may be asymptomatic if small large PDA: tachypnea, poor feeding, failure to thrive, frequent infections classic murmur: continuous "machinery-like" murmur at left upper sternal border widened pulse pressure, bounding pulses, active precordium echocardiogram confirms diagnosis and shunt direction chest x-ray: cardiomegaly, pulmonary vascular markings ECG: LV hypertrophy or biventricular hypertrophy if large PDA oxygen challenge test may help differentiate from other CHDs failure of ductus to close, especially in premature infants associated with congenital rubella syndrome prematurity (most common), high altitude birth, female sex* maternal infections (e.g., rubella), congenital anomalies indomethacin or ibuprofen to promote closure in preemies surgical ligation or catheter-based coil embolization if meds fail or in full-term infants monitor small PDAs, may close spontaneously monitor respiratory effort, signs of CHF administer and monitor effects of NSAID therapy ensure adequate nutrition (high-calorie feeds, NG if needed) post-op care if closed surgically: monitor vitals, perfusion, infection signs chronic volume overload of LA and LV → CHF risk of endocarditis if Eisenmenger develops: differential cyanosis (cyanotic toes, pink fingers) pulmonary hypertension, CHF, failure to thrive* infective endocarditis, Eisenmenger syndrome if untreated possible renal hypoperfusion in severe cases

item.title: Atrial Septal Defect
item.description: Congenital heart defect with opening in atrial septum causes left-to-right shunt due to higher LA pressure common types: ostium secundum (most common), primum, sinus venosus oxygenated blood from LA → RA → ↑ pulmonary blood flow over time: RA and RV dilation, pulmonary overcirculation usually acyanotic, but cyanosis can occur if shunt reverses (Eisenmenger) may be asymptomatic early in life if symptomatic: fatigue, dyspnea with exertion, frequent URIs wide fixed split of S2 is classic finding may also hear a systolic ejection murmur at pulmonary valve area echocardiogram with Doppler is gold standard ECG may show Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB), RV hypertrophy chest x-ray: cardiomegaly, increased pulmonary vasculature bubble study can help detect small or occult ASDs mostly sporadic associated with genetic syndromes (e.g., Trisomy 21, Holt-Oram) maternal alcohol use, diabetes, lupus family history of CHD small ASDs may close spontaneously catheter-based device closure preferred if possible surgical closure for large or non-device-suitable ASDs closure before school age prevents long-term complications monitor for s/s of CHF, respiratory issues support nutrition and growth pre-op and post-op care if closure is done educate on activity tolerance and follow-up imaging prolonged shunting may lead to RV failure, arrhythmias, stroke from paradoxical embolism risk of pulmonary hypertension if untreated Eisenmenger syndrome (rare but serious if untreated) stroke/TIA from paradoxical emboli (esp. with patent foramen ovale) atrial arrhythmias (e.g. atrial flutter or fibrillation)

item.title: Ventricular Septal Defect
