item.description: Opening in interventricular septum causes abnormal blood flow Most common acyanotic CHD Left ventricle has higher pressure than right Blood shunts from LV → RV (left-to-right shunt) Oxygenated blood recirculates to lungs → volume overload in pulmonary circulation ↑ Pulmonary blood flow → pulmonary edema, ↑ work of breathing ↑ Venous return to left heart → LV dilation, hypertrophy → CHF Prolonged overload can cause ↑ PVR → reversal of shunt (Eisenmenger) → cyanosis Asymptomatic if small defect Loud holosystolic murmur at lower left sternal border Tachypnea, dyspnea, feeding difficulty Diaphoresis with feeds, FTT Frequent lower respiratory infections Signs of CHF if moderate to large Observation for small VSDs (may close spontaneously) Meds for CHF: diuretics, ACE inhibitors, digoxin High-calorie formula or NG feeds Surgical closure with patch if symptomatic or large defect Monitor for CHF symptoms, feeding difficulties Daily weights, strict I&Os Cluster care to reduce energy expenditure Administer cardiac meds as prescribed Support parental bonding, educate on disease and postop care Echocardiogram = diagnostic test of choice Chest X-ray: cardiomegaly, ↑ pulmonary vascular markings ECG: possible LVH or RVH Cardiac cath if complex or unclear anatomy Usually idiopathic congenital defect May be associated with genetic syndromes (e.g., Down, DiGeorge) Linked to maternal rubella, alcohol, diabetes, meds Family history of CHD Chromosomal anomalies Maternal illness or teratogen exposure Pulmonary overcirculation → pulmonary HTN Left-sided volume overload → LV dysfunction, CHF Risk of endocarditis Can progress to Eisenmenger if untreated CHF Pulmonary hypertension Failure to thrive Infective endocarditis Eisenmenger syndrome → cyanosis, irreversible pulmonary damage

item.title: Aortic Stenosis
item.description: Congenital or acquired narrowing of the aortic valve* Obstructs blood flow from LV to aorta Leads to increased LV pressure, hypertrophy, and decreased cardiac output Stenotic valve → LV must pump harder → LV hypertrophy LV hypertrophy → ↓ compliance, ↑ myocardial O2 demand Eventually → LV failure if untreated Severe stenosis = fixed cardiac output, risk of syncope and sudden death In neonates: ductal closure may trigger cardiogenic shock Echocardiogram = gold standard CXR: possible cardiomegaly ECG: LV hypertrophy Cardiac cath: pressure gradients across valve Auscultation: harsh systolic murmur, right upper sternal border, radiates to neck Neonates (critical stenosis): cyanosis, shock, poor feeding, tachypnea Children: fatigue, exercise intolerance, chest pain Older patients: syncope, angina, dyspnea on exertion Murmur: crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur => Holosystolic, harsh murmur along the left sternal border Congenital bicuspid aortic valve = most common Post-rheumatic fever (rare in U.S.) Degenerative calcification (adults) Congenital heart defects Turner syndrome Rheumatic heart disease Aging (degenerative) Neonates: prostaglandin E1 to keep ductus open Balloon valvuloplasty (temporary fix in children) Surgical valve repair or replacement for severe cases Ross procedure (aortic valve replaced with pulmonary valve) in pediatrics Lifelong cardiology follow-up Monitor heart sounds, pulses, BP Administer PGE1 if indicated Support feeding and reduce oxygen demand Educate on activity restrictions if symptomatic Monitor for signs of LV failure post-op Prepare for cardiac surgery or cath procedures Heart failure Arrhythmias Sudden cardiac death (esp. during exertion) Endocarditis Aortic regurgitation after valve interventions

item.title: Prostaglandin
item.description: Synthetic prostaglandin used to maintain patency of the ductus arteriosus Critical in ductal-dependent congenital heart defects Also called Alprostadil Congenital heart defects needing ductal flow (e.g., transposition, tricuspid atresia, HLHS, coarctation, pulmonary atresia) Prevents closure of ductus arteriosus until surgical intervention Temporary measure in critical cardiac lesions Relaxes smooth muscle of ductus arteriosus Causes vasodilation → keeps ductus open Maintains systemic or pulmonary circulation, depending on defect IV infusion (central or peripheral) Initial dose: 0.05–0.1 mcg/kg/min* Maintenance: 0.01–0.05 mcg/kg/min* Titrate to effect and tolerance Apnea (esp. in neonates) Hypotension Bradycardia Fever Flushing Seizures (rare) GI effects: diarrhea Monitor HR, BP, RR, SpO2 continuously Prepare for intubation due to apnea risk Titrate dose as per MD orders Assess perfusion to lower extremities (esp. in ductal-dependent systemic flow) Watch for signs of overdose: apnea, severe hypotension Educate parents: drug is life-sustaining until surgery Avoid in respiratory-depressed infants without airway access Use caution in neonates with bleeding disorders* Must be kept refrigerated Use dedicated IV line Short half-life: effects stop quickly if infusion interrupted* Often started in transport to surgical center*

item.title: Tetralogy of Fallot
item.description: Congenital Heart Diseases, four main abnormalities: Pulmonary stenosis - Right ventricular hypertrophy Overriding aorta Ventricular septal defect => (PROV) - PROV It! Cyanotic heart disease (right-to-left shunting) Unknown in most cases Genetic and environmental factors implicated Pulmonary Stenosis: Narrowing of the pulmonary valve or artery, obstructing blood flow from the right ventricle to the lungs. Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD): Hole between the right and left ventricles, allowing blood to shunt. Overriding Aorta: Aorta is displaced to the right, sitting directly over the VSD, receiving blood from both ventricles. Right Ventricular Hypertrophy: Right ventricle muscle thickens from increased workload due to pulmonary stenosis and pumping against systemic pressure via the VSD. Shunting: Degree of pulmonary stenosis dictates direction of shunt and severity of symptoms. Mild Stenosis: May be left-to-right shunt (acyanotic) initially. Severe Stenosis: Increased right ventricular pressure forces deoxygenated blood through the VSD into the left ventricle and overriding aorta (right-to-left shunt) = cyanosis. Tet Spells: Acute increase in right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (spasm), leading to a sudden, dramatic increase in right-to-left shunting and severe cyanosis. Maternal rubella or other viral illnesses during pregnancy Poor maternal nutrition Maternal alcohol consumption Maternal age over 40 Diabetes in the mother Genetic disorders (e.g., Down syndrome) Cyanosis (bluish discoloration of skin, lips, nail beds), especially with crying or feeding "Tet spells" (hypercyanotic spells): sudden, marked increase in cyanosis, dyspnea, limpness - Think "Tet-a-tat-tat" = rapid onset Clubbing of fingers and toes (chronic hypoxemia) Difficulty feeding, poor weight gain Fatigue, irritability Heart murmur (loud, harsh systolic ejection murmur) Polycythemia (increased red blood cells due to chronic hypoxemia) Thromboembolism (stroke risk from polycythemia) Brain abscess (risk from paradoxical emboli) Endocarditis Arrhythmias Ventricular dysfunction Echocardiogram: Confirms diagnosis, visualizes all four defects Chest X-ray: "Boot-shaped" heart due to right ventricular hypertrophy ECG: Right ventricular hypertrophy, right axis deviation Cardiac catheterization (less common for diagnosis, more for intervention planning) Pulse oximetry: Low oxygen saturation Medical Management (temporary/palliative): Tet spells: Place infant in knee-chest position (increases SVR, decreases right-to-left shunt) - Knee-chest = Kicking Cyanosis Administer oxygen Morphine sulfate (calms infant, decreases infundibular spasm) IV fluids Beta-blockers (e.g., propranolol) to prevent spasms Prostaglandin E1: To maintain patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in severe cases (to increase pulmonary blood flow) Surgical Repair (definitive): Usually performed between 4-6 months of age Includes widening of the pulmonary outflow tract, patching the VSD, and addressing overriding aorta. Monitoring: Closely monitor vital signs, oxygen saturation, and signs of cyanosis. Assess for growth and development. Monitor for signs of heart failure (rare pre-op, can occur post-op). Tet Spell Management (NCLEX Tip): Prioritize knee-chest position first, then oxygen, then medications. Document spell characteristics and interventions. quiet environment pacifier small & frequent feedings swaddle or hold infant Fluid Balance: Maintain adequate hydration to prevent polycythemia and reduce stroke risk. Infection Prevention: Prophylactic antibiotics for dental procedures/surgeries (to prevent endocarditis). Post-operative care: Strict I&O, pain management, wound care, cardiac monitoring, gradual increase in activity. Emotional Support: Provide support to parents/caregivers, addressing anxieties and fears. Disease understanding: Explain TOF in simple terms, including the four defects and potential symptoms. Tet spell recognition and management: Teach parents how to identify a tet spell and the appropriate actions (knee-chest position, remaining calm, seeking medical attention). Medication administration: Proper dosage, timing, and side effects. Infection prevention: Importance of good oral hygiene and prophylactic antibiotics. Nutritional needs: Encourage frequent, small feeds; high-calorie formula if needed. Activity restrictions: Guide parents on appropriate activity levels for the child, balancing rest and play. Follow-up care: Emphasize the importance of regular cardiology appointments. Surgical preparation and post-op care: Prepare parents for the surgical process and what to expect during recovery.

item.title: Spina Bifida
item.description: Before birth: open fetal surgery, fetoscopic fetal surgery After birth: post natal repair, shunt to prevent hydrocephalus

item.title: i. Infancy
item.description: average weight 3.4 kg (7.5 lbs) - lose 5-50% of bw double weight by 4-5 months triple weight at 1 year old average length: 50cm or 20 in head circ: 35cm or 13.5 in - increased 10 cm from birth to 1 yr Anterior fontanelle - open until 12-18 months Posterior Fontanelle - closes 2-3 months Primitive Reflexes disappear over months Except: Moro - disappears at 12 months Persistent primitive reflexes - abnormalProtective Reflexes that Persists: Neck Righting Parachute (sideways and forward, backward) narrower overall larynx is funnel shaped larger tongue less alveoli high risk of respiratory compromise lack of IGA leads to frequent infections Develop from head to toe - cephalocaudalDevelop proximal to distal (center to peripheral) BM until 6 months 8 mos - add texture to food 6-8 mos - use cup fruit juice - unecessary, do not use until 6 months need 10-19 hours per day Colic - inconsolable crying that lasts 3 hours or longer

item.title: iv. School-Age
item.description: period of slow progressive physical growth social developmental - increased growth rate - 6-7cm or 2.5 in per year 3-3.5 kg per year Prepubescence - usually 2 years before beginning of puberty; development of secondary sexual characteristics Bladder capacity - age + 2oz (example: 7 years old => 9 oz) many activities: biking, skating, swimming limited fead d/t strong impulse of exploration Strabismus - malalignment of the eyes amblyopia - reduced vision on an eye that has not been adequately used during early development.

item.title: Health Assessment
item.description: Newborn & Infants if quiet - auscultate first best to examine 1-2 hours before feeding Toddlers Demographics Chief Complaint HPI Past Health Histor Family Health History ROS Developmental History - determine age of when milestones achieved Functional Assessment - anything about daily routine Safety measures - car seats, seat belt, smoke detectors, etc Routine Health and Dental care Nutrition - 24 hour diet recall, food diary Physical activity TV, screen time sleep elimination patterns hearing/vision religion assistive devices sexual practices

item.title: Atraumatic Care
item.description: Atraumatic care - minimize/eliminates psychological or physical stress; do not harm Child Life Specialist (CLS) - trained in developmental impact of illlness, injury, trauma provides programs that prepare children for hospitalization, etc Minimize Physical Stress During Procedures therapeutic hugging - holding position that promotes contact examples: sitting on parents lap cuddled over parents shoulder

item.title: Social Emotional
item.description: real smile at 2 months mimic facial movements peak a boo Stranger Anxiety - develops at 8 months Separation Anxiety typica aggressive behaviors - do not blame for impulsive behavior allow limited choices Separation Anxiety - reemerge 18-24 Parallel play - next to each other but not with each other possess social skills - sharing, kindness, affection display, conversation, helping others, making friends extreme emotions - happy and extreme dissapointment vivid imagination egocentric developing sense of identity - gender, culture, family

item.title: v. Adolescent
item.description: see ch. 29Menarche - begins 9-15 thelarce - breast budding; 9-11Bone Ossification - incomplete until late adolescence; more advanced in girls

item.title: Dentition
item.description: Birth–6 months => no teeth, natal/neonatal teeth possible 6–10 months => lower central incisors erupt 8–12 months => upper central incisors erupt 9–13 months => upper lateral incisors erupt 10–16 months => lower lateral incisors erupt 13–19 months => first molars erupt (upper then lower) 16–22 months => canines erupt 23–33 months => second molars erupt By 2.5–3 years => all 20 primary teeth present 6–7 years => first permanent molars ("6-year molars") erupt, lower central incisors erupt 7–8 years => upper central incisors erupt 8–9 years => lateral incisors erupt 9–11 years => first premolars erupt 10–12 years => second premolars erupt 11–13 years => second molars ("12-year molars") erupt 17–25 years => third molars (wisdom teeth) may erupt

item.title: ii. Toddler
item.description: Linear fashion: 3-5 lbs/year Length: 7.62 or 3 in per year half of adult height by 2 Anterior Fontanelle - closed by 18 mos GU - UOP 1ml/kg/hr MSK - still have swayback with potbelly toddler gait - not walk smoothly, legs wide apart, sway from side to side by 3 yrs - heal to toe similar to adult holding utensils fitting a uzzle piece or stringing a bead Limit milk to 24 oz per day

item.title: iii. Preschooler
item.description: bowel and bladder control by age 3 innocent murmur may be heard Standing on tiptoes or on one foot still requires extra concentration. can move each finger independently scribble freely

item.title: Communication
item.description: crying - primary means coos, vocalizations 4-5 months: simple vowel sounds, responds to won name, "N" 4-7- distinguish emotions 6 months - sealing and yelling 7-10 - babbling 9-12- say dada mama, 3 words, imitate animal sounds receptive language more advanced than expressive language Echolalia - repetition of words and phrases without meaning; 30 months Telegraphic Speech - contains only essential words to get point across potentially bilingual child may blend two languages

item.title: Myths and Facts about Violence
item.guid: OB/vi. Misc Topics/Myths and Facts about Violence.md

item.title: Cycle of Violence Against Women
item.description: Phase 1: Tension Building – Victim walks on eggshells, internalizes blame to prevent violence. Phase 2: Physically Abusive Phase – Violence erupts; victim minimizes harm and avoids care. Phase 3: Honeymoon – Abuser apologizes; victim clings to hope and feels responsible. Phases of Rape Victims Acute phase (disorganization) – Overwhelmed by shock, fear, and intense emotional distress. Outward adjustment phase (denial) – Appears stable but suppresses trauma and avoids help. Reorganization – Struggles resurface, survivor seeks change and emotional distance. Integration and recovery – Regains trust, feels empowered, may support others.
item.guid: OB/vi. Misc Topics/Cycle of Violence Against Women.md

item.title: Fetal Circulation
item.description: Key Purpose: Designed to bypass the non-functional fetal lungs and liver, prioritizing oxygenated blood to the brain and heart. Oxygenation Source: Placenta (maternal blood). Major Shunts: Ductus Venosus: Bypasses the liver, shunting oxygenated blood from the umbilical vein directly to the inferior vena cava. Foramen Ovale: An opening between the right and left atria, shunting oxygenated blood from the right atrium to the left atrium, bypassing the lungs. Ductus Arteriosus: Connects the pulmonary artery to the aorta, shunting blood from the pulmonary artery away from the lungs into the systemic circulation. Vessels: Umbilical Vein (1): Carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus. Umbilical Arteries (2): Carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus back to the placenta. Blood Flow Path: Oxygenated blood from placenta Umbilical vein Ductus venosus Inferior vena cava Right atrium Foramen ovale Left atrium Left ventricle Aorta (to head/upper body) / Some from right atrium Right ventricle Pulmonary artery Ductus arteriosus Aorta (to lower body) / Small amount to lungs Hypogastric (internal iliac) arteries Umbilical arteries Placenta. Underlying Issues: Conditions that compromise uteroplacental function or fetal cardiovascular development. Examples of Risk Factors/Conditions: Placental Insufficiency: Reduced blood flow or damage to the placenta (e.g., preeclampsia, chronic abruption, maternal hypertension/diabetes) leading to inadequate oxygen/nutrient exchange. Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR): Often a consequence of compromised placental function, leading to adaptive fetal circulatory changes (e.g., brain-sparing effect where blood is preferentially shunted to the brain). Congenital Heart Defects (CHDs): Structural abnormalities of the heart or great vessels that alter normal fetal shunting patterns and blood flow, potentially leading to cardiac strain or inadequate oxygenation (e.g., hypoplastic left heart syndrome, transposition of the great arteries). Fetal Anemia: Reduces oxygen-carrying capacity, forcing the fetal heart to work harder. Fetal Infection: Some infections (e.g., TORCH) can directly damage the fetal heart or vasculature, impacting circulation. Persistent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) / Patent Foramen Ovale (PFO) after birth: Failure of these fetal shunts to close post-natally leads to abnormal shunting, increased pulmonary blood flow (PDA), or deoxygenated blood entering systemic circulation (PFO with right-to-left shunt). Pulmonary Hypertension (PPHN): Failure of pulmonary vascular resistance to decrease at birth, leading to persistent shunting away from the lungs (via PFO and PDA), resulting in hypoxemia. Manifestations of Compromise: Abnormal Doppler flow studies (e.g., absent/reversed end-diastolic flow in umbilical artery). Fetal bradycardia or tachycardia (indicating distress). Hydrops fetalis (fluid accumulation in fetal compartments). Altered fetal growth. Abnormal shunting patterns observed on fetal echocardiogram. Clinical Significance: These high-risk variations require close monitoring and often intervention to optimize fetal well-being or prepare for postnatal management.

item.title: Patient Education
item.description: Live Vaccines (Rubella) - do not cross breast milk, can continue breastfeeding cannot get pregnant for at least 1 month do not administer during pregnancy Every 4 weeks up to 28 weeks (7 months) Every 2 weeks from 29 to 36 weeks Every week from 37 weeks to birthNote: Frequency may increase with high-risk pregnancies or complications.

item.title: Newborn Behavior
item.description: Characteristics: Alert, active, hungry appearance; myoclonic eye movements, Moro reflexes, sucking/rooting, fine tremors. Physiology: Elevated heart/respiratory rates, increased muscle tone. Significance: Ideal for initial parent-newborn interaction and initiating breastfeeding. Characteristics: Sleep phase, decreased activity, relaxed muscles, diminished responsiveness. Physiology: Declining heart/respiratory rates. Significance: Quiet time for rest for both mother and newborn; difficult to arouse or feed. Characteristics: Awakens, interested in stimuli, increased motor activity and coordination. Physiology: Increased heart/respiratory rates, increased peristalsis (may pass meconium/void). Significance: Good for continued parent-newborn interaction, examination, and questions.

item.title: GTPAL
item.description: GP System Gravida - pregnancy numbers Para - Number of pregnancies delivered after 20 weeks (regardless if delivered alive or not)GTPAL System - more details G: Gravida – Total number of pregnancies, including the current pregnancy if applicable. T: Term births – Number of full-term births (deliveries at 37 weeks or later). P: Preterm births – Number of preterm births (deliveries between 20 and 36 weeks). A: Abortions – Number of pregnancies that ended in miscarriage or abortions L: Living children – Number of living children the woman has. Example of GTPAL Notation: G3T1P1A1L2 G3: The woman has been pregnant 3 times (includes current pregnancy if applicable). T1: She has had 1 full-term delivery (after 37 weeks). P1: She has had 1 preterm delivery (between 20 and 36 weeks). A1: She has had 1 miscarriage or elective abortion before 20 weeks. L2: She has 2 living children

item.title: Alfa-Fetoprotein (AFP) Analysis
item.description: What is it – Blood test screening for fetal neural tube defects and chromosomal anomalies Clinical Presentation – Routine prenatal screening, especially at 16–18 weeks Treatment – Not a treatment; may prompt further testing (e.g., amniocentesis, ultrasound) Nursing Interventions – Confirm LMP, weight, race, gestational age; educate on venipuncture procedure Diagnostic Tools – Maternal serum AFP ± triple/quad/penta screen Causes of ↑AFP – Neural tube defect, underestimated gestational age, multiples, GI defect Causes of ↓AFP – Overestimated age, fetal death, Down syndrome, trisomy 18, molar pregnancy Risk Factors – Incorrect dating, maternal weight extremes, diabetes, multiple gestation Systemic Effects – None directly; indicates risk for fetal abnormality Complications – False positives → anxiety, unnecessary follow-up tests, financial/emotional stress

item.title: Nonstress Test
item.description: Pre-test – Explain procedure, empty bladder, semi-Fowler position, apply belts Documentation – Note start time, client info, reason, vitals, baseline strip (15–30 min) During test – Watch for fetal movement with HR accelerations Interpretation – Reactive = 2 accelerations (15 bpm × 15 sec in 20 min) Nonreactive – No 15×15 accelerations after 40 min → possible distress/IUGR Follow-up – May need BPP or further testing Post-test – Help off table, give fluids, restroom, review results and warning signs, Nonstress Test (NST) – Interpretation Reactive (normal) – ≥2 accelerations in 20 minutes, each ↑15 bpm for ≥15 sec (≥32 wks) Reactive (before 32 wks) – ≥2 accelerations ↑10 bpm for ≥10 sec in 20 minutes Nonreactive – Lacks sufficient accelerations; may indicate fetal sleep, immaturity, or distress Follow-up for nonreactive – Extend test to 40 min, use vibroacoustic stimulation, consider BPP or CST Significance – Reactive = reassuring; Nonreactive = requires further assessment

item.title: Pregnancy Discomforts
item.description: see p.405N/V Eat 6 small meals/day avoid empty stomach at all times! Avoid highly seasoned or greasy foods Drink at least 8 (8oz) glasses of water/day Ask for medication Urinary Frequency - d/t compression of bladder Fatigue Breast Tenderness Exessive salivation & increased discharge - d/t increased estrogen => bathe daily, no douching Heartburn: ↑ progesterone, ↑ pressure => Use antacids, small meals, sit upright for 30 min after eatingBackache Varicosities of the vulva and legs Hemorrhoids Flatulence with bloatingReturn of first trimester discomforts Shortness of breath and dyspnea Heartburn and indigestion Dependent edema Braxton Hicks contractions2nd & 3rd Trim Discomforts Ankle Edema - ↑ sodium & cap permeability, circulatory congestion, prolonged standing/sitting, Frequent dorsiflexion Get up and move for at least 5 min Q hr, Supportive hose (used for varicosities too) Hemorrhoids - constipation, pressure, sitz bath, witch hazel pads, ointments Constipation/Flatulence: ↑ progesterone, ↓ fluids, ↓ exercise => tx: ↑ fluids, ↑ fresh fruit/veggies (non-gassy), stool softeners Backache: ↑ lumbar curve, ↑ hormones Proper body mechanics and pelvis-tilt exercise Leg cramps: ↑ nerve pressure, electrolyte imbalances, ↓ circulation Dorsiflexion, dietary changes, heating pad Syncope: Anemia, postural hypotension Keep body temp normal, stand up slowly, check H&H Dyspnea: ↓ vital capacity, anemia Sleep propped on pillows

item.title: Fundal Height in Pregnancy
item.description: Fundal Height = weeks of pregnancy in terms of cm McDonald Method - lying down, top of pubic bone to top of fundus => knees flexed => if growth curve flattens or stable - indicates FGR (fetal growth restriction)

item.title: Placental Hormones
item.description: Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG): Maintains the corpus luteum to ensure continued progesterone production in early pregnancy. Progesterone: Maintains the uterine lining, relaxes uterine muscles, and prevents preterm contractions. Estrogen (primarily Estriol): Stimulates uterine growth, promotes uteroplacental blood flow, and prepares the breasts for lactation. Human Placental Lactogen (hPL) / Human Chorionic Somatomammotropin (hCS): Modifies maternal metabolism to provide nutrients for the fetus and prepares mammary glands for lactation. Relaxin: Relaxes pelvic ligaments and softens the cervix, aiding in childbirth. Placental Growth Hormone: Regulates maternal metabolism and fetal growth, becoming predominant later in pregnancy. Corticotropin-Releasing Hormone (CRH): Influences the timing of labor and fetal lung maturation.

item.title: Persistent Pulmonary Hypertension of the Newborn (PPHN)
item.description:
Pulmonary Hypertension (PH) in newborns, most commonly refers to Persistent Pulmonary Hypertension of the Newborn (PPHN). PPHN is a condition where the normal drop in pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) at birth fails to occur, or it increases after initially falling. This results in high blood pressure in the arteries supplying the lungs, leading to reduced blood flow to the lungs for oxygenation. Deoxygenated blood then bypasses the lungs via fetal shunts (foramen ovale, ductus arteriosus), leading to severe hypoxemia. It is a failure of the normal circulatory transition from fetal to extrauterine life. Failure of Normal Circulatory Transition: Pulmonary vessels remain constricted or become constricted after birth. Underlying Lung Diseases: Meconium Aspiration Syndrome (MAS) - most common cause.
Respiratory Distress Syndrome in Newborn (RDS) - especially if severe. Pneumonia or Sepsis. Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH) - leads to underdeveloped lungs (pulmonary hypoplasia). Pulmonary Hypoplasia (e.g., due to oligohydramnios). Maldevelopment of Pulmonary Vasculature: Abnormal structure or number of pulmonary vessels. Idiopathic PPHN: No clear underlying cause. In Utero Closure of Ductus Arteriosus. Perinatal Asphyxia: Lack of oxygen before, during, or after birth. Meconium Aspiration Syndrome (MAS). Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS). Sepsis/Pneumonia. Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH). Maternal factors: Diabetes, preeclampsia, chorioamnionitis, maternal obesity, smoking, use of SSRIs or NSAIDs during late pregnancy. Delivery: Cesarean section (without labor), precipitous delivery. Fetal factors: Large for gestational age (LGA), small for gestational age (SGA), post-term gestation. Congenital Heart Defects: Such as transposition of the great arteries. Signs usually appear within the first 12-72 hours of life. Severe Hypoxemia: Low oxygen levels despite receiving 100% oxygen. Labile Oxygenation: Oxygen saturation fluctuates wildly. Respiratory Distress: Tachypnea (rapid breathing), retractions (subcostal, intercostal), nasal flaring, grunting. Cyanosis: Bluish discoloration of skin and mucous membranes, may be differential (pink upper body, cyanotic lower body) if ductus arteriosus is open with right-to-left shunt. Tachycardia. Hypotension. Heart Murmur: Due to shunting through patent ductus arteriosus or patent foramen ovale. Cool extremities. Poor perfusion. NCLEX Tip: Persistent hypoxemia despite maximal oxygen support is a hallmark of PPHN. Hypoxic-Ischemic Encephalopathy (HIE): Brain damage due to lack of oxygen. Multi-organ dysfunction: Kidney injury, liver dysfunction. Pulmonary Hemorrhage. Barotrauma/Volutrauma: Due to mechanical ventilation (e.g., pneumothorax). Hearing loss. Neurodevelopmental Impairment: Learning disabilities, developmental delays, cerebral palsy. Chronic Lung Disease (Bronchopulmonary Dysplasia). Death. Clinical Suspicion: Based on symptoms of respiratory distress and persistent hypoxemia. Hyperoxia Test: Administering 100% oxygen. If PaO2 remains low, suggests shunting (PPHN or cyanotic heart disease). Pre- and Post-Ductal Pulse Oximetry: Significant difference () suggests right-to-left shunting across the ductus arteriosus. Echocardiogram (Cardiac Ultrasound): Definitive diagnosis. Visualizes heart structure, assesses pulmonary artery pressure, identifies shunting (ductus arteriosus, foramen ovale), and assesses right ventricular function. Chest X-ray: May show underlying lung disease (e.g., MAS, pneumonia) but often appears normal in primary PPHN. Arterial Blood Gas (ABG): Shows hypoxemia, often with respiratory or metabolic acidosis. Goal: Reduce PVR, improve oxygenation, support systemic blood pressure. Supportive Care: Optimal Thermoregulation: Maintain neutral thermal environment. Minimize Stimulation/Handling: Cluster care, sedation to reduce agitation and oxygen consumption. Fluid and Electrolyte Balance: Strict monitoring. Nutrition: IV fluids or gavage feedings. Oxygen Therapy: Maintain adequate oxygenation. Mechanical Ventilation: Often required, carefully managed to avoid lung injury, optimize lung volume, and minimize PVR. Pharmacological Agents: Inhaled Nitric Oxide (iNO): First-line specific pulmonary vasodilator. Selectively relaxes pulmonary blood vessels without affecting systemic blood pressure. Sildenafil (Viagra/Revatio): Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor, used orally or IV to relax pulmonary vessels. Milrinone: Phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitor, improves cardiac contractility and causes pulmonary vasodilation. Prostaglandins (e.g., Iloprost): Pulmonary vasodilators. Vasopressors/Inotropes: (e.g., Dopamine, Dobutamine) to maintain systemic blood pressure and cardiac output, ensuring adequate perfusion and preventing shunting. Surfactant Therapy: If underlying RDS or MAS with surfactant deficiency. Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO): Cardiopulmonary bypass used for severe, refractory PPHN when maximal conventional therapy fails. Continuous Monitoring: Intensive care setting. Continuous monitoring of HR, BP, RR, SpO2 (pre- and post-ductal). Arterial line for continuous BP and ABG sampling. Respiratory Management: Meticulous ventilator management. Avoid sudden changes in settings. Frequent assessment for air leaks (pneumothorax). Fluid and Electrolyte Balance: Strict I&O, monitor electrolytes, acid-base status. Medication Administration: Administer iNO (requires special equipment/monitoring), vasodilators, inotropes, and sedatives precisely. Monitor for desired effects and adverse reactions (e.g., hypotension with vasodilators). Minimize Stimulation: Create a quiet, dark environment. Cluster care, handle gently, avoid unnecessary procedures. Sedation often used. Thermoregulation: Maintain normothermia to minimize oxygen consumption. Neuroprotection: Monitor for signs of HIE. Parental Support: This is a critical illness. Provide consistent updates, answer questions honestly, facilitate bonding, and offer emotional support and resources. NCLEX Tip: Prioritize oxygenation and ventilation, followed by maintaining systemic blood pressure and reducing pulmonary vascular resistance. Recognize signs of deterioration quickly. Explanation of PPHN: Explain the condition simply – that the blood vessels in the lungs are too tight, making it hard for the baby to get enough oxygen. Causes and Risk Factors: Discuss why their baby might have developed PPHN (e.g., MAS, premature birth, C-section). Treatment Plan: Detail the various treatments (oxygen, ventilation, iNO, other medications), explaining their purpose and what to expect (e.g., baby will be on a breathing machine, may need special IVs). Critical Care: Explain the need for intensive monitoring and the equipment in the NICU. Prognosis and Complications: Be honest about the severity of the condition, potential for long-term complications (brain injury, hearing loss, developmental delays), but also offer hope and emphasize the importance of early intervention and follow-up. Parental Role: Explain how parents can help (e.g., minimizing stimulation, talking gently, touch). Long-term Follow-up: Stress the importance of developmental follow-up clinics, early intervention services, and hearing screenings for neurodevelopmental monitoring. NCLEX Tip: Reassure parents that PPHN is not their fault and provide them with clear, consistent information to reduce anxiety.
item.guid: OB/v. Newborn/Complications/Persistent Pulmonary Hypertension of the Newborn (PPHN).md

item.title: APGAR
item.description: xz if it's below 7 at 5 min, do it again in 5 min

item.title: Periventricular-Intraventricular Hemorrhage (PIVH)
item.description: Hemorrhage (bleeding) that occurs in the brain of premature newborns. Specifically, it involves bleeding into the periventricular (area around the ventricles) and intraventricular (within the ventricles, spaces containing cerebrospinal fluid) regions. The bleeding originates from the germinal matrix, a highly vascularized and fragile area of the brain found in premature infants, which largely involutes (disappears) by 33-34 weeks gestation. Graded I to IV based on severity (Papile grading): Grade I: Hemorrhage confined to the germinal matrix (subependymal). Grade II: Intraventricular hemorrhage without ventricular dilation. Grade III: Intraventricular hemorrhage with ventricular dilation (blood fills and expands the ventricles). Grade IV: Hemorrhage extends into the brain parenchyma (tissue) adjacent to the ventricle (often termed periventricular hemorrhagic infarction). Fragile Germinal Matrix Vessels: Premature infants have delicate, immature blood vessels in the germinal matrix that are prone to rupture. Fluctuations in Cerebral Blood Flow (CBF): Premature infants have impaired cerebral autoregulation (ability to maintain stable CBF despite changes in systemic blood pressure). Sudden increases or decreases in systemic blood pressure can lead to rupture of fragile vessels. Hypoxia-Ischemia: Lack of oxygen or blood flow to the brain can damage vessels. Reperfusion Injury: After an ischemic event, restoration of blood flow can cause vessel damage and bleeding. Prematurity: Gestational age weeks (especially extremely low birth weight infants, ). Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS): Requires mechanical ventilation, which can cause fluctuations in blood pressure and CBF. Mechanical Ventilation: Especially if unstable (e.g., rapid changes in ventilatory settings). Perinatal Asphyxia/Hypoxia. Rapid changes in blood pressure: Hypotension followed by rapid fluid resuscitation or use of vasopressors. Acidosis. Pneumothorax. Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA). Sepsis/Infection. Coagulopathy/Bleeding disorders. Rapid volume expansion. Umbilical cord clamping delays. Traumatic delivery. Maternal factors: Chorioamnionitis, maternal hypertension (some studies). NCLEX Tip: The more premature the infant, the higher the risk of PIVH. Often asymptomatic, especially Grade I/II, detected by screening ultrasound. Acute Deterioration (more common in Grade III/IV, "saltatory" course): Apnea and bradycardia (sudden onset). Pallor. Cyanosis. Poor muscle tone (hypotonia). Weak cry, lethargy. Bulging or tense fontanelle (indicates increased intracranial pressure). Seizures (focal or generalized). Decreased reflexes. Metabolic acidosis. Drop in hematocrit. NCLEX Tip: Be alert for sudden, unexplained changes in a preterm infant's neurological status, breathing pattern, or vital signs. Hydrocephalus (Post-hemorrhagic hydrocephalus): Most common complication, especially with Grade III/IV, due to obstruction of CSF flow by blood clots. Requires ventricular taps or shunt placement. Periventricular Leukomalacia (PVL): Damage to the white matter, often due to ischemia or infarction near the hemorrhage, leading to motor deficits. Cerebral Palsy (CP): Especially spastic diplegia (affecting legs more), related to white matter injury. Neurodevelopmental Impairment: Cognitive deficits, learning disabilities, behavioral problems. Seizure disorder. Vision and hearing impairment. Death: More common with severe (Grade III/IV) hemorrhage. Cranial Ultrasound (CUS): Primary diagnostic tool. Non-invasive, bedside, highly effective. Recommended for all infants weeks gestation: At 7-14 days of life (when most bleeds manifest). Repeat at 4-6 weeks corrected age, or if clinical signs suggest deterioration. Earlier screening within the first 72 hours for high-risk infants. MRI: May be used for more detailed evaluation, especially in later follow-up or if CUS is inconclusive. No specific treatment to stop the bleeding once it occurs. Supportive Care (primary focus is prevention and minimizing secondary injury): Stabilize blood pressure: Avoid wide fluctuations (both hypotension and hypertension). Respiratory support: Optimize ventilation, minimize hypercapnia or hypocapnia. Maintain normal acid-base balance. Minimize handling/stress: Cluster care, gentle movements. Head in midline position: Avoid neck hyperextension/flexion. Strict fluid and electrolyte management. Correct coagulopathies. Management of Hydrocephalus (if develops): Serial lumbar punctures/ventricular taps: To remove CSF and reduce pressure. Ventricular reservoir placement: Temporary measure to drain CSF. Ventricular-peritoneal (VP) shunt: Surgical insertion of a permanent drain from brain to abdomen for CSF drainage. Neuroprotection (Prevention): Antenatal Corticosteroids: Administered to mothers at risk of preterm birth (reduces incidence and severity of PIVH). Delayed cord clamping: May help stabilize CBF. Avoidance of rapid intravenous fluid boluses. Indomethacin (for PDA): May reduce PIVH risk, but controversial. Prevention: Adhere strictly to prevention protocols for preterm infants (e.g., gentle handling, neutral head position, minimal stimulation, careful fluid management). Neurological Assessment: Frequent and thorough neurological assessments, looking for subtle changes in tone, activity, reflexes, fontanelle, and cry. Vital Sign Stability: Meticulous monitoring of HR, BP, RR, SpO2. Report significant fluctuations promptly. Respiratory Support: Ensure optimal ventilatory settings, minimize suctioning trauma. Fluid Management: Accurately measure intake and output. Administer fluids and medications precisely. Head Circumference: Measure daily and plot on a growth chart to detect rapid increases indicative of hydrocephalus. Clustering Care: Organize care activities to minimize disturbances and allow for longer periods of uninterrupted rest. Pain Management: Assess for and manage pain/discomfort appropriately. Parental Support: Provide clear, compassionate communication about the infant's condition, prognosis, and potential long-term outcomes. Encourage bonding and involvement in care. NCLEX Tip: Any sudden change in neurological status, feeding, or vital signs in a preterm infant should raise immediate suspicion for PIVH or its complications. Explanation of PIVH: Explain what the bleed is, why it happened (fragile vessels, prematurity), and its potential implications using clear, simple language. Grading System: Explain the Papile grading (I-IV) and what each grade signifies in terms of severity and potential outcome. Prognosis: Be honest but hopeful. For Grade I/II, explain good prognosis. For Grade III/IV, discuss potential for hydrocephalus, cerebral palsy, and developmental delays, emphasizing that outcomes vary. Monitoring: Explain the need for frequent ultrasounds and other tests. Signs of Complications: Educate parents on signs of increasing head circumference, bulging fontanelle, vomiting, irritability, lethargy, or seizures, and when to seek immediate medical attention. Long-term Follow-up: Stress the importance of developmental follow-up programs (e.g., NICU follow-up clinic, early intervention services) to monitor and support neurodevelopment. Home Care: If discharged with a shunt, provide detailed instructions on shunt care and signs of malfunction or infection. Support Resources: Provide information on support groups or resources for parents of preterm infants or children with special needs.

item.title: Pathologic Jaundice in Newborns
item.description: Jaundice (yellow discoloration of skin and sclera) in a newborn that is not benign physiological jaundice. Characterized by early onset (within the first 24 hours of life), rapid rise in bilirubin levels, very high total serum bilirubin (TSB) levels, or prolonged duration. Indicates an underlying pathological condition. NOTE DIFFERENCE between: Physiological Jaundice of the Newborn => occurs after 24 HOURS Hemolysis: Blood group incompatibility (most common): ABO incompatibility (mother O, baby A or B), Rh incompatibility (mother Rh-, baby Rh+). G6PD deficiency: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (enzyme deficiency in red blood cells leading to hemolysis). Other red blood cell abnormalities: Hereditary spherocytosis, alpha-thalassemia. Extravasated blood: Cephalohematoma, significant bruising, intracranial hemorrhage (breakdown of blood increases bilirubin load). Infection: Sepsis, TORCH infections (Toxoplasmosis, Other [syphilis, varicella, parvovirus], Rubella, Cytomegalovirus, Herpes simplex virus). Liver disease/Biliary Obstruction: Biliary atresia, choledochal cyst, neonatal hepatitis, metabolic disorders (e.g., galactosemia, alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency). Increased enterohepatic circulation: Pyloric stenosis, bowel obstruction. Hypothyroidism. Crigler-Najjar syndrome, Gilbert syndrome (rare genetic conditions affecting bilirubin metabolism). Jaundice appearing within the first 24 hours of life. TSB levels increasing rapidly (e.g., per day). TSB levels higher than expected for age in hours on a nomogram. Prolonged jaundice (persisting weeks in term infants, weeks in preterm infants). Signs of underlying illness (lethargy, poor feeding, dark urine, pale stools). Positive family history of hemolytic disease. Exclusive breastfeeding with poor intake/weight loss. Prematurity (immature liver, less efficient bilirubin excretion). East Asian ethnicity. Sibling who had significant jaundice requiring treatment. Yellowing of skin and sclera: Appears within 24 hours of birth, may be intense or spread rapidly (cephalocaudal progression). Other symptoms indicating underlying pathology or complications: Dark urine (cola-colored) or pale/acholic (clay-colored) stools (suggestive of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia or biliary obstruction). Lethargy, poor feeding, irritability, high-pitched cry. Fever. Vomiting. Hypo/hypertonia, arching of the back (opisthotonus) - signs of acute bilirubin encephalopathy. Seizures. Acute Bilirubin Encephalopathy (ABE): Bilirubin crosses the blood-brain barrier and is toxic to brain cells. Early signs: lethargy, poor feeding, high-pitched cry, hypotonia. Kernicterus (Chronic Bilirubin Encephalopathy): Irreversible brain damage resulting from prolonged exposure to high bilirubin levels. Can lead to: Athetoid cerebral palsy (involuntary, uncontrolled movements). Permanent upward gaze. Hearing loss. Enamel dysplasia of teeth. Intellectual disability. Anemia (from hemolysis). Liver damage (if underlying liver disease). Total Serum Bilirubin (TSB) and Conjugated/Direct Bilirubin levels: TSB percentile for age in hours on a nomogram. Jaundice within 24 hours of life is always pathologic. Direct bilirubin or of TSB is always pathologic and requires immediate workup for cholestasis/liver disease. Blood type and Coombs test (direct and indirect): To check for ABO/Rh incompatibility. CBC with differential and reticulocyte count: To assess for anemia and hemolysis. G6PD screen. Liver function tests (LFTs). Thyroid function tests (TFTs). Urine for reducing substances, cultures (blood, urine, CSF) if infection suspected. Abdominal ultrasound: If biliary atresia or other structural liver/biliary abnormalities suspected. Phototherapy: Uses blue-green light to convert unconjugated bilirubin into water-soluble isomers that can be excreted. Intensity and duration depend on TSB level, age, and risk factors. May involve single, double, or triple phototherapy. Exchange Transfusion: Used for extremely high TSB levels, rapid rise despite phototherapy, or signs of acute bilirubin encephalopathy. Involves removing small amounts of infant's blood and replacing with donor blood to quickly lower bilirubin and remove antibodies. Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG): May be used in immune-mediated hemolytic jaundice (e.g., ABO/Rh incompatibility) to reduce antibody-mediated hemolysis and decrease need for exchange transfusion. Treat underlying cause: Antibiotics for sepsis. Surgery for biliary atresia. Specific treatments for metabolic disorders. Hydration: Ensure adequate fluid intake (oral or IV) to promote bilirubin excretion. Monitoring: Frequent TSB levels: As ordered, plot on nomogram. Vital signs: Especially temperature (phototherapy can cause hyperthermia) and respiratory rate. Hydration status: Assess for signs of dehydration (urine output, fontanelles, skin turgor, weight loss). Feeding patterns: Ensure adequate intake to promote bowel movements. Neurological status: Monitor for signs of acute bilirubin encephalopathy (lethargy, poor feeding, high-pitched cry, abnormal tone, seizures). Phototherapy Care: Maximize skin exposure: Undress infant (diaper only), ensure maximum surface area exposure to light. Eye protection: Apply opaque eye patches to prevent retinal damage. Reposition frequently: To expose all skin surfaces to light. Maintain thermoregulation: Use radiant warmer/isolette, monitor temperature closely. Increase fluid intake: Offer frequent feedings or IV fluids to prevent dehydration from increased insensible water loss and promote bilirubin excretion. Skin integrity: Monitor for rashes, bronzing baby syndrome (rare side effect with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia). Parent-infant bonding: Encourage parents to remove baby for brief feeding and cuddling breaks if TSB levels allow; otherwise, encourage touch and presence at bedside. Education: Provide clear explanations to parents about the condition, treatment, and potential complications. NCLEX Tip: Jaundice within the first 24 hours is always pathologic and requires immediate investigation. Causes and Importance: Explain that this type of jaundice is serious and caused by specific underlying problems, needing prompt treatment to prevent brain damage (kernicterus). Phototherapy: Explain why it's needed and how it works. Emphasize importance of eye patches and maximizing skin exposure. Discuss the need for frequent feedings/hydration. Reassure about the safety of phototherapy. Signs to Watch For: Worsening yellow color (especially palms/soles). Changes in behavior: lethargy, difficulty waking, poor feeding, high-pitched cry, irritability. Fever. Dark urine or pale stools. Any unusual movements or arching. NCLEX Tip: Always provide written instructions on when to call the provider after discharge (e.g., specific bilirubin level thresholds, worsening jaundice, behavioral changes). Follow-up: Stress the critical importance of all follow-up appointments for TSB checks and developmental assessments. Feeding: Encourage frequent and effective feeding (breastfeeding or formula) to promote bilirubin excretion through stools. May need temporary formula supplementation or IV fluids if intake is poor or levels are very high. No sunlight for treatment: Emphasize that household lights or direct sunlight are not effective or safe treatments for pathologic jaundice.

item.title: Physiological Jaundice of the Newborn
item.description: Benign, common, and transient yellow discoloration of the skin and sclera in newborns due to elevated unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin levels. Occurs in most newborns as part of normal physiological adaptation after birth. Typically appears after 24 hours of life, peaks at 3-5 days, and resolves within 1-2 weeks. NOTE: difference in Pathologic Jaundice in Newborns => appears WITHIN 24 hours Increased Bilirubin Production: High red blood cell (RBC) volume in newborns. Shorter lifespan of fetal RBCs (approx. 70-90 days vs. 120 days in adults). Increased breakdown of RBCs (hemolysis) releasing bilirubin. Impaired Bilirubin Conjugation: Immature neonatal liver has lower levels and activity of UDP-glucuronyl transferase (UGT), the enzyme responsible for conjugating bilirubin. Increased Enterohepatic Circulation: Higher levels of beta-glucuronidase in the neonatal gut, which deconjugates bilirubin in the intestines. Slower gut motility and less frequent stools in newborns mean more unconjugated bilirubin is reabsorbed into circulation. Breastfeeding (Breastfeeding Jaundice/Breast Milk Jaundice): Breastfeeding Jaundice (Early-onset): Due to insufficient milk intake, leading to dehydration and increased enterohepatic circulation. Occurs in the first week. Breast Milk Jaundice (Late-onset): Due to substances in breast milk (e.g., glucuronidase) that interfere with bilirubin conjugation or increase enterohepatic circulation. Can last for several weeks or months. Prematurity (even late preterm, 34-36 weeks). East Asian ethnicity. Family history of physiologic jaundice. Maternal diabetes. Male gender. Polycythemia. History of cephalohematoma or significant bruising. Yellowing of skin and sclera: Typically visible when total serum bilirubin (TSB) levels reach . Appears after 24 hours of life. Progression is usually cephalocaudal (starts on face, progresses to trunk and extremities). Jaundice typically resolves spontaneously within 1-2 weeks in term infants. Infant usually appears otherwise healthy, feeding well, and active. NCLEX Tip: Differentiating between physiologic and pathologic jaundice is crucial. Remember: physiologic jaundice never appears in the first 24 hours of life. Generally no complications as it's a benign process. Untreated severe hyperbilirubinemia (even if initially physiologic) can become pathologic and lead to: Acute bilirubin encephalopathy. Kernicterus (chronic bilirubin encephalopathy) - permanent neurological damage. This happens when bilirubin levels are excessively high and toxic to the brain. Clinical assessment: Visual inspection (blanch skin to check for yellowing), typically done every 8-12 hours in the first few days. Transcutaneous Bilirubin (TcB) measurement: Non-invasive device used for screening. If TcB is high, a TSB (Total Serum Bilirubin) blood test is performed. Total Serum Bilirubin (TSB) measurement: Blood test is the gold standard. Levels are plotted on a nomogram based on the infant's age in hours to assess risk for hyperbilirubinemia. Assessment of feeding and hydration. Rule out pathologic causes: If jaundice is severe, early onset, or persists, further investigation is needed (e.g., direct Coombs test, blood type, CBC, direct bilirubin). No specific treatment often required: Many infants with physiologic jaundice do not need intervention beyond monitoring. Frequent and effective feedings: Breastfed infants: Nurse times in 24 hours to promote bilirubin excretion through stools and ensure adequate hydration. Avoid water or dextrose water supplementation. Formula-fed infants: Ensure adequate intake. Phototherapy: If TSB levels cross specific thresholds on the nomogram for the infant's age and risk factors. Blue-green light converts unconjugated bilirubin into water-soluble isomers for excretion. Discontinuation of breastfeeding (temporarily): Rarely indicated for breast milk jaundice if bilirubin levels are dangerously high and other measures fail. Mother can pump to maintain supply. Assessment: Visual assessment for jaundice: Check skin color (blanching on forehead/nose), sclera. Note progression. Feeding assessment: Observe latch, suck, swallow, and number of wet diapers/stools. Promote effective feeding. Hydration status: Assess fontanelles, skin turgor, mucous membranes. Vital signs: Especially temperature (phototherapy can cause hyperthermia). Monitoring: Bilirubin levels: Track TcB/TSB results and plot on nomogram. Weight: Monitor for excessive weight loss. Output: Document number of wet diapers and stools. Patient Education: Explain physiologic jaundice as a normal process. Teach parents how to assess for jaundice and when to seek medical attention. Emphasize the importance of frequent feedings and adequate hydration. Phototherapy Care (if needed): Maximize skin exposure (diaper only). Apply eye patches. Monitor temperature closely. Ensure adequate fluid intake. Promote parent-infant bonding during breaks. NCLEX Tip: Focus on education and supportive measures. Early and effective feeding is key in preventing severe physiologic jaundice. Normal vs. concerning jaundice: Explain that mild yellowing after 24 hours is common and usually resolves, but explain signs that warrant concern. Monitoring at home: Teach parents how to check for jaundice (blanching skin) and how far it has progressed. Feeding is key: Emphasize the importance of frequent (8-12 times/day) and effective feedings to help baby pass bilirubin in stools. Warning signs to call the provider: Jaundice appears within the first 24 hours of life. Jaundice spreads rapidly or appears very deep yellow/orange. Baby is difficult to wake, not feeding well, excessively sleepy, irritable, has a high-pitched cry. Fewer wet diapers or stools than expected. Fever. No home remedies: Advise against using using sunlight or other unproven methods for treating jaundice, as they are ineffective and potentially harmful. Follow-up: Stress the importance of all scheduled bilirubin checks and well-baby visits.
item.guid: OB/v. Newborn/Complications/Physiological Jaundice of the Newborn.md

item.title: Transient Tachypnea of the Newborn
item.description: Self-limiting respiratory condition in newborns characterized by rapid breathing shortly after birth. Caused by delayed clearance of fetal lung fluid. Also known as "wet lung" or "Type II RDS." Delayed Clearance of Fetal Lung Fluid: During vaginal birth, the thoracic squeeze helps expel fluid from the lungs. In TTN, this mechanism is impaired or incomplete. Commonly seen in: C-section births (especially elective, without labor). Rapid vaginal births. Infants of diabetic mothers. Late preterm infants (34-36 weeks gestation). Cesarean section delivery (especially without labor onset). Preterm or late preterm birth (34-36 weeks gestation). Macrosomia (large-for-gestational-age infant). Maternal diabetes. Male gender. Perinatal asphyxia. Maternal asthma. Tachypnea: Respiratory rate often breaths/minute (can be breaths/minute). Retractions: Subcostal, intercostal, or xiphoid retractions. Nasal flaring. Grunting: Audible expiratory grunt. Cyanosis: Mild perioral or circumoral cyanosis, or central cyanosis (if severe). Increased anteroposterior diameter of the chest. Symptoms usually appear within the first few hours of birth and resolve within 24-72 hours. Generally benign and self-limiting. Rarely, severe cases may lead to: Pulmonary hypertension (due to persistent high pulmonary vascular resistance). Pneumothorax (rare). Aspiration (if fed orally while tachypneic). Hypoxia requiring prolonged respiratory support. Clinical presentation: Based on the characteristic signs of respiratory distress appearing shortly after birth and rapid improvement. Chest X-ray: Classic findings: Prominent perihilar streaking, fluid in the fissures, hyperexpansion, flattened diaphragms, possible cardiomegaly. Differs from RDS (Hyaline Membrane Disease) which shows diffuse ground-glass appearance and air bronchograms. Blood gas: May show mild hypoxemia. Rule out other causes: Important to differentiate from more serious conditions like sepsis, pneumonia, or respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). Supportive Care: Oxygen therapy: Humidified oxygen via nasal cannula or oxygen hood to maintain SpO2 . Nasal CPAP: Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) may be used for persistent hypoxemia or significant retractions. Thermoregulation: Maintain neutral thermal environment to minimize oxygen consumption. Nutritional support: IV fluids until respiratory status improves enough for oral feedings to prevent aspiration. Gavage feedings may be used. Monitoring: Continuous pulse oximetry, respiratory rate and effort. Antibiotics: May be initiated empirically if sepsis cannot be immediately ruled out, especially if risk factors for infection are present. Discontinued if cultures are negative. Respiratory Assessment: Frequent and thorough assessment of respiratory rate, effort, presence of retractions, grunting, nasal flaring, and cyanosis. Oxygen Administration: Ensure proper setup and monitoring of oxygen delivery. Thermoregulation: Keep infant warm to prevent cold stress, which increases oxygen demand. Hydration/Nutrition: Administer IV fluids as prescribed. Withhold oral feedings if respiratory rate is high () to prevent aspiration; initiate gavage feedings. Positioning: Head of bed slightly elevated, or "sniffing" position to optimize airway. Parental Support: Explain the condition to parents, reassuring them it is usually temporary and self-limiting. Educate on signs of worsening distress. Differentiation: Be vigilant for signs that might indicate a more serious underlying condition. NCLEX Tip: Remember "Too Tired to Nourish": Infants with TTN are often too tachypneic to safely breastfeed or bottle-feed, necessitating gavage feeding or IV fluids. Nature of TTN: Explain that it's a temporary condition due to "wet lungs" that usually resolves quickly. Symptoms: Describe the symptoms observed (fast breathing, grunting) and why the baby needs monitoring. Treatment: Explain the purpose of oxygen, IV fluids, and temporary feeding tubes (if used). Monitoring: Inform parents about the continuous monitoring of breathing and oxygen levels. Reassurance: Emphasize that most babies recover fully without long-term problems. Expected Course: Explain that symptoms typically improve within 24-72 hours. When to Call: Educate parents on signs of respiratory distress to watch for after discharge.
item.guid: OB/v. Newborn/Complications/Transient Tachypnea of the Newborn.md

item.title: Birth Weight - Gestational Age
item.description: Usual weight range: 2,500 to 4,000 gUsual height: 44 to 55 cm (17 to 22 in)Head disproportionately large compared with rest of body (asymmetric) Wasted appearance of extremities Reduced subcutaneous fat stores Jittery secondary to hypoglycemia Decreased amount of breast tissue Scaphoid abdomen (sunken appearance) Temperature instability Wide skull sutures secondary to inadequate bone growth Poor muscle tone over buttocks and cheeks Loose and dry skin that appears oversized Thin umbilical cordLarge body and appears plump and full faced The increase in body size is proportional. head circumference and body length are in the upper limits of intrauterine growth poor motor skills difficulty in regulating behavioral states more difficult to arouse to a quiet alert stateLow birth weight (LBW): Weight of 2,500 g or less at birthIntrauterine growth restriction (IUGR): Growth rate does not meet expected norms. Early term is defined as occurring from 37 0/7 weeks through 38 6/7 weeks. Full term is defined as occurring from 39 0/7 through 40 6/7 weeks. Late term is defined as occurring from 41 0/7 weeks through 41 6/7 weeks. Preterm or premature: Born prior to 37 0/7 weeks of gestation. Late preterm is defined as occurring from 34 0/7 through 36 6/7 weeks. Postterm:**** Born after the completion of 42 0/7 weeks of gestation.Postmature: Born after the completion of 42 weeks of gestation with evidence of placental insufficiency.

item.title: Post-Partum Hemorrhage
item.description: Blood loss of after vaginal birth or after C-section within 24 hours of birth (Primary/Early PPH). Or, blood loss occurring 24 hours to 6-12 weeks postpartum (Secondary/Late PPH). A leading cause of maternal morbidity and mortality worldwide. 5 T's Tone: uterine atony (most common), distended bladder Tissue: retained placenta and clots; uterine subinvolution Trauma: lacerations, hematoma, inversion, rupture Thrombin: coagulopathy (preexisting or acquired) Traction: too much pulling on umbilical cord Uterine Atony: Overdistension of uterus (multiples, polyhydramnios, macrosomia). Prolonged labor, rapid labor. Grand multiparity ( pregnancies). Oxytocin use during labor. MgSO4 administration. Chorioamnionitis. Trauma: Operative vaginal delivery (forceps, vacuum), precipitous delivery, large infant. Tissue: Placenta previa, accreta, increta, percreta. Thrombin: Pre-existing bleeding disorders, severe preeclampsia, placental abruption, sepsis. Early signs: Excessive vaginal bleeding (saturating pads quickly, steady trickle), boggy uterus (not firm). Late signs (Hypovolemic Shock): Hypotension, tachycardia, pallor, dizziness, oliguria, altered mental status. NCLEX Tip: Don't wait for signs of shock; recognize and act on early signs of excessive bleeding! Hypovolemic shock. Anemia. Acute kidney injury. Sheehan's Syndrome (postpartum pituitary necrosis due to severe blood loss). Peripartum hysterectomy. Maternal death. Clinical assessment: Quantify blood loss (weighing pads/chux, collecting blood in calibrated drapes). Visual estimation often underestimates. Physical exam: Fundal massage, inspection for lacerations, assessment for retained placental fragments. Laboratory tests: CBC (H&H), type and crossmatch, coagulation studies (PT/INR, PTT, fibrinogen). Atony (Fundal Massage & Medications): First-line: Firm uterine fundal massage. Uterotonics: Oxytocin (Pitocin): IV bolus or infusion. NCLEX Tip: Always first-line uterotonic. Methylergonovine (Methergine): IM. Contraindicated in hypertension/preeclampsia. Carboprost tromethamine (Hemabate): IM. Contraindicated in asthma. Misoprostol (Cytotec): Rectal or oral. Trauma: Repair of lacerations, evacuation of hematomas. Tissue: Manual removal of retained placenta, D&C (Dilation & Curettage). Thrombin: Administer blood products (pRBCs, FFP, platelets, cryoprecipitate) as indicated. Surgical intervention: Uterine artery embolization, B-Lynch suture, hysterectomy (last resort). Fluid resuscitation: IV crystalloids, blood transfusion. Assess Fundus: Immediately after birth and frequently. Should be firm, midline, at or below umbilicus. If boggy, massage until firm. Assess Lochia: Quantity, color, presence of clots. Quantify blood loss accurately. Vital Signs: Monitor every 5-15 minutes in acute hemorrhage. Recognize subtle changes. Bladder: Ensure bladder is empty (full bladder can displace uterus and prevent contraction). Straight catheterize if needed. IV Access: Ensure at least two large-bore (18-gauge) IVs for fluid and blood product administration. Medication Administration: Understand mechanism of action, dosages, routes, and contraindications of uterotonics. Emotional Support: Keep patient and family informed. Maintain a calm environment. Team Communication: Alert provider immediately for signs of PPH. Initiate rapid response if indicated. Post-PPH Care: Monitor for anemia, fatigue. Administer iron supplements as prescribed. Warning Signs: Educate patient on signs of excessive bleeding (e.g., soaking more than one pad per hour, large clots, dizziness). Activity: Gradual increase in activity; avoid heavy lifting. Nutrition: Importance of iron-rich foods to replenish stores (e.g., red meat, leafy greens, fortified cereals). Rest: Emphasize importance of rest and sleep. Follow-up: Stress importance of postpartum follow-up appointments. NCLEX Tip: Teach signs of infection and when to seek immediate medical attention (e.g., fever, foul-smelling lochia).

item.title: Perineal Lacerations
item.description: extent of the laceration is defined by depth First Degree - extends through the skin Second Degree - extends through the muscles of the perineal body Third Degree - continues through the anal sphincter muscle => risk for fecal incontinence Fourth Degree - involves the anterior rectal wall => risk for fecal incontinence

item.title: Lochia
item.description: Color: dark red or bright red Consistency: moderately heavy flow may contain small clots Content: primarily blood with decidual tissue fetal membrane fragments and some mucus Smell: fleshy (foul odor = infection) Color: pink brownish or watery red Consistency: thinner flow less clotted Content: blood serum leukocytes cervical mucus and tissue debris Color: yellow white or creamy Consistency: light scant discharge Content: mostly leukocytes mucus epithelial cells and bacteria minimal to no blood Scant: a 1- to 2-in lochia stain on the perineal pad or approximately a 10-mL loss Light or small: an approximately 4-in stain or a 10- to 25-mL loss Moderate: a 4- to 6-in stain with an estimated loss of 25 to 50 mL Large or heavy: a pad is saturated within 1 hour after changing it

item.title: Emotional
item.description: per RicciBonding = close emotional attraction to a newborn by the parents that develops during the first 30 to 60 minutes after birthAttachment = development of strong affection between an infant and a significant other (mother, father, sibling, and caregiver). Contact: The sensory experiences of touching, holding, and gazing at the infant are part of proximity-seeking behavior. Emotional state: The emotional state emerges from the affective experience of the new parents toward their infant and the parental role. Individualization: Parents are aware of the need to differentiate the infant’s needs from themselves and to recognize and respond to them appropriately, making the attachment process also, in a way, one of detachment.

item.title: Phases of Maternal Role Attainment
item.description: 24-48 hrs focus on meeting personal needs rely on others for assistance excited, talkative need to review birth experience with others "he has my nose" day 2-3 lasts 10 days to several weeks focus on baby care, improving caregiving competency learn and practice deal with physical and emotional discomforts "BABY BLUES" want to take charge but need acceptance from others focus on family as a unit resumption of role (intimate partner, individual) reestablishes relationships with other people establishes a lifestyle that includes the infant relinquishes the fantasy infant and accepts the real one.
item.guid: OB/iv. Postpartum/Assessments/Phases of Maternal Role Attainment.md

item.title: Breast Engorgement
item.description: Swelling, firmness, and discomfort in breasts due to increased blood flow and milk production postpartum Commonly occurs 3–5 days after delivery Can affect breastfeeding and cause pain or difficulty latching Sudden increase in milk volume (lactogenesis II) Infrequent or ineffective breastfeeding or pumping Breast milk stasis and venous/lymphatic congestion Primiparity Delayed breastfeeding initiation Infrequent feedings Formula supplementation Poor infant latch or ineffective suck Bilateral breast fullness, hardness, warmth, pain Shiny, tight skin with flattened nipples Low-grade fever possible (< 100.4°F) Baby may struggle to latch due to breast firmness Plugged ducts Mastitis Breast abscess Breastfeeding cessation Clinical diagnosis based on symptoms and timing postpartum Rule out mastitis if fever > 100.4°F, redness, systemic symptoms Breastfeed or pump frequently (q2–3h) Warm compresses before feeding (↑ milk flow) Cold compresses or chilled cabbage leaves after feeding (↓ swelling) Gentle breast massage during feeds NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) for pain/inflammation Assess for signs of mastitis Encourage early and frequent breastfeeding Teach proper latch and positioning Support hand expression if too full to latch Monitor for maternal discomfort, fever Document breast exam findings and interventions Engorgement is temporary and improves with regular milk removal Breastfeed 8–12x/day; don’t skip night feedings Use cold packs post-feed to reduce swelling Wear supportive, non-restrictive bra Avoid tight bras or binding (can worsen engorgement) Contact provider if fever, redness, or flu-like symptoms occur 🧠 NCLEX Tip: Warm before, cold after. Frequent emptying prevents complications. 🧠 Mnemonic: ENGORGED = Express milk, NSAIDs, Gentle massage, Offer feed often, Relieve with cold, Get baby to latch well, Educate, Detect mastitis early.

item.title: Fundal Height Postpartum
item.description: Fundus is at or just below the umbilicus (midline)Fundus remains at or slightly above the umbilicusFundus at level of umbilicus, may rise slightly (1 cm above umbilicus) but should be firm and midlineFundus begins to descend (involution) Each postpartum day thereafter Fundus descends approximately 1 fingerbreadth (1 cm) per day Day 1: 1 cm below umbilicus Day 2: 2 cm below umbilicus Day 3: 3 cm below umbilicus And so onFundus is no longer palpable abdominally Returns to pre-pregnancy size by 6 weeks

item.title: Biophysical Profile
item.description: Prenatal test assessing fetal well-being Combines ultrasound + nonstress test (NST) Evaluates 5 parameters, each scored 0 or 2 Max score = 10, modified BPP (no US) = out of 8 NST (Nonstress Test): 2 = Reactive (≥2 accelerations in 20 mins) 0 = Nonreactive Fetal Breathing Movements: 2 = ≥1 episode ≥30 seconds in 30 mins 0 = Absent or <30 seconds Fetal Movement: 2 = ≥3 discrete body/limb movements 0 = <3 movements Fetal Tone: 2 = ≥1 episode of flexion-extension-return (e.g., hand or limb) 0 = Slow return or no movement Amniotic Fluid Volume (AFV): 2 = ≥1 vertical pocket ≥2 cm 0 = No pocket ≥2 cm 8–10 = Normal (low risk of asphyxia) 6 = Equivocal → repeat in 24 hrs or delivery if term ≤4 = Abnormal → delivery indicated (especially if term or deteriorating) Modified BPP = NST + AFV only (max score = 8) Decreased fetal movement Nonreactive NST Suspected IUGR Post-term pregnancy Hypertensive disorders, DM, or other high-risk conditions

item.title: Miperidine
item.description: Opioid analgesic Acts on CNS opioid receptors to alter pain perception and response Class: Schedule II controlled substance Moderate to severe pain in L&D Analgesia during labor when epidural not used or contraindicated May be used adjunctively in postpartum for severe uterine cramping Rare use in PPH pain management (not first-line) Binds to mu-opioid receptors in CNS Inhibits ascending pain pathways Produces analgesia, sedation, and respiratory depression Onset: 10–15 min IM/SC, 5 min IV Peak: 30–60 min Duration: 2–4 hrs MAOI use within 14 days (risk of serotonin syndrome) Severe respiratory depression Laboring patients if birth expected within 1–4 hrs (risk of neonatal CNS/respiratory depression) Hypersensitivity Maternal: sedation, dizziness, hypotension, N/V, respiratory depression Neonatal: decreased variability, CNS depression, delayed respiration if given near delivery May cause tachycardia (metabolite normeperidine can be neurotoxic with repeated dosing) Assess pain, VS, FHR before/after admin Monitor for sedation, hypotension, respiratory depression Use cautiously if delivery imminent Keep naloxone (Narcan) on hand for newborn or maternal reversal Avoid repeated dosing — risk of normeperidine accumulation and seizures Crosses placenta — can depress neonatal respiration, especially if administered 1–4 hrs before birth IM: 50–100 mg q3–4h PRN IV: 25–50 mg slow push over ≥5 min Onset is rapid IV, but duration is short — not ideal for prolonged labor pain May cause drowsiness — avoid standing or walking unassisted Avoid other CNS depressants (alcohol, sedatives) Report decreased fetal movement or unusual sedation Medication will reduce pain but may not eliminate it fully Inform that it may affect baby temporarily after birth (esp. if given close to delivery)

item.title: NEC
item.description: Necrotizing Enterocolitis (NEC) in Neonates Acute inflammatory disease causing intestinal necrosis Primarily affects preterm and low birth weight neonates Most common GI emergency in neonates Ischemia and hypoxia → mucosal injury Bacterial colonization of sterile gut Enteral feeding (especially formula) triggers inflammation Prematurity (underdeveloped gut and immune system) Formula feeding (vs. breast milk) Hypoxia or perinatal asphyxia Patent ductus arteriosus, sepsis, or hypotension Prolonged antibiotic use Intestinal ischemia (e.g., from Respiratory Distress Syndrome in Newborn or heart defects) Abdominal distention and tenderness Bloody stools or hemoccult-positive stools Feeding intolerance, vomiting (may be bilious) Lethargy, temperature instability, apnea Decreased bowel sounds Bowel perforation → peritonitis, sepsis Short bowel syndrome if resection is needed Strictures, abscesses Death if not promptly treated Abdominal X-ray: pneumatosis intestinalis (air in bowel wall) CBC: leukocytosis or leukopenia, thrombocytopenia Blood cultures (r/o sepsis) Electrolyte imbalances C-reactive protein ↑ NPO (bowel rest), IV fluids, TPN Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics Nasogastric decompression Serial abdominal X-rays and labs Surgery if perforation or necrosis present Monitor abdominal girth every shift Assess for bloody stools, emesis, or signs of sepsis Maintain strict NPO status if suspected Support thermoregulation and oxygenation Prepare for possible surgical intervention Minimize stress and handling Educate parents on signs of NEC and long-term risks Encourage breast milk feeding (protective antibodies) Report feeding intolerance, abdominal swelling, or bloody stools Stress importance of follow-up care if discharged after NEC Explain potential long-term GI complications Provide emotional support due to high morbidity

item.title: BUBBLE HEVN
item.description: BUBBLE - Breast, Uterus, Bowel, Bladder, Lochia, Episiotomy HEAVN: Homan's, Emotional, Affect, Vitals, Nutrition Assess for redness, pain, tenderness Check for engorgement or fullness Examine for striae and skin integrity Inspect nipples for redness, cracks, fissures, bleeding, colostrum, and signs of latching problems Palpate fundus for boggy or firm consistency Assess position of fundus (midline or deviated) Check proper height according to postpartum day Support lower uterine segment during assessment Massage gently if uterus is soft If C/S delivery, inspect abdominal dressing for drainage and/or REEDA (redness, edema, ecchymosis, drainage, approximation) Auscultate bowel sounds in all quadrants Note presence, absence, or hypoactivity of bowel sounds Assess for firmness or softness of abdomen Inquire about passing gas or stool, note frequency, consistency, constipation Confirm bladder assessment was completed prior to postpartum assessment Ask if bladder has been emptied Document urine output amount and color If Foley catheter present, confirm patency, inspect amount and color, note signs of infection Inspect perineal pad for bleeding Note character, quality, presence of clots, and odor Assess perineum for healing Inspect episiotomy or lacerations using REEDA (redness, edema, ecchymosis, drainage, approximation) Assess calves for pain with dorsiflexion, tenderness, redness, striae, swelling, warmth, or induration Observe maternal emotional status Note interaction with infant, bonding behaviors, family and caregiver support Screen for postpartum depression or anxiety Refer to bowel section for bowel sounds and distention Palpate for tenderness, distention, or surgical incision (if C/S) Assess for diastasis recti Review temperature, pulse, respiratory rate, blood pressure, pain level Compare to postpartum norms Assess intake and output Educate on balanced diet postpartum, adequate fluids, extra calories if breastfeeding Recommend iron-rich and protein-rich foods Discuss foods to promote healing and lactation Advise on avoiding certain foods if contraindicated

item.title: Dystocia
item.description:
Abnormal or difficult labor resulting from problems with components of labor: 4 P's powers - expulsive forces passageway passenger or fetal development psyche or maternal stress It is a leading cause of cesarean delivery Umbrella Term for "failure to progress" with labor due to: lac of progressive cervical dilation lack of descent of fetal head or both POWERS Ineffective uterine contractions (hypotonic or hypertonic) Hypertonic Uterine Dysfunction - erratic contractions; irregular, uncoordinated, ineffective => uterus never fully relaxes between contractions treatment: sedate, analgesia, hydrate, reposition Hypotonic Uterine Dysfunction - Contractions become poor in quality and lack sufficient intensity to dilate and efface the cervix; high risk for hemorrhage treatment: augment via Pitocin, amniptomy to enchance labor, hydrate Protracted disorders - very slow dilation and descent Arrest Disorders - no progress or failure of descent Precipitate Labor - completed in 3 hours or less; "cannonball baby" => too fast of delivery => cervical lacerations, uterine rupture PASSENGER Positioning => any position other than occiput anterior (head down and anterior facing) = higher risk Persistent Occiput Posterior - most common Shoulder Distocia - head delivered but shoulder is blocking; EMERGENCY => can lead to brachial plexus palsy - no nerve control, shoulder is drooping => high risk for uterine lacerations, bleeding => "turtling" - head of the baby emerging from the birth canal, then retracting back Multiple Gestation - twins or more (plan for vaginal birth if twins are VERTEX) Macrosomia - 4kg or more baby PASSAGEWAY Pelvis Shape = "Good Anatomy Allows Passage" Gynecoid - good; best shape, round Anthropoid - oval, "ape-like", okay for delivery Android - "andro" => male pevis, difficult! Platypelloid - platypus=flatl POOR FIT! obstructions of maternal birth canal - swelling of cervix FetoPelvic Disproportion (FPD) - Fetal head is too large or pelvis is too smallPSYCHE mom emotions => psychological stress hormones from intense anxiety anxiety => increased fer, tension, pain tolerance First-time pregnancy (nulliparity) Advanced maternal age Obesity Epidural anesthesia Prolonged labor Hydramnios Short maternal status (less than 5 ft tall) More than 8.8 lbs fetus GA >41 wks Abnormal fetal presentation (e.g., occiput posterior, breech) Chorioamnionitis high caffeine intake Ineffective uterine contractions High fetal station at complete cervical dilation note: acrocyanosis is normal Slowed or stalled cervical dilation Lack of fetal descent despite adequate contractions Abnormal contraction patterns Maternal fatigue Fetal distress may develop Prolonged labor Fetal hypoxia or distress Uterine rupture (especially with prior C-section) Maternal infection or hemorrhage Increased likelihood of operative delivery
