Erb's Palsy Monitor Progress of Labor - 1cm per hour dilation is standard Physical exam to assess dilation, effacement, and fetal station Ultrasound for fetal position and estimated weight Intrauterine pressure catheter (IUPC) to measure contraction strength Pelvimetry in suspected CPD Amniotomy to augment labor => breaking water Oxytocin (Pitocin) for hypotonic contractions Upright positioning - promote fetal rotation and descent; change frequently Operative delivery (vacuum, forceps) if indicated Cesarean delivery if labor fails to progress or complications arise suprapubic bone for shoulder dystocia Monitor labor progression closely Assess fetal heart rate and uterine contraction pattern Encourage position changes and ambulation if appropriate Administer pain management and oxytocin as ordered backrubs to promote fetal rotation Explain interventions and rationale (e.g., amniotomy, oxytocin) Discuss signs of labor progress and when to alert staff Provide reassurance and emotional support Prepare patient for possible surgical delivery if needed

item.title: Erb's Palsy
item.description: aka Erb-Duchenne Paralysis (Erb’s Palsy) Paralysis of upper brachial plexus (C5–C6) Caused by traction injury during birth Results in characteristic arm weakness and positioning Most common type of neonatal brachial plexus injury Shoulder Distocia during vaginal delivery Excessive lateral traction on the head/neck during birth Breech delivery with arm extended Trauma or traction to brachial plexus outside birth (less common) Macrosomia Prolonged second stage of labor Instrumental delivery (forceps, vacuum) Maternal diabetes Shoulder dystocia history Affected arm hangs limp and internally rotated Elbow extended, forearm pronated ("waiter's tip" position) Absent Moro reflex on affected side Intact grasp reflex Decreased or absent biceps and brachioradialis reflexes Permanent motor deficits if not resolved Muscle atrophy or joint contractures Limb length discrepancy Functional impairment in severe or untreated cases Clinical diagnosis based on physical findings MRI or nerve conduction studies if persistent beyond 3–6 months Rule out fractures or clavicle injury Passive range of motion exercises Physical and occupational therapy Surgical nerve grafting or transfer if no improvement by 3–6 months Splinting may be used early to prevent contractures Handle affected arm gently; avoid traction or overextension Educate parents on passive ROM and splint care Monitor motor improvement and reflex recovery Encourage bonding and normal developmental activities Collaborate with PT/OT for early intervention Explain typical prognosis (most recover by 3–6 months) Teach safe handling and positioning of infant Emphasize importance of therapy adherence Report signs of worsening function or lack of improvement Provide emotional support and referral to early intervention if needed

item.title: Placental Abruption
item.description:
early separation of the placenta from the uterine wall MEDICAL EMERGENCY! It can be partial or complete Leads to compromised fetal oxygenation and maternal hemorrhage Classification: based on extent of separation (maybe too in-depth for this course)Can also be concealed or apparentSEE Comparison Chart 19.1 in textbook Sudden trauma (e.g., car accident, fall, abuse) Chronic hypertension or preeclampsia => very common Cocaine or tobacco use Premature rupture of membranes Previous abruption Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy => most common (i.e., Preeclampsia, Eclampsia) Abdominal trauma Multiple gestation History of placental abruption AMA - 35yo multifetal pregnancy substance abuse male fetal gender chorioamnionitis prolonged prelabor ROM oligohydramnios pre-eclampsia Sudden onset of painful vaginal bleeding
per ATI = > Abruptio is DARK RED VAGINAL BLEEDING (Placenta Previa is RED) Firm, tender uterus Uterine hypertonicity (frequent contractions or constant tone) Non-reassuring fetal heart rate or fetal demise => ABSENT FETAL HEART TONES Hypovolemic shock in severe cases increased fundal height - may be sign of bleeding because of blood stuck in womb
DIC symptoms: bleeding gums, tachy, petechiae, bleeding from IV site (complication) Fetal hypoxia or death
Maternal Hemorrhage or Shock
DIC Preterm labor and delivery Uterine rupture (rare) Clinical presentation is key Ultrasound may detect retroplacental clot but not always reliable CBC coagulation profile - fibrinogen levels, clotting cascade Kleihauer-Betke test to detect fetal cells in maternal blood = > ATI QUESTION Nonstress test - findings of fetal jeopardy manifested by late decelerations or bradycardia. Biophysical profile: Aids in evaluating clients with chronic abruption; a low score (less than 6 points) suggests possible fetal compromise Monitor maternal and fetal status closely => treatment guided by fetal viability, severity, maternal status IV fluids and blood products as needed Immediate delivery if severe or fetal compromise present Cesarean delivery often required for unstable cases
Treat DIC: blood products, ffp w/ cryoprecipitate, heparin Assess bleeding amount, pain, and fetal heart tones immediately on bed rest Prepare for emergency delivery Avoid vaginal exams if abruption suspected Monitor vital signs and signs of shock Support emotional needs of patient and family resources: neonatal intensive care Report any abdominal trauma or sudden pain/bleeding Importance of prenatal care and managing blood pressure Avoid smoking, drug use, and high-risk behaviors Understand emergency delivery may be needed

item.title: Spina Bifida Occulta
item.description: Mildest form of neural tube defect Incomplete fusion of vertebral arch without protrusion of spinal cord or meninges Often found at lumbosacral area, typically asymptomatic Covered by skin, may have visible skin markers Failure of neural tube closure during 3rd to 4th week of embryonic development Genetic predisposition Folate (vitamin B9) deficiency during pregnancy Environmental exposures like anti-seizure meds (valproate, carbamazepine) Maternal folate deficiency Family history of neural tube defects Maternal diabetes or obesity Use of teratogenic medications in early pregnancy Often asymptomatic at birth Cutaneous signs over lower spine (tuft of hair, dimple, lipoma, hemangioma) Rarely associated with subtle motor or bladder issues No external sac or bulge Tethered cord syndrome (may develop later in life) Bladder or bowel dysfunction Lower limb weakness or sensory deficits in rare cases Orthopedic problems like foot deformities (late-onset) Prenatal ultrasound may miss occulta type Postnatal diagnosis via physical exam and spinal ultrasound or MRI X-ray may show vertebral arch defect MRI confirms occult spinal dysraphism if symptoms present Usually no treatment if asymptomatic Neurosurgical evaluation if neurologic symptoms or tethered cord suspected Ongoing monitoring for late-onset complications Family reassurance and education Assess for skin markers over lumbosacral spine Monitor for changes in bowel, bladder, or lower extremity function Educate parents on signs of tethered cord (e.g., gait changes, incontinence) Support parental concerns and provide genetic counseling if needed Most cases are benign and require no intervention Teach importance of routine monitoring for neuro or urologic symptoms Emphasize prenatal folic acid supplementation (400–800 mcg/day) Reassure that condition is often stable and non-progressive

item.title: Terbutraline
item.description: beta-2 adrenergic agonist used off-label as a tocolytic short-term uterine relaxant not a first-line agent due to maternal side effects short-term tocolysis to delay preterm labor (usually <48–72 hrs) emergency management of uterine tachysystole with fetal distress bronchodilator (original FDA indication) stimulates beta-2 receptors in uterine smooth muscle causes uterine relaxation decreases frequency and intensity of contractions also relaxes bronchial smooth muscle maternal heart disease poorly controlled hyperthyroidism or diabetes significant hemorrhage intrauterine infection gestational age >34 weeks (tocolysis no longer recommended) palpitations tremors nervousness nausea headache hyperglycemia tachycardia (maternal and fetal) arrhythmias hypotension pulmonary edema => dyspnea myocardial ischemia hypokalemia => ATI question monitor maternal HR, BP, glucose, and respiratory status hold dose if maternal HR >120 bpm or chest pain occurs assess fetal heart rate and uterine activity continuously monitor for signs of pulmonary edema: dyspnea, crackles, hypoxia ensure IV access and emergency equipment available typically administered subQ or IV in L&D FDA black box warning: not for prolonged tocolysis (>48–72 hrs) use lowest effective dose for shortest time caution with concurrent corticosteroid use (↑ risk of pulmonary edema) educate patient about side effects (especially palpitations, jitteriness) requires close monitoring; high-risk medication in OB

item.title: Parvovirus B19
item.description: Viral infection caused by parvovirus B19 Spread through respiratory droplets or transplacental transmission Known as “Fifth disease” in children (slapped cheek rash) Dangerous in pregnancy due to risk of fetal anemia and hydrops Human parvovirus B19 infection Transmission via respiratory secretions or vertical (mother-to-fetus) route Pregnant women without prior immunity Close contact with young children (e.g., teachers, daycare workers) Infection during first or second trimester Often asymptomatic in pregnant women Flu-like symptoms including low-grade fever, fatigue, myalgia Arthralgia or arthritis, especially in hands and knees Fetal effects include hydrops fetalis, intrauterine growth restriction, or fetal demise Fetal hydrops due to severe anemia Intrauterine fetal death, especially if infected before 20 weeks Rare maternal complications like aplastic anemia or thrombocytopenia Maternal serology for IgM (recent) and IgG (immunity) PCR testing of amniotic fluid if fetal infection suspected Ultrasound to detect fetal hydrops or ascites Doppler ultrasound of middle cerebral artery to assess fetal anemia No specific antiviral treatment Intrauterine transfusion if fetal anemia or hydrops is detected Serial ultrasounds to monitor fetal condition Supportive care for maternal symptoms Screen for exposure history and occupational risks Educate on infection control practices like hand hygiene Coordinate follow-up with maternal-fetal medicine if infection confirmed Monitor for fetal complications with ultrasound and Doppler Provide emotional support due to risk of fetal loss Inform about common exposure in children and potential pregnancy risks Emphasize hygiene and avoidance of sick contacts Explain the need for testing and monitoring if exposed Reassure that most pregnancies with infection have favorable outcomes No vaccine available, so prevention is key

item.title: Betamethasone
item.description: Corticosteroid used to accelerate fetal lung maturity Commonly used glucocorticoid for antenatal corticosteroid therapy Indications Pregnant women at risk for preterm delivery between 24–34 weeks gestation May be considered between 22–23+6 weeks or 34–36+6 weeks in select cases Dosage 12 mg IM every 24 hrs × 2 doses Mechanism of Action Stimulates surfactant production in fetal lungs Reduces risk of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), and neonatal death Benefits Decreases incidence/severity of RDS Lowers risk of neonatal complications Promotes lung and brain maturity Side Effects Maternal: hyperglycemia, immunosuppression, fluid retention Fetal: transient decrease in fetal movement and HR variability Nursing Interventions Administer IM in ventrogluteal or vastus lateralis Monitor maternal blood glucose (especially in diabetics) Educate patient on purpose and benefits Assess fetal heart rate and movement Watch for infection due to immunosuppressive effects Contraindications Systemic infection (relative) Caution in poorly controlled diabetes Timing Ideally given at least 24 hours before birth Full benefit seen if delivery occurs at least 48 hrs after first dose Effects last ~7 days

item.title: Post-Partum Hemorrhage Meds
item.description: MCTOM Methergine Carboprost Tromethamine TXA Oxytocin Misoprostol Indications: Prevention and treatment of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) caused by uterine atony or subinvolution. Mechanism of Action: Directly stimulates smooth muscle of the uterus, causing rapid, sustained tetanic uterine contraction; also constricts peripheral and coronary blood vessels. Contraindications: Hypersensitivity to methergine, hypertension (pre-eclampsia, eclampsia, chronic hypertension), cardiac disease, peripheral vascular disease, hepatic or renal impairment, sepsis, threatened spontaneous abortion (before delivery of placenta), induction of labor. Expected Side Effects: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain/cramping, dizziness, headache, diaphoresis. Adverse Effects: Severe hypertension (potentially leading to cerebral hemorrhage), seizures, palpitations, chest pain, myocardial infarction, dyspnea, pulmonary edema, stroke, allergic reactions (rash, anaphylaxis), ergotism (rare, with prolonged use or overdose: peripheral vasospasm, cyanosis, cold extremities). Nursing Considerations: Assess blood pressure frequently (every 15 minutes or more often as indicated) during administration and for several hours afterward; monitor uterine tone, vaginal bleeding, and fundal height; administer IV slowly over at least 60 seconds (rapid IV push can cause severe hypertension and cerebrovascular accident); monitor for signs of ergotism; educate patient about potential side effects and to report any severe headache, chest pain, or vision changes; typically given IM; IV is reserved for emergent situations due to risk of severe hypertension. Specific Parameters to Discontinue Med: 140/90 BP or greater; signs of severe hypertension or neurological symptoms (e.g., severe headache, visual disturbances, seizures); chest pain or signs of myocardial ischemia. Indications: Treatment of postpartum hemorrhage due to uterine atony that is unresponsive to other oxytocic agents; used in pregnancy termination. Mechanism of Action: Potent prostaglandin F2-alpha analog; directly stimulates sustained contraction of uterine smooth muscle; also causes contraction of bronchial and vascular smooth muscle. Contraindications: Hypersensitivity to carboprost or prostaglandins, acute pelvic inflammatory disease, active cardiac, pulmonary, renal, or hepatic disease, asthma (absolute contraindication due to bronchoconstriction); caution with hypertension, hypotension, anemia, jaundice, diabetes, epilepsy, previous uterine surgery (e.g., C-section). Expected Side Effects: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea (very common due to smooth muscle stimulation), fever, chills, flushing, headache, tachycardia. Adverse Effects: Bronchospasm, wheezing, dyspnea, hypertension or hypotension, pulmonary edema, Uterine Rupture (rare, especially with overuse or in grand multiparas), uterine hypertonus, tetanic contractions, arrhythmias, DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation, rare). Nursing Considerations: Administer deep IM only; avoid IV administration; rotate injection sites if multiple doses are needed; monitor uterine tone, vaginal bleeding, and vital signs (BP, pulse, respirations, temperature) frequently; have antiemetics and antidiarrheals readily available and consider pre-medication; auscultate lung sounds for signs of bronchospasm; assess for fever, which is a common but usually transient side effect; educate patient about common GI side effects. Specific Parameters to Discontinue Med: Severe bronchospasm or respiratory distress; sustained severe hypertension or hypotension refractory to treatment; signs of uterine rupture. Indications: Treatment of postpartum hemorrhage when conservative management is insufficient; reduces blood loss in various surgical procedures and trauma. Mechanism of Action: Antifibrinolytic agent; reversibly binds to plasminogen and plasmin, preventing fibrinolysis (breakdown of blood clots); stabilizes existing clots. Contraindications: Hypersensitivity to TXA, active intravascular clotting (e.g., DIC, unless primary fibrinolysis is predominant), history of thrombosis (DVT, PE, stroke, MI), unless benefits clearly outweigh risks, severe renal impairment (dose adjustment needed), history of seizures (may increase seizure risk), color vision impairment (can mask retinal toxicity). Expected Side Effects: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, dizziness, headache, hypotension (if administered too rapidly IV), abdominal pain. Adverse Effects: Thromboembolic events (DVT, PE, stroke, MI) – although studies suggest low risk in PPH; seizures (especially with rapid IV administration or high doses); visual disturbances, impaired color vision; allergic reactions; renal cortical necrosis (rare, with prolonged use/high doses). Nursing Considerations: Administer intravenously slowly over 10 minutes to prevent hypotension; monitor for signs of thrombosis (e.g., leg pain, swelling, chest pain, shortness of breath, neurological changes); assess for any changes in vision or color perception; monitor vital signs, uterine tone, and blood loss; ensure proper hydration; typically given within 3 hours of birth for PPH benefit. Specific Parameters to Discontinue Med: Signs of active thrombosis (e.g., new onset chest pain, dyspnea, calf pain, neurological deficits); severe allergic reaction; new onset or worsening seizures; significant visual changes. Indications: Prevention and treatment of postpartum hemorrhage due to uterine atony; induction and augmentation of labor; to promote milk let-down (nasal spray, rare). Mechanism of Action: Synthetic polypeptide hormone structurally identical to natural oxytocin; acts on oxytocin receptors in the uterus, causing rhythmic contractions of uterine smooth muscle; increases the frequency and intensity of contractions; also has antidiuretic effects at high doses. Contraindications: Hypersensitivity to oxytocin, cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD), unfavorable fetal position or presentation, significant placenta previa or vasa previa, umbilical cord prolapse, uterine hypertonicity or fetal distress when delivery is not imminent, severe toxemia, active genital herpes, undelivered placenta (before delivery of placenta in PPH management, it's typically given after delivery). Expected Side Effects: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain/cramping, headache, flushing. Adverse Effects: Maternal: Uterine hyperstimulation/tetany (leading to uterine rupture, placental abruption, fetal distress), water intoxication (hyponatremia, cerebral edema, seizures, coma) with high doses and large volumes of hypotonic fluids, hypotension or hypertension (less common), arrhythmias, postpartum hemorrhage (paradoxical, if receptors are saturated or overstimulated), allergic reactions; Fetal: Fetal distress (due to uterine hyperstimulation), bradycardia, hypoxia, acidosis. Nursing Considerations: Administer as a dilute IV infusion via a pump, typically as a piggyback into a main IV line; never administer undiluted IV push in PPH management (can cause severe hypotension or cardiac arrhythmias); monitor uterine activity (frequency, duration, intensity of contractions), uterine resting tone, and vaginal bleeding; monitor vital signs (BP, pulse) frequently; assess intake and output to monitor for water intoxication; assess for signs of uterine hyperstimulation (contractions lasting >90 seconds, less than 2 minutes apart, or resting tone >20 mmHg); have tocolytics (e.g., terbutaline) available to relax the uterus in case of hyperstimulation. Specific Parameters to Discontinue Med: Signs of uterine hyperstimulation (contractions too frequent, too long, or resting tone too high); signs of fetal distress (if used antepartum); signs of water intoxication (e.g., hyponatremia, decreased urine output, confusion, seizures); significant maternal hypotension or arrhythmia. Indications: Treatment of postpartum hemorrhage due to uterine atony; cervical ripening and labor induction; abortion (medical); prevention of NSAID-induced gastric ulcers. Mechanism of Action: Synthetic prostaglandin E1 analog; causes strong uterine contractions; also causes cervical softening and dilation. Contraindications: Hypersensitivity to misoprostol or other prostaglandins, known allergy to other prostaglandins; in the context of PPH, generally few absolute contraindications once the baby and placenta are delivered, as it's a critical situation; however, caution in patients with glaucoma, asthma (less of a concern than carboprost but still a prostaglandin), or severe cardiovascular disease; active gastrointestinal disease (if given orally for ulcer prevention). Expected Side Effects: Shivering, chills, fever (very common), nausea, vomiting, diarrhea (common), abdominal pain/cramping, headache. Adverse Effects: Uterine hyperstimulation/tetany (leading to uterine rupture, especially with high doses or in cases of previous uterine surgery), hypotension or hypertension, bradycardia or tachycardia, allergic reactions, bronchospasm (less common than with carboprost), DIC (rare). Nursing Considerations: Can be administered orally, sublingually, rectally, or vaginally for PPH; rectal administration is often preferred in emergent PPH due to rapid absorption and less GI side effects; monitor uterine tone, vaginal bleeding, and vital signs (BP, pulse, temperature) frequently; anticipate and manage shivering/chills with warm blankets; provide comfort measures for nausea and vomiting; educate patient about common side effects; ensure accurate dosage and route of administration. Specific Parameters to Discontinue Med: Sustained uterine hypertonus not responding to other measures; signs of uterine rupture; severe allergic reaction.

item.title: Oxytocin
item.description: aka Pitocin Synthetic hormone identical to endogenous oxytocin stimulates uterine smooth muscle contractions does not cross placenta For Induction: 0.5-1 mUnit/min IV, titrate 1-2 mUnit/min q15-60min until contraction pattern reached that is similiar to normal labor Labor induction or augmentation Management of postpartum hemorrhage Incomplete or inevitable miscarriage (to aid uterine evacuation) Binds to oxytocin receptors in uterine smooth muscle → increases intracellular calcium → promotes rhythmic uterine contractions; also promotes milk let-down reflex via myoepithelial contraction in breasts Fetal distress without imminent delivery Unfavorable fetal position (e.g., transverse lie) Previous uterine surgery (e.g., classical C-section or extensive myomectomy) Placenta previa or vasa previa Active genital herpes Hypertonic uterine patterns or hypersensitivity Mild hypotension Flushing Headache Nausea and vomiting Abdominal cramping Uterine hypertonicity or tachysystole Pelvic discomfort or pain Water retention or hyponatremia (due to antidiuretic properties) Restlessness or anxiety Drowsiness or confusion (in cases of water intoxication) Uterine Tachysystole: >5 contractions in 10 minutes, may reduce fetal oxygenation Uterine Hypertonicity: Sustained contractions or inadequate uterine relaxation, increases risk of fetal distress Fetal Distress: Late decelerations, bradycardia, or decreased variability due to reduced placental perfusion Uterine Rupture: Especially in patients with prior uterine surgery or high-dose/prolonged use Postpartum Hemorrhage: From uterine atony following prolonged stimulation Water Intoxication/Hyponatremia: Rare but serious, due to oxytocin’s antidiuretic effect Hypotension: Especially with rapid IV bolus Nausea/Vomiting: Mild but possible GI effects Anaphylaxis or hypersensitivity: Rare, but must be monitored High vigilance and titrated dosing are essential to minimize these risks. Continuous fetal and contraction monitoring (risk of uterine tachysystole or fetal distress) Monitor for uterine hyperstimulation (>5 contractions in 10 min or contractions lasting >90 sec) Assess I&O due to risk of water intoxication (oxytocin has antidiuretic effect) Titrate infusion per protocol (commonly in milliunits/min) Stop infusion and notify provider if fetal decelerations or uterine hypertonicity occur Monitor BP, HR, and uterine tone postpartum

item.title: Hormones
item.description: Detected in maternal serum by 8-10 days after conception Signals corpus luteum not to degenerate until placenta secretes adequate estrogen and progesterone. Prevents immunological rejection of implanting embryo. Has thyroid-stimulating abilitystimulates maternal metabolism to produce nutrients needed for fetal growth facilitates glucose transfer across placenta prepares maternal breast development to prepare for lactationMaintains endometrium Decreases contractility of uterus Stimulates maternal metabolism and development of alveolar tissueBy 7th week, placenta produces more estrogen than corpus luteum – primarily as estriol Measuring maternal serum estriol levels is one way to test for placental function during pregnancy Estrogens stimulate uterine growth and uteroplacental blood flow Production increases greatly toward end of pregnancy

item.title: Head
item.description: Fontanels: Anterior fontanel: 4 to 6 cm, diamond-shaped, closes by 12–18 months Posterior fontanel: 0.5 to 1 cm, triangular, closes by 2–3 months Molding: Overlapping of cranial bones during birth; resolves in a few days Caput succedaneum: Edema crossing suture lines; resolves within 48–72 hours Cephalohematoma: Rupture of blood vessels during delivery; does not cross suture lines; resolves over weeks to months Sutures: Should be palpable, not fused; allow for brain growth Scalp hair: Soft, may have varying patterns or bald spots from intrauterine position Facial symmetry: Assess for nerve injury (e.g., facial nerve palsy) Bruising: Common from delivery; monitor for jaundice due to increased bilirubin from breakdown of RBCs Craniotabes: Soft skull bones near suture lines; common in preterm infants; resolves as bones harden Subgaleal hemorrhage: Fluctuant mass that crosses suture lines; requires urgent evaluation due to risk of significant blood loss Microcephaly Head circumference >2 SD below average or <10% normal parameters for gestational age Due to failed brain development, reduced neuron production, reduced brain/skull size Affects 1 in 800–5,000 infants/year in the US Severe microcephaly: >3 SD below mean, often with imaging abnormalities, severe developmental impairments Associated with: seizures, developmental delay, intellectual disability, hearing loss, vision/movement/balance/feeding problems Causes: genetics, infections (CMV, rubella, toxoplasmosis), Zika, trisomies 13/18/21, alcohol/drugs exposure Macrocephaly Head circumference >90% of normal Often benign, no treatment needed Related to hydrocephalus, often familial (autosomal dominant) May be isolated or part of other conditions (hydrocephalus, skeletal disorders like achondroplasia) Large Fontanels more than 6 cm anterior or >1 cm posterior diameter Causes: malnutrition, hydrocephalus, congenital hypothyroidism, trisomies 13/18/21, osteogenesis imperfecta Small/Closed Fontanels Smaller-than-normal or closed at birth Causes: craniosynostosis (premature suture fusion), abnormal brain development Associated with microcephaly Management: multidisciplinary subspecialty teams, reconstructive approaches

item.title: Nonpharmacologic Pain Management
item.description: Continuous Labor Support Hydrotherapy - showering, regular tub, whirlpool, helps release muscle tension Hypnosis Ambulation - walking and upright position in 1st stage reduce length of labor d/t gravity Maternal Position Changes Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS) Acupuncture Acupressure Attention Focusing and Imagery Therapeutic Touch Massage Breathing Techniques Effleurage - light, stroking, superficial touch of the abdomen, in rhythm with breathing during contractions Lamaze is a method of childbirth preparation that focuses on natural techniques like controlled breathing, relaxation, and movement to help manage labor and potentially reduce the need for pain medication.

item.title: Intraventricular Hemorrhage
item.description: Bleeding into the brain’s ventricular system, common in preterm infants Often originates from germinal matrix due to fragile vasculature Prematurity: fragile capillaries in germinal matrix Hypoxic-ischemic injury Rapid changes in cerebral blood flow Mechanical ventilation Birth <32 weeks gestation Very low birth weight (<1500g) Respiratory distress syndrome Fluctuating cerebral blood flow (e.g., rapid volume expansion) Asymptomatic (mild cases) Sudden apnea, bradycardia Lethargy, hypotonia Bulging fontanel, seizures Anemia Hydrocephalus Cerebral palsy Developmental delay Seizure disorders Cranial ultrasound (preferred) CT or MRI for detailed evaluation Supportive care: manage oxygenation, ventilation, and perfusion Monitor for hydrocephalus (serial head circumference) Neurosurgical intervention for hydrocephalus (ventriculoperitoneal shunt) Monitor head circumference and fontanels Minimize handling to reduce stress and fluctuations in cerebral blood flow Maintain neutral head position to optimize venous drainage Educate parents on long-term developmental monitoring Provide emotional support and counseling regarding prognosis and outcomes Clinical Pearl: Keep oxygenation and perfusion stable to prevent further bleeding NCLEX Tip: Preemies at highest risk due to fragile germinal matrix; watch for bulging fontanel and sudden neurologic changes

item.title: Weight Loss
item.description: 1 kg (2.2 lb) per month if lactating

item.title: MSK Assessments
item.description: Purpose: Detects dislocated hip that can be reduced (congenital hip dysplasia) Technique: With infant supine, hips and knees flexed 90°, gently abduct the thighs while applying anterior pressure on greater trochanters Positive sign: Feel or hear a “clunk” as the femoral head relocates into the acetabulum Purpose: Detects dislocatable hip (can be pushed out of socket) Technique: With infant supine, hips and knees flexed 90°, gently adduct the thighs while applying posterior pressure on the knees Positive sign: Feeling the femoral head slip out of the socket (a “clunk” or sensation of instability)

item.title: Skin Variations
item.description: Milia: Small white papules on nose and cheeks; clogged sebaceous glands; resolves spontaneously Erythema toxicum: Red macules with yellow-white papules (flea-bite rash); common in first week; no treatment needed Mongolian spots: Bluish-gray pigmentation over sacrum/buttocks; common in darker-skinned infants; fades over time Vernix caseosa: White, cheese-like protective covering; present at birth; absorbs into skin Lanugo: Fine hair on back, shoulders, face; common in preterm; disappears with age Acrocyanosis: Blue hands and feet; normal in first 24–48 hours due to immature circulation Nevus simplex (salmon patch/stork bite): Flat pink/red mark on nape of neck, eyelids, or forehead; blanches; fades with time Milia: Tiny white bumps; nose, cheeks; due to immature sweat glands; no treatment Transient pustular melanosis: Superficial pustules that rupture and leave hyperpigmented spots; more common in darker-skinned infants Harlequin color change: Transient red-to-pale color split; resolves spontaneously Sebaceous hyperplasia: Small yellowish spots from maternal hormones; resolves spontaneously Neonatal acne: Papules/pustules on cheeks/forehead; from maternal hormones; resolves without treatment

item.title: New Ballard Score
item.description: Higher score = more mature = higher GA Scores range from -10 (very preterm) to 50 (post-term) Posture: Very preterm: Extended limbs Term: Arms & legs flexed Square Window (Wrist Flexion): Term: 0–30° angle Preterm: >90° Arm Recoil: Term: Quick recoil after extension Preterm: Slow or no recoil Popliteal Angle (Knee): Term: <90° Preterm: >120° Scarf Sign (Elbow across chest): Term: Elbow doesn’t cross midline Preterm: Elbow crosses easily Heel to Ear: Term: Resistance before heel reaches ear Preterm: Heel easily reaches ear Skin: Term: Opaque, cracks, few veins Preterm: Thin, transparent, many veins Lanugo: Term: Mostly gone Preterm: Abundant Plantar Surface: Term: Creases over entire sole Preterm: Smooth or few creases Breast: Term: Well-developed areola, palpable nodule Preterm: Barely perceptible areola Eye/Ear: Term: Thick cartilage, forms instant recoil Preterm: Thin cartilage, slow recoil Genitals: Male: Term: Testes fully descended, rugae on scrotum Female: Term: Labia majora cover labia minora and clitoris

item.title: Cold Stress
item.description: newborns lose heat faster than they can produce it, leading to hypothermia and metabolic complications Also called hypothermia in neonates Evaporation: Wet skin after birth Conduction: Contact with cold surfaces Convection: Air movement over skin Radiation: Heat loss to nearby cold objects Prematurity (less brown fat, thin skin) Low birth weight Prolonged resuscitation Delivery room cold environment Hypothermia: Excessive heat loss through evaporation, conduction, convection, and radiation Lethargy: Decreased metabolic rate and energy availability Poor feeding: Energy diverted from feeding to maintaining body temperature Hypoglycemia: Increased glucose consumption to generate heat Respiratory distress: Increased oxygen demand and metabolic rate to produce heat Metabolic acidosis: Anaerobic metabolism due to increased energy expenditure leading to lactic acid buildup Jaundice Decreased Surfactant production Hypoglycemia Metabolic acidosis Respiratory distress Increased oxygen consumption leading to hypoxia Axillary temperature monitoring (<36.5°C) Blood glucose levels (rule out hypoglycemia) Blood gases (check for acidosis) Dry and warm the baby immediately after birth Skin-to-skin contact (Kangaroo care) Radiant warmer or incubator Warmed IV fluids if needed Monitor glucose levels Maintain neutral thermal environment Educate parents on keeping baby warm Monitor for signs of cold stress and hypoglycemia Avoid exposing baby to drafts or cold surfaces Implement early feeding to prevent hypoglycemia Remember: Cold stress increases oxygen consumption → respiratory distress → hypoxia (NCLEX Tip) Clinical Pearl: "Keep the baby warm, feed early, and monitor closely." Avoiding the placement of a skin temperature probe over a bony area or one with brown fat => does not give an accurate assessment each parents to keep the baby warm using skin-to-skin contact, warm clothing, and blankets Instruct on avoiding exposure to cold air, drafts, and cold surfaces Explain the importance of feeding early and regularly to maintain energy stores Show how to check baby's temperature (axillary) and recognize signs of cold stress (cool skin, lethargy, poor feeding) Emphasize the need to report any symptoms like excessive sleepiness, poor feeding, or rapid breathing Reinforce that preventing cold stress reduces risk of hypoglycemia and respiratory distress Provide guidance on maintaining a warm environment during bathing and diaper changes Review safe sleep practices: room temperature (avoid overheating but prevent cold stress) Encourage use of hats and warm wraps especially in colder climates

item.title: Physiological Changes
item.description: Closure of foramen ovale, ductus arteriosus, and ductus venosus Increase in systemic vascular resistance and decrease in pulmonary vascular resistance Heart rate initially high (120–160 bpm) then stabilizes Blood volume approximately 80–85 mL/kg Increase in red blood cells, but rapid decrease over first weeks (physiological anemia) First breath establishes functional residual capacity Surfactant reduces surface tension, prevents alveolar collapse Respiratory rate 30–60 breaths per minute Periodic breathing is common (pauses <15 seconds normal) Risk of transient tachypnea if fluid clearance delayed Thermoregulation immature; prone to heat loss Brown fat metabolism generates heat (non-shivering thermogenesis) Requires neutral thermal environment to prevent cold stress Bilirubin levels decline to normal adult after 14 days Limited glycogen stores; risk for hypoglycemia Immature conjugation of bilirubin; risk for jaundice Coagulation factors dependent on vitamin K (administer vitamin K at birth) => need gut bacteria from Breast Milk Slow metabolism of certain drugs Iron stored in the liver from maternal transfer during third trimester Stomach capacity increases rapidly (30–90 mL) Cardiac Sphincter or LES immature => leads to vomiting after feeding Suck-swallow coordination matures over first few days Meconium passed within 24–48 hours Limited enzyme function (low amylase, pancreatic lipase) Immature kidney function GFR low, limits urine concentrating ability First void usually within 24 hours Risk for dehydration and electrolyte imbalance Passive immunity from maternal IgG Skin and mucous membranes immature; risk for infection Limited inflammatory response Vernix caseosa protects skin in utero; gradually absorbed Lanugo fine hair present on back and shoulders Milia, erythema toxicum, and other benign rashes common Skin thin and prone to injury and heat loss Reflexes present (Moro, rooting, grasp) Myelination incomplete Sleep-wake cycles irregular CNS sensitive to hypoglycemia and hypoxia Begins at birth, lasts 30 min–2 hours Alert, moving, may appear hungry Myoclonic eye movements, spontaneous Moro reflex Sucking motions, chewing, rooting, fine tremors Increased muscle tone, motor activity Elevated heart and respiratory rates, gradually slow Ideal time for parent-newborn bonding Sucking and rooting behaviors; opportunity to initiate breastfeeding Starts at 30–120 min of age Sleep phase; decreased activity Less jerky, less frequent movements Decline in heart and respiratory rates Relaxed muscles, diminished response to stimuli Difficult to arouse; no interest in sucking Quiet time for mother-newborn rest Begins as newborn awakens Lasts 2–8 hours Increased heart and respiratory rates Increased peristalsis; possible meconium passage or voiding Increased motor activity, muscle tone, coordination Encouraged mother-newborn interaction Opportunity for parents to bond, ask questions

item.title: Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy
item.description: Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP) is a liver disorder during pregnancy characterized by impaired bile flow. Presents in the third trimester, resolves postpartum. Hormonal changes (estrogen, progesterone) leading to bile acid buildup. Genetic predisposition. Multiple gestations. Personal or family history of ICP. History of liver disease. Pruritus (especially on palms and soles). Elevated bile acids (>10 µmol/L). Mild jaundice in some cases. Dark urine, pale stools. Fetal distress. Preterm labor. Stillbirth (monitor bile acids >40 µmol/L). Maternal vitamin K deficiency (risk of PPH). Serum bile acids: >10 µmol/L diagnostic. LFTs: ↑ ALT, AST. Rule out other causes: hepatitis panel, ultrasound. Ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA): First-line to reduce bile acids. Early delivery (typically 37–38 weeks). Antihistamines for pruritus (symptomatic relief). Vitamin K supplementation to reduce bleeding risk. Monitor fetal well-being (NST, BPP). Educate on fetal kick counts and when to report decreased movement. Counsel on symptom relief (cool baths, loose clothing). Monitor for PPH due to vitamin K deficiency. Administer UDCA as prescribed, monitor LFTs and bile acids. Reinforce early delivery plan (coordinate with OB).
item.guid: OB/ii. Pregnancy/High Risk/Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy.md

item.title: Post-Mature
item.description: Newborn born after 42 weeks gestation (post-term) At risk for complications due to aging placenta True post-term pregnancy (>42 weeks) Unknown triggers; may involve placental factors or fetal genetics First pregnancy Prior post-term pregnancy Maternal obesity Male fetus Dry, cracked, peeling skin Overgrown nails Abundant scalp hair Little or no vernix (Vernix caseosa, also known as vernix, is the waxy white substance found coating the skin of newborn human babies) Meconium-stained skin and nails Long, thin body with decreased subcutaneous fat Alert, wide-eyed appearance Signs of placental insufficiency (oligohydramnios, hypoglycemia, meconium aspiration risk) Meconium aspiration syndrome Hypoglycemia due to depleted glycogen stores Polycythemia from chronic hypoxia Birth trauma (macrosomia) Hypothermia from decreased fat Neonatal asphyxia due to placental aging Gestational age assessment (Ballard score) Amniotic fluid volume (decreased in post-maturity) Monitor for meconium in amniotic fluid Close monitoring during labor (NST, biophysical profile) Induction of labor if risk factors present Early detection of fetal distress Manage complications promptly (e.g., glucose for hypoglycemia) Monitor glucose levels regularly (risk of hypoglycemia) Watch for signs of meconium aspiration (tachypnea, cyanosis, grunting) Maintain neutral thermal environment (prevent hypothermia) Monitor oxygenation and support respiratory function Educate parents about increased risk and monitoring needs Document signs of post-maturity and interventions

item.title: Mastitis
item.description: Infection of the breast tissue, commonly occurring during breastfeeding Involves pain, redness, and swelling in affected area Milk stasis due to incomplete emptying Bacterial entry (often Staphylococcus aureus) via cracked nipples Overproduction of milk Nipple trauma or cracks Poor latch or infrequent breastfeeding Blocked ducts Stress and fatigue Localized, painful, red, warm area on the breast Fever (>38.4°C/101°F), chills, malaise Flu-like symptoms May have breast engorgement Breast abscess (requires drainage) Sepsis if untreated Clinical presentation Ultrasound if abscess suspected Culture of milk if severe, recurrent, or unresponsive Continue breastfeeding or milk expression to empty breast Warm compresses and massage Analgesics (e.g., ibuprofen) for pain and inflammation Antibiotics: dicloxacillin or cephalexin; clindamycin if penicillin allergy Rest and hydration Educate on correct latch and breastfeeding techniques Encourage frequent and complete emptying of affected breast Monitor for signs of abscess (fluctuant mass, worsening pain) Advise supportive bra, avoid tight clothing Explain that breastfeeding can continue on affected side unless abscess forms Teach proper nipple care to prevent cracks and infection

item.title: Meconium Aspiration Syndrome
item.description: Inhalation of meconium-stained amniotic fluid during or before birth Causes airway obstruction, chemical pneumonitis, and surfactant dysfunction Common cause of respiratory distress in term and post-term newborns Surfactant is a phospholipid that assists in alveoli expansion. Surfactant keeps alveoli from collapsing and allows gas exchange to occur. Meconium passage in utero (due to fetal distress or hypoxia) Gasps in utero or during delivery → aspiration of meconium Post-term pregnancy (>42 weeks) Fetal distress (hypoxia, cord compression) Maternal hypertension or diabetes Prolonged labor or difficult delivery Respiratory distress: tachypnea, grunting, nasal flaring, retractions Cyanosis, decreased breath sounds, coarse crackles Barrel-shaped chest from overinflation Meconium-stained skin, nails, or umbilical cord Airway obstruction → hypoxia Pneumothorax or pneumomediastinum Persistent pulmonary hypertension (PPHN) Severe respiratory failure, death History of meconium-stained amniotic fluid Chest x-ray: patchy infiltrates, hyperinflation, flattened diaphragm Blood gases: hypoxemia, respiratory acidosis Clinical presentation Suction only if visible meconium in airway and baby is non-vigorous Oxygen therapy, mechanical ventilation as needed Surfactant therapy to reduce surface tension Beractant, calfactant, lucinactant Nitric oxide or ECMO for severe cases with PPHN Antibiotics if infection is suspected Monitor respiratory status closely (rate, effort, oxygen saturation) Prepare for possible intubation and ventilation Maintain neutral thermal environment Provide parental education and emotional support Administer oxygen cautiously to avoid oxygen toxicity Monitor for signs of PPHN and pneumothorax Document all assessments and interventions accurately

item.title: Respiratory Distress Syndrome in Newborn
item.description: Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), also called hyaline membrane disease Common cause of respiratory distress in preterm newborns Due to insufficient surfactant production leading to alveolar collapse Prematurity (before 34 weeks) → immature lungs, low surfactant Maternal diabetes → delayed surfactant synthesis Perinatal asphyxia → surfactant inactivation Prematurity (most significant) Maternal diabetes mellitus Cesarean delivery without labor Male infants Second-born twin Tachypnea (>60 breaths/min) Nasal flaring, grunting, intercostal/substernal retractions Cyanosis, decreased breath sounds Hypoxia and respiratory acidosis Ground-glass appearance on chest x-ray Hypoxia → organ damage Pneumothorax (air leak) Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) with prolonged oxygen use Intraventricular hemorrhage Chest x-ray: ground-glass opacities, air bronchograms Blood gases: hypoxemia, respiratory acidosis Clinical signs + risk factors Antenatal corticosteroids (betamethasone) to promote surfactant production if preterm delivery expected Exogenous surfactant administration via ET tube after birth Oxygen therapy (careful to avoid oxygen toxicity) CPAP or mechanical ventilation as needed Maintain neutral thermal environment Monitor respiratory rate, effort, and oxygen saturation Provide supplemental oxygen, titrate to avoid hyperoxia Maintain warmth and minimize handling Educate parents about prematurity and RDS treatment Monitor for signs of complications (pneumothorax, BPD) Administer medications as ordered (surfactant, corticosteroids) Encourage kangaroo care if stable Mnemonic for RDS risk factors: "Premature Males Can Die" Prematurity, Male, Cesarean, Diabetes NCLEX Tip: RDS is due to surfactant deficiency; exogenous surfactant and respiratory support are key interventions.
item.guid: OB/v. Newborn/Complications/Respiratory Distress Syndrome in Newborn.md

item.title: Vital Signs
item.description: Respiratory Rate 30 to 60 breaths per minute. Periods of apnea less than 15 seconds are normal during REM sleep. Apnea lasting longer than 15 seconds should be evaluated. Crackles and wheezing can indicate fluid or infection. Grunting and nasal flaring suggest respiratory distress. obligatory nose breathers Heart Rate 110 to 160 beats per minute. Brief fluctuations may occur depending on activity (crying, sleeping). Apical pulse is assessed for 1 full minute at the fourth or fifth intercostal space, left midclavicular line. Heart murmurs should be documented and reported. Blood Pressure 60 to 80 mm Hg systolic. 40 to 50 mm Hg diastolic. Temperature 36.5°C to 37.5°C (97.7°F to 99.5°F). Average of 37°C (98.6°F).

item.title: Naegel's Rule
item.description: add: +9 months, +7 daysNaegele's Rule is a method used to estimate the expected due date of a pregnancy, based on the first day of the woman's last menstrual period (LMP). Icommon tool for quickly getting a rough estimate of the delivery date, particularly in the early stages of pregnancy. How it Works:Start with the LMP: Identify the first day of the woman's last menstrual period. Subtract three calendar months: Count back three full calendar months from the LMP date. Add seven days: Add seven days to the date obtained in step 2. Add one year (if needed): If the date falls in the previous year, add one year to the date. Example: Let's say the first day of a woman's LMP was September 9, 2023. Subtract three months: September - 3 months = June. Add seven days: June 9 + 7 days = June 16. Add one year (if needed): Since the date is in the current year (2024), we don't add a year. Therefore, the estimated due date would be June 16, 2024

item.title: Neonatal Reflexes
item.description: Rooting: turns head toward touch on cheek, opens mouth (disappears by 4 months) Sucking: sucks when roof of mouth is touched (present at birth) Moro (startle): arms extend and fan out when startled, then flex back (disappears by 4–6 months) Palmar grasp: grasps object placed in palm (disappears by 3–4 months) Plantar grasp: toes curl when sole is touched (disappears by 8 months) Babinski: toes fan outward when sole is stroked (normal up to 1 year) Stepping: makes stepping motions when held upright (disappears by 2 months) Tonic neck (fencing): head turned to one side, arm extends on that side while opposite arm flexes (disappears by 4 months)

item.title: Endometritis
item.description: Infection and inflammation of the endometrium (uterine lining) postpartum or post-procedure Common cause of postpartum fever and morbidity Bacterial invasion during or after delivery, miscarriage, or gynecologic procedures Polymicrobial: often Staphylococcus, Streptococcus, anaerobes Retained placental fragments increase risk Cesarean section (especially emergency) Prolonged labor or membrane rupture (>18 hours) Multiple vaginal exams during labor Poor aseptic technique Retained products of conception Immunosuppression Fever (>38°C/100.4°F), chills Lower abdominal/pelvic pain and tenderness Foul-smelling, purulent lochia Uterine tenderness on palpation Tachycardia Malaise and fatigue Pelvic abscess Sepsis Infertility from scarring Chronic pelvic pain Clinical diagnosis based on symptoms and signs CBC: elevated WBC with left shift Blood cultures if febrile/septic Ultrasound to identify retained products or abscess Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics (e.g., clindamycin + gentamicin) Removal of retained products if present (D&C) Antipyretics and pain control Hydration and rest Monitor vital signs and temperature regularly Assess uterine size, tenderness, and vaginal discharge Educate on importance of hygiene and reporting fever or foul discharge Administer antibiotics on time, monitor for side effects Encourage early ambulation and hydration Provide comfort measures and emotional support Teach signs of worsening infection or sepsis for early intervention Mnemonic for endometritis risks: "C-PROM" Cesarean, Prolonged Rupture Of MembranesNCLEX Tip: Fever, uterine tenderness, and foul lochia after cesarean or prolonged labor strongly suggest endometritis.

item.title: Uterine Inversion
item.description: Uterus turns inside out, protruding through the cervix or vagina after delivery MEDICAL EMERGENCY! rare but life-threatening Causes severe hemorrhage and shock Excessive traction on umbilical cord during placenta delivery Fundal pressure before placenta detaches Weak uterine tone or atony Short umbilical cord Fundal implantation of placenta Rapid or prolonged labor Use of oxytocin causing uterine hyperstimulation Manual removal of placenta Sudden severe vaginal bleeding Severe lower abdominal pain Visible mass protruding from the vagina (if complete inversion) Shock disproportionate to blood loss (due to vagal response) Uterus not palpable abdominally or very depressed Hypovolemic shock Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) Uterine rupture Death if untreated Clinical diagnosis by physical exam Visualization of inverted uterus through cervix or vagina Ultrasound to confirm if uncertain Immediate manual repositioning of uterus (Johnson maneuver) General anesthesia or tocolytics may be needed for relaxation => Terbutraline Replace uterus gently into correct position Uterotonics after repositioning to maintain tone (e.g., oxytocin) Surgical intervention if manual reposition fails IV fluids and blood transfusion as needed Call for emergency help immediately Monitor vital signs closely, prepare for shock management Provide emotional support, explain urgent procedures Administer medications as ordered (tocolytics before reposition, uterotonics after) Maintain large-bore IV access for fluids/blood Monitor bleeding, uterine tone, and signs of infection post-reposition Document event and interventions clearly NCLEX Tip: Uterine inversion presents with sudden bleeding and shock disproportionate to visible blood loss—immediate manual replacement is critical.

item.title: Methylergonovine
item.description: Indications Prevention and treatment of postpartum hemorrhage caused by uterine atony or subinvolution Control of uterine bleeding after delivery or abortion part of Post-Partum Hemorrhage Meds Contraindications Hypertension or preeclampsia/eclampsia Severe liver or kidney disease Known hypersensitivity to ergot alkaloids Pregnancy (except during delivery/postpartum) Coronary artery disease, peripheral vascular disease Nursing Considerations Monitor blood pressure closely; risk of severe hypertension Assess uterine tone and vaginal bleeding before and after administration Administer intramuscularly (IM); avoid IV due to risk of hypertensive crisis Educate patient on possible side effects: headache, nausea, vomiting, chest pain Have emergency hypertensive treatment ready if needed Do not administer if patient has elevated blood pressure or pre-existing cardiovascular disease Document response to drug and uterine firmness Side Effects Hypertension (most serious) Headache Nausea, vomiting Dizziness Chest pain, palpitations Adverse Effects Severe hypertensive crisis Myocardial infarction or stroke (rare but serious) Uterine cramping causing pain or ischemia

item.title: Subinvolution of the Uterus
item.description:
Failure of the uterus to return to its normal size and condition after childbirth Leads to prolonged uterine enlargement and bleeding Retained placental fragments Infection (endometritis) Pelvic inflammatory disease Poor uterine contractions postpartum Prolonged labor Multiple pregnancies Overdistended uterus Cesarean section or complicated delivery Poor postpartum care Persistent vaginal bleeding beyond expected postpartum period Enlarged, soft uterus on palpation Pelvic pain or tenderness Possible foul-smelling lochia if infection present Secondary Post-Partum Hemorrhage Infection spreading to pelvic organs
Anemia due to prolonged bleeding Infertility if untreated Pelvic exam showing enlarged uterus Ultrasound to detect retained placental tissue or infection CBC for anemia and infection markers Culture if infection suspected Removal of retained products (D&C if needed) Antibiotics for infection Uterotonic agents to stimulate contractions Adequate rest and hydration Monitor amount and character of vaginal bleeding Assess uterine size regularly Educate patient on signs of infection and when to seek care Administer prescribed antibiotics and uterotonics Promote good hygiene to prevent infection Encourage follow-up appointments for uterine involution check NCLEX Tip: Subinvolution often presents with prolonged bleeding and an enlarged uterus after the expected postpartum period.

item.title: Uterine Atony
item.description:
Uterine atony is failure of the uterus to contract effectively after delivery Leading cause of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) Results in heavy bleeding due to poor uterine muscle tone Prolonged labor or rapid labor Overdistended uterus (e.g., multiple gestation, polyhydramnios) Use of uterine relaxants (Tocolytics - MINT, MgSO4) High parity (multiple previous births) Retained placenta fragments General anesthesia 5 pregnancies (multiparity) Large baby (>4000g)
Prolonged Oxytocin use during labor
History of Uterine Atony or PPH Chorioamnionitis or infection Magnesium sulfate therapy Excessive, bright red vaginal bleeding Soft, boggy uterus on palpation ("boggy uterus") Tachycardia and hypotension (signs of hypovolemia) Pallor, weakness, dizziness Decreased urine output if hypovolemia progresses Severe postpartum hemorrhage Hypovolemic shock
Anemia
DIC Need for blood transfusion or hysterectomy Clinical diagnosis: heavy vaginal bleeding + boggy uterus Ultrasound to rule out retained products of conception CBC for anemia assessment Coagulation profile if bleeding persists Immediate fundal massage to stimulate contractions IV fluids and blood transfusion if needed
Uterotonic drugs: => Post-Partum Hemorrhage Meds = MCTOM Oxytocin (first line) Methylergonovine (avoid if hypertensive) Carboprost tromethamine (avoid in asthma) Misoprostol (rectal or oral) TXA Surgical intervention if conservative measures fail (e.g., uterine tamponade, hysterectomy) Monitor vital signs closely, watch for hypovolemic shock Assess uterine tone and vaginal bleeding frequently Administer uterotonic meds as ordered, know contraindications Educate patient on importance of reporting heavy bleeding or dizziness Maintain IV access, prepare for possible transfusion Provide emotional support and explain interventions Monitor urine output as indicator of perfusion Prepare for potential surgical interventions if bleeding uncontrolled

item.title: Tocolytics - MINT
item.description: Medications used to suppress preterm labor by inhibiting uterine contractions; typically used short-term (up to 48 hours) to allow for fetal lung maturity interventions (e.g., corticosteroids)MINT Mag Sulfate Indomethacin Nifedipine Terbutraline Preterm labor before 34 weeks gestation with no contraindications to prolonging pregnancy To facilitate maternal transfer or corticosteroid administration Sometimes used during procedures (e.g., external cephalic version) Varies by drug class: Beta-agonists (e.g., terbutaline): relax uterine smooth muscle via β2 stimulation Calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine): reduce calcium influx in smooth muscle NSAIDs (e.g., indomethacin): inhibit prostaglandin synthesis Magnesium sulfate: decreases uterine muscle contractility (less common as first-line) Maternal: severe preeclampsia, hemorrhage, cardiac disease, infection Fetal: intrauterine fetal demise, lethal anomaly, non-reassuring fetal status, gestational age >34 weeks Maternal Hypotension: SBP <90 mmHg or symptomatic hypotension (especially for nifedipine) Maternal Tachycardia: HR >120–130 bpm (common with beta-agonists like terbutaline) Maternal Respiratory Depression: RR <12/min or signs of distress (critical for magnesium sulfate use) Fever: Maternal temp >38°C (100.4°F), suggestive of chorioamnionitis Oxygen Saturation: SpO₂ <95% or signs of hypoxia Fetal Distress: Non-reassuring fetal heart rate patterns (e.g., persistent late decelerations) Uterine Findings: Uterine infection, abruption, or evidence of fetal compromise Additional labs or findings to monitor: Elevated WBC + uterine tenderness: Suggestive of infection Abnormal LFTs or platelets: Especially relevant in severe preeclampsia/HELLP Signs of cardiac instability: Especially with beta-agonists or underlying maternal heart disease Monitor maternal VS (especially HR, BP, respiratory status) Assess fetal status via continuous monitoring Watch for side effects (e.g., tachycardia with terbutaline, hypotension with nifedipine, GI issues with indomethacin) Educate patient on signs of labor and medication side effects Ensure corticosteroids are administered if under 34 weeks Monitor fluid balance, especially with magnesium sulfate

item.title: Abortion Medications
item.description: Indication: Medical abortion, cervical ripening, postpartum hemorrhage Mechanism: Prostaglandin E1 analog — stimulates uterine contractions and cervical softening Nursing Implications: Monitor for uterine cramping and bleeding Assess for complete expulsion in medical abortion Educate on expected side effects (e.g., chills, fever, diarrhea, N/V, dyspepsia) Monitor for signs and symptoms of shock, such as tachycardia, hypotension, and anxiety. Indication: Medical abortion (often combined with misoprostol) Mechanism: Progesterone receptor antagonist — blocks progesterone, leading to decidual breakdown and detachment of pregnancy Nursing Implications: Monitor for headache, vomiting, diarrhea, and heavy bleeding. Anticipate administration of antiemetic prior to use to reduce nausea and vomiting. Encourage client to use acetaminophen to reduce discomfort from cramping. Indication: Cervical ripening and labor induction Mechanism: Prostaglandin E2 analog — promotes cervical softening and stimulates uterine contractions Administration: gel form, warm it first, sterile technique, lie supine for 30 minutes Nursing Implications: Monitor fetal heart rate and uterine activity continuously Remove insert if uterine tachysystole occurs Educate on potential side effects (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea) Sterile technique, supine position for 30 minutes after admin Indication: Prevention of Rh alloimmunization in Rh-negative mothers Mechanism: Passive immunization — binds Rh-positive fetal cells in maternal circulation to prevent immune response Nursing Implications: Confirm mother’s Rh-negative status and absence of sensitization Administer at 28 weeks and within 72 hours postpartum (or after procedures like amniocentesis) Educate mother on purpose and timing of administration

item.title: Continuous Fetal Monitoring
item.description: Chapter 13 - Ricci Text book provides information on fetal oxygenation during labor goal: detect FHR changes early before they are prolonged can be internal or external two ultrasound transducers, each of which is attached to a belt, are applied around the woman’s abdomen Tocotransducer - placed over the uterine fundus in the area of greatest contractility to monitor uterine contractions Other transducer - baseline FHR, long-term variability, accelerations, and decelerations placed midline between the umbilicus and the symphysis pubis Pros Noninvasive Can be used before ROM (membranes intact) Quick to apply No risk of uterine perforation or infection Detects FHR baseline, variability, accelerations, and decelerations good continuous data Cons limits maternal movement, encourage supine positioning => reduces placental perfusion Less accurate FHR detection in obese women May pick up maternal heart rate artifact Cannot measure uterine contraction intensity—only frequency and duration May need frequent repositioning due to fetal/maternal movement Less reliable in multiples (twins, etc.) for higher risk labor: multiple gestation, decreased fetal movement, abnormal FHR, Preeclampsia, etc spiral electrode into the fetal presenting part, usually the parietal bone on the head pressure transducer placed internally within the uterus to record uterine contractions Pros More accurate FHR detection; less artifact Measures true uterine contraction intensity with IUPC Not affected by maternal position or movement Directly records beat-to-beat variability Cons Requires ROM (artificial or spontaneous) Requires cervical dilation ≥2 cm Invasive—risk of infection and uterine perforation Contraindicated in cases of placenta previa, herpes, HIV, hepatitis Potential fetal injury from electrode placement CRITERIA FOR INTERNAL MONITORING: Ruptured membranes Cervical dilation ≥2 cm Presenting part engaged (not floating) No maternal infections (e.g., HIV, herpes) Skilled provider available

item.title: VEAL-CHOP
item.description: FOR DECELARTIONs ONLY

item.title: Fetal Heart Monitoring Cheat Sheet
item.description: 1 second = 1 mm ÷ (3 cm/min) = 0.2 cm/sec So, every 1 mm (small box) on the paper = 10 seconds 6 small boxes (1 cm) = 60 seconds / 1 minute A 10-minute strip is typically 30 cm long 1 Red Line Divider = 1 minute 1 small box = 10 secondsCategory I: Normal Baseline rate: 110–160 bpm Baseline variability: moderate (6–25 bpm) No late or variable decelerations Early decelerations: present or absent Accelerations: present or absent → Indicates normal fetal acid-base status; no intervention needed. Category II: Indeterminate Includes any tracing not categorized as I or III Examples: Bradycardia with variability Tachycardia Minimal, absent, or marked variability Absence of accelerations after stimulation Recurrent variable decels with minimal/moderate variability → Requires close monitoring and clinical evaluation. Category III: Abnormal - LV "luis vitton" => late & variable decels Absent variability and any of the following: Recurrent late decelerations Recurrent variable decelerations Bradycardia Sinusoidal pattern → Indicates abnormal fetal acid-base status; requires prompt intervention (e.g., oxygen, repositioning, delivery if unresolved). Fluctuations in the baseline FHR that are irregular in amplitude and frequency Reflects the interplay between sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems Key indicator of fetal well-being 1. Absent No detectable fluctuations May indicate fetal hypoxia, acidosis, or neurologic depression Concerning—requires immediate evaluation prepare for emergency delivery 2. Minimal Amplitude range: ≤5 bpm Causes: sleep cycle, sedation (e.g., opioids, magnesium sulfate), prematurity, or hypoxia Evaluate context and other FHR patterns 3. Moderate (Normal) Amplitude range: 6–25 bpm Indicates well-oxygenated fetus with intact CNS Most reassuring variability 4. Marked Amplitude: >25 bpm Causes: acute hypoxia, fetal stimulation, or cord compression May be transient but warrants monitoring Moderate variability = reassuring Absent/minimal = concerning when persistent, especially with decels or bradycardia Marked = assess for cause, monitor for fetal stress1. Early Decelerations Cause: Head compression (normal response during contractions) Timing: Mirrors the contraction; nadir aligns with peak Appearance: Gradual onset/return, uniform shape Significance: still type 1!, benign, usually not concerning 2. Variable Decelerations Cause: Umbilical cord compression Timing: Abrupt onset; varies in timing with contractions Appearance: Sharp drop (V, U, or W shaped), quick recovery Significance: May require intervention if recurrent or severe 3. Late Decelerations Cause: Uteroplacental insufficiency (e.g., hypoxia, hypertension, post-dates) Timing: Begins after contraction starts; nadir after peak Appearance: Gradual onset/return Significance: Concerning—indicates fetal distress, requires evaluation and possible intervention Late decels = LIONS (L → Left side, I → IV fluids, O → Oxygen, N → Notify provider, S → Stop oxytocin) 4. Prolonged Decelerations Cause: Interruption in fetal oxygen (e.g., cord prolapse, hypotension, uterine rupture) Timing: Lasts 2–10 minutes Appearance: Sharp drop, sustained Significance: Emergent—requires prompt evaluation and action
item.guid: OB/i. Fetal Monitoring/Fetal Heart Monitoring Cheat Sheet.md

item.title: Factors Affecting Labor Process
item.description: Chapter 13: Labor and Birth Process (Ricci) Original 5 P's Passageway Passenger Powers Position Psychological Response birth canal Pelvis: must be at least 11.5 cm diagonal conjugate, true conjugate 10cm or more Soft Tissues: must efface (thin out) Pelvic Floor muscles => help rotate fetus during labor (Kegels!) Pelvic Shapes: Gynecoid - "G for Good", best, round shape, roomy outlet Anthropoid - "Anthro = average", not ideal but better than ANDROID or PLATYPELLOID Android - "male robot = male pelvis"; funnel shape, not good, usually C-section Platypelloid (flat) - least common, not good HEAD largest part cranial sutures & soft fontanelle = >help head elongate with pressure overlapping sutures = molding; elongated Caput succedaneum - edema of the scalp at the presenting part (resolves in 3-4 days) Cephalohematoma - Collection of blood between the periosteum and the bone that occurs several hours after birth. Fetal Attitude posturing or FLEXION or EXTESION of joints FULL FLEXION - good; more compressed body FETAL LIE - relationship of long spin to spine of motherLIE to LTO longitudinal - parallel to maternal spine transverse oblique - fetal long axis is at an angle to the bony inlet FETAL PRESENTATION - part that is peeking out of the vajayjay Cephalic - head first; more common 1. Vertex - occipital lobe first; most preferred 2. Military 3. Brow - Largest diameter presents; labor often does not progress; usually requires C-section 4. Face - May cause facial edema, bruising; larger presenting diameter makes vaginal delivery challenging. Breech - pelvis first; umbilical cord can compress; largest part last; risk for birth trauma, head entrapment, often c-section Frank Breech - baby's legs are straight up in front, with the feet near the head, and the buttocks present first. Complete - knees bent Single Footling - one foot down Double Footling - two feet down Shoulder - scapula first; risk for Shoulder Distocia, cannot be delivered vaginally; high risk of cord prolapse; requires C-section. TURTLE SIGN - neonate’s head slowly extends and emerges over the perineum but then retracts back FETAL POSITION - position in the womb j described by the baby’s head, back, and limbs relative to the mother’s pelvisJay Loa & Roa = baby's most favorable positionLeft Occiput Anterior (LOA)- most favorable Right Occiput Anterior (ROA) - 2nd most favorable Posterior (xOP)- least favorable L or R - left or right O/S/M/A/D - Occupit, Sacrum, Mentum, Acrominion, Dorsal A/P/T - anterior, posterior, transverse FETAL STATION - relationship of the presenting part to the level of the maternal pelvic ischial spines scale of -4 not +4 -4 not engage, +4 crowning, ready to delivery 0 stations - head aligned with ischial spine in pelvis, considered as "engaged" FETAL ENGAGEMENT - largest diameter of the fetal presenting partCARDINAL MOVEMENTS OF LABOR - EDFIREEE Engagement Fetal head enters pelvic inlet (0 station) Indicates head is engaged and labor is progressing normally Descent Head moves deeper into pelvis with contractions and maternal effort Indicates progression toward delivery; continued descent is necessary for successful vaginal birth Flexion Fetal chin tucks to chest, presenting the smallest diameter Allows for easier passage through the pelvis Internal Rotation Head rotates to align with the anteroposterior diameter of the pelvis Proper rotation reduces risk of prolonged labor and aids in head alignment for delivery Extension Fetal head extends as it passes under the pubic symphysis Facilitates delivery of the head; guides provider to prepare for crowning External Rotation (Restitution) Head realigns with shoulders after head is delivered Allows shoulders to align with pelvis; prepares for shoulder delivery Expulsion Shoulders and body are delivered Marks the completion of delivery and transition to newborn care UTERINE CONTRACTIONS - involuntary; responsible for thinning and dilating cervix Effacement - % based on cervical canal length 2 cm = 0% 1 cm = 50% 0 cm = 100%. Dilation Frequency & Duration: early labor => 30 sections, 5-7 minutes apart Intensity - measured by internal intrauterine pressure catheter Contraction Phase: increment - start to peak acme - actual peak decrement - peak to baseline; relaxation of the uterine muscle fibers INTRA-ABDOMINAL PRESSURE - caused by voluntary muscle contractions more pressure, the better expulsion sedation decreases upright maternal positioning uses gravity to bring fetus down, less risk of aorta compression common practice - adopt maternal position of comfort peanut ball can decrease time of labor more emotional support = better

item.title: L&D - Anemia
item.description:
Hemoglobin levels are lower than normal, reducing oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood Most common type is iron-deficiency anemia, but folate and vitamin B12 deficiencies can also occur See also: L&D - Thalassemia => mild form form of anemia that does not respond to iron supplements
L&D - Sickle Cell AnemiaCriteria for Iron-Deficiency Anemia: low hemoglobin (less than 11 g/dL or 110 g/L) low hematocrit (less than 35% or 0.35) low serum iron (less than 30 μg/dL or 5.37 μmol/L) microcytic and hypochromic cells low serum ferritin (less than 100 ng/dL or 100 μg/L) Increased iron demand due to fetal growth Poor dietary intake or absorption of iron, folate, or B12 Blood loss (e.g., GI bleeding, frequent pregnancies close together) Hemoglobinopathies (e.g., sickle cell, thalassemia) Inadequate prenatal nutrition Multiple gestations Close pregnancy spacing Adolescents or underweight individuals History of heavy menstruation or chronic illness Fatigue, weakness, pallor Dizziness or lightheadedness Shortness of breath on exertion Palpitations Headaches Pica Preterm birth Low birth weight Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) Postpartum hemorrhage Increased maternal morbidity intellectual disability CBC showing low hemoglobin and hematocrit Low serum ferritin and iron levels Elevated total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) Peripheral smear for red blood cell morphology Iron supplements (oral ferrous sulfate preferred) => take with Vitamin C side effect: black stool, constipation, nausea, abdominal pain take on empty stomach => if tolerated do not take with coffee, tea, chocolate, high fiber foods Increase dietary iron (red meat, leafy greens, fortified cereals) Vitamin C to enhance iron absorption => orange juice MILK WILL INHIHBIT ABSORPTION Folic acid and B12 supplements if deficient Severe cases may require parenteral iron or transfusion Educate on iron-rich diet and supplement adherence Administer iron between meals with vitamin C Monitor for side effects (constipation, GI upset) Track hemoglobin and ferritin levels over time Reinforce importance of prenatal visits and labs Take iron supplements on an empty stomach if tolerated Avoid taking iron with calcium, dairy, or antacids Include iron-rich foods and stay hydrated Report persistent fatigue, palpitations, or dizziness Follow up for blood work as scheduled

item.title: Placenta Previa
item.description:
Placenta previa occurs when the placenta partially or completely covers the cervical os => opening is covered Major cause of painless third-trimester bleeding Can lead to complications during labor and delivery high risk of prenatal and postpartum hemorrhage, perinatal mortality Actually two subtypes: Low Lying Placenta - placental edge is less than 2 cm from the internal os but does not cover it Placentia Previa proper - covers internal os Abnormal implantation of the placenta in the lower uterine segment Exact cause unknown, but linked to uterine scarring or anomalies Previous placenta previa History of C-Sectionor uterine surgery Multiparity Advanced maternal age - AMA, 35 yo Smoking Multiple gestation infertility treatment previous abortion Painless bright red vaginal bleeding in the second or third trimester => signature symptom
=> note that Placental Abruption is DARK RED BLOOD (KNOW THE DIFFERENCE) Soft, non-tender uterus Normal fetal heart rate unless severe bleeding occurs Often detected on routine ultrasound Hemorrhage Preterm birth Placenta accreta (if previa and scarring co-exist) - placenta attaches too deeply into the uterine wall Fetal growth restriction Emergency cesarean delivery Transvaginal or transabdominal ultrasound confirms placental location Avoid digital vaginal exam if previa suspected Serial ultrasounds used to monitor placental position "wait and see" approach - mom and fetus stable Pelvic rest (no intercourse, tampons, or vaginal exams) Monitor bleeding and fetal well-being Corticosteroids if early delivery is likely Cesarean section if previa persists near term => highly likely Monitor for bleeding and signs of labor Avoid vaginal exams unless previa ruled out Prepare for possible preterm delivery Maintain IV access and blood type/crossmatch if active bleeding
Rhogam if Rh negative at 28 weeks
Tocolytics - MINT if preterm (meds to delay preterm labor by inhibiting contractions)
Potocin / Oxytocin PRN Avoid activities that could trigger bleeding Immediately report any vaginal bleeding Explain importance of follow-up ultrasounds Discuss possible need for cesarean delivery

item.title: Preeclampsia
item.description:
pregnancy-specific hypertensive disorder that typically occurs after 20 weeks of gestation characterized by new-onset hypertension and proteinuria or signs of organ dysfunction. CRITERIA: any BP that is over 140/90 on two separate occasions 2 Stages: Widespread vasospasm high BP Liver Perfusion => decreased (elev. LFTs) Brain Perfusion - decreased (headaches, visual disturbances, high DTR) GFR => decreased (low UOP, high BUN, high Uric acid, high cr => edema) response to abnormal placentation - HTN, proteinuria, HA, N/V, retinal vascular changes (blurred vision), hyperreflexia d/t hypoperfusion Patho: placenta didn't have good vascular connection leaky vessels - protein in blood stream => edema (where protein goes, water goes) Liver and Kidney - damaged d/t protein in blood stream SEVERE PREECLAMPSIA ≥160/110 mmHg (x2, 4 hrs apart) Urine protein ≥ 500mg/24 hours Hyperreflexia Severe edema 💡 Note: “Mild” preeclampsia is better referred to as “without severe features” in updated guidelines. Eclampsia = severe preeclampsia + seizures, with no other identifiable neurologic cause. Exact cause unknown Likely due to abnormal placental development and vascular dysfunction Immune response, genetic, and inflammatory factors contribute First pregnancy (nulliparity) Maternal age <20 or >35 History of pre-eclampsia or family history Multiple gestation (twins, etc.) Chronic hypertension or kidney disease Diabetes mellitus Obesity Autoimmune disorders (e.g., lupus, antiphospholipid syndrome) Blood pressure ≥140/90 mmHg on two occasions 4 hours apart Proteinuria ≥300 mg/24 hours or protein/creatinine ratio ≥0.3 Headache (persistent and severe) Visual disturbances (blurred vision, flashing lights) Upper abdominal pain (especially RUQ) Edema (especially hands and face) Hyperreflexia Sudden weight gain Oliguria Elevated liver enzymes, thrombocytopenia (severe pre-eclampsia) Eclampsia (seizures)
HELLP syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets)
Placental Abruption Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) Preterm labor or delivery Maternal stroke or organ failure Fetal hypoxia or demise
DIC Blood pressure monitoring Urinalysis for proteinuria CBC => platelets may be DECREASED d/t consumption for endothelial damage
very low <100k if it progresses to HELLP (normal is 150-450k) liver function tests => elevated Serum creatinine, uric acid Fetal assessment (NST, BPP, ultrasound for growth) 24-hour urine collection (for definitive proteinuria) Mild cases: Close monitoring, rest, frequent prenatal visits Antihypertensives (e.g., labetalol, hydralazine, nifedipine) Magnesium sulfate to prevent seizures (during labor and 24 hours postpartum) => therapeutic range: 4-7 mEq/L (normal range is 1.5-2.5) Corticosteroids (e.g., betamethasone) to promote fetal lung maturity if preterm delivery likely prenatal low dose aspirin - prevention during 12 weeks GA to delivery for high risk Delivery of placenta => definitive treatment — timing depends on severity and gestational age Mild HTN: bed rest at home => avoid strenuous activity like walking! lateral recumbent position - improve placental blood flow, promote diuresis Monitor BP => q4-6 hours while awake Monitor urine output closely record daily kick counts - report decreased fetal movements Assess for signs of worsening (e.g., headache, vision changes, RUQ pain) Administer meds as ordered (antihypertensives, magnesium sulfate) Maintain seizure precautions Monitor for magnesium toxicity (↓ DTRs, ↓ respirations, hypotension, urine retention) administer calcium gluconate for magnesium toxicity Support fetal monitoring and prep for potential delivery Provide emotional support to patient and family Report symptoms: headache, vision changes, swelling, decreased fetal movement Adhere to follow-up appointments Take prescribed medications as directed Reduce stress and increase rest Understand potential need for hospitalization or early delivery Avoid NSAIDs postpartum (can raise BP further)
