item.title: PROM
item.description: spontaneous rupture of the amniotic sac before the onset of labor If it occurs before 37 weeks, it's referred to as preterm PROM (PPROM) Can lead to complications for both mother and fetus if not managed appropriately Prolonged PROM (>24 hrs) can lead to infection => chorioamnionitis, endometritis, sepsis, neonatal infections NOTE: do not confuse with PPROM!<37wks = preterm 37 weeks = early term 39-40 weeks = full term largely unknown (per ricci) => mostly vaginal bleeding spontaneous Infection (e.g., chorioamnionitis, urinary tract infection) Uterine overdistension (e.g., polyhydramnios, multiple gestation) Cervical insufficiency or trauma Previous preterm birth or PROM Smoking or substance use Prior PROM or preterm birth Genital tract infection or UTIs Short cervical length Low socioeconomic status => no prenatal care Invasive procedures (e.g., amniocentesis) tobacco, drug use History of Placenta Previa, Placenta Previa Cerclage - stitched cervix Amniocentesis Sudden gush or steady leakage of clear fluid from the vagina Absence of contractions initially Fluid may test positive for amniotic markers (e.g., nitrazine, ferning) Risk for infection increases over time Chorioamnionitis Preterm labor and birth Cord prolapse Placental abruption Neonatal infection or sepsis Sterile speculum exam to confirm fluid pooling => inspect only Nitrazine paper test (alkaline pH) => blue=amniotic fluid Fern Test - sample taken, Ferning pattern under microscope Ultrasound for amniotic fluid volume Avoid digital vaginal exams unless delivery is imminent Meconium - fetal distress R/T hypoxia Hospitalization and monitoring (especially with PPROM) Antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent infection Corticosteroids to promote fetal lung maturity if <34 weeks Tocolytics in select cases to delay labor briefly Induction of labor if term and no contraindications Amnioinfusion if indicated per policy Monitor fetal heart rate and signs of infection NO UNSTERILE DIGITAL EXAMS Assess amount, color, and odor of amniotic fluid Limit vaginal exams to reduce infection risk Provide emotional support and education Prepare for potential preterm delivery if PPROM Report fever, foul-smelling discharge, or contractions Monitor for decreased fetal movement Importance of follow-up and hospitalization if ordered Avoid sexual activity and insertion of anything into the vagina Understand risks and signs of preterm labor Activity restrictions Record daily kick counts Take temp daily

item.title: Hypertensive Disorders of Pregnancy
item.description:
Overview Chronic Hypertension - (ObGyn) - exists prior to pregnancy or develops before 20 weeks gestation, BP more than 140/90
Gestational Hypertension - new-onset blood pressure elevation (140/90 mm Hg) identified after 20 weeks’ gestation without proteinuria; blood pressure returns to normal by 12 weeks’ postpartum
Preeclampsia & HELLP develops with proteinuria after 20 weeks’ gestation accompanied by at least 1: proteinuria elevated creatinine - decreased renal perfusion due to vasoconstriction and endothelial dysfunction. liver involvement - hepatic endothelial injury causing fibrin deposition and periportal hemorrhage. epigastric pain - stretching of Glisson’s capsule from hepatic swelling and subcapsular hematoma. neuro complications - Cerebral edema and vasospasm causing headaches, visual changes, or seizures. hematologic complications - microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and platelet consumption from endothelial activation. uteroplacental dysfunction - impaired trophoblast invasion and spiral artery remodeling leading to placental ischemia.
Eclampsia - seizure activity develops
Chronic hypertension with superimposed preeclampsia - develops after 20 weeks gestations
item.guid: OB/ii. Pregnancy/High Risk/Hypertensive Disorders/Hypertensive Disorders of Pregnancy.md

item.title: Hemorrhage
item.description: obstetric hemorrhage - highest mortality in pregnancy and childbirth can occur early or late Spontaneous abortion - unintentional loss of pregnancy before 20 weeks Uterine fibroids - benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterus Ectopic pregnancy - implantation of fertilized egg outside the uterus Gestational trophoblastic disease - abnormal growth of trophoblastic tissue during pregnancy Cervical insufficiency - premature cervical dilation leading to pregnancy loss Placenta previa - placenta covers all or part of the cervical opening Placental abruption - premature separation of the placenta from the uterus Placenta accreta - abnormal attachment of placenta into the uterine wall Oxytocin - stimulates uterine contractions to reduce bleeding; monitor for uterine tone, assess for water intoxication and hypotension Ergometrine - causes sustained uterine contractions to control hemorrhage; monitor blood pressure closely, contraindicated in hypertension Prostaglandins - promote uterine contraction and vasoconstriction; assess for fever, nausea, vomiting, and monitor for bronchospasm in asthmatic patients Balloon tamponade - inserts device into uterus to apply pressure and stop bleeding; monitor for proper placement, bleeding control, and signs of infection or uterine rupture Compression sutures - stitches placed to compress uterus and control bleeding; monitor for return of uterine tone, bleeding, and potential complications from impaired uterine perfusion Arterial ligation - surgical tying of uterine or pelvic arteries to reduce blood flow; monitor for hemodynamic stability, assess for signs of ischemic complications and ongoing bleeding

item.title: Nursing Management
item.description:
high-touch, low-tech care admission history: - EDD - prmonitory labor signs experienced - GTPAL - contractions description, ROM - suport lab results: GBS, HIV birth plan physical assessment: - Leopold Maneuvers - Fundal Height - FHR - Vaginal Exam nurses should not be controlling this stage of labor but rather empowering women to achieve a satisfying experience Goal: direct patient to push to shorten second stage
assess Perineal Lacerations Episiotomy - incision made to enlarge vaginal outlet midline - most common; least amount of pain right and left mediolateral
assess for Placental Separation
assess for Perineal Trauma Goals: close observation for hemorrhage provision of comfort measures promotion of family attachment. Vitals - q15min for first hour, then q30 for next hour if needed

item.title: Perineal Trauma
item.description: Firm fundus with bright red blood trickling: laceration Boggy fundus with red blood flowing: uterine atony (need pit) Boggy fundus with dark blood and clots: retained placenta Inspecting the perineum for condition of episiotomy if performed Assessing for perineal lacerations and ensuring repair by birth attendant

item.title: Placental Separation
item.description: Occurs during Third Stage of LaborSigns of Placental Separation: Firmly contracting uterus Change in uterine shape from discoid to globular ovoid Sudden gush of dark blood from vaginal opening Lengthening of umbilical cord protruding from vagina

item.title: Stages of Labor
item.description: Notes: sedation can increase duration of dilation process primagravida - 1st stage of labor can last up to 20 hours Epidural - dulls the urge to push Fundus should be firm and well contracted at 4th stage; massage it if boggy

item.title: True vs False Labor
item.description: 411 or 511 rule - contractions 4–5 minutes apart, lasting 1 minute each, and persisting for at least 1 hour). come to the hospital!

item.title: Pain Management in Labor
item.description: onset - within minutes and lasts for several hours complication: respiratory depression Opioids: morphine, demerol, fentanyl can cross placenta Antiemetics: hydroxyzine, promethazine, Compazine Benzodiazepines Midazolam/Versed - amnesia effect, adjunct for anesthesia Diazepam - enhance pain relief, sedation Inhaled Analgesics - nitrous oxide, self-administered => empowering, less perception of pain local anesthetic agents with or without added opioids to bring about pain relief or numbness through the drug’s effects on the spinal cord and nerve roots pain relief without loss of consciousness usually T8 to T10 The woman can participate in the birthing process and still have good pain control administration of opioids or anesthetics into the epidural or intrathecal space small catheter is then passed through the epidural needle Epidural analgesia increases the duration of the second stage of labor meds: combination of lidocaine anesthetic, opioid analgesic Contraindication: receiving anticoagulants indwelling epidural catheter with an infusion of medication and a programmed pump allows patient controlled dosing injection of local anesthetic into the superficial perineal nerves to numb the perineal area injection of a local anesthetic agent into the pudendal nerves near each ischial spine provides pain relief in the lower vagina, vulva, and perineum injection of an anesthetic “caine” agent with or without opioids into the subarachnoid space usually used in c-sections contraindications: bleeding precautions intrathecal narcotics state of unconsciousness and insensitivity to pain during surgery Usually: barbiturate + propofol (unconsciousness) + muscle relaxant crosses placenta Complications: fetal depression, uterine relaxation, vomiting/aspiration, inability to intubate Considerations: ensure NPO, IV line, administer clear oral antacid or PPI and H2 Blockers Ensure placement of wedge on right hip to prevent vena cava compression

item.title: FHR Patterns
item.description: normal: 110-160 BPM see Fetal Heart Monitoring Cheat Sheet Bradycardia below 110 Causes: hypoxia, prolonged maternal hypoglycemia, fetal acidosis, administration of analgesic drugs to the mother, hypothermia, anesthetic agents (epidural), maternal hypotension, fetal hypothermia, prolonged umbilical cord compression, and fetal congenital heart block Tachycardia: greater than 160 Causes: hypoxia, maternal fever, maternal dehydration, amnionitis, drugs (e.g., cocaine, amphetamines, nicotine), maternal hyperthyroidism, maternal anxiety, fetal anemia, prematurity, fetal infection, chronic hypoxemia, congenital anomalies, fetal heart failure, and fetal arrhythmias Can be an ominous sign if it is accompanied by a decrease in variability and late decelerations clinical indicator that is predictive of fetal acid–base balance and cerebral tissue perfusion Key indicator of fetal well-being 1. Absent No detectable fluctuations May indicate fetal hypoxia, acidosis, or neurologic depression Concerning—requires immediate evaluation prepare for emergency delivery 2. Minimal Amplitude range: ≤5 bpm Causes: sleep cycle, sedation (e.g., opioids, magnesium sulfate), prematurity, or hypoxia Evaluate context and other FHR patterns 3. Moderate (Normal) Amplitude range: 6–25 bpm Indicates well-oxygenated fetus with intact CNS Most reassuring variability 4. Marked Amplitude: >25 bpm Causes: acute hypoxia, fetal stimulation, or cord compression May be transient but warrants monitoring

item.title: Intermittent FHR with Doppler
item.description: Periodic assessment of fetal heart rate (FHR) using handheld Doppler or fetoscope Uses ultrasound waves to detect fetal heart echoes Acceptable for low-risk laboring women Promotes mobility and physiologic birth Allows maternal mobility during labor Less restrictive than continuous EFM Encourages natural labor progression Cannot detect variability or types of decelerations Does not provide a continuous record of fetal status May miss transient or late decelerations Use Leopold maneuvers to locate fetal back Apply water-soluble gel to abdomen Place Doppler in lower abdominal quadrant (cephalic) or umbilicus level (breech) Palpate maternal radial pulse to differentiate from maternal HR Baseline FHR: auscultate for 1 minute after contraction Routine checks: 30 seconds x 2 (if no changes) Initial: 10-20 min continuous FHR upon admission Low-risk active labor: q30min High-risk active labor: q15min Second stage low-risk: q15min Second stage high-risk: q5min Assess FHR before and after vaginal exams, ROM, meds, ambulation Monitor FHR after position changes, pain meds, or other interventions FHR may shift location as fetus descends Not recommended for undiagnosed high-risk labor Safe for low-risk women with no evidence of fetal compromise Does not replace continuous monitoring for high-risk cases Late decels: best detected by listening at end of contraction Chorioamnionitis: monitor for maternal fever & fetal tachycardia Document: FHR baseline, rhythm, rate, and maternal VS For low-risk patients, no difference in Apgar or outcomes vs. continuous EFM
item.guid: OB/iii. Labor/Assessments - Fetal/Intermittent FHR with Doppler.md

item.title: Amniotic Fluid Analysis
item.description: Amniotic fluid analysis involves assessing fluid obtained from ruptured membranes (spontaneous or artificial) during labor Helps evaluate fetal well-being, infection, and labor progression Confirm membrane rupture Assess fetal lung maturity (if indicated, but usually done antenatally) Evaluate infection risk (chorioamnionitis) Identify meconium presence (fetal distress) Color Clear/slightly cloudy: normal Greenish/brown: meconium-stained → possible fetal distress or post-term Yellow: hemolytic disease (Rh incompatibility) Red: possible abruption or bleeding Odor Foul smell = chorioamnionitis (infection) Volume Oligohydramnios: <500 mL at term → risk of cord compression, growth restriction Polyhydramnios: >2000 mL at term → risk of prolapsed cord, preterm labor pH/Nitrazine test pH > 6.5 = amniotic fluid (alkaline) Vaginal secretions = acidic (pH 4.5–5.5) Ferning test Microscopic exam shows fern pattern → confirms rupture of membranes Leukocytes Elevated WBC (>30/mm³) → infection Nitrazine paper turns blue if fluid is alkaline (ruptured membranes) Fern test: Dry fluid on slide → microscopic fern-like crystals Meconium-stained fluid = fetal stress; may need neonatal resuscitation Cloudy, foul-smelling fluid = possible infection → start antibiotics Explain procedure and obtain informed consent if needed Use sterile gloves when collecting samples to prevent infection Document color, odor, amount, and time of rupture Monitor for infection: maternal fever, fetal tachycardia, uterine tenderness Notify provider immediately if meconium is present → risk of meconium aspiration syndrome Prepare for neonatal resuscitation if meconium-stained fluid Teach patient to report changes in color, odor, or amount of fluid Reinforce hand hygiene and peri-care after fluid leaks Prolonged rupture (>18 hours) → increased risk of infection → monitor for chorioamnionitis Yellow fluid → think Rh hemolytic disease Always confirm ferning test before assuming membranes have ruptured Blue Nitrazine paper alone can yield false positives (e.g., blood, semen) → confirm with ferning test

item.title: Leopold Maneuvers
item.description: Systematic abdominal palpation technique to determine fetal lie, presentation, position, and engagement Essential tool in prenatal assessment starting around 28 weeks gestation Helps guide delivery planning and monitor fetal well-being First Maneuver (Fundal Grip) Palpate top of uterus (fundus) to identify fetal part (head = hard/round/moveable; buttocks = soft/irregular) Second Maneuver (Lateral Grip) Palpate sides of uterus to locate fetal back (smooth/firm) vs. small parts (limbs, irregular) Third Maneuver (Pawlik’s Grip) Grasp just above symphysis pubis to determine presenting part (head or breech) and mobility Fourth Maneuver (Pelvic Grip) Facing mother’s feet, slide hands down sides of uterus to assess fetal descent into pelvis and attitude of head (flexed = easier delivery; extended = possible complications) Lie: Relationship of fetus’s spine to mother’s spine (longitudinal/transverse/oblique) Presentation: Part of fetus that enters pelvis first (cephalic/breech/shoulder) Position: Relationship of presenting part to maternal pelvis (e.g., LOA) Attitude: Fetal flexion/extension Head = hard, round, moves independently Buttocks = soft, irregular, moves with trunk Back = smooth, firm Limbs = small, irregular, kicking Explain procedure to patient; ensure privacy and comfort Ask patient to empty bladder to improve accuracy Position patient supine with knees flexed and slight head elevation* Use warm hands to avoid discomfort Perform fetal heart rate monitoring before and after maneuvers to ensure fetal well-being Document findings: lie, presentation, position, engagement Remember accuracy decreases with obesity, polyhydramnios, anterior placenta, or multiple gestation Recognize LOA (left occiput anterior) as most common, optimal position for delivery Engagement means the presenting part has passed the pelvic inlet (station 0) Flexed head = easier vaginal delivery; deflexed head may cause complications Never perform Leopold maneuvers during contractions (wait until relaxation phase)

item.title: Vaginal Exam
item.description: Chapter 13 - Ricci Text book Nursing Management During Labor and Birth => Maternal Assessment During Labor & Birth vaginal exam or U/S if not bleeding upon admission Assess: Dilation Effacement Fetal Membrane Status Presentation Position Station Degree of fetal head flexion presence of skull swelling or molding Position - on her back Sterile technique Insert index and middle fingers Measures how open the cervix is (0–10 cm) 10 cm = fully dilated and ready for pushing 0 cm: external cervical os is closed 5 cm: external cervical os is halfway dilated 10 cm: external os is fully dilated and ready for birth passage Thinning and shortening of the cervix Expressed as a percentage 0%: cervical canal is 2 cm long 50%: cervical canal is 1 cm long 100%: cervical canal is obliterated Refers to fetal head position relative to ischial spines Measured from -5 (high) to +4 (crowning) 0 station = at ischial spines Describes fetal presenting part’s orientation in the pelvis Includes occiput anterior (OA), posterior (OP), or transverse (OT) OA is most favorable for vaginal birth Indicates whether amniotic sac is intact or ruptured Document as "intact" or "ruptured" Note color, odor, and time of rupture if applicable Nitrazine Yellow Swab: => Yellow = acidic; vaginal fluid => Blue = basic; amniotic fluid

item.title: Uterine Contractions
item.description: Frequency – Time from the start of one contraction to the start of the next; measured in minutes Duration – Length of a single contraction from start to end; measured in seconds Intensity – Strength of contraction (mild, moderate, strong); assessed by palpation or internal monitor (IUPC) => Mild - tip of the nose => Moderate - like chin => Strong - like forehead IUPC - 30 mmHg or greater => cervical dilation Resting tone – Pressure in the uterus between contractions; should remain soft; assessed by palpation or IUPC Pattern – Evaluate for regularity, adequate recovery time, and tachysystole (more than 5 contractions in 10 minutes)

item.title: Premonitory Signs of Labor
item.description: cervical softening and possible cervical dilation descent of presenting par elongated cervix to shortened, thinned segment ripening and softening fetal presenting part begins to descend into the true pelvis uterus lowers and moves into a more anterior position breathing much easier Increased pelvic pressure, leg cramping, dependent edema in the lower legs, and low back discomfort increase in vaginal discharge and more frequent urination nesting 24-48 hours before onset of laborsmall amount of blood mixed with mucus => pink-tinged secretions mucus plug that fills the cervical canal during pregnancy is expelledfelt as a tightening or pulling sensation of the top of the uterus primarily in the abdomen and groin and gradually spread downward before relaxing NOTE: TRUE LABOR CONTRACTIONS are in the LOWER BACK reshape the cervix: ripen and shorten, more anteriorloss of amniotic fluid prior to the onset of labor only occurs in 8-10% of pregnancies barrier to infection is gone and an ascending infection is possible increased risk of cord prolapse!

item.title: Amniotic Fluid Embolism
item.description:
Rare, life-threatening obstetric emergency Amniotic fluid enters maternal circulation, triggering systemic inflammatory and anaphylactoid reaction Amniotic fluid, fetal cells, hair, or other debris enter maternal bloodstream, usually during labor, delivery, or shortly postpartum Advanced maternal age Multiple gestation Placenta Previa, Placental Abruption
Eclampsia
C-Section or instrumental delivery => Forceps or Vacuum Assisted Birth
Uterine Rupture Induction of labor Sudden shortness of breath => signature first sign Hypotension Cyanosis
Pulmonary Edema Tachycardia Seizures Altered mental status Cardiac arrest
Coagulopathy or DIC => bleeding Uterine atony and massive hemorrhage Cardiopulmonary collapse Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) Multi-organ failure Neurologic injury Maternal death Fetal distress or death Clinical diagnosis based on sudden onset of symptoms Rule out other causes (e.g., pulmonary embolism, anaphylaxis) Lab: Coagulation studies (may show DIC), ABGs (hypoxemia), CBC Imaging: Chest X-ray or echocardiogram to rule out other conditions Immediate supportive care Oxygen, mechanical ventilation Hemodynamic support with IV fluids and vasopressors Blood products for coagulopathy Emergency delivery if not yet delivered ICU monitoring Rapid recognition and activation of emergency response Maintain airway and breathing Administer oxygen and assist with intubation if needed Monitor vital signs and fetal heart tones Initiate IV access and fluid resuscitation Prepare for emergency C-section Administer blood products and medications per orders Emotional support to family Very rare and unpredictable condition Emphasis on close monitoring in high-risk pregnancies Provide information post-event to help with psychological recovery Encourage follow-up care and mental health support

item.title: Uterine Rupture
item.description: Full-thickness tear through the uterine wall, often at a previous cesarean scar, that can result in life-threatening maternal and fetal complications. It is a rare obstetric emergency requiring immediate surgical intervention. Previous cesarean delivery (especially classical incision) Trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC) Trauma (e.g., motor vehicle accident) Overdistended uterus (e.g., polyhydramnios, macrosomia) Excessive uterine stimulation (oxytocin or prostaglandins) Obstructed labor Previous uterine surgery (cesarean, myomectomy) High parity Induction or augmentation of labor Multifetal gestation Congenital uterine anomalies FETAL DISTRESS (e.g., bradycardia, decelerations) Sudden, severe abdominal pain unrelieved by contractions Vaginal bleeding Loss of fetal station Cessation of uterine contractions Maternal tachycardia, hypotension, or signs of shock Fetal hypoxia, brain injury, or death Maternal hemorrhage Hysterectomy Infection Maternal death Based on clinical signs and symptoms Fetal heart rate monitoring for sudden abnormalities Ultrasound may help in some cases Confirmed surgically Immediate emergency cesarean section Blood transfusion if needed Possible hysterectomy if bleeding is uncontrollable Intensive care support for mother and neonate Recognize early warning signs (sudden pain, fetal distress) Notify provider immediately Discontinue oxytocin if in use Monitor vital signs and fetal heart rate Prepare for rapid surgical intervention Support patient and family emotionally Document all observations and interventions Discuss risks if considering VBAC (vaginal birth after cesarean) Educate on signs of uterine rupture during labor Emphasize importance of hospital birth with prior uterine surgery Review future pregnancy planning and surgical history implications

item.title: Umbilical Cord Prolapse
item.description:
Umbilical cord slips ahead of the presenting fetal part, typically after membrane rupture, leading to cord compression and impaired fetal oxygenation. It is an obstetric emergency! CALL FOR MORE RESOURCES ASAP! DO NOT LEAVE PATIENT Requiring immediate intervention to prevent fetal hypoxia or death. Premature rupture of membranes Malpresentation (breech, transverse lie) Polyhydramnios Long umbilical cord Multiple gestation High station at time of membrane rupture External cephalic version
Pre-Term Labor Low birth weight Multiparity Pelvic tumors or uterine abnormalities Artificial rupture of membranes (amniotomy) Sudden fetal bradycardia or decelerations after ROM Visible or palpable cord in or outside the vagina Cord may protrude from the introitus Reports of cord pulsations or pressure Fetal hypoxia or anoxia Stillbirth or neonatal death Emergency cesarean delivery Maternal distress or trauma Visual inspection or vaginal exam reveals cord in vagina Continuous fetal monitoring shows bradycardia or variable decelerations Ultrasound may confirm cord position if not palpable Immediate manual elevation of presenting fetal part off the cord per Petitte: keep your hand in the vagina to open cervix => "apply vertical pressure to presenting part" Place mother in knee-chest, SIMS, or Trendelenburg position Administer oxygen and IV fluids Do not attempt to push cord back inside Prepare for emergency cesarean section Minimize cord handling to prevent vasospasm Prepare for imminent C-section Stay with the patient and call for emergency assistance Reposition mother to relieve cord pressure Monitor fetal heart tones continuously Provide emotional support and updates Assist with rapid transport to OR for cesarean Document time of ROM, cord prolapse, and interventions

item.title: Pre-Term Labor
item.description:
The Onset of regular uterine contractions causing cervical changes (dilation and/or effacement) before 37 weeks of gestation. It increases the risk of neonatal complications due to immature organ development. Pre-Term - 37wks or younger Full Term - 39-40wks +6d Post-Term Labor - 42wks + Infections (e.g., UTIs, chorioamnionitis) Multiple gestation Placental abnormalities Uterine overdistention Trauma or stress Smoking, substance abuse History of preterm birth Short cervical length Incompetent cervix Low socioeconomic status Limited prenatal care Maternal age extremes (<17 or >35) Uterine contractions (more than 6/hour) Pelvic pressure or menstrual-like cramps Lower back pain Vaginal discharge or spotting Cervical dilation and/or effacement Preterm birth Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome Intraventricular hemorrhage Necrotizing enterocolitis Long-term neurodevelopmental delays death Fetal fibronectin test Cervical length via transvaginal ultrasound Vaginal/cervical cultures Urinalysis for infection Electronic fetal monitoring
Tocolytics - MINT (e.g., nifedipine, indomethacin) to suppress labor (2-7 days only) => usually before 34 weeks => only delays, not treat pre-term birth
=> contraindicated: Placental Abruption, Preeclampsia / Eclampsia, active vaginal bleeding, PROM, fetal distress, and more Corticosteroids (e.g., betamethasone) to accelerate fetal lung maturity Magnesium sulfate for neuroprotection <32 weeks => reduces muscle contraction strength Indocin (indomethacin, cyclooxygenase inhibitr) - reduces prostaglandin synthesis
Antibiotics prophylaxis for GBS Positive Bed rest or activity restriction (individualized) Pelvic Rest - no vaginal exam Monitor uterine activity and fetal heart rate Administer and monitor response to tocolytics and corticosteroids Ensure hydration and manage underlying conditions (e.g., infections) Provide emotional support and prepare for possible NICU care Educate on signs of preterm labor and when to seek care stop whatever you are doing empty bladder lie down on left side drink 2-3 glasses of water note contraction strength and notify provider Recognize signs of preterm labor (contractions, pressure, discharge) Importance of hydration and avoiding heavy activity Medication instructions if discharged on tocolytics Keep prenatal appointments and follow restrictions as advised Discuss NICU and neonatal outcomes if preterm birth is likely

item.title: Shoulder Distocia
item.description: an obstetric emergency fetal anterior shoulder becomes lodged behind the maternal pubic bone during delivery delaying birth after the head is delivered. Large fetal size (macrosomia) Maternal diabetes Prolonged labor Excessive maternal weight gain History of shoulder dystocia in previous delivery Short maternal stature => small pelvis Maternal Age over 35 => decreased uterine efficiency Breech fetal presentation Gestational diabetes - big baby Obesity - big baby Post-term pregnancy - big baby Previous shoulder dystocia Instrumental delivery (forceps or vacuum) Head delivers but shoulders fail to follow Turtle sign (retraction of the fetal head against the perineum) Prolonged second stage of labor Fetal distress (abnormal heart rate) Fetal: Brachial plexus injury (Erb’s palsy) Clavicle or humerus fracture Hypoxia, brain injury, or death Maternal: Postpartum hemorrhage Vaginal or perineal lacerations Uterine rupture (rare) Immediate maneuvers to relieve shoulder impaction (McRoberts maneuver, suprapubic pressure) Episiotomy to enlarge the vaginal opening Delivery of posterior arm Advanced maneuvers or emergency cesarean if unsuccessful Recognize and report shoulder dystocia immediately Prepare for neonatal resuscitation Assist with positioning and application of maneuvers Provide emotional support to mother and family Document the event, interventions, and outcomes thoroughly DO NOT PROVIDE ABDOMINAL PRESSURE

item.title: Tachysystole
item.description: Definition – More than 5 uterine contractions in 10 minutes, averaged over 30 minutes Causes – Excessive oxytocin (Pitocin), uterine stimulants, spontaneous labor hyperstimulation Risks – Fetal hypoxia, uterine rupture, placental abruption, decreased fetal oxygenation Assessment – Frequent contractions with little rest, fetal heart rate changes (late decels, bradycardia), increased uterine tone Nursing Interventions Stop or reduce oxytocin infusion Reposition mother (left lateral) Administer oxygen via face mask (8–10 L/min) IV fluid bolus Notify provider Prepare for emergency interventions if unresolved Monitoring – Continuous fetal heart rate and contraction pattern via external or internal monitor

item.title: Vulnerable Populations
item.description:
very less likely to get prenatal care => high risk no resources no knowledge of sexual heath, contraception => unplanned pregnancies Advanced Maternal Age = over 35 Same assessment as any pregnant woman Amniocentesis & Genetic Screenings - routinely offered to allow detection of chromosomal abnoysHigher Risk for infertility pregnancy loss fetal abnormalities still birth Gestational Diabetes
Gestational Hypertension => Preeclampsia small for GA C-section BMI>30
High risk for: everything: Gestational Diabetes, Hypertension, thromboembolism, macrosomia Plan for possible anesthesia complications and fetal monitoring difficulties during labor Encourage thromboprophylaxis postpartum if risk is high Risk for poor prenatal care, intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), fetal anomalies, neonatal abstinence syndrome, placental abruption no prenatal care Alcohol = > Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder - FASD down syndrome cerebral palsy CF, spina bifida SIDS Manifestations: low nasal bridge short nose flat midface short palpebral fissures epicanthal folds minor ear abnormalities thin upper lip receding jaw Opioid - Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome (NAS) => very dangerous irritability, hypertonicity, jitteriness, fever, cry, V/D, etc treatment: oral methadone + psycotherapy Nursing Considerations: Use trauma-informed, nonjudgmental approach Screen with validated tools (CRAFFT) Provide referrals to addiction services and social work Monitor fetal growth and signs of withdrawal in newborn Caffeine - keep less than 200 mg/day

item.title: Cardiac Arrest
item.description: Uterine displacement in second half of pregnancy Defibrillation paddles must be placed one rib space higher.Lacerations of liver or spleen Fracture of sternum or ribs If CPR is not effective within 4 to 5 minutes, consider perimortem cesarean birth.

item.title: Cardiac Tamponade
item.description:
A life-threatening condition caused by excess fluid accumulation in the pericardial sac, compressing the heart and impairing its ability to pump blood. Leads to decreased cardiac output, hypotension, and potential cardiovascular collapse. Considered a medical emergency requiring immediate intervention Normal Fluid: 15-50 mL, CT = 200-300 mL MOST COMMON: percutaneous cardiac interventions, MI complications, aortic dissection, pericarditis Trauma: Blunt or penetrating chest injury Pericarditis: Inflammation leading to fluid accumulation. Malignancy: Metastatic cancer invading the pericardium. Myocardial infarction (MI) complications: Ventricular wall rupture. Aortic dissection: tearing of aorta, Blood leaks into the pericardium. Cardiac surgery or invasive procedures: Postoperative bleeding, central line placements, pCI Uremia: Kidney failure leading to pericardial effusion. History of pericarditis or pericardial effusion Recent cardiac surgery or trauma Connective tissue disorders (e.g., lupus, rheumatoid arthritis) Advanced malignancy (lung, breast, lymphoma)
ESRD (leading to uremic pericarditis) Anticoagulation therapy (increased risk of pericardial bleeding) HIV+ Beck's Triad => Classic sign: hypotension, JVD, muffled heart sounds Pulsus paradoxus: A drop in systolic BP >10 mmHg during inspiration. Ewart's sign: dullness with bronchial breath sounds auscultated just below the scapula area Tachycardia & hypotension: Compensatory response to reduced cardiac output. Dyspnea & tachypnea: Due to poor oxygenation and pulmonary congestion. Weak peripheral pulses: Reduced perfusion. Cool, clammy skin: Signs of circulatory collapse.
Cardiogenic Shock leading to multi-organ failure (MODS)
Med-Surg/Cardiovascular/Cardiac Arrest due to severe heart compression PEA Pulmonary edema from fluid backup Death if untreated echocardiogram => gold standard, shows extent of effusion and compression ECG CXR - "watter bottle" appearance Hemodynamic monitoring cardiac catherization pericardiocentesis - needle drainage of pericardial fluid pericardial window - surgical drainage supportive: IVF, vasopressors Treat the cause: abx, chemo, dialysis for uremic pericarditis Vasopressors elevate legs to increase venous return
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing

item.title: Misopristol
item.description: synthetic prostaglandin E1 analog used for GI and OB indications promotes gastric mucosa protection induces uterine contractions - cervical ripening more indicated for inducing labor than Oxytocin prevention of NSAID-induced gastric ulcers induction of labor medical termination of pregnancy (with mifepristone) postpartum hemorrhage treatment binds prostaglandin receptors in stomach and uterus decreases gastric acid secretion increases bicarbonate and mucus secretion stimulates uterine smooth muscle contractions pregnancy (if used for ulcer prevention) hypersensitivity to prostaglandins prior uterine surgery or C-section (for labor induction) cardiovascular disease (relative, caution advised) abdominal cramps diarrhea nausea flatulence headache uterine rupture (especially with prior uterine surgery) severe bleeding or incomplete abortion hypotension allergic reactions confirm pregnancy status before use for ulcers educate patient on expected effects if used for induction monitor uterine activity and fetal heart rate if used in OB assess GI symptoms and hydration status instruct patient to take with food to reduce GI upset category X for pregnancy (unless used intentionally for OB purposes) use effective contraception during treatment for ulcers black box warning: not for pregnancy use unless indicated must be administered with careful monitoring in obstetric use educate patient on complete medication regimen if used for abortion

item.title: Chronic Hypertension - (ObGyn)
item.description:
more than 140/90 BEFORE pregnancy or 20 weeks gestation should be monitored for Preeclampsia also called pre-existing
if it is after 20 weeks => Gestational Hypertension140-149 sys - mild/moderate => no treatment 160+ sys => treat d/t risk for stroke or acute renal failure main: lifestyle meds => severe hypertension Labetalol Hydralazine Nifedipine Low-dose aspirin (81mg/day) after 12 weeks => preventative

item.title: Chronic hypertension with superimposed preeclampsia
item.description: has high BP but developed other end-organ damage
item.guid: OB/ii. Pregnancy/High Risk/Hypertensive Disorders/Chronic hypertension with superimposed preeclampsia.md

item.title: Placenta Accreta Spectrum
item.description: abnormal adherence of the placenta to the uterine wall Can cause severe bleeding during placental delivery potentially life-threatening due to risk of hemorrhage during labor (manual attempts to detach placenta) Classification: Accreta - attaches to myometrium; most common; highest risk of pp hemorrhage Increta - invades myometrium, goes further in Percreta - penetrates uterus; gone OUTSIDE the uterus => implants to other organs like bladder largely unknown Defective decidua basalis layer during implantation Often associated with scarring from previous uterine surgeries Previous cesarean section (risk increases with number of C-sections) Placenta previa Prior uterine surgery or curettage Advanced maternal age Multiparity Often asymptomatic until delivery May present with bleeding in third trimester if previa is also present Difficulty separating placenta after delivery Massive postpartum hemorrhage Life-threatening hemorrhage Uterine rupture Need for hysterectomy Maternal shock or death Preterm birth Post-partum hemorrhage Usually diagnosed after birth Prenatal diagnosis with ultrasound and MRI => not reliable Signs include loss of clear zone, placental lacunae, and abnormal vascularity High index of suspicion with placenta previa and uterine scar Planned cesarean delivery with possible hysterectomy (C-hyst) Multidisciplinary team (OB, anesthesiology, blood bank) Blood products and surgical prep essential Monitor for prenatal bleeding Prepare patient for potential early delivery and hysterectomy Blood type and crossmatch Support patient and family emotionally Importance of prenatal imaging if at risk Discuss delivery planning and possible hysterectomy Alert signs of bleeding or contractions Emotional support and counseling for fertility loss if hysterectomy needed
item.guid: OB/ii. Pregnancy/High Risk/Placental Disorders/Placenta Accreta Spectrum.md

item.title: Cervical Insufficiency
item.description: aka premature dilation of the cervix Painless cervical dilation during the second trimester Leads to recurrent pregnancy loss or early preterm birth Often asymptomatic until advanced cervical change or membrane rupture largely unknown cervical weakness Congenital cervical or uterine anomalies Prior cervical trauma (e.g., dilation and curettage, cervical surgery) Connective tissue disorders (e.g., Ehlers-Danlos) In-utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES) Previous second-trimester losses without contractions Short cervix noted on ultrasound (<25 mm before 24 weeks) History of cervical surgery (e.g., LEEP, cone biopsy) Multiple gestation Pelvic pressure or vaginal fullness => hallmark sign Increased vaginal discharge Painless cervical dilation => may continue to PROM, contractions delivery Possible vaginal spotting or bulging membranes cramping Funneling - inner OS is starting to open up like a funnel Recurrent second-trimester losses Preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM) Chorioamnionitis Preterm labor Transvaginal ultrasound showing cervical shortening or funneling Cervical length <25 mm before 24 weeks => high RISK of preterm labor History of painless cervical dilation and pregnancy loss Cervical cerclage placement (prophylactic or emergent) - placing a stitch or band around the cervix to prevent it from opening too early during pregnancy Cervical Pessary - a round, silicone device at the mouth of the cervix Progesterone therapy for short cervix Activity and pelvic rest in some cases Serial ultrasound monitoring of cervical length avoid heavy lifting Monitor for pre-term labor: contractions, backache, PROM monitor vaginal bleeding, or signs of infection Provide emotional support after pregnancy loss Post-cerclage care: monitor for signs of rupture or labor Educate on follow-up and lifestyle modifications Avoid heavy lifting, prolonged standing, or intercourse if advised Report symptoms: leaking fluid, pelvic pressure, bleeding, or contractions Adhere to follow-up appointments and cervical length checks Understand cerclage procedure and when to seek emergency care

item.title: Gestational Trophoblastic Disease
item.description:
abnormal cells grow instead of a healthy baby "empty egg" group of rare tumors involving abnormal growth of trophoblastic tissue after conception all male chromosomes - 46 no circulation is established; no baby Most forms are benign, but some can become malignant signature manifestation: HCG levels are present Types: Complete mole – no fetal tissue, empty egg fertilized, benign Partial mole – abnormal fetus/placenta, egg fertilized by two sperm Invasive mole – mole invades uterine wall, local spread Choriocarcinoma – malignant, fast-growing, spreads to lungs/brain Abnormal fertilization of an egg Complete mole: empty egg fertilized by sperm Partial mole: egg fertilized by two sperm or one sperm that duplicates Extremes of maternal age (<20 or >35) History of GTD Nutritional deficiencies (low carotene or folic acid) History of miscarriage Vaginal bleeding in first trimester Uterus larger than expected for gestational age usual pregnancy symptoms fetal parts not evident with palpation Severe nausea and vomiting (hyperemesis gravidarum) Absent fetal heart tones High hCG levels Grape-like vesicles passed vaginally Preeclampsia signs before 20 weeks gestation fluid retention Hemorrhage
Anemia
Hyperthyroidism Trophoblastic embolism Progression to choriocarcinoma increased risk of cancer Transvaginal ultrasound (shows snowstorm or cluster-of-grapes appearance) Quantitative serum hCG (markedly elevated) Chest X-ray to rule out metastasis if malignancy is suspected Histologic examination after uterine evacuation Removal of uterine contents ASAP! D&C - dilation and curettage => remove tissue from uterus Suction curettage for mole removal Serial hCG levels post-evacuation until undetectable (usually 1 year) elevated HCG = tissue still there Chemotherapy if malignant (usually methotrexate) Avoid pregnancy for 1 year during follow-up => can interfere with HCG trends follow-up for 1 year => d/t increased risk of cancer Monitor vaginal bleeding and uterine size Administer Rho(D) immune globulin if Rh-negative Provide emotional support and grief counseling Educate on importance of hCG follow-up Monitor for signs of malignancy Avoid pregnancy during monitoring period Use reliable contraception (oral contraceptives preferred) Report return of symptoms such as bleeding or pelvic pain Follow all lab appointments for hCG testing future pregnancy = possible after close follow-up 1 yr

item.title: Spontaneous Abortion
item.description: most common complication of early pregnancy - usually before week 20 GA loss of fetus from natural causes aka "miscarriage" clarification: "stillbirth" => occurs later in pregnancy fetal genetic abnormalities => usually first semester cervical insufficiency uterine septum or fibroid hypothyroidism diabetes mellitus chronic nephritis substance abuse - alcohol, smoking, drugs thrombophilia lupus polycystic ovary syndrome severe hypertension infections: rubella, cytomegalovirus, HSV, BV, toxoplasmosis history of previous miscarriages maternal age over 35 chronic conditions exposures to environmental toxins vaginal bleeding low back pain abdominal cramping Possible absence of fetal heartbeat on ultrasound Hemorrhage Infection (especially if tissue remains) Emotional distress or grief Future pregnancy complications (depending on cause) Ultrasound to assess fetal viability and contents of uterus Serial hCG levels (typically fall in a non-viable pregnancy) Pelvic exam to check for cervical dilation or passage of tissue CBC and blood type/Rh factor Expectant management (wait for natural passage) Medication (e.g., misoprostol to expel tissue) PGE₂ (Prostaglandin E2, e.g., dinoprostone) - soften and dilate the cervix or induce uterine contractions to evacuate the uterus after spontaneous abortion. administered intravaginally, or cervix => sterile technique After administration, the patient should be monitored for at least 30 minutes to 1 hour for: Uterine response Vital signs Adverse effects such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, fever, or uterine hyperstimulation Dilation and curettage (D&C) if incomplete or excessive bleeding Rh immunoglobulin (Rhogam) if Rh-negative mother assess ASAP: note color, consistency, presence of clot or tissue bright red - concerning provide psychological support r/t loss and grief administer RhoGAM if RH-neg within 72 hours after abortion Ensure Rh status is known and treated accordingly Avoid intercourse and heavy lifting until bleeding stops Monitor for fever, foul-smelling discharge, or increased bleeding Discuss grief and emotional health resources Follow-up appointments for hCG monitoring or ultrasound Wait a recommended time (often 1–3 menstrual cycles) before attempting to conceive again

item.title: Bishop Score
item.description: Max score: 13, Min score: 0 Pharmacologic: Misoprostol (Cytotec), Dinoprostone (Cervidil, Prepidil) Mechanical: Foley balloon catheter, Laminaria

item.title: Fetal Heart Monitoring Lecture
item.description: Use of Internal Fetal Monitor Criteria: Ruptured Membranes Cervical Dilation of at least 2 cm Presenting fetal part low enough to allow placement of the scalp electrode experienced practitioner
item.guid: OB/i. Fetal Monitoring/Fetal Heart Monitoring Lecture.md

item.title: Post-Term Labor
item.description:
Post-term labor refers to a pregnancy that extends beyond 42 weeks of gestation. It increases the risk of complications for both the mother and fetus due to aging placenta and decreased amniotic fluid. Unknown in many cases Miscalculated due date History of post-term pregnancy Obesity Genetic predisposition Nulliparity male fetus Decreased fetal movement Dry, peeling skin of the fetus (if already delivered) Overgrown nails and hair Meconium-stained amniotic fluid Oligohydramnios => amniotic fluid drying up Fetal macrosomia => big baby Meconium aspiration syndrome => fetus is hypoxic and stressed from Oligohydramnios Placental insufficiency Birth trauma or stillbirth Increased risk of cesarean delivery Accurate dating with early ultrasound Non-stress test (NST) Biophysical profile (BPP) Amniotic fluid index (AFI) Induction of labor typically recommended at or after 41 weeks Cervical ripening => softening of cervix => (prostaglandins or Foley balloon) => mechanical: foley balloon, hygroscopic dilators, laminaria (use of seaweeds to use as giant tampons = swell and open cervix) => surgical: stripping of membranes + amniotomy => pharmacologic: prostaglandins => misoprostol, dinoprostone gel
Oxytocin to stimulate labor if cervix is favorable Cesarean section if induction fails or complications arise
Discontinue Oxytocin, uterine hyperstimulation, or CATII or CATIII Assess amniotic fluid volume regularly Observe for signs of fetal distress or meconium-stained fluid Support and educate patient regarding induction process and potential outcomes
Monitor for uterine hyperstimulation from Oxytocin => leads to fetal demise Importance of fetal movement counting Risks of prolonged pregnancy Methods and expectations of labor induction Signs to report immediately, such as decreased fetal movement or fluid leakage

item.title: VBAC
item.description: Vaginal Birth After Cesarean (VBAC) refers to delivering a baby vaginally after having had a previous cesarean delivery. It is an option for many women, depending on the type of uterine incision and individual risk factors. Desire to avoid repeat surgery Previous low transverse cesarean incision => best candidate Absence of contraindications to vaginal birth Adequate pelvis and favorable cervix Vertical/classical uterine incision History of uterine rupture More than two previous cesarean deliveries Short interval between pregnancies (<18 months) Macrosomia or fetal malpresentation Normal progression of labor similar to any vaginal delivery Continuous fetal monitoring to detect signs of uterine rupture Pain, bleeding, or abnormal fetal heart rate may indicate complications Uterine rupture (most serious) Emergency cesarean section Hemorrhage Infection Neonatal complications if labor becomes prolonged or complicated Review of prior surgical records to confirm uterine incision type Pelvic assessment to evaluate feasibility of vaginal delivery Ultrasound to assess fetal position and growth Trial of Labor After Cesarean (TOLAC) under close monitoring Emergency response plan available for complications Oxytocin may be used cautiously for labor augmentation Epidural analgesia may be offered Verify eligibility for VBAC Continuous electronic fetal monitoring Monitor for signs of uterine rupture (sudden pain, loss of fetal station, abnormal fetal heart tones) Prepare for emergency cesarean if needed Provide emotional support and pain management Discuss benefits and risks of VBAC vs repeat cesarean Explain signs of labor and when to come to hospital Emphasize importance of delivering in facility equipped for emergency cesarean Review birth plan and involve patient in decision-making process

item.title: Forceps or Vacuum Assisted Birth
item.description: Forceps- or vacuum-assisted birth (operative vaginal delivery) helps deliver the baby when spontaneous delivery is not progressing adequately during the second stage of labor. It uses instruments—either forceps or a vacuum extractor—to guide the fetal head out through the birth canal. Prolonged second stage of labor Non-reassuring fetal heart rate needing urgent delivery Maternal exhaustion Maternal medical conditions that limit pushing (e.g., cardiac issues) Malposition of the fetal head (e.g., occiput posterior) Incomplete cervical dilation Unengaged fetal head Suspected fetal bleeding disorders (e.g., hemophilia) Gestational age <34 weeks (vacuum) Face or breech presentation Cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) Maternal: Vaginal or perineal lacerations Postpartum hemorrhage Pelvic floor injury Fetal: Scalp lacerations or cephalohematoma (vacuum) Caput Succedaneum - common with vacuum; swelling of scalp across suture lines Succ = vacuum; literally translates to HEAD SUCKS Facial nerve injury or skull fracture (forceps) Intracranial hemorrhage (rare) Ensure informed consent is obtained Monitor fetal heart rate continuously Assist with positioning and support during procedure Anticipate possible need for neonatal resuscitation Assess newborn for trauma or complications post-delivery Monitor for maternal bleeding and perineal injury Provide emotional support and explain procedure to patient Explain purpose and process of assisted delivery before or during labor Reassure safety and commonality of procedure when indicated Inform about potential postpartum discomfort and recovery Discuss reasons for intervention during debriefing after birth Encourage questions and provide emotional support
item.guid: OB/iii. Labor/Complications/Forceps or Vacuum Assisted Birth.md

item.title: L&D - Infectious Diseases
item.description: Overview: Member of herpesvirus family; transmitted via contact with urine, saliva, blood, breast milk, and other body fluids Transmission to fetus: Transplacental, during delivery, or via breast milk Risk to fetus: Sensorineural hearing loss, seizures, microcephaly, hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delays Nursing considerations: No approved treatment during pregnancy; avoid exposure to young children's secretions; reinforce strict hand hygiene Overview: RNA virus spread via respiratory droplets; usually mild in adults Transmission to fetus: Transplacental Risk to fetus: Congenital rubella syndrome – cataracts, cardiac defects, deafness, microcephaly, intellectual disability Nursing considerations: Assess rubella immunity at first prenatal visit; avoid exposure to infected individuals; MMR vaccine contraindicated during pregnancy but given postpartum if nonimmune Overview: HSV-1 (oral) and HSV-2 (genital); causes lifelong recurrent outbreaks Transmission to fetus: During vaginal delivery if maternal lesions are present Risk to fetus: Neonatal HSV – encephalitis, disseminated disease, skin/eye/mouth infections, death Nursing considerations: Start suppressive therapy (acyclovir) at 36 weeks for women with history; perform C-section if lesions or prodromal symptoms at labor onset Overview: Bloodborne liver infection; transmitted via blood, sexual contact, and perinatal exposure see Hepatitis Transmission to fetus: During delivery (contact with infected blood and vaginal fluids) Risk to fetus: Chronic HBV infection, liver damage, cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma Nursing considerations: Screen all pregnant women administer HBIG and first HBV vaccine dose within 12 hours of birth breastfeeding permitted if infant receives immunoprophylaxis Overview: DNA virus that causes chickenpox and later shingles; transmitted via airborne droplets and direct contact Transmission to fetus: Transplacental or perinatal if maternal infection occurs near delivery Risk to fetus: Congenital varicella syndrome (limb hypoplasia, eye defects, skin scarring); neonatal varicella can be severe if maternal infection 5 days before to 2 days after delivery Nursing considerations: Check immunity at booking; nonimmune exposed women may receive VZIG; vaccine contraindicated during pregnancy, given postpartum Overview: Viral illness in children with “slapped cheek” rash; spread by respiratory droplets Transmission to fetus: Transplacental Risk to fetus: Fetal anemia, hydrops fetalis, miscarriage, especially in early pregnancy Nursing considerations: No vaccine or treatment; advise avoiding exposure to infected children; serial ultrasounds and Doppler if maternal infection confirmed Overview: Bacteria colonizing vagina/rectum in many women; usually asymptomatic in mother Transmission to fetus: During vaginal delivery Risk to fetus: Neonatal sepsis, pneumonia, meningitis (early-onset GBS disease) Nursing considerations: Screen between 36–37 weeks; if positive, give intrapartum IV penicillin; treat if status unknown and risk factors present (e.g., fever, ROM ≥18 hr) Overview: Protozoan infection from raw meat or cat feces; often asymptomatic in healthy adults Transmission to fetus: Transplacental Risk to fetus: Hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications, developmental delay Nursing considerations: Educate to avoid undercooked meat (cook to 160F), soil, and cat litter; treat confirmed fetal infections with spiramycin or pyrimethamine-sulfadiazine plus folinic acid

item.title: Gestational Diabetes
item.description: Diabetes in pregnancy includes pre-existing diabetes (Type 1 or 2) and gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) GDM develops during pregnancy and usually resolves after delivery All types require close monitoring to avoid complications for mother and baby Hormonal changes during pregnancy cause insulin resistance Placental hormones (e.g., human placental lactogen) increase glucose levels Pre-existing impaired glucose tolerance or obesity Obesity Family history of diabetes Previous large baby (>9 lbs) History of GDM in prior pregnancy Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) Maternal age >25 Often asymptomatic May include polyuria, polydipsia, fatigue, or recurrent infections Elevated fasting or postprandial blood glucose levels Maternal: preeclampsia, cesarean delivery, infections Fetal: macrosomia (large BW), hypoglycemia, respiratory distress syndrome, congenital anomalies (in pregestational diabetes) Neonatal: hypoglycemia, hyperbilirubinemia (macrosomia => more O2 demands => inc. RBC prodution => RBC die after birth => more bili excreted) Screening with 1-hour glucose challenge test (24–28 weeks) Diagnostic 3-hour oral glucose tolerance test if 1-hour is abnormal Fasting blood glucose and A1C in early pregnancy for high-risk women glucose targets (Durnwald, 2020) are: - Fasting blood glucose level: Less than 95 mg/dL - At 1 hour: Less than 140 mg/dL - At 2 hours: Less than 120 mg/dL - At 3 hours: Less than 95 mg/dL One or more abnormal result = Gestational Diabetes Goal: glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) level < 7% Diet modification (carbohydrate-controlled meals) Blood glucose monitoring (fasting and postprandial) Insulin therapy if diet/exercise insufficient => does not cross placenta Oral hypoglycemics (metformin or glyburide) in some cases => also does not cross Delivery planning (usually by 39 weeks if well controlled) Monitor blood glucose and fetal growth Teach glucose monitoring and insulin administration Assess for signs of complications (e.g., preeclampsia, infections) Collaborate with dietitian for meal planning Encourage compliance with prenatal visits and testing Importance of diet and exercise to manage glucose Eat 3 meals a day plus 3 snacks to promote glycemic control: 45% carbs 35% protein 25% fat small frequent feedings are recommended bed time snacks are okay How to perform self-monitoring of blood glucose - 4x/day or fasting, post meals Signs of hypo/hyperglycemia and when to seek care Risk of recurrence in future pregnancies or development of Type 2 DM Postpartum follow-up glucose testing (6–12 weeks after birth) record daily kick counts Insulin => eat breakfast within 30 minutes after admin

item.title: L&D - Autoimmune Disorders
item.description:
see Lupus High-risk pregnancy due to increased risk of complications (e.g., preeclampsia, preterm birth, miscarriage, fetal growth restriction) Plan pregnancy during remission (≥6 months remission recommended before conception) Avoid pregnancy during flare-ups – worsens maternal and fetal outcomes Monitor for hypertension, proteinuria, edema (may mimic or mask preeclampsia) Increased risk of neonatal lupus and congenital heart block (monitor fetal heart rate via ultrasound/ECHO) Medications: Some immunosuppressants (e.g., hydroxychloroquine) may be continued; avoid methotrexate and cyclophosphamide Risk of flare-ups during pregnancy and postpartum Monitor renal function closely (SLE nephritis may worsen) Encourage rest, hydration, and infection prevention May require antenatal corticosteroids or aspirin for preeclampsia prevention
see Multiple Sclerosis Pregnancy often reduces MS relapse rate; however, relapse risk increases postpartum No increase in miscarriage or congenital anomalies Encourage vaginal delivery unless physical disability or fatigue impedes labor Fatigue, weakness, and muscle spasticity may affect ability to push or care for newborn Risk for neurogenic bladder → assess urinary retention or UTIs Avoid live vaccines if on immunosuppressive therapy Corticosteroids (e.g., methylprednisolone) may be used during relapse, especially postpartum Delay breastfeeding for several hours if high-dose corticosteroids are administered Avoid teratogenic MS drugs before and during pregnancy (e.g., fingolimod, methotrexate)
see Rheumatoid Arthritis Symptoms often improve during pregnancy, flare postpartum RA does not affect fertility, but joint pain/fatigue may impair caregiving NSAIDs and methotrexate are contraindicated during pregnancy Safe medications: hydroxychloroquine, sulfasalazine, low-dose corticosteroids Monitor for joint pain, stiffness, fatigue, especially in third trimester and postpartum Assess ability to perform activities of daily living (ADLs) and care for infant Encourage joint protection strategies, rest, and physical therapy Support breastfeeding plans; some RA meds are safe, others must be avoided

item.title: L&D - Asthma
item.description: affects oxygenation for both mother and fetus; poor control increases risks of complications Goal: maintain optimal pulmonary function throughout pregnancy Triggered by allergens, respiratory infections, exercise, stress, or environmental irritants Hormonal and physiological changes in pregnancy can affect airway reactivity Maternal hypoxia Preeclampsia Preterm birth Low birth weight Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) Increased cesarean delivery risk Rescue: albuterol, ipratropium Maintenance: beclomethasone, salmeterol Monitor respiratory status and fetal well-being Reinforce medication adherence and trigger avoidance Educate about recognizing signs of exacerbation Coordinate care with OB and pulmonary specialists Monitor for signs of preeclampsia or growth restriction Avoid known asthma triggers Continue prescribed medications, even during pregnancy Use peak flow meter to track lung function Seek immediate care for severe shortness of breath or decreased fetal movement Stay current with flu and pertussis vaccines

item.title: L&D - Sickle Cell Anemia
item.description: see Sickle Cell Anemia Pregnancy increases risk of complications due to higher oxygen demands and vascular stress must screen before conception Preeclampsia Miscarriage or stillbirth Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) Preterm labor Placental abruption Infection/sepsis => spleen (w/c fights infections) can become fibrotic and nonfunctional Impaired leukocyte function (in some cases) can increase risk of sepsis Hemoglobin electrophoresis to confirm type CBC showing chronic hemolytic anemia Monitor fetal growth and placental function via ultrasound Folic acid supplementation => chronic hemolysis causes increased demand for erythropoiesis (needs folic acid for DNA synthesis ) Prophylactic antibiotics (e.g., penicillin) Blood transfusions as needed to reduce sickling events Pain management during crises (avoid NSAIDs in 3rd trimester) Hydration and oxygen therapy Close maternal-fetal monitoring Monitor for signs of crisis and intervene early: severe abdominal pain, muscle spasms, leg pain, joint pain, fever, stiff neck, N/V Prevent triggers (dehydration, infection, hypoxia) Monitor fetal well-being and maternal oxygenation Pain control plan in labor and postpartum Coordinate care with hematology and maternal-fetal medicine Importance of hydration and infection prevention Report early signs of crisis or decreased fetal movement Adherence to prenatal appointments and lab monitoring Avoid overexertion and stay warm Discuss genetic counseling and implications for the baby

item.title: C-Section
item.description:
Cesarean birth (C-section) is a surgical procedure to deliver a baby through incisions in the abdomen and uterus. May be planned or performed emergently based on maternal or fetal conditions. Previous cesarean or uterine surgery Fetal distress Placenta previa or Placental Abruption Cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) Malpresentation (e.g., breech) Multiple gestation Failed labor progression
Maternal health conditions (e.g., active herpes, severe Preeclampsia) Maternal: Hemorrhage Infection Injury to bladder, bowel, or uterus Anesthesia complications Thromboembolism Fetal: Respiratory distress (especially if early) Lacerations or minor trauma Delayed bonding or breastfeeding Skin Incision: Horizontal (Pfannenstiel) or vertical Uterine Incision: Low transverse (preferred), low vertical, or classical Pre-op: NPO status, IV access, labs (CBC, type & screen), fetal monitoring, informed consent Intra-op: Assist with positioning, monitor vital signs, support patient and partner Post-op: Monitor lochia (vaginal discharge), incision site, pain, respiratory function, bowel sounds, and urinary output, VS q15min first hr, then q30min Encourage early ambulation and deep breathing exercises Promote bonding and breastfeeding as soon as possible Explain reasons for C-section and what to expect during and after surgery Review signs of infection and complications to report (fever, heavy bleeding, wound issues) Encourage use of incentive spirometer and mobility Provide emotional support, especially if unplanned Teach proper incision care and pain management strategies

item.title: Intrauterine Fetal Demise
item.description: Intrauterine Fetal Demise (IUFD) refers to the death of a fetus in utero after 20 weeks of gestation but before the onset of labor. Also known as stillbirth, it requires prompt emotional, medical, and obstetric care. Placental insufficiency Chromosomal abnormalities Infections (e.g., TORCH, syphilis) Cord accidents (knots, prolapse) Preeclampsia, eclampsia Maternal chronic conditions (e.g., diabetes, lupus) Trauma or substance use Advanced maternal age Smoking, drug or alcohol use Previous history of IUFD Poorly controlled chronic disease Multiple gestation Obesity Fetal growth restriction Absence of fetal movement reported by the mother No fetal heart tones detected by Doppler or ultrasound Loss of uterine growth Possible signs of labor or infection if fetal death is prolonged Coagulopathy (especially DIC if fetus retained >4 weeks) Infection Hemorrhage Psychological trauma, grief, depression, PTSD Impaired future fertility if complications arise Ultrasound confirms absence of fetal cardiac activity Doppler unable to detect fetal heart tones Blood tests for maternal clotting profile and infection screen Autopsy or placental exam may determine cause Induction of labor is recommended to deliver the fetus Cesarean not routinely indicated unless obstetrically necessary Misoprostol or oxytocin used for induction Emotional support and bereavement counseling provided Discussion of options for memory-making (e.g., photos, keepsakes) Support patient and family emotionally Use compassionate, non-judgmental communication Prepare the family for delivery and appearance of fetus Provide privacy and facilitate time with the baby if desired Monitor for signs of hemorrhage, infection, and coagulopathy Coordinate spiritual or cultural needs Discuss potential causes and options for future pregnancy planning Offer resources for grief support and counseling Review signs of complications post-delivery (bleeding, fever) Explain follow-up appointments and emotional health screening Discuss autopsy and genetic testing if appropriate and consented

item.title: GBS Positive
item.description: Group B Streptococcus (GBS) is a common bacterial colonizer of the lower GI and genitourinary tracts in women, often asymptomatic. In pregnancy, GBS can be passed to the newborn during labor/delivery, potentially causing serious infections. Natural colonization by Streptococcus agalactiae in the vaginal or rectal area Not sexually transmitted, but may ascend during labor Previous infant with GBS disease GBS bacteriuria during current pregnancy Preterm labor (<37 weeks) Prolonged rupture of membranes (>18 hours) Maternal fever during labor (>100.4°F or 38°C) Maternal: Often asymptomatic Neonate: Sepsis, pneumonia, meningitis, lethargy, poor feeding, respiratory distress Neonatal sepsis or meningitis Preterm labor Fetal demise (in rare severe cases) Increased neonatal morbidity/mortality if untreated Vaginal and rectal swab culture between 36–37 weeks gestation Urine culture if GBS bacteriuria suspected earlier in pregnancy Intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis (IAP) during labor Penicillin G is the first-line treatment Alternatives include ampicillin or cefazolin (if penicillin allergic without anaphylaxis risk) Clindamycin if allergic with high anaphylaxis risk and sensitivity confirmed Ensure GBS culture is obtained at 36–37 weeks Review GBS status upon admission to labor and delivery Administer antibiotics at least 4 hours prior to delivery when possible Monitor mother and infant for signs of infection Educate on importance of IAP for GBS-positive women GBS is common and not harmful to the mother in most cases Prophylactic antibiotics during labor protect the baby No treatment is needed before labor unless GBS bacteriuria is present GBS status should be communicated to all care providers during delivery planning

item.title: L&D - HIV
item.description: see HIV-AIDS it poses a risk of vertical (mother-to-child) transmission during pregnancy, delivery, or breastfeeding NOT passing HIV to fetus IS POSSIBLE with proper treatment: Without treatment: Risk of transmission is 15–45% With effective antiretroviral therapy (ART) during pregnancy and labor plus appropriate newborn care: Risk is reduced to <1–2% C-section at 38 weeks if viral load >1,000 copies/mL also reduces risk Avoiding breastfeeding further minimizes postnatal transmission in countries where formula is safe and accessible Placenta During delivery breastfeeding Vertical transmission to fetus Preterm labor Low birth weight Opportunistic infections Increased risk of maternal morbidity and mortality Initial: Rapid HIV test, ELISA with confirmatory Western blot Monitor: Viral load, CD4+ count, resistance testing Prenatal: Routine HIV screening early in pregnancy ART (antiretroviral therapy) for all HIV-positive pregnant patients Zidovudine (ZDV) during labor and to newborn (w/in 6-12 hours of birth) C-section recommended if viral load >1000 copies/mL at delivery No breastfeeding in high-resource settings Ensure ART adherence to reduce transmission risk => zidovudine Scheduled C-section at 38 weeks if viral load >1,000 copies/mL Avoid breastfeeding unless viral suppression is confirmed and supported by national guidelines Avoid amniocentesis, fetal scalp electrodes, and artificial ROM when possible to reduce transmission risk Newborn receives ZDV for 4–6 weeks postpartum Avoid breastfeeding Infant will receive ART prophylaxis and monitoring Discuss safe sexual practices and partner testing Follow-up for infant HIV testing at birth, 2 weeks, 4–6 weeks, and 4–6 months

item.title: L&D - STDs
item.description: Cause: Treponema pallidum (bacterial) Transmission to fetus: Transplacental Risk to fetus: Congenital syphilis Miscarriage, stillbirth, preterm labor Bone deformities, hepatosplenomegaly, rash, anemia, neurologic damage Nursing considerations: Screen all pregnant patients at first prenatal visit; repeat at 28–32 weeks if high risk Treat with *IM benzathine penicillin G Desensitize if allergic (penicillin is the only safe and effective treatment) Monitor for Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction post-treatment Educate on abstinence until treatment is completed Treat and notify all sexual partners Cause: Neisseria gonorrhoeae (bacterial) Transmission to fetus: During vaginal delivery Risk to fetus: Neonatal conjunctivitis → blindness Preterm birth, PROM Nursing considerations: Screen at first prenatal visit; rescreen in 3rd trimester if high risk Treat with ceftriaxone IM plus azithromycin (or doxycycline if not pregnant) Administer erythromycin eye ointment to newborn within 1 hour of birth Educate patient and partner on abstinence until both are treated No test of cure required unless symptoms persist Cause: Chlamydia trachomatis (bacterial) Transmission to fetus: During vaginal delivery Risk to fetus: Neonatal pneumonia Neonatal conjunctivitis (not fully prevented by eye ointment) Preterm labor, low birth weight Nursing considerations: Screen at first prenatal visit; repeat in 3rd trimester if <25 or high risk Treat with azithromycin 1g PO once (amoxicillin is an alternative) Retest in 3–4 weeks to confirm cure Educate patient to abstain from sex until both partners are treated Erythromycin ointment still administered to prevent gonorrhea-related conjunctivitis Cause: HPV virus (viral) Transmission to fetus: Rare; possible *during vaginal delivery Risk to fetus: Rare neonatal laryngeal papillomatosis (benign airway growths) Nursing considerations: HPV does not routinely affect pregnancy outcome C-section only if large genital warts obstruct the birth canal HPV vaccine *not given during pregnancy Remove warts with cryotherapy or chemical treatment if symptomatic Resume cervical screening postpartum Encourage safe sex practices Cause: Trichomonas vaginalis (protozoan parasite) Transmission to fetus: During vaginal delivery Risk to fetus: Preterm labor, PROM, low birth weight Nursing considerations: Treat with metronidazole 2g PO once Safe during pregnancy; avoid alcohol during and 24 hrs after treatment Treat all partners; no intercourse until treatment complete Symptoms: frothy green discharge, foul odor, vulvar irritation Not typically part of routine STI screen—test if symptomatic or high risk

item.title: L&D - Thalassemia
item.description: inherited blood disorder causing abnormal hemoglobin production, leading to chronic anemia Can be alpha or beta thalassemia, with minor (trait) and major (disease) forms Pregnancy may worsen anemia and increase maternal-fetal risks Management depends on severity Genetic mutation affecting globin chain production Alpha: missing genes for alpha globin Beta: mutation in beta globin gene Family history of thalassemia Ethnic backgrounds: Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, South Asian, African Asymptomatic or mild anemia => does NOT respond to iron therapy Severe form: fatigue, pallor, bone deformities, splenomegaly In pregnancy: worsening fatigue, hemoglobin drop, transfusion needs Fetal growth restriction Preterm birth Hemolysis and transfusion-related risks Cardiac strain in mother Increased risk of iron overload with transfusions CBC with microcytic anemia Hemoglobin electrophoresis confirms type Ferritin and iron studies Genetic counseling and partner testing Mild: nutritional support, folic acid Severe: regular transfusions, iron chelation postpartum if needed Avoid iron unless iron-deficiency confirmed Close fetal monitoring for growth Monitor hemoglobin levels and symptoms of anemia Educate on importance of follow-ups and transfusion safety Avoid iron unless deficiency proven Coordinate care with hematologist and maternal-fetal medicine Importance of prenatal care and genetic counseling Adherence to folic acid and transfusion schedule Report fatigue, SOB, or signs of worsening anemia Avoid iron supplements without provider direction Consider testing of partner and fetal screening if both parents are carriers

item.title: L&D - TB
item.description: infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis Can be active or latent Early detection and treatment are essential to prevent maternal and fetal complications* Airborne transmission through inhalation of droplets from an infected person Reactivation of latent TB due to immune changes in pregnancy NOTE: TB does not cross placenta => airborne only Close contact with someone with active TB History of TB infection HIV or other immunocompromised states Living in or traveling to TB-endemic areas Homelessness, incarceration, or substance use Persistent cough (>3 weeks) Hemoptysis (coughing up blood) Fever and night sweats Fatigue and weight loss Chest pain and shortness of breath Preterm labor Low birth weight Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) Maternal dissemination (miliary TB, TB meningitis) Vertical transmission (rare, but possible in active TB) Tuberculin skin test (TST) or interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA) Chest X-ray with abdominal shielding Sputum acid-fast bacilli (AFB) smear and culture Nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) for rapid diagnosis Latent TB: treated after delivery unless at high risk of activation Active TB: treated during pregnancy with first-line drugs (e.g., isoniazid, rifampin, ethambutol) for at least 6 months Avoid streptomycin (teratogenic) Monitor liver function and adherence do not breast feed if mother is untreated for TB during child birth - no direct contact until after 2 weeks of starting TB meds Take all medications as prescribed, even if feeling better Practice good cough etiquette Avoid exposing others, especially infants, until non-infectious Keep follow-up appointments for monitoring and testing Inform healthcare team about TB history during labor and delivery

item.title: Cardiovascular Disorders in OB
item.description:
Include congenital or acquired heart diseases that may be exacerbated by physiological changes of pregnancy Pregnancy increases blood volume, cardiac output, and heart rate, placing added stress on the heart Can lead to maternal and fetal complications if not well managed Congenital heart defects (e.g., septal defects, coarctation of aorta) Rheumatic heart disease - caused by rheumatic fever, which in turn is a complication of untreated strep throat or scarlet fever Cardiomyopathy (especially peripartum) Arrhythmias
Valvular Dysfunctions (e.g., mitral stenosis)
Hypertensive Disorders of Pregnancy Pre-existing cardiac disease Obesity Advanced maternal age Hypertension Diabetes History of cardiac events or surgery Dyspnea, fatigue (especially with exertion) Orthopnea Palpitations Chest pain Syncope Cyanosis or clubbing in severe cases Edema, jugular vein distension Heart failure Pulmonary edema Arrhythmias Thromboembolism Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) Preterm labor or fetal demise Echocardiogram ECG Chest X-ray (with shielding) BNP levels Fetal ultrasound for growth monitoring Individualized based on type and severity of heart disease Beta-blockers, diuretics (cautiously), anticoagulants (heparin preferred) Oxygen therapy as needed Limit physical activity Planned delivery with multidisciplinary team (usually vaginal unless contraindicated) Monitor vital signs, oxygenation, and signs of decompensation Limit stress and exertion Positioning to maximize cardiac output (left lateral) Administer medications as ordered and monitor effects Educate patient on signs of worsening condition DO NOT ADMINISTER WARFARIN (COUMADIN) => crosses placenta Importance of regular prenatal care and cardiac follow-up Activity restrictions and rest periods Medication compliance and safety Recognize signs of worsening cardiac status Plan for labor and delivery with appropriate medical support

item.title: Rhogam
item.description: RhoGAM is an injection of Rh immunoglobulin given to prevent Rh-negative individuals from developing antibodies against Rh-positive blood cells. Rh-negative pregnant women with potential exposure to Rh-positive fetal blood After miscarriage, abortion, ectopic pregnancy, or trauma Postpartum if baby is Rh-positive After procedures like amniocentesis or chorionic villus sampling RhoGAM contains anti-D antibodies that destroy any fetal Rh-positive red blood cells in the mother's bloodstream before her immune system can react and form permanent antibodies. Rh-positive individuals Already sensitized (positive indirect Coombs test) Allergy to human immunoglobulin or components of the product Confirm mother is Rh-negative and not already sensitized Administer IM, usually at 28 weeks and within 72 hours postpartum Monitor for allergic reactions Verify correct timing and dose based on event (e.g., delivery, trauma) Explain purpose is to protect future pregnancies RhoGAM does not harm the current baby Report signs of allergic reaction (e.g., rash, difficulty breathing) Importance of receiving RhoGAM after each potential Rh exposure

item.title: HELLP
item.description:
a severe form of Preeclampsia Acronym: Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, and Low Platelet count Can occur during pregnancy or postpartum Life-threatening for mother and fetus Diagnostic Criteria: H - schistocytes, elevated bilirubin, elev. BUN
EL - elevated LFT => LDH, AST, ALT, bilirubin LP - platelets <100k (normal is 150-450k)also: high uric, Cr, LOW hematocrit Unknown exact cause Believed to result from abnormal placental development and systemic endothelial dysfunction Often a complication of preeclampsia
