History of Preeclampsia or HELLP First pregnancy Maternal age over 35 Multiple gestation Hypertension or autoimmune disease RUQ or epigastric pain (liver involvement) Nausea, vomiting Headache, blurred vision Malaise or flu-like symptoms Hypertension and proteinuria Jaundice (in severe cases) Liver hematoma or rupture
Disseminated intravascular coagulation DIC
Placental Abruption
AKI
Eclampsia Maternal or fetal death Cerebral Hemorrhage Retinal Detachment
Pulmonary Edema CBC: low platelets, evidence of hemolysis (schistocytes, elevated bilirubin) LFTs: elevated AST and ALT Coagulation panel, urinalysis for protein Fetal monitoring for distress Immediate delivery if gestational age ≥34 weeks or maternal/fetal instability Corticosteroids (e.g., betamethasone) to mature fetal lungs if <34 weeks Magnesium sulfate to prevent seizures Antihypertensives PRN (hydralazine or labetalol) Blood products (platelets) if bleeding risk is high => PRBC, FFP, platelets Monitor vitals, bleeding, and labs closely Seizure precautions and magnesium sulfate monitoring Prepare for emergency delivery Support maternal and fetal hemodynamic stability
Monitor urine output, liver function, and signs of DIC Report RUQ pain, severe headache, or vision changes Adhere to follow-up appointments and lab work Explain possible need for early delivery Discuss future pregnancy risks and early monitoring for preeclampsia recurrence

item.title: Hydralazine
item.description: Direct-acting vasodilator used primarily for hypertension and heart failure; often given IV or PO; rapid onset especially with IV formSevere hypertension including hypertensive emergency Heart failure (especially in combination with nitrates) Pregnancy-induced hypertension or preeclampsia (off-label)Directly relaxes arteriolar smooth muscle → ↓ systemic vascular resistance (afterload) → ↓ blood pressure; triggers reflex sympathetic activation (↑ HR, ↑ renin)Coronary artery disease Mitral valve rheumatic heart disease Hypersensitivity Caution in cerebrovascular disease or hypotensionMonitor BP closely, especially after IV administration Watch for reflex tachycardia or hypotension Assess for fluid retention or edema May cause lupus-like syndrome with long-term use Often combined with beta-blockers to blunt reflex tachycardia Educate patient on signs of hypotension (dizziness, lightheadedness)

item.title: Blood Incompatibility
item.description:
refers to Rh incompatibility or ABO incompatibility between mother and fetus Can lead to maternal immune response against fetal red blood cells, causing hemolysis ABO compatibility is LESS important than RH in fetus-mother Rh-negative mother with Rh-positive fetus → maternal immune system produces anti-D antibodies in most cases - first born RH+ infants are not affected because of short exposure period risk increases with each pregnancy => each infant is more anemic Less commonly, ABO incompatibility (mother is type O, fetus is A or B) Rh-negative maternal blood type Previous pregnancy with Rh-positive fetus No administration of Rhogam - Rho(D) immune globulin Trauma, amniocentesis, or procedures that mix maternal-fetal blood Often asymptomatic in the mother Fetal effects: anemia, jaundice, hydrops fetalis, heart failure, stillbirth Newborn may present with hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN) Hemolysis of fetal red blood cells If a mom is Rh-negative and her baby is Rh-positive, her body can get "tricked" into thinking the baby’s red blood cells are invaders. So, her immune system makes anti-D antibodies that can attack and destroy the baby's Rh-positive blood cells, like tiny soldiers fighting what they think is a threat. Neonatal jaundice and kernicterus Hydrops fetalis (severe fetal edema) Intrauterine fetal demise if untreated Maternal blood type and Rh factor screening early in pregnancy
Indirect Coombs test (detects maternal anti-D antibodies) => if negative, no antibodies (okay to give Rhogam) if Coombs positive => RhoGAM is useless; mom already attacking Rh blood cells Negative is good! Fetal monitoring via ultrasound for signs of anemia or hydrops Doppler studies of fetal middle cerebral artery
Rho(D) immune globulin (Rhogam) given to Rh-negative mothers at 28 weeks and within 72 hours postpartum if baby is Rh-positive Intrauterine transfusions for severely affected fetuses Phototherapy or exchange transfusion in newborn if jaundice develops Verify maternal blood type and Rh status at initial prenatal visit
Ensure administration of Rhogam as scheduled Educate about signs of fetal distress or anemia Monitor newborn for jaundice or anemia Provide emotional support if complications arise Importance of early prenatal care and blood typing Purpose and timing of RhoGAM injections Monitor newborn for yellowing of skin or eyes Report any trauma or bleeding during pregnancy immediately

item.title: Multiple Gestation
item.description:
pregnancy with more than one fetus (e.g., twins, triplets) Can be monozygotic (identical) or dizygotic (fraternal) Increases maternal and fetal risks compared to singleton pregnancies Monozygotic (identical) - single, fertilized ovum splits during the first 2 weeks after conceptionDizygotic (fraternal) - two sperm fertilizing two ova Assisted reproductive technology (e.g., IVF) Fertility medications (e.g., clomiphene) Family history of multiples (especially fraternal) Advanced maternal age Use of fertility treatments Maternal age over 35 Multiparity Race (higher incidence in African descent) Rapid uterine growth Elevated hCG levels More pronounced pregnancy symptoms Detection of multiple fetal heart tones Confirmed via ultrasound Pre-term Labor & birth Polyhydramnios
Hyperemesis Gravidarum
Preeclampsia Antepartum Hemorrhage Prematurity Respiratory Distress Syndrome Asphyxia Congenital Anomalies Twin-to-twin transfusion Syndrome IUGR Conjoined Twins Ultrasound for number of fetuses and chorionicity Fundal height measurement Elevated hCG and AFP levels Routine monitoring for complications (e.g., growth scans, NSTs) CBC - anemia may be expected Increased prenatal surveillance Early and frequent ultrasounds Monitor for signs of preterm labor and complications Possible hospitalization for high-risk cases Scheduled delivery by 38 weeks if uncomplicated Educate on signs of preterm labor and complications Monitor maternal nutrition and weight gain Ensure adequate rest and support Coordinate care with high-risk OB team Support emotional well-being Importance of frequent prenatal visits Nutritional needs and weight gain goals Signs of preterm labor, preeclampsia, and fetal concerns Discuss birth plans, delivery options (vaginal vs. cesarean) Prepare for neonatal care, especially if premature birth occurs

item.title: Oligohydramnios
item.description: too little amniotic fluid (less than 500 mL) => normal is based on AFI Defined as amniotic fluid index (AFI) <5 cm or deepest vertical pocket <2 cm increased risk of perinatal morbidity and mortality see also Polyhydramnios (too much water) Fetal renal anomalies (e.g., bilateral renal agenesis, obstructive uropathy) Premature rupture of membranes (PROM) Placental insufficiency Post-term pregnancy => pregnancy longer than 42 weeks, amniotic fluid naturally dries up Maternal dehydration or hypertension Maternal Diabetes IUGR Polycystic Kidney Disease Urinary Tract Obstructions Post-term pregnancy Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy Use of NSAIDs History of PROM or prior oligohydramnios Fundal height smaller than expected for gestational age Reduced fetal movement Difficult palpation of fetal parts May be asymptomatic and discovered on ultrasound Fetal compression leading to musculoskeletal deformities Pulmonary hypoplasia Umbilical cord compression Intrauterine growth restriction Increased risk for cesarean delivery Ultrasound (AFI <5 cm or single pocket <2 cm) Non-stress test or biophysical profile for fetal well-being Assess for rupture of membranes Address underlying cause (e.g., rehydration, treat hypertension) usually outpatient => no intervention needed if no fetal concerns; otherwise: Amnioinfusion during labor to relieve cord compression => add amniotic fluid to the uterus to improve fetal heart rate and prevent cord compression Maternal hydration (oral or IV) Delivery if fetal compromise or term gestation Monitor fetal heart tones closely Observe for signs of labor or distress Prepare for possible amnioinfusion or early delivery Provide emotional support for maternal anxiety Encourage hydration if appropriate Report decreased fetal movement Maintain hydration Attend regular prenatal visits and follow-up ultrasounds Understand possible need for early delivery or interventions

item.title: Polyhydramnios
item.description: excessive amniotic fluid accumulation (more than 2000 mL) during 32-36 weeks Typically defined as amniotic fluid index (AFI) >24 cm or deepest vertical pocket >8 cm associated with poorer fetal outcomes: more preterm births fetal malpresentation cord prolapse increased cesarean births low 5-min APGAR congenital anomalies NICU admission see also Oligohydramnios Maternal diabetes mellitus Fetal anomalies (e.g., anencephaly, esophageal/duodenal atresia) Multiple gestation Fetal anemia or infections Idiopathic in many cases Pre-existing or gestational diabetes Fetal structural or chromosomal abnormalities Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome Rh incompatibility Rapid uterine growth => uterus is large as fuck (maternal abdominal girth and fundal height) Difficulty breathing or discomfort due to uterine distension Increased fundal height => discrepancy with gestational age Fetal parts may be difficult to palpate Increased fetal movement Preterm labor or premature rupture of membranes Placental abruption Umbilical cord prolapse Malpresentation Postpartum hemorrhage Ultrasound to measure AFI or deepest vertical pocket or estimate volume Fetal anatomy scan Glucose tolerance test for maternal diabetes Amniocentesis for karyotyping or infection studies Treat underlying cause (e.g., control maternal diabetes) Indomethacin (reduces fetal urine output; used cautiously) => prostaglandin synthesis inhibitor (may cause premature closing of ductus arteriosus) Amniocentesis or artificial ROM for severe cases Close fetal monitoring Consider early delivery if complications develop Monitor for signs of preterm labor and PROM Educate on symptoms of complications (e.g., contractions, fluid leakage) Assist with procedures like amnioreduction if ordered Support maternal comfort and respiratory function Monitor fetal status closely Report increased abdominal pressure, contractions, or leaking fluid Importance of follow-up ultrasounds Blood sugar control if diabetic Signs of labor or cord prolapse to watch for at home

item.title: Ectopic Pregnancy
item.description: fertilized ovum implants outside the uterine cavity embryo draws blood supplies from site of abnormal implantation potential for organ rupture = MEDICAL EMERGENCY most common site for implantation - fallopian tubes, can also happen in intestine, ovary, cervix, abdominal cavity Conditions that obstruct or slow the passage of the fertilized ovum through the fallopian tube to the uterus Pelvic Inflammatory Disease Chlamydia history tubal surgery infertility previous pregnancy loss IUDs multiple sex partners progestin-only oral contraceptives postpartum or postabortion infection douching 35+ age cigarette smoking DES Unilateral lower abdominal pain Vaginal bleeding (light to heavy spotting) Missed menstrual period Positive pregnancy test but no intrauterine pregnancy on ultrasound Referred shoulder pain (from diaphragmatic irritation if ruptured) Signs of shock: hypotension, tachycardia, dizziness (if ruptured) Tubal rupture Hemorrhage and hypovolemic shock => monitor VS Infertility or increased risk for future ectopic pregnancies Transvaginal ultrasound (no gestational sac in uterus) Serial hCG levels => normal pregnacy: continuous increase until 60-90 days, ectopic: LOW (means impending abortion) Pelvic exam (may show adnexal tenderness or mass) Methotrexate (if stable and unruptured) to stop fetal cell growth conditional: no bleeding, low HCG (<5k), mass must be unruptured Methotrexate - treats cancer by slowing growth of cells Surgical intervention (e.g., salpingostomy or salpingectomy) if ruptured or unstable Salpingostomy - removal of tube Rh immunoglobulin (Rhogam) for Rh-negative women Monitor vital signs for signs of bleeding or shock Assess pain level and administer analgesics Administer medications as ordered (e.g., methotrexate) Provide emotional support and education Prepare for surgery if indicated Avoid alcohol and folic acid with methotrexate (interferes with drug action) Report worsening abdominal pain, heavy bleeding, or dizziness Follow up with serial hCG monitoring until undetectable => VERY IMPORTANT! (blood test?) Delay attempts at conception for at least 3 months post-methotrexate Use contraception as advised until cleared for future pregnancy

item.title: Eclampsia
item.description: Onset of seizures in a woman with Preeclampsia MEDICAL EMERGENCY! A severe progression of hypertensive disorder in pregnancy Life-threatening for both mother and fetus Progression from untreated or severe preeclampsia Cerebral edema, ischemia, or vasospasm may trigger seizures Generalized tonic-clonic seizures facial twitching generalized muscle rigidity facial distortion protruding eyes foaming at mouth Severe headache Visual disturbances (blurred vision, flashing lights) RUQ/epigastric pain Altered mental status or unresponsiveness Increased DTR Maternal injury from seizure Intracranial hemorrhage Placental abruption Fetal distress or death Cardiopulmonary arrest Magnesium sulfate IV to prevent and treat seizures Antihypertensives to manage severe BP (labetalol, hydralazine) Stabilize and plan for delivery once maternal condition is controlled Maintain airway and oxygenation Position on Left Side Seizure precautions (padded side rails, suction, oxygen) Continuous fetal and maternal monitoring Assess deep tendon reflexes and respiratory status for Mg toxicity Prepare for possible emergency delivery Provide calm environment > dim lights, quiet Provide emotional support Monitor serum magnesium levels, rr, reflexes, OUP => avoid mag tox Importance of early prenatal care and reporting symptoms Inform about seizure warning signs (aura, headache, vision changes) Adherence to magnesium sulfate protocol and monitoring Need for follow-up postpartum due to risk of recurrence or chronic hypertension Encourage high protein diet (per Ricci)

item.title: Gestational Hypertension
item.description: New-onset hypertension (≥140/90 mmHg) after 20 weeks gestation No proteinuria or signs of end-organ damage Temporary condition that typically resolves postpartum temporary diagnosis for women that do not meet criteria for Preeclampsia Exact cause unknown Thought to involve abnormal placental development and vascular resistance First pregnancy Multiple gestation History of preeclampsia or hypertension Obesity Maternal age <20 or >35 Diabetes Elevated blood pressure ≥140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks Typically no proteinuria No significant systemic symptoms unless progresses Risk of progression to preeclampsia Placental abruption Preterm birth Fetal growth restriction BP monitoring on two occasions at least 4 hours apart Urinalysis to rule out proteinuria Labs to assess for liver/kidney involvement if symptoms develop Close monitoring of BP and fetal growth Antihypertensives if BP ≥160/110 (labetalol, hydralazine) Delivery if condition worsens or at term Weekly or biweekly prenatal visits Educate on home BP monitoring Monitor for signs of progression to preeclampsia Promote rest and reduce stress Support adherence to follow-up and medication plan Report symptoms like headache, visual changes, swelling Avoid high-sodium foods Adhere to prenatal appointments and testing Know potential signs of preeclampsia for early intervention

item.title: Hyperemesis Gravidarum
item.description: Severe and persistent nausea and vomiting during pregnancy Leads to dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, and weight loss More severe than typical morning sickness Exact cause unknown Possibly linked to high levels of hCG and estrogen May have genetic, hormonal, or psychological factors First pregnancy Multiple gestation History of motion sickness or migraines H. Pylori infection Molar pregnancy Previous hyperemesis gravidarum Persistent vomiting not relieved by typical measures Weight loss >5% of pre-pregnancy weight Dehydration (dry mucous membranes, poor skin turgor) Electrolyte imbalance (especially hypokalemia) Ketonuria Wernicke’s encephalopathy (thiamine deficiency) Esophageal rupture Fetal growth restriction Preterm birth Metabolic Alkalosis ketosis hypokalemia retinal hemorrhage Clinical symptoms Electrolytes, BUN, creatinine for dehydration Urinalysis for ketones Ultrasound to rule out molar pregnancy or multiples LFT - rule out Hepatitis, Pancreatitis, etc CBC - assess hydration h/h Urine ketones - positive when body breaks down fat in absence of adequate intake TSH T4 - r/o thyroid disease U/S - evaluate multiple gestation, molar pregnancy IV fluids for rehydration Electrolyte replacement NPO => allow GI rest Vitamin supplementation (especially thiamine) Antiemetics (ondansetron, promethazine) Nutritional support if oral intake not possible (NG or TPN) Monitor weight, intake/output, and lab values Encourage small, frequent meals if tolerated Fluid volume deficit - hypotension Assess for signs of dehydration and nutritional deficits Provide emotional support Report inability to keep food or fluids down Importance of rest and hydration Avoid triggers (strong smells, spicy foods) Follow-up for weight and fetal growth monitoring

item.title: Endometriosis
item.description: a chronic gynecologic condition where endometrial-like tissue grows outside the uterus. ectopic tissues respond to hormonal cycles, leading to inflammation, pain, and possible infertility. unknown: possibly retrograde menstruation, genetics, immune dysfunction Family history (first-degree relatives) Early menarche or late menopause Short menstrual cycles (<27 days) Heavy menstrual bleeding Nulliparity Obstructed menstrual flow Chronic pelvic pain Dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation) Dyspareunia (painful intercourse) Infertility Pain with bowel movements or urination (especially during menstruation) Abnormal bleeding Infertility Ovarian cysts (endometriomas) Adhesions and pelvic scarring Bowel or bladder dysfunction (rare but possible with advanced disease) Emotional stress or depression Pelvic exam (may reveal tender nodules or masses) Transvaginal ultrasound (limited sensitivity) Laparoscopy (gold standard for diagnosis and staging) MRI (for deep or extensive disease) NSAIDs for pain relief Hormonal therapy including oral contraceptives and GnRH agonists Progestin therapy Surgical removal of endometrial implants Hysterectomy in severe, refractory cases Fertility treatments if conception is a goal Discuss fertility options if relevant Inform about potential need for surgery

item.title: Ch.11 - Maternal Adaptation
item.description: Signs & Symptoms of Pregnancy: Presumptive Probable Positive least reliable indicators (amenorrhea => can be menopause, endocrine dysfunction, malnutrition, etc)Subjective: fatigue breast tenderness N/V amenorrhea urinary frequency hyperpigmentation of skin fetal movements =>"quickening" uterine enlargement breast enlargement more reliable but are also not 100% in confirming tumors, infections can also change uterine shape, size, consistency ovarian cancer, choriocarcinoma can also elevate HCG levels Hegar Sign - softening of the lower uterine segment or isthmus Goodell Sign - softening of the cervix => good gooey gervix Chadwick Sign - bluish-purple coloration of the vaginal mucosa and cervix change in shape/size of uterus, abdominal enlargement Braxton Hicks Contractions - aka practice contractions or false labor, are sporadic uterine contractions that may start around six weeks into a pregnancy Ballottement - rebound from the floating fetus Pregnancy Test - also a probable sign; usually thru HCG detection (5 mIU/mL or lower is negative, 25 mIU/mL or higher is positive)Fetus is growing inside uterus can be as early as 2 weeks after missed menses**IMPORTANT: Ultrasound verification of embryo or fetus Fetal movement felt by experienced clinician Auscultation of fetal heart tones via Doppler Increase in size, weight, length, width, depth, volume, and overall capacity Pear shape to ovoid shape; positive Hegar sign Enhanced uterine contractility; Braxton Hicks contractions Ascent into abdomen after first 3 months Fundal height by 20 weeks’ gestation at level of umbilicus; 20 cm; reliable determination of gestational age until 36 weeks’ gestation => top of the pubic bone until fundusFundus = top of uterus; is at level of umbilicus by 20 weeks reaches highest level (xyphoid process) at 36 weeks presses against diaphragm = SOB at 36-38 weeks, fetus descends, fundus drops, pressess against bladder = more urinary frequency Lightening - fetal head begins to descend and engage in the pelvisSoftening (Goodell sign) => vasocongestion More mucus => plug formation (purpose: to keep infection off the baby) Increased vascularization (Chadwick sign) => cyanosis or bluish purple discoloration Ripening about 4 weeks before birthIncreased vascularity, hypertrophy => preparing to give birth mucosa thickening Lengthening of vaginal vault Secretions more acidic, white, and thick; leukorrhea Candida albicans, a monilial vaginitis => common, benign, but uncomfortable => can be transmitted to neonate at birth (thrush)Enlargement until 12th to 14th week of gestation Cessation of ovulation => caused by elevated estrogen and progesterone (blocks secretion of FSH and LH)Increase in size and nodularity to prepare for lactation; increase in nipple size, becoming more erect and pigmented Production of colostrum: antibody-rich, yellow fluid that can be expressed after the 12th week; conversion to mature milk after deliveryLES => relaxed, GERD Gums: hyperemic, swollen, and friable Ptyalism => excessive salivation Dental problems; gingivitis Decreased peristalsis and smooth muscle relaxation Constipation + increased venous pressure + pressure from uterus = hemorrhoids Slowed gastric emptying; heartburn Prolonged gallbladder emptying Nausea and vomiting progesterone preserves the uterus but causes several side effectsIncrease in blood volume (50% above prepregnancy levels) Anemia => large volume expansion with small increase in RBC, hemodilution Increase in cardiac output; increased venous return; increased heart rate BP - slight decrease until midpregnancy, then returning to prepregnancy levelsIncrease in iron demands, fibrin and plasma fibrinogen levels, and some clotting factors, leading to hypercoagulable state Breathing more diaphragmatic than abdominal due to increase in diaphragmatic excursion, chest circumference, and tidal volume oxygen needs increase for fetus placenta and maternal organs increased oxygen demand and structural changes raise risk of decompensation in women with respiratory conditions estrogen-driven vascular congestion leads to nasal stuffiness, epistaxis, rhinitis, and voice changes increased vascularity => frequent nosebleedsDilation of renal pelvis; elongation, widening, and increase in curve of ureters Increase in length and weight of kidneys Increase in glomerular filtration rate; increased urine flow and volume Increase in kidney activity with woman lying down; greater increase in later pregnancy with woman lying on side => more frequent urinationlying on side puts less pressure on vena cavaSoftening and stretching of ligaments holding sacroiliac joints and pubis symphysis => make childbirth easier Postural changes: increased swayback and upper spine extension => lower back pain Forward shifting of center of gravity Increase in lumbosacral curve (lordosis); compensatory curve in cervicodorsal area Waddle gaitHyperpigmentation; mask of pregnancy (facial melasma) Linea nigra Striae gravidarum => stretch marks Varicosities => result from distention, poor circulation Vascular spiders => common in white women, d/t estrogen levels Palmar erythema => palm Decline in hair growth; increase in nail growthThyroid gland: slight enlargement; increased activity; increase in BMR Pituitary gland: enlargement; decrease in TSH, GH; inhibition of FSH and LH; increase in prolactin, MSH; gradual increase in oxytocin with fetal maturation Pancreas: insulin resistance due to hPL and other hormones in second half of pregnancy (see Box 11.2) Adrenal glands: increase in cortisol and aldosterone secretion Prostaglandin secretion Placental secretion: hCG, hPL, relaxin, progesterone, estrogen (see Table 11.3)Increased innate immunity suppressed adaptive immunity (foreign antigen) inadequate intake = low BW, preterm, congenital anomalies excessive = fetal macrosomia, difficult birth, continued obesity, neonatal hypoglycemia supplements => iron, folic acid => support new blood cells, prevent anemia (take iron with juice or gummies) folic acid - prevent neural tube defects in early weeks Increase in protein, iron, folate, and calories (see Table 11.5) Use of USDA’s Food Guide MyPlate (see Figure 11.5) Avoidance of some fish due to mercury content Listeria => listeriorsis: avoid raw, unpasteurized food, can be passed down to newborn Healthy weight BMI: 25 to 35 lb First trimester: 3.5 to 5 lb Second and third trimesters: 1 lb/wk BMI <19.8: 28 to 40 lb  First trimester: 5 lb Second and third trimesters: +1 lb/wk BMI >25: 15 to 25 lb  First trimester: 2 lb Second and third trimesters: 2/3 lb/wk Special Considerations: Lactose Intolerance => need for calcium supplements Vegetarian => low gestational weight, iron-deficiency anemia, low protein, low mineral absorption => substitute and supplement accordingly Pica - intense craving r eating nonfood items for at least a month Couvade Syndrome - husband also partakes in cravings

item.title: Physical Assessment Findings of Pregnancy
item.description: Weight gain appropriate to gestational age (approx. 25–35 lbs total for normal BMI) Fatigue especially in the first and third trimesters Linea nigra: dark line from pubis to umbilicus Striae gravidarum: stretch marks on abdomen, breasts, thighs Chloasma: "mask of pregnancy"—hyperpigmentation on face Palmar erythema due to increased estrogen Increased perspiration and sebaceous activity Mild thyroid enlargement can be normal Increased hair growth during pregnancy (may shed postpartum) Slight corneal thickening (reversible postpartum) Dry eyes or blurred vision occasionally Tenderness, enlargement, and heaviness Darkened areolas and Montgomery tubercles Colostrum production in late pregnancy Slight increase in respiratory rate Shortness of breath in 3rd trimester (uterus pressing diaphragm) Nasal congestion or epistaxis due to estrogen-induced vascular changes Systolic murmurs may be present (common and usually benign) Increased heart rate (10–15 bpm) Lower blood pressure in 2nd trimester, returns to baseline by 3rd Dependent edema (especially feet/ankles) Varicose veins or hemorrhoids may develop due to venous stasis Nausea/vomiting (especially 1st trimester) Heartburn due to relaxed lower esophageal sphincter Constipation due to progesterone slowing GI motility Abdominal distension and decreased bowel sounds Increased urinary frequency (especially 1st and 3rd trimesters) Chadwick’s sign: bluish discoloration of cervix/vagina Goodell’s sign: softening of cervix Hegar’s sign: softening of uterine isthmus Leukorrhea: increased vaginal discharge Lordosis: compensatory curvature due to weight of uterus Waddling gait from pelvic joint relaxation Round ligament pain or backache Diastasis recti: separation of abdominal muscles Carpal tunnel syndrome (numbness/tingling in hands) Leg cramps (especially at night) Mood swings or emotional lability
item.guid: OB/i. Maternal Assessment/Physical Assessment Findings of Pregnancy.md

item.title: Ch.12 - Nursing Management in Pregnancy
item.description:
should occur any time a health care provider sees a woman of reproductive age avoid live vaccines: MMR, Varicella, etc also avoid: HPVRisk Factors in Adverse Pregnancies: Isotretinoins (accutane) - birth defects, cleft palate, congenital heart defects, hearing loss, microcephaly alcohol - FAS Antiepileptic drugs - valproic acid => lower dose diabetes Folic Acid Deficiency - must have at least 400-800 mcg of folic acid daily to reduce neural tube defects by 2/3 Hepatitis B
HIV-AIDS Rubella - must vaccinate Obesity - maternal obesity associated with neural tube deffects, pre-term delivery, diabetes, cesarean, HTN, thromboembolic disease STI - chlamydia, neisseria gonorrhoeae - ectopic pregnancy, infertility smoking - low BW, pre-term birth Assess the following: Immunization status Underlying medical conditions Reproductive health care practices Sexuality and sexual practices Nutrition Lifestyle practices Psychosocial issues Medication and drug use Support system delayed prenatal care => associated with increased rates of NICU admissions 2 approach: individual and centering (group or cohort moms) Gestational diabetes => maintain A1cc lower than 6.5, fasting BSL of 95mg/dL or lower determine LMP to get EDD History: medical & surgical; smoking, alcohol drugs Reproductive History = GP or GTPAL system
Estimating Expected Date of birth or delivery: EDB/EDD => Naegel's Rule birth wheel ultrasound = more accurate to determine GA and date the pregnancy empty bladder first => collect urine while at it (clean catch) soft systolic murmur = may be normal Estrogen => relaxation of ligaments of joints and ribs = larger chest diameter = increase in RR Linea Nigra - runs thru umbilicus Palpate fundus DVT, edema, pulses, varicose veins Cervix Expected findings Gooddell sign - sofetened Hegar Sign - uterine isthmus softened Chadwick's sign = bluish discoloration of cevix and vaginal mucosa Papanicolaou (Pap) Smear - screen for gonorrhea and chlamydia More assessments: assess fundal height fetal heart rate BP, weight urinalysis: glucose, protein Pelvic shape: gynecoid android anthropoid platypelloid Pelvic measurements: diagonal conjugate true (obstetric) conjugate ischial tuberosity Rhogam - used to prevend development of antibodies to Rh-positice cells, such as during amniocentesis or spontaneous abortionFundal Height = weeks of pregnancy in terms of cm McDonald Method - lying down, top of pubic bone to top of fundus => knees flexed => if growth curve flattens or stable - indicates FGR (fetal growth restriction)Fetal Movements - lack of these can mean asphyxia and FGR Education: count fetal movemnts, and it's significanceContractions Early contraction => lead to preterm birth not to be confused with Braxton Hicks contractions => stop with rest or sleep and are usually felt in the abdomen, not the lower back Signs of preterm labor: contractions every 10 minutes or more frequently, vaginal discharge changes, pelvic pressure, cramps, low backache, and diarrhea. Early detection is crucial, as medications can sometimes stop labor if cervical dilation hasn't progressed. If symptoms arise =>lie on her left side, drink 2–3 glasses of water, and monitor for 1 hour—if symptoms persist or worsen, she should contact her provider. GP System Gravida - pregnancy numbers Para - Number of pregnancies delivered after 20 weeksGTPAL System - more details G: Gravida – Total number of pregnancies, including the current pregnancy if applicable. T: Term births – Number of full-term births (deliveries at 37 weeks or later). P: Preterm births – Number of preterm births (deliveries between 20 and 36 weeks). A: Abortions – Number of pregnancies that ended in miscarriage or elective abortion before 20 weeks. L: Living children – Number of living children the woman has. Example of GTPAL Notation: G3T1P1A1L2 G3: The woman has been pregnant 3 times (includes current pregnancy if applicable). T1: She has had 1 full-term delivery (after 37 weeks). P1: She has had 1 preterm delivery (between 20 and 36 weeks). A1: She has had 1 miscarriage or elective abortion before 20 weeks. L2: She has 2 living children
CBC Albumin, Glucose, ketones, bacteria Blood Typing HEP B STIProtein in urine = pre-eclampsia Glucose in Urine => Gestational Diabetes Mellitusat 37 weeks: repeat all, in addition to GBS, gonorrhea, clap Ultrasonography Doppler flow studies - use of sound waves to examine the flow of blood in blood vessels Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) analysis = elevated => neural tube defects Marker screening tests - aneuploidy (trisomies 13, 18, and 21) and neural tube defects Nuchal translucency screening usually done in 11-14 weeks detects fetal chromosomal and structural abnormalities Amniocentesis - transabdominal puncture of the amniotic sac to obtain a sample of amniotic fluid empty bladder first to avoid risk of bladder puncture fetal monitoring strip is obtained to evaluate fetal well being and baseline Chorionic villus sampling (CVS). - 18g thru suction cathere thru cervix under US guidance; alternative to amniocentesis; rule out genetic disorders, fewer risks Percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS) Nonstress test; contraction stress test => most common, provides measurement of uteroplacental function must have empty bladder reactive: at least 2 FHR accelerations from baseline Non reactive: if it's not the above for at least 15 sec within 20 min timeframe Contraction stress test Biophysical profile - real-time ultrasound and NST to allow assessment of various parameters of fetal well-being that are sensitive to hypoxia see p.405N/V Eat 6 small meals/day avoid empty stomach at all times! Avoid highly seasoned or greasy foods Drink at least 8 (8oz) glasses of water/day Ask for medication Urinary Frequency - d/t compression of bladder Fatigue Breast Tenderness Exessive salivation & increased discharge - d/t increased estrogen => bathe daily, no douching Heartburn: ↑ progesterone, ↑ pressure => Use antacids, small meals, sit upright for 30 min after eatingBackache Varicosities of the vulva and legs Hemorrhoids Flatulence with bloatingReturn of first trimester discomforts Shortness of breath and dyspnea Heartburn and indigestion Dependent edema Braxton Hicks contractions2nd & 3rd Trim Discomforts Ankle Edema - ↑ sodium & cap permeability, circulatory congestion, prolonged standing/sitting, Frequent dorsiflexion Get up and move for at least 5 min Q hr, Supportive hose (used for varicosities too) Hemorrhoids - constipation, pressure, sitz bath, witch hazel pads, ointments Constipation/Flatulence: ↑ progesterone, ↓ fluids, ↓ exercise => tx: ↑ fluids, ↑ fresh fruit/veggies (non-gassy), stool softeners Backache: ↑ lumbar curve, ↑ hormones Proper body mechanics and pelvis-tilt exercise Leg cramps: ↑ nerve pressure, electrolyte imbalances, ↓ circulation Dorsiflexion, dietary changes, heating pad Syncope: Anemia, postural hypotension Keep body temp normal, stand up slowly, check H&H Dyspnea: ↓ vital capacity, anemia Sleep propped on pillows First trimester spotting or bleeding possible miscarriage Painful urination may indicate infection Severe persistent vomiting may indicate hyperemesis gravidarum Fever over 100°F 37.7°C may indicate infection Lower abdominal pain with dizziness and shoulder pain may indicate ruptured ectopic pregnancy Second trimester regular uterine contractions may indicate preterm labor Calf pain worse with foot flexion may indicate DVT Sudden gush or fluid leakage may indicate prelabor rupture of membranes No fetal movement over 12 hours may indicate fetal distress or demise Third trimester sudden weight gain or facial swelling may indicate gestational hypertension or preeclampsia Severe upper abdominal pain headache or visual changes may indicate preeclampsia Decreased fetal movement over 24 hours may indicate possible fetal demise see slides Perinatal education Childbirth education Lamaze (psychoprophylactic) method: focus on breathing and relaxation techniques Bradley (partner-coached childbirth) method: focus on exercises and slow, controlled abdominal breathing Dick-Read (natural childbirth) method: focus on fear reduction via knowledge and abdominal breathing techniques Options for birth setting Hospitals: delivery room, birthing suite Birth centers Home birth Options for care providers Obstetrician Midwife Doula Feeding choices Breast-feeding: advantages and disadvantages Bottle feeding: advantages and disadvantages Teaching Final preparation for labor and birth
item.guid: OB/ii. Pregnancy/Ch.12 - Nursing Management in Pregnancy.md

item.title: Fetal Growth Restriction
item.description: FGRFetal Growth Restriction (FGR) is a condition where a fetus does not grow at the expected rate during pregnancy. This can lead to low birth weight and may increase the risk of complications during labor and delivery. Placental insufficiency (most common cause) Maternal hypertension or pre-eclampsia Chronic maternal illness (e.g., diabetes, kidney disease) Infections (e.g., cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, rubella) Substance abuse (e.g., smoking, alcohol, drugs) Multiple gestation (twins or higher-order multiples) Genetic abnormalities (e.g., chromosomal disorders) Poor maternal nutrition Uterine anomalies Hypertension (pre-eclampsia or chronic hypertension) Obesity or underweight Multiple pregnancies (twins, triplets) Advanced maternal age (>35 years) Smoking or substance abuse Inadequate prenatal care History of FGR in previous pregnancies Small for gestational age (SGA) on ultrasound Increased fundal height discrepancy Decreased fetal movement (late sign) Ultrasound measurements (growth scans) reveal that the fetus is smaller than expected for gestational age Oligohydramnios (low amniotic fluid) Preterm birth Stillbirth Neonatal hypoglycemia Respiratory distress syndrome Meconium aspiration Neonatal infection Long-term developmental issues Increased risk of metabolic syndrome and cardiovascular disease in later life Ultrasound (most accurate tool for diagnosing FGR) Doppler ultrasound to assess blood flow in the umbilical artery Biophysical profile (BPP) or Non-stress test (NST) to monitor fetal well-being Amniotic fluid index (AFI) to check for oligohydramnios Symphysis fundal height measurement (to assess for discrepancies) Maternal management (control underlying conditions like hypertension or diabetes) Early delivery if FGR is severe or if fetal distress is observed Increased prenatal visits for close monitoring of fetal growth Steroid therapy to accelerate fetal lung maturity if preterm delivery is anticipated Monitor fetal movements and educate the mother on how to do so (e.g., "count-to-ten" method) Educate on signs of preterm labor and when to seek medical care Monitor maternal health (e.g., blood pressure, weight, urine for protein) Support maternal nutrition (adequate caloric intake, balanced diet) Encourage cessation of smoking and avoid alcohol and drugs Prepare for potential early delivery and complications Signs of FGR: Decreased fetal movements or small abdomen Importance of prenatal visits for early detection and monitoring Nutrition: Ensure a balanced, nutritious diet to support fetal growth Smoking cessation and avoiding alcohol/substance abuse Understand fetal monitoring techniques (e.g., NST, BPP) Discuss delivery plans if early induction or cesarean section is needed

item.title: Ch.10 - Fetal Development
item.description: Fetal Development measured n number of weeks pregnancy duration is 40 weeks from time of fertilization = 9 months or 266-280 days Stages of Human Development: Zygotic Stage - fertilization of sperm and egg through the second week. Blastocyst Stage - Zygote divides into a solid ball of cells which attaches to the uterus. outer layer of cells around the blastocyst is known as trophoblast (eventually becomes the placenta) inner cells of the blastocyst form the fetus Embryonic Stage - major organs and structures begin to emerge begins at Day 15 to week 8 Amniotic sac = maintians body temp of fetus, cushion, promote fetal movement oligohydramnios - <500 ml, low amniotic fluid volume => high risk of surgical birth, low BW infant hydramnios - >2000ml, associated with maternal diabetes, neural tube defects, chromosomal deviations, etc Fetal Stage - differentiation and structures specialize by end of the eighth week until birth HCG - Human Chroionic Gonadotropin a hormone that ensures that the endometrium will be receptive to the implanting embryo. signals corpus lutem not to degenerate until placenta secretes adequate hormones present 3 days after conception Placenta - develops at end of 2nd week, complete by week 12 protects fetus from immune attack by mother removes waste, regulates hormones depends on maternal BP => impaired function if there is obstruction of blood Serving as the interface between the mother and fetus Making hormones to control the physiology of the mother to ensure fetus is supplied with nutrients and oxygen needed for growth Inducing the mother to bring more food to the placenta Producing hormones that mature into fetal organs Causes of Decreased Placental Blood Flow: Vasoconstriction or hypertension – maternal blood vessels constrict due to chronic hypertension, preeclampsia, smoking, or drug use (e.g., cocaine), reducing uteroplacental perfusion Decreased maternal blood pressure or cardiac output – maternal hypotension, cardiac disease, hemorrhage, epidural-induced hypotension, or shock reduce overall blood volume and delivery of oxygen and nutrients to the placenta Supine hypotension – gravid uterus compresses inferior vena cava when mother lies flat, decreasing venous return and cardiac output, leading to reduced placental perfusion => have mom lay on the side Excessive maternal exercise – prolonged intense activity diverts blood flow to skeletal muscles and away from uterus and placenta, transiently decreasing oxygen and nutrient delivery to the fetus Decreased blood flow to fetus: intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) or small for gestational age infant (IGA) weighs less than the 10th percentile for gestational age due to prolonged reduction in placental blood flow, leading to lower birth weight and potential long-term health effects Placental Barrier - fetal tissues that prevent the fetus and mother's blood from mixing Human Chorionic gonadotropin – preserves corpus luteum and progesterone, to maintain endometrium, basis of pregnancy tests Prolactin – regulates insulin production and sensitivity, supports lactation Human placental lactogen – modulates metabolism, develops maternal breasts, decreases insulin sensitivity to increase fetal nutrition Estrogen – enlarges breasts, uterus, genitalia, stimulates myometrial contractility Progesterone – maintains endometrium, decreases uterine contractility, stimulates metabolism and breast development, nourishes early conceptus Relaxin – vasodilates, regulates hemodynamics, works with progesterone, maintains pregnancy, relaxes pelvic ligaments, softens cervix for birth has unique shunts and vessels that close after birth lung finish developing after birth; fetal lungs are nonfunctional placenta functions as lungs => oxygenation and gas exchange fetal liver - non functioning Only brain and heart is maintained by fetus liver & lungs = > maintained by placenta 3 Important Shunts Ductus venosus — bypasses the liver and connects the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava. short cut of the liver goes from umbilical vein directly to IVC Ductus arteriosus — bypasses the lungs and connects the main pulmonary artery to the descending aorta. Foramen ovale — bypasses the right ventricle and lungs via an anatomic opening between the right and left atrium. => aka hole in the middle of the heart Umbilicus - 2 arteries, 1 VeinAt birth: foramen ovale closes with 1-2 hours, permanent closure by 6 months ductus venosus (links IVC with umbilical vein) - closes with clamping of umbilicus ductus arteriosus - closes within 72 hours after birth, permanent closure at 3-4 weeks (delayed closure results in innocent or functional murmur) L/S Ratio - helps determine lung maturity (amino only), not used as muchFormed from the amnion Lifeline from the mother to the growing embryo Contains one large vein and two small arteries Wharton jelly surrounds the vein and arteries to prevent compression At term, the average umbilical cord is 22 in long and about 1 in wideFunctions: Maintain steady thermal environment Cushion against trauma Source of oral fluid Allows the infant freedom of movementVariable decelerations may be present if there is not enough fluidFormed from: Diffusion of fluids from maternal blood Fetal urine Fetus swallows amniotic fluid Fetus breathes amniotic fluid Plays a role in lung maturation Normal volume is 800-1200 ml by term Oligohydrominos "oligo" - too little amnio, <500 ml Polyhydraminos = too much >2000 ml (might have kidney issues, check with US then check after delivery)no need to memorize critical periods of embryonic development

item.title: Menstruation Cycle
item.description: aka Ovarian Cycle Follicular phase (day 1 through ovulation, approximately days 10 to 14) Ovulation (day 14 of a 28-day cycle) Luteal phase (day 15 through day 28 of a 28-day cycle)

item.title: Headaches
item.description:
pain from stretching, constriction, dilation, or nociceptor stimulation of muscle fibers, meninges, facial structures, blood vessels, or cranial or spinal nerves varies in location, intensity (sharp, throbbing, or a dull ache) Primary Headaches - not caused by other conditions; examples: migraines, cluster headaches, tension-type headaches (TTH) Secondary - caused by other conditions such as trauma, infections, ICP, vascular disorders, etcMigraines - recurrent headaches that last for four to 72 hr; from change in cerebral perfusion; not fully understoodStatus Migrainosis - lasts for more than 72 hours Head trauma Caffeine Foods containing nitrates or tyramine Artificial sweeteners Hormonal changes Bright lights Strong odors Changes in weather Stress Skipping meals Carbon monoxide poisoning Cerebrovascular Accident
Intracranial hemorrhage (see Subarachnoid Hemorrhage - blood in space under the arachnoid membrane, most commonly from trauma/rupture of an aneurysm) Hypertension emergencies Meningitis Encephalitis Acute angle-closure glaucoma Brain tumor mild/moderate pain on both sides of head dull/band-like pressure Muscle tightness in the shoulder, neck, or back associated with sleep disturbances lasts 30 min to 7 days Severe unilateral head pain, often behind the eye Lacrimation, nasal congestion, eyelid/facial swelling, ptosis may occur (ptosis - drooping eyelid) Excruciating, nonfluctuating pain; clients may pace or rock Duration: 15 min to hours, may occur multiple times daily Prodormal Phase (Hours to Days Before Headache) Sensitivity to light, sound, odor Fatigue, yawning Food cravings, excessive thirst Mood swings Constipation or diarrhea Aura Phase (Lasts ~60 min, Precedes Headache, Reversible Symptoms, Affects ~25%) Visual, sensory, motor disturbances Tunnel vision, blindness, visual field loss Heaviness in limbs Speech/language disturbances Scintillating scotoma Tingling in face/limbs Headache Phase (Unilateral, Throbbing, Lasts Hours to Days, >72 hr = Status Migrainosus) Nausea/vomiting Photophobia, phonophobia => sensitivity to light and sound Rhinorrhea, lachrymation Loss of appetite, fatigue Postdromal Phase ("Migraine Hangover," Lasts 1–2 Days) Pain with movement in migraine location Exhaustion, dizziness Difficulty concentrating Euphoria none; usually MRI/CT - for older than 50 with no hx, if present with hypertension or AMS
Lumbar Puncture - analyze CSF for Meningitis
Analgesia - usually OTC: aspirin, aceta, NSAID Caffeine with analgesics Opioids NOT recommended Pharmacological treatments - only for headaches 3-15 times/month
Triptans - constrict intracranial vessels (e.g.: Sumatriptans, razatiptan) see Migraines pharm section Anticonvulscants - valpiruc acid, topiramate beta blockers tricyclic antidepressants botulinum toxins IV fluids steroids non pharm: biofeedback, CBT, chiropractor, assage, craniosacal therapy, yoga, accupuntcture ensure dark, quiet room NOTE: if patient complains that it is their WORST HEADACHE, assess for secondary headache to rule out life-threats avoid: cheese, meats with nitrites, aspartame, pickled foods, MSG
#nursing #medsurg #neuro

item.title: Autonomic Dysreflexia
item.description: a life-threatening condition that occurs in individuals with spinal cord injury typically at or above the T6 level => Spinal Cord Injury - SCI characterized by sudden, severe hypertension and sympathetic nervous system overactivity in response to a noxious stimulus below the level of injury Bladder distention (most common) Bowel impaction Skin irritation (tight clothing, pressure ulcers) Painful stimuli (e.g., ingrown toenail, burns) Urinary tract infections Labor in pregnant women with SCI Spinal cord injury at T6 level or higher History of previous autonomic dysreflexia episodes Poor bladder or bowel management Skin breakdown or wounds Sudden, severe hypertension Bradycardia (sometimes tachycardia) Severe pounding headache Flushing and sweating above the level of injury Pale, cool skin below the level of injury Nasal congestion Blurred vision Anxiety or feeling of impending doom Stroke Seizures Retinal hemorrhage Cardiac arrest Death if untreated Primarily clinical diagnosis based on symptoms in at-risk individuals Blood pressure monitoring Identification of trigger (bladder scan, bowel assessment, skin inspection) Sit the patient upright immediately to lower blood pressure Loosen tight clothing and remove restrictive devices Quickly assess for and treat the cause (empty bladder, disimpact bowel, treat wounds) Administer antihypertensives (e.g., nifedipine) if blood pressure remains high Monitor blood pressure frequently until episode resolves Monitor and manage bladder and bowel schedules to prevent triggers Perform regular skin inspections to prevent pressure injuries Educate patient and caregivers on early signs and emergency actions Keep emergency medications at bedside for high-risk patients Document and report all episodes of AD to the healthcare provider Recognize early signs and symptoms of AD Adhere to bowel and bladder regimens Avoid triggers such as tight clothing and prolonged pressure Carry emergency card/medical ID indicating risk for autonomic dysreflexia Seek immediate medical help if symptoms occur

item.title: Burns
item.description:
results in release of histamine and prostaglandins => vasodilation, capillary permeability => increased edema decreased immunity => no skin, exposed tissue, decreased senses increased metabolic demand => high risk for malnutrition; higher caloric needs severe dehydration => organ failure, kidney injury edema deep burns => release myoglobin => rhabdomyolysis (Release of protein and electrolytes with damage to muscle) body image issues decreased mobility d/t edema, dressings => advocate to ambulate In Terms of Thickness: Superficial - Damage to epidermis only. Appearance similar to a sunburn Superficial Partial Thickness - damage to epidermis and superficial portion of dermis and is usually pink or red and blistering and wet. Deep Partial Thickness - damage to deep in the dermis and wound is usually white or yellow, dry, and nonblanchable. Full Thickness - Damage to epidermis and dermis and subcutaneous tissue and is usually white or black/brown, dry and leathery, and nonblanchable. In Terms of Degrees: First Degree: Damage to the epidermis, such as sunburn Second degree: Damage to epidermis and dermis Third degree: Damage to epidermis and dermis that will require skin grafting Fourth degree: Same as third degree but extending into fat layer Fifth degree: Same as third degree but extending into muscle layer Sixth degree: Same as third degree but extending to the bone Bleeding => Coags
Anemia => CBC WBC
Electrolytes => CMP Albumin - low levels => edema; also indicates nutrition status BUN, Urea, Cr => kidney function ABG - respiratory acidosis Liver Enzymes
Rule of 9s TBSA: One arm: 9% One leg: 18% Head: 9% Torso Front: 18% Torso Back: 18% Groin: 1% Emergency treatment cool the burn with cool water => do not use ice ABCs 500 mL/hr of Lactated Ringer, then infuse via Parkland formula => 2-4 mL x kg x TBSA % insert foley (goal OUP of 0.5 mL/kg/hr) OG/NG decompression PRN HOB 30 Minor burns => 4c's: cool with tap or saline water, clean with mild soap, cover with ointment or dressing, comfort with OTC pain meds Major burns: debride or excision of nonviable tissue Debride within 24 hours Escharotomy - removes stiff dead skin to allow tissues to expand (important for torso or extremity as burns here can cause compartment syndrome) Parkland Formula => 2-4 mL x kg x TBSA %Rehabilitative Treatment Range of Motion exercises skin grafts (autograft = own skin, allograft = cadaver or donor, xenograft = animal) Monitor for infection record daily weights Pharmacological: Pain: opitates, sedation Benzo for anxiety Abx Topical abx with wound dressings Silver Sulfadiazine Silver Nitrate Apiary Honey Fluid Replacement goal: 0.5 mL/kg/hr of UOP or 30/mL/hr sys 90 mmHg no AMS HR < 120 see parkland formula delivery half in first 8 hours, then the remainder over 16 hours example:: 4 mL x 70kg x 40% = 11,200 mL Half in first 8 hours = 5,600 mL or 700 mL/hr the rest in 16 hours = 5,600 mL or 350 mL/hr

item.title: Pleural Effusion
item.description: abnormal accumulation of fluid in the pleural space between the visceral and parietal pleura surrounding the lungs can impair lung expansion and gas exchange. Heart failure (most common transudative cause) Pneumonia (common exudative cause) Malignancy Pulmonary embolism Liver cirrhosis (hepatic hydrothorax) Nephrotic syndrome Tuberculosis Autoimmune diseases (e.g., lupus, rheumatoid arthritis) Chronic heart or liver disease Recent thoracic surgery or trauma Malignancies Infections like pneumonia or TB Autoimmune conditions Long-term mechanical ventilation dyspnea diminished breath sounds pleuritic chest pain coughing tachypnea Underlying cause (infection): fever, chills, fatigue intercostal fullness, dullness upon percussion reduced tactile fremitus pleural friction rub CXR thoracentesis - Removal of fluid or air from around the lung. US Thoracentesis - can be at the bedside, w/ or w/o ultrasound guidance Bloody fluid = trauma milky fluid - effusion has been sitting there a long time purulent - infection Fluid Analysis => determine if a transudate or exudative effusion is present. Thoracoscopy - insertion of a thin tube with a camera into the pleural space to evaluate the pleural space and take samples of the lung tissue and lymph nodes. ​​​​​​​ Treat Cause: abx for infection, if HF => diuretics, nitroglycerin, PE => anticoagluants Pleurodesis - procedure that aims to eliminate the pleural space, the area between the lungs and chest wall, by making the two layers of the pleura (the membrane lining the lungs and chest wall) stick together. This is done to prevent the accumulation of fluid or air in the pleural space, Surgical Pleurectomy or Pleuroperitoneal Shunt Insertion - small catheter attached to a drainage bottle is inserted into the effusion. The client’s treatment can be managed on an outpatient basis.

item.title: ARDS
item.description:
Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome => occurs after 7 days of a triggering event results in pulmonary artery vasoconstriction => pulmonary hypertension life threatening and requires ventilation! Key Differences Between regular pneumonia: ARDS: can be infections or non infectious (PNA is caused by infection) rapid onset widespread alveolar damage (PNA is localized) treated with supportive care only (PNA is antibiotics + supportive) higher mortality of 30-40% Injury Trigger: Direct (e.g. pneumonia, aspiration) or indirect (e.g. sepsis, trauma) lung injury causes inflammation Alveolar-Capillary Damage: Inflammatory mediators damage alveolar-capillary membrane → increased permeability Fluid Leak: Protein-rich fluid leaks into alveoli → pulmonary edema Impaired Gas Exchange: Edema + collapsed alveoli (atelectasis) → ↓ surfactant, ↓ compliance, severe hypoxemia Ventilation-Perfusion Mismatch: Poor oxygenation despite oxygen therapy (refractory hypoxemia) Progression: Can lead to fibrotic lung changes and multi-organ failure if not reversed BERLIN DIAGNOSTIC CRITERIA (all 4 must be met): Timing - Within 1 week of clinical insult or new/worsening respiratory symptoms Chest Imaging - Bilateral opacities not fully explained by effusions, lobar/lung collapse, or nodules Origin of Edema: Respiratory failure not fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload Objective assessment (e.g., echo) needed if no clear risk factor Oxygenation (on PEEP ≥5 cm H₂O) Mild ARDS: PaO₂/FiO₂ 200–300 mmHg Moderate ARDS: PaO₂/FiO₂ 100–200 mmHg Severe ARDS: PaO₂/FiO₂ ≤100 mmHg Sepsis => MOST COMMON CAUSE Pneumonia - also common Aspiration - also common Community Acquired Pneumonia (CAP) female 60+ trauma drowning drug OD TBI recent cardiac surgery smoking alcohol abuse HIV or any Immunosuppressive state
COPD
Heart Failure - chronic
Liver Cirrhosis Blood Malignancies: cancers Immunosuppression dyspnea => progressively worsens within 6 to 72 hours after the event respiratory distress tachypnea diffuse crackles tachycardia Severe cases: somnolent, cyanosis, diaphoresis NOTE SIGNATURE MANIFESTATION: DOES NOT RESPOND TO OXYGENATION! Somnolent - reduced level of consciousness that is described as lethargic or drowsy muscle wasting - due to inactivity, patients are too SOB to do anything weight loss Functional Impairment - due to decreased mobility, atrophy, weakness Cognitive loss - caused by brain hypoxia Dependency on: g-tube for nutrition, new tracheostomy Prolonged symptoms: exertional dyspnea, exercise intolerance greater impact for geriatric Berlin Criteria for ARDS: onset occurring within 7 days of an event non-cardiac origin imaging indicating bilateral lung infiltrates specific abnormal oxygenation measurements (PaO/FiO ratio of less than 300 mm Hg to confirm the diagnosis) Other Diagnostic Tools: ABG PaO2/Fio2 - less than 300 mm Hg (normal range is over 400 => note that this is a ratio!) FiO2 & PaO2 => determines severity of ARDS (mild, moderate, severe)
Impaired Kidney Function - elevated, CMP Cardiac Enzymes - rule out cardiac origin Goals: increase O2 delivery avoid injury to lungs decrease shunting decrease O2 consumption Strategies: Lung Protective Ventilation (avoid ventilator induced trauma, not too in-depth in exam) judicious suctioning only PRN Pain Management & Sedation V/Q match Avoid infection/VAPs: HOB 30, oral care, hand hygiene Turning: passive ROMs, avoiding DVT/PE (thru SCDs, anticoagulants) Ventilator Weaning ias tolerated Treatment Interventions: Pre-intubation: high-flow O2 NC or FM Intubation meds: Sedative (etomidate), neuromuscular Blockers (succinylcholine) note: sedate before you paralyze, BVM at bedside (1 breath q.1sec) Very tube placement: CXR Verify collar pressure: between 20 and 30 cm of water Positioning: prone to relieve pressure in lungs Diuretic Nutrition: OG, NGT, PEG
Peptic Ulcer Disease prophylaxis => prevent GI bleeds or stress ulcers (usually thru PPI, see PPI and H2 Blockers) DVT Prophylaxis Trend Labs: monitor for impending sepsis or renal failure Skin Integrity Monitor for Oxygen Toxicity, Pulmonary Edema (early on), Left Ventricular dysfunction
MODS is a huge possibility Delirium - sign of hypoxia, difficulty in administering treatments max intubation is 14 days Intubated patient: vitals signs q5min Sedation scales - do not go too in-depth but familiarize yourself Assess, prevent, and manage pain Both spontaneous awakening trials (SAT) and spontaneous breathing trials (SBT) = > wean off vent, reduce o2 support, sedation vacation Choice of analgesia and sedation Delirium: assess, prevent, and manage Early mobility and exercise Family engagement and empowerment Focused Assessments: ABC: A - attend, intubated => tube placement, line tracing, vent settings, patient response (ABGs reassuring), b/l lung sounds, infection (oral care), capnography B - dyspnea, tachypnea, low SPO2, crackles, rales, C - tachycardia, cyanosis, hypotensive,

item.title: CAD & MI
item.description:
Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) - broad term involving arteries in heart leading to: either Chronic Stable Angina or ACS CAD = CSA or ACSChronic Stable Angina - predictable chest pain during exertion, resolves with rest or nitroglycerin, can progress to unstable ECG: Normal at rest; ST depression or T wave inversion during stress Cardiac Biomarkers: normal Treatment: Lifestyle changes, nitrates, beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, statins Acute Coronary Syndromes (ACS) sudden, life-threatening condition caused by a sudden reduction in blood flow to the heart Umbrella term for UA (unstable angina), NSTEMI, and STEMI ACS = STEMI / NSTEMI / UASTEMI - ischemia causing full-thickness myocardial infarction cardiac biomarkers: elevated troponin, CK-MB Treatment: Emergency PCI or thrombolysis, MONA (morphine, oxygen, nitrates, aspirin). NSTEMI - ischemia with myocardial infarction but without full-thickness injury caused by- spasm of artery, stable plaque, a cardiac embolism, or arteritis and injury to the heart similar to UA but more severe and prolonged, unrelieved by rest or nitroglycerin Cardiac Biomarkers: Elevated (troponin, CK-MB). Treatment: Same as UA with emphasis on revascularization (PCI). Unstable Angina (UA)- ischemia without myocardial infarction, cardiac markers are NOT elevated. Occurs at rest, increasing frequency/severity, lasts >20 minutes, unrelieved by nitroglycerin. Treatment: Antiplatelets (aspirin), anticoagulants, beta-blockers, nitrates, PCI if high risk. Terms to note: Infarction - tissue death or necrosis caused by prolonged lack of blood supply Ischemia - reduced cardiac tissue perfusion, can progress to infarction if unresolvedMiscellaneous Things to note: Prinzmetal angina (vasospastic angina or variant angina) - chest discomfort or pain at rest with transient ECG changes in the ST segment, and with a prompt response to nitroglycerin Atherosclerosis - plaques that narrow or occlude blood flow to coronary arteries, decreasing perfusion oxygen and nutrient demand outpace supply then causes pain hypertension, having a sedentary lifestyle, using tobacco or smoking, and by having insulin resistance or diabetes Non modifiable Risk Factors: Age (45 men, 55 women), Sex, Family history/genetics, race/ethnicity (higher w non-Hispanic white individuals) Modifiable risk factors: inactivity, poor sleep, vaping/tobacco, obesity, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, stress Comorbidities: hypertension, hyperlipidemia, thyroid disease, dm, depression, obesity, gout, cancer Chest discomfort or angina (only when demand is greater than supply) pain can radiate to the left arm, the neck, jaw, or back diaphoresis, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, SOB, lightheadedness, and weakness females may not experience chest pain (may present with extreme fatigue, dizziness, abdominal pain, nausea, and pressure in the chest) Cardiac Biomarkers - detect heart muscle damage Troponin - peaks in 24-48 hours, protein found in heart muscle, detects myocardial injury, elevated in NSTEMI, STEMI Creatine Kinase-MB - elevated; enzyme found in the heart muscle, indicates MI B-type Natriuretic Peptide (BNP) - Primarily used to r/o HF and assess the severity of volume overload or cardiac stress. C-Reactive Protein (CRP)- Measures inflammation levels; Non-specific, but often elevated in CAD & ACS Lipoprotein - LDL, HDL (see Lipid Panel) Stress Test evaluate how well the heart functions with activity, diagnose CAD and arrhythmias, evaluate treatment, and determine the risk of having an MI Exercise Stress Test - exercises on a treadmill or bicycle, with increasing intensity. HR, BP, and EKG are monitored during the test. stop stress test once chest pain is present Stress Test Echocardiogram - same as exercise but with echo (U/S) Nuclear Stress Test - radioactive dye is used during stress test Initial management: MONA (morphine, aspirin, nitro, O2)STEMI Cardiac Catherization / Coronary Angiogram - diagnostic and/or therapeutic procedure; insertion of catheter into a blood vessel visualize the coronary arteries using contrast dye and X-ray imaging to identify blockages, narrowing, or other abnormalities used to plan angioplasty, stent placement, or other revascularization procedures. PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention) - non-surgical procedure to treat coronary artery blockages and restore blood flow to the heart aka Angioplasty within 90 minutes, if not: fibrinolysis within 120 minutes catheter through the skin (usually via the groin or wrist) and threading it to the coronary arteries to open up blockages balloon angioplasty, stent placement, atherectomy CABG - coronary artery bypass graft dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and a P2Y12 inhibitor (clopidogrel, ticagrelor, or prasugrel) not first line therapy, must be given 6-9 hoursNSTEMI / UA more conservative treatment, depends on severity DAPT/anticoags, betablockers heparin does not dissolve clots, only prevents it post catherization: absent pedal pulses may be present 4-12 hourschest pain = EKG, lab draw ST is LOW = O2 is low ST is HIGH = muscles have diedelevated troponin = 150-300 mg aspirin, IV heparin antiplatelet therapy with either ticagrelor or clopidogrel taken by mouth
#nursing #medsurg #cardiovascular #mi

item.title: EKG - Critical Care
item.description:
Note only shockable rhythms: VFib, pulseless VTsee EKG for basics Overview: A rapid, abnormal heart rhythm originating in the ventricles, often life-threatening and requiring immediate intervention. Rate: 100-250 bpm Rhythm: Regular P-Waves: Not typically visible or unrelated to QRS complex QRS Complex: Wide (greater than 0.12 seconds), bizarre shape PR Interval: Not measurable or absent Stable VTACH Treatment: minimal symptoms: administer amiodarone or lidocaine (antiarrhythmic drugs), consider cardioversion if drug therapy is ineffective. unstable VTACH: immediate synchronized cardioversion or defibrillation if no pulse is present. Consider an ICD (Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator) for recurrent episodes. Symptoms: palpitations, syncope, chest pain, shortness of breath, cardiac arrest, or even sudden cardiac death. Synchronized Cardioversion typically less than what is required for defib set to synchronize => track R waves typically 50-100 joules, max 200 Remember: pulseless VT => defib, CPR, intubate, epi, ami/lidonote: VTACH is from ventricles, SVT is from atrium note: VTACH has wide QRS, SVT has narrow QRSCardioversion - performed on clients who have a pulse but are not stable hemodynamically; a low energy, synchronous shock that is delivered at the exact point of the QRS complex - R to be exactNote: follow CAB priority framework during CPRCauses: underlying ischemic heart disease, acute MI, dilated cardiomyppathy, e-, structural heart disaese, illicit drug use (meth, coke)
Overview: A rapid, erratic electrical activity in the ventricles, causing ineffective quivering instead of a coordinated contraction, leading to no pulse and requiring immediate intervention. Rate: Indeterminate (chaotic electrical activity), 150-500 bpm Rhythm: Irregular, erratic P-Waves: None QRS Complex: None, appears as a chaotic, irregular baseline PR Interval: None Treatment: Immediate defibrillation is the primary treatment. Perform CPR until defibrillator is available, followed by epinephrine or amiodarone if necessary. Advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) protocols should be followed. Causes: MI, structural heart disease, e- imbalance: hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia, hyperkalemia, hypoxia, acidosis, etcManifestations: sudden collapse due to cardiac arrest, no pulse, unresponsive

Overview: A condition where there is organized electrical activity on the EKG but no mechanical heart activity or pulse, often associated with cardiac arrest, requiring immediate intervention. Rate: Varies depending on underlying rhythm Rhythm: Can be regular or irregular depending on underlying electrical activity P-Waves: Present or absent, depending on the underlying rhythm QRS Complex: Present or absent, depending on the underlying rhythm PR Interval: Present or absent, depending on the underlying rhythm Treatment: Immediate CPR, administer epinephrine, and correct the underlying cause (e.g., hypoxia, electrolyte imbalances, trauma). Follow ACLS protocols for resuscitation. Primary Causes: cardiac Secondary Causes: Hypoxia or resp failure (50% of cases), H's & T'sH: hypovolemia, hypoxia, htdrogen ion, hypo/per-kalemia, hypothermia T: Tension pneumo, trauma, tamponade, thrombosis-pulm, thrombosis-coronaryNOTE: for CPR, follow CAB priority framework Epinephrine 1 mg q3-5 min amiodarone 300mg or lidocaine 1-1.5 mg/kg flatline result of the failure of the intrinsic electrical system of the heart often result of VFib, pulseless VTach, PEA also be the result of attempted defibrillation for another dysrhythmia terminal rhythm Presentation: no pulse, unresponsive, flatline EKGTreatment: Asystole is a non-shockable rhythm! intubation of the airway CPR (with minimal interruption of < 5 seconds) IV epinephrine (ideally within 5 minutes of the start of cardiac arrest) followed by 1 mg every 3 to 5 minutes. A conduction delay at the AV node resulting in prolonged PR interval without dropped beats; generally asymptomatic and often benign. Rate: Usually normal Rhythm: Regular P-Waves: Present, one for each QRS complex PR Interval: Prolonged (>0.20 seconds) but consistent QRS Complex: Normal (0.06-0.10 seconds) Treatment: Typically no treatment required unless symptomatic. Monitor for progression to higher-degree blocks. Address underlying causes such as medication effects, electrolyte imbalances, or ischemia.
Longer, longer, longer, drop! Then you have a WENCKEBACH Overview: A progressive delay in AV node conduction until a QRS complex is dropped; often transient and may not require treatment. Rate: Usually normal or slightly slow Rhythm: Irregular due to dropped beats P-Waves: Present, with more P-waves than QRS complexes QRS Complex: Normal (0.06-0.10 seconds) PR Interval: Progressively lengthens until a QRS complex is dropped Treatment: Typically no intervention if asymptomatic. If symptomatic (e.g., dizziness, syncope), consider atropine (for brady) or temporary pacing. Monitor closely for progression to a higher-degree block. Causes: medications sch as CCBs, beta-blockers, digitalis, amiodarone, adenosine, increase in vagal tone, post cardiac surgery, e- imbalance, cardiomyopathies, hyperkalemia, MI, myocarditisPresentation: no physical manifestations, and minimal hemodynamic alterationsIf some P’s don’t get through, then you have MOBITZ II Overview: A more serious block where some P-waves are not conducted to the ventricles without a progressive PR interval change; higher risk of progressing to third-degree block. Location: bundle of His, bundle branches, or fascicles (basically the ventricles) Rate: Usually slow, depending on the number of dropped beats Rhythm: Regular or irregular (based on conduction pattern) P-Waves: Present, with more P-waves than QRS complexes QRS Complex: Often widened (>0.12 seconds) if block occurs below the AV node PR Interval: Constant in conducted beats (no progressive lengthening) Treatment: Permanent pacemaker placement is often indicated due to risk of progression to complete heart block. Temporary pacing is done while waiting. Other info: Causes: MI, necrosis in heart, e-, CCBs, betablockers, amiodarone, digoxin, adenosine, post cardiac surgery Patho: block in conduction system (usually bundle of HIS or bundle branches) Presentation: bradycardia, fatigue, syncope, dyspnea, dizziness, palpitations, shortness of breath, and nausea Things to note if caused by meds, stop those meds there is increased risk for falls d/t fatigue, dizziness, SOB If P’s and Q’s don’t agree, then you have a THIRD DEGREE Overview: A complete heartblock! Total disruption of electrical conduction between the atria and ventricles, causing them to beat independently; a medical emergency requiring immediate intervention. Rate: Atrial rate typically normal, ventricular rate slow (usually < 40 bpm) Rhythm: Regular, but atrial and ventricular rhythms are independent P-Waves: Present, unrelated to QRS complexes (no consistent PR interval) QRS Complex: May be narrow or wide depending on the location of the block PR Interval: Variable with no consistent relationship between P-waves and QRS complexes Treatment: Immediate intervention required; temporary transcutaneous pacing followed by permanent pacemaker placement is the primary treatment. Administer atropine or epinephrine if symptomatic while awaiting pacing manifestations: varies: bradycardia, chest pain, shortness of breath, generalized fatigue, or syncope, altered LOC, JVDbradycardic manifestations: decompensated heart failure, decreased capillary refill, cool skin, diaphoresis, altered mental status, tachypnea, cool skin, retraction, and respiratory distress Things to note: increased risk for falls increased risk for nausea and aspiration Atropine is for bradycardia since 3rd Degree blocks feature a ventricular escape rhythm (which is slower) Amiodarone is for tachyarrhythmias (AFIB, VT, VF) post-op: avoid strenuous activity, keep arm immobilized do not drive for 2-3 weeks use arm sling during night time (and during day if possible) do not move arm above shoulder level wear medical alert bracelet beware of magnets, large motors, radars, MRIs no contact sports keep cellphones at least 6 inches regular monitoring of function, battery life, identified abnormal rhythms
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing

item.title: Renal Transplant
item.description: indications: ESRD, dependence on Dialysis must have donor recipient tissue match best donor: living donors, alternatives: non-heart-beating, cadaver Other indications: anuria proteinuria Marked azotemia (elevated blood urea nitrogen [BUN] and blood creatinine) Severe electrolyte imbalance (hyperkalemia, hypernatremia) Fluid volume excess conditions (heart failure, pulmonary edema) Uremic lung age younger than 2 older than 70 => age group has more comorbidities and risk factors Advanced, untreatable cardiac disease Active or recent cancer Chemical dependency Chronic infections or systemic diseases (HIV, hepatitis B or C) Coagulopathies and certain immune disorders Obesity (BMI > 35 kg/m2)Diabetes mellitus Chronic pulmonary disease Untreated gastrointestinal diseases, such as peptic ulcer disease schedule assessments: labs, bleeding times, blood type, cross match initiate: abx Immunosuppressants: corticosteroids, anti-rejection meds, cyclosporine Cyclosporine - immunosuppressive agent used to treat organ rejection post-transplant vitals q15, advance to q1hr monitor UOP => expected: 30ml/hr daily weight monitor infection, e-, organ rejection turn, cough, deep breathe, ambulate Low-fat to decrease cholesterol High-fiber to avoid constipation Increased protein to promote healing, and rebuild and maintain muscle mass Adequate intake of potassium, calcium, and phosphorus Restricted sodium intake to prevent fluid retention and hypertension especially when taking prednisone Avoidance of concentrated sugars or carbohydrates to control glycemic factors when on prednisone Magnesium supplements because cyclosporine can reduce magnesium levels​​​​​​​ Note: avoid grapefruit => causes increased cyclosporine blood levels, when taking cyclosporine. classified based on timing Hyperacute within 48 hours after surgery small blood clots to form in the transplanted kidney irreversible fever, hypertension, pain treatment: removal of kidney Acute 1 week to 2 years after surgery body destroys the donor kidney => vasculitis, cellular destruction starts with inflammation Oliguria, anuria, low-grade fever, hypertension, tenderness over the transplanted kidney, lethargy, azotemia, and fluid retention Treatment: Involves increased doses of immunosuppressive medications Chronic gradually over months to years Blood vessel injury from overgrowth of the smooth muscles of the blood vessels causing fibrotic tissue to replace normal tissue, resulting in a nonfunctioning donor kidney gradual return of azotemia, fluid retention, electrolyte imbalance, and fatigue Treatment: Conservative (monitor kidney status, continue immunosuppressive therapy) until dialysis is required Renal artery stenosis is due to scarring of surgical anastomosis. findings: hypertension, bruit, decreased kidney function: oliguria, elevated BUN & Cr task: kidney scan to verify renal blood flow treatment: angioplasty or surgery

item.title: CKD
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary gradual loss of kidney function over time
will lead to ESRD
Differences between AKI: AKI is usually reversible, CKD is not CKD is progressive, AKI is sudden (hence the term "acute") Just note that normal GFR is ≥ 90
Diabetes T2 => most common cause (Diabetes T1 can also be cause but less rare) Hypertension
Glomerulonephritis Polycystic Kidney Disease
Obstructions like Renal Calculi, BPH, tumors Chronic use of NSAIDs
Metabolic Syndrome smoking higher risk: Asian, Hispanic, and Black male 65 and older Early stage (mild to moderate): no symptoms in earlier stages; can be vague symptoms like fatigue, edema, changes in urination Fluid overload: edema, jugular vein distention, crackles in lungs, uncontrolled hypertension anemia (causes fatigue) => because of low EPO (produced by the kidneys), EPO produces RBC e- imbalance metabolic acidosis Neuro: lethargy, confusion, hand tremors, sleep disturbances, unusual behavior, and decreased mental sharpness pruritus (itchy skin) urine changes: dark, foamy, bloody urine metallic taste in mouth poor appetite & unintentional weight loss Uremic Pericarditis: S3 gallop or pericardial friction rub may be present uremic frost crystals - crystals form on the skin because your kidneys are so shot that waste builds up in your blood, causing it to sweat out and leave nasty, gritty white crystals all over you
ESRD Anemia: decreased erythropoietin production leads to lower red blood cell count Cardiovascular Disease: Increased risk of heart attack, stroke, or heart failure due to CKD's effect on blood vessels constant fluid overload Metabolic Acidosis Electrolyte Imbalances: Such as hyperkalemia (high potassium) or hyperphosphatemia Bone Mineral Disorder: Alterations in calcium and phosphate balance, leading to weakened bones.
GFR
CMP: BUN, Creatinine, e- UA: + for protein or blood Urine Albumin-to-Creatinine Ratio: A marker for kidney damage. Ultrasound or CT Scan: To evaluate kidney size, cysts, or obstructions. Kidney Biopsy: In some cases, to determine the exact cause of CKD. fluid restrictions
Diuretics
Manage BP: Hypertension meds: ACEi, ARBS Diet: low protein (to reduce kidney workload = avoid uremia), Na + K restrictions Manage anemia: ESA and iron supplements
Dialysis: hemo or peritoneal for ESRD
Kidney transplant for ESRD strict I/O monitor daily weight control blood glucose avoid nephrotoxins: NSAID, smoking, alcohol limit: phosphate, potassium, sodium => hard to excrete protein restriction Monitor vital signs (BP, HR, temp) before, during, and after dialysis. Weigh the patient before and after dialysis to assess fluid removal. Care for the dialysis access site, checking for infection, clotting, or poor flow.
