Monitor for electrolyte imbalances and adjust dialysis as needed. Hold medications like antihypertensives before dialysis. Educate the patient on treatment, diet, fluid restrictions, and adherence. Watch for complications like dialysis disequilibrium syndrome, air embolism, or bleeding. Provide emotional and psychosocial support to manage chronic illness. Ensure proper anticoagulation and monitor post-dialysis for side effects (hypotension, cramps). Practice infection control and aseptic technique when accessing the dialysis port. Excess Fluid Volume - Related to decreased kidney filtration, fluid retention. Risk for Electrolyte Imbalance - Related to impaired renal function, decreased excretion of electrolytes. Imbalanced Nutrition: Less Than Body Requirements - Related to decreased appetite, nausea, and vomiting. Fatigue - Related to anemia, uremia, altered metabolism, decreased kidney function. Risk for Infection - Related to impaired immune system, dialysis access sites. Risk for Impaired Skin Integrity - Related to edema, frequent dialysis, uremic pruritus. Disturbed Body Image - Related to physical changes (e.g., edema, dialysis access devices). Activity Intolerance - Related to decreased oxygenation, fatigue, and weakness. Risk for Impaired Gas Exchange - Related to pulmonary edema, fluid overload, respiratory distress. Chronic Pain - Related to renal disease, uremic pruritus, musculoskeletal pain.

item.title: Cirrhosis
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinalNote difference between Liver Failure & Cirrhosis Liver Failure - loss of liver function caused by damage from drugs, infection, or cirrhosis late-stage condition that presents with advanced fibrosis or scarring of the liver = impaired liver function irreversible but can be slowed with treatment can be compensated or non-compensated can advance to liver failure compensated - liver has compensated and continues to make corrections accordingly with no external indications of the disorder non-compensated - presents with ascites, hepatic encephalopathy, GI bleed jaundice alcohol abuse
Hepatitis BCD NAFLD, NASH genetic bile duct disease meds obesity, diabetes, age, family hx exposure to toxins or chemicals IV Drug use, sharing needles unprotected sex meds that affect liver jaundice of eyes and skin N/V abdominal pain, swelling increased bruising lower extremity edema hyponatremia spider angioma - spiderlike veins on skin weight loss or muscle wasting pruritus (caused by buildup of bile salts) hepatic encephalopathy Ascites - fluid in peritoneal cavity severe: confusion, drowsiness, personality change (indicates hepatic encephalopathy) bilirubin in urine: amber or coca-cola urine Portal Hypertension - causes ascites; blood pressure in the liver’s veins gets so high, it starts causing swollen belly and bleedingAlcoholics: early satiety; because all they do usually is drink
fluid in peritoneal cavity may lead to pulmonary complications, hernias, Peritonitis, sepsis Variceal Rupture - a life-threatening condition that occurs when abnormally enlarged veins in the esophagus or stomach burst and bleed
Ammonia build-up leading to Cerebral Edema and ultimately increased ICP Hepatic encephalopathy: A decline in brain function due to the liver's inability to remove toxins, leading to confusion, drowsiness, and even coma.
Coagulopathy - cant stop bleeding, Thrombocytopenia Hemodynamic Instability: fatigue, anemia, reduced oxygen delivery liver cancer
infections - from Peritonitis antinuclear antibody (ANA) test, the anti-mitochondrial antibody (AMA) test, and the anti-smooth muscle antibody (SAM) test => confirms cirrhosis, and autoimmune diseases
CBC - r/o anemia/internal bleeding Imaging - MRI, US, CT, MRE Elastography - noninvasive scans to check fibrosis Hepatitis Panel
LFT: ↑ AST, ALT, ALP, GGT, Bili
Coags: increased bleeding risk (Low levels of coagulation factors produced by the liver): ↑PT, INR, aPTT
CBC: anemia Other: ↑ ammonia, ↓ cholesterol
treat cause (see Hepatitis) no cure for cirrhosis => only option is liver transplant edema/ascites - diuretics Lactulose - reduce ammonia levels, encephalopathy Betablockers - portal hypertension Vit K & FFP = coagulopathy Parecentesis - remove fluid from ascites Cancer treatment Surgery - ligation of varices monitor bleeding / shock - from variceal rupture sodium restriction - 5-5.6g/day low fat diet check weight d/t edema, ascites check abdominal girth observe LOC (Hepatic Encephalopathy) low Na diet
monitor LFT calculate calorie requirement using ideal body weight no long nails eat smaller, more frequent meals => reduce N/V Risk for Bleeding: Due to impaired clotting factor production. Fluid Volume Excess: Caused by ascites and edema from portal hypertension. Imbalanced Nutrition: Less than Body Requirements: Due to reduced appetite, malabsorption, and metabolic changes. Risk for Infection: Due to compromised immune function and potential for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Acute Pain: Related to liver inflammation or distension from ascites. Disturbed Thought Processes: From hepatic encephalopathy caused by toxin buildup. Fatigue: Due to decreased liver function and overall metabolic disturbances. Impaired Skin Integrity: Related to pruritus, ascites, or jaundice. Impaired Liver Function: Related to ongoing liver damage. Anxiety: Due to chronic illness and concerns about disease progression.

item.title: Parkinson's
item.description:
degenerative, progressive condition primarily caused by dopamine depletion in substantia nigra leads to motor and non-motor symptoms mainly affects movement but can also impact cognition and autonomic functions Low on Dope: dopamine High on Acetylcholine => lots of secretions and drooling (rest and digest) Low on Norepinephrine Hallmark finding: Lewy bodies => abnormal structures inside brain cells Idiopathic (most common) Genetic mutations (e.g., PARK genes) Environmental toxins (e.g., pesticides, heavy metals) Brain injury or repeated head trauma Certain medications (drug-induced parkinsonism) male family history Age >60 years exposure to environmental toxins (heavy metals, pesticides, and chemical toxins) history of TBI
Diabetes T2 Low dopamine effects: tremors, slow movement, stiffness, and problems with balance (fall risk) Low norepinephrine effects: fatigue, irregularities in blood pressure, and slowed movement of the gastrointestinal tract. HIGH Acetylcholine Effects: secretions, drooling Motor Symptoms: Resting tremor (pill-rolling, worsens at rest) = decreased when diverted by activity Gait: propulsive shuffling, decreased arm swing Bradykinesia (slowed movements, difficulty initiating) Muscle rigidity (cogwheel or lead-pipe rigidity) Postural instability (frequent falls, shuffling gait) Non-Motor Symptoms: Autonomic dysfunction (orthostatic hypotension, constipation, urinary retention) drooling Cognitive impairment (dementia in later stages) Depression, anxiety Sleep disturbances (REM behavior disorder, insomnia) Anosmia (loss of smell) Increased fall risk leading to fractures Aspiration pneumonia (due to dysphagia and excessive drooling) => suction at bedside available!
Dementia (Parkinson’s disease dementia) Depression, social isolation Medication side effects (dyskinesia, hallucinations) no definitive test mainly clinical diagnosis (based on motor symptoms, response to levodopa) MRI/CT (rule out other conditions) DaTscan (dopamine transporter imaging to support diagnosis) Levodopa-carbidopa (most effective for motor symptoms) Dopamine agonists (pramipexole, ropinirole) MAO-B inhibitors (selegiline, rasagiline) Anticholinergics (for tremors in younger patients) Amantadine (for dyskinesia) Deep brain stimulation (DBS) for medication-resistant cases Rehab: expiratory muscle strength training PT OT speech High-protein diet timing (to avoid interfering with levodopa absorption) =>Leave the PROTEIN with LEVOdopa wandering precautions => use signs on doors, place locks Falls Risk Dysphagia => Aspiration encourage physical activity expiratory muscle strength training (EMST)
#nursing #medsurg #neuro

item.title: Spinal Cord Injury - SCI
item.description:
CNS => brain & spinal cord Meninges - continuous connective tissue layers covering the spine and brain Layers of meninges: pia mater, arachnoid, dura CSF = located in subarachnoid space Spinal Cord roles: send stimuli from body to brain send motor instructions from brain to body direct reflexes Spinal Cord Reflexes - do not rely on brain to transmit reflexVertebrae Count- In Order: Breakfast at 7, Lunch at 12, Dinner at 5 Cervical - 7 (but has 8 cervical nerve roots) Thoracic - 12 Lumbar - 5 Sacral - 5 Coccyx - 1 Classification based on Mechanism of Injury: Compression of Spinal Cord - most common, caused by vertebral fractures with bone fragments or dislocation Intermittent Compression - often seen in hyperextension injuries Distraction Injury - two adjoining vertebrae have been pulled apart, causing the spine to stretch and tear. Transection and Laceration - a projectile object or bone fragments from significant dislocations can tear or sever the spinal cord. Classification based on Location => see vertebrae countClassification based on Severity => loss of all sensation and control below the damage (complete, vs incomplete) A - complete SCI, no sensory function, no motor function B - some sensory function, no motor function C - some sensory function, some motor function (less than half can lift against gravity) D - same as C, but more than half have motor Secondary Injury - result after the initial injury d/t impaired blood flow (e.g. inflammation, hematoma formation, blood loss, and hypovolemic shock) Impaired Mobility Sexual Dysfunction - depends on level of injury Mental health: dealing with changes and limitations, body image, suicide risk Aging => patients with SCIs age faster => more likely to have bone loss, chronic pain, kidney stones, and pressure injuries prevention: motor vehicle safety, seat belts, airbags, car seats, no texting, no DUIs Falls risk for elderly responsible gun ownership sports protective gear water safety Trampolines are well lit and ground level to prevent falls, avoid crowing, netting in place, supervise **Tetraplegia injuries from C1 to T1 unable to move all extremities (can be all the way from head, neck, to legs) Paraplegia loss of fnuction of lower portion of body from chest to lower extremities T2 to S5 5 Plexuses: C1 to C4: ventilator dependence C1 to C8: limited proprioception T1 to T8: affects trunk movement, lack of abdominal control T9 to T12: limited abdominal control L1 to S5: loss of bowel and bladder functioning, affects sexual function GI: spastic bladder => leakage of stool and urine, bladder flaccidity, inability to expel stool or urine a complication wherein severe SCI causes loss of muscle tone and reflexes spinal cord may appear functionless transient and can have some recovery manifestations: loss of anal sphincter tone, and the absence of bowel and bladder control Atelectasis & Pneumonia => decreased cough strength, higher risk of pulmonary complications Heterotopic Ossification - abnormal bone growth into non-skeletal areas, such as soft tissues, muscles, or tendons develops 3-12 weeks after injury, but can occur years later usually occurs in the shoulders, elbows, and knees more common in females
Autonomic Dysreflexia - exaggerated reflexive response which increases blood pressure due to a noxious stimulus below the level of injury BP over 150 mm Hg sys, or over 40 diastolic over baseline caused by certain triggers: pain pressure ulcers, fractures, urinary tract infections, sexual intercourse, constipation, and surgery. Any noxious stimulus can trigger AD. increased risk of clots and skin breakdown d/t decreased movement treatment: ROM exercises, meds, therapy can be life threatening for above the T6 level SCI Skin Issues => logroll using c-collar, remove backboards ASAP, use dynamic mattresses patient sit upright with legs dangling remove tight clothing vitals Q5 remove triggering stimulis: drain bladder, fecal impaction Lower BP: nifedipine 10 mg via bite and swallow technique, repeat q20-30 min, or nitroglycerine preventL self-catherization 5-6 times per day, digital rectal stimulation laxatives Imaging: XR, CT, MRI
GCS Halo Fixation Device - rigid external immobilization device for the upper cervical spine consent needed nurse: ensure wrenches and tools are attached to the vest in case of an emergent need to remove or tighten the device Pin Care: daily or per provider orders, clean with hydrogen peroxide, betadine, or other antiseptic. crusts are removed with cottown swabs separate supplies for each pin site Surgical - removal of vertebrae, herniated discs, or bone fragments pressing on spine Surgical - spinal decompression => relives pressures Rehabilitation - PT, OT => begins on day one NGT Decompression => if paralytic ileus is present foley for retention (expected) TENS - transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation Diet: fluid and fiber intake to increase their stool's water content to encourage gastric transit Injury Prevention: decrease the frequency of propulsive strokes during wheelchair mobility and to decrease the number of transfers in a day

item.title: SIADH
item.description:
SI = "soaked inside", same amount of koolaid but diluted with too much water => hyponatremia (no flavor), low osmolality condition characterized by excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) => aka too much VASOPRESSIN causes water retention, dilutional hyponatremia, and low serum osmolality. Commonly associated with malignancies, neurological disorders, and certain medications. Note: Diabetes Insipidus is the direct opposite of SIADH
Note: ADH is also called Vasopressin, so in order to treat SIADH, Vasopressin ANTAGONISTS are used (Tolvaptan, Conivaptan) => only in severe cases
Cancer: Small cell lung cancer (common test question), pancreatic cancer, leukemia.
CNS disorders: Stroke, TBI, Meningitis, brain tumors.
Pulmonary conditions: Pneumonia, tuberculosis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Medications: SSRIs, opioids, antipsychotics, chemotherapy agents. Postoperative stress: Surgical procedures, especially brain or thoracic surgeries. mnemonic: SSS S - small cell lung cancer S - severe brain trauma S - sepsis infections of brain (meningitis) Elderly individuals: More prone to impaired water balance.
Cancer patients: Particularly with small cell lung cancer. Neurological disorders: Brain trauma, infections, and strokes increase risk. Certain medications: Drugs that enhance ADH secretion or action. Neurological symptoms: Headache, confusion, irritability, seizures, coma (due to hyponatremia). Gastrointestinal symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, anorexia. Fluid retention: Weight gain, without edema (since fluid is retained intracellularly). Cardiovascular effects: Hypertension, bounding pulses, jugular vein distension. Urinary changes: Decreased UOP, concentrated urine with high specific gravity. Severe hyponatremia (<120 mEq/L): Can lead to seizures, coma, and death. Cerebral edema: Due to water shifting into brain cells, leading to increased intracranial pressure (ICP). Pulmonary edema: Fluid overload can impair respiratory function. ADH elevated (normal 1-5 ng/L) Low serum sodium (<135 mEq/L). Low serum osmolality (<280 mOsm/kg) => normal is 275-290 mOsm/kg Normal or high urine sodium. High urine osmolality (>100 mOsm/kg). High urine specific gravity (>1.030). => normal range is between 1.005 and 1.030. ADH levels: Increased despite normal or expanded intravascular volume. Fluid restriction: First-line treatment (500–1000 mL/day) to prevent further dilutional hyponatremia. Hypertonic saline (3%): For severe hyponatremia, given cautiously to prevent rapid sodium shifts. Diuretics (loop diuretics like furosemide): To promote free water excretion if sodium is >125 mEq/L. Demeclocycline: A tetracycline that blocks ADH action in kidneys. Vasopressin receptor antagonists (Tolvaptan, Conivaptan): Block ADH effect in severe cases. Monitor sodium levels closely to prevent complications of rapid correction (e.g., central pontine myelinolysis). Assess for neurological changes: Confusion, restlessness, seizures, and coma. Strict fluid intake and output (I&O) monitoring to prevent fluid overload. Daily weights to detect fluid retention. Implement seizure precautions for patients with severe hyponatremia. Educate patients on fluid restrictions and symptoms of worsening SIADH. Excess fluid volume related to water retention. Risk for electrolyte imbalance related to hyponatremia. Risk for injury related to confusion, seizures, or altered mental status. Ineffective cerebral perfusion related to cerebral edema from hyponatremia.

item.title: Cerebral Edema
item.description:
swelling of brain can be fatal results in herniation = swelling exerts pressure on brain (ICP), blood restriction induces hypoxia
TBI / concussion
Stroke Brain Tumors or abscesses
Interstitial Shift: CSF increased, hydrocephalus, Meningitis, encephalitis Osmotic Shift/Edema: DKA, hyponatremia High-altitude cerebral edema (HACE) Carbon Monoxide poisoning Reye's syndrome lead poisoning Hepatitis (Ammonia buildup in bloodstream causes brain swelling) uncontrolled BP smoking Diabetes => DKA activities that result in high risk for falls headache (most common) neck rigidity/pain Cushing's Triad => 1. hypertension, 2. brady, 3. irregular respirations N/V dizziness respiratory pattern changes vision changes ataxia - lack of muscle coordination, balance aphasia - inability to speak or understand speecj seizure LOC pupil changes CN deficit
increased ICP, leads to herniation coma, brains stem compression respiratory failure CT/MRI - determine midline shift, herniation ICP monitoring - invasive procedure
CBC - e- LP goal: decrease hypertension, control edema, decrease ICP Surgical: removal of tumors/lesions, shunt insertion, damaged vessel repair hyperbaric oxygen therapy hypertonic IVF to decrease CE Induced hypothermia to redice swelling Ventriculostomy - drain CSF Diuretics - reduce swelling (i.e. osmotic diuretics such as mannitol, hypertonic saline) glucocorticoids - reduce swelling induced coma anticonvulsants monitor GCS & pupil response - detect deterioration maintain HOB @ 30 deg avoid excessive stimulation: loud noises, bright lights, frequent repositioning Avoid HTN Prevent fever: increases metabolic demand and ICP Avoid dehydration and HYPOnatermia: worsens CE Prepare for intubation if brainstem compression worsens Prepare for seizures
#nursing #medsurg #neuro

item.title: ICP
item.description:
Increased pressure within the skull due to brain swelling, excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), or bleeding Can lead to brain herniation and death if untreated Normal ICP: 5-10 mmHg; Critical ICP: >20 mmHg Note: MAP (Mean Arterial Pressure) => good indicator of cerebral perfusion; minimum: 60 mm Hg; too high MAP leads to decreased blood flow to brain Increase in Brain volume: Cerebral Edema, hemorrhage, tumor, abscess, infarction
Increase in CSF: hydrocephalus, Meningitis, choroid plexus tumor, just plain old increase CSF Increased Blood Volume: venous stasis, elevated CVP Other Causes - idiopathic intracranial hypertension, skull deformities, tetracycline use Individual Causes:
TBI
Stroke
Cerebral Edema - head trauma, hypoxia, liver failure (ammonia buildup) Intracranial Hemorrhage Severe Hypertension Head trauma (falls, car accidents, assaults) Aneurysm rupture (subarachnoid hemorrhage) Severe infections (meningitis, encephalitis) Brain tumors or metastases Congenital conditions (hydrocephalus, Arnold-Chiari malformation) Liver failure (risk of cerebral edema from ammonia buildup) Early Signs: altered LOC: confusion, restlessness, drowsiness Headache (worsens with movement, coughing, or straining) Blurred vision, diplopia (double vision) Photophobia N/V Late Signs (Cushing’s Triad - Brainstem Compression): Hypertension with widening pulse pressure Bradycardia (slow heart rate) Irregular respirations (Cheyne-Stokes or Biot’s breathing) Other late signs: Papilledema (swelling of optic disc) Pupil changes (unequal, sluggish, or fixed/dilated) Posturing: decorticate (flexion), decerebrate (extension) seizures coma Brain herniation (fatal displacement of brain tissue) Permanent neurological deficits (motor, sensory, cognitive impairments)
Seizures Coma and death CT scan/MRI (detect swelling, bleeding, tumors, hydrocephalus) ICP monitoring (ventriculostomy, intraparenchymal device) Lumbar puncture contraindicated => increases ICP (d/t decreasing pressure gradient in spine further pushes brain downward) Fundoscopic exam (papilledema) Ventriculostomy - insertion of a catheter into one of the brain's ventricles to drain cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) or to monitor intracranial pressure. Ventriculostomy Transducer => maintain at the level of the tragus Reduce ICP and prevent complications Elevate HOB 30 degrees (promotes venous drainage) Oxygen therapy (maintain cerebral oxygenation) Mechanical ventilation (if necessary) – PaCO₂ 30-35 mmHg to reduce cerebral blood flow Surgery: craniotomy, external ventricular drain (EVD) to drain excess CSF, decompressive craniectomy (remove park of skull) Decrease metabolic demand: barbiturates, sedation, pain control Medications: Osmotic diuretics (mannitol) – reduces cerebral edema => initial target of serum osmolality is often set at 300–320 mOsmol/kg. Hypertonic saline (3%) – pulls fluid out of brain cells Corticosteroids (dexamethasone) – for tumors, inflammation Sedatives (propofol, benzodiazepines) – decrease metabolic demand Antiepileptics – prevent seizures: benzo, phenytoin, valproic acid Neuromuscular blockers (for severe cases requiring intubation) No Lumbar Punctures allowed! => increases ICP (d/t decreasing pressure gradient in spine further pushes brain downward) Monitor LOC and Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) (↓ GCS = worsening ICP) maintaining the ventriculostomy transducer at the level of the tragus Assess pupil reaction (PERRLA) and vital signs frequently Maintain head and neck alignment (avoid flexion or turning head) Minimize stimulation (low lights, quiet room) Avoid straining (stool softeners, prevent coughing/sneezing) Cluster nursing care to minimize ICP spikes Seizure precautions (padded rails, oxygen, suction at bedside) Monitor for signs of herniation (fixed dilated pupils, loss of reflexes, coma)

item.title: Seizures
item.description:
abnormal and unregulated electrical impulses in the brain’s gray matter caused by acute medical issue or recurring (epilepsy) varied presentation Types: generalized (both hemispheres), focal (one hemisphere), unknown Category: motor, nonmotorStatus Epilepticus seizure lasting more than 5 minutes recurring seizures without regaining consciousness between episodes emergency! leads to permanent brain damage, hypoxia, death Priority: maintain airway, benzo, antiepileptics if continuous: intubate and sedate Structural abnormalities (tumors, stroke, trauma) Metabolic imbalances (Hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, hypoxia)
Infections (Meningitis, encephalitis, fever in children) - most common Toxic exposure (alcohol withdrawal, drug overdose) Genetic disorders (epilepsy syndromes) Unknown Stress Sleep Deprivation or Fatigue Strobe Lights Stimulants Sugar and Low Sodium 4 Stages of Seizures: Prodormal - hours or days before seizure, anxiety, mood changes, difficulty sleeping Early Ictal or Aura - warning stage: strange smells, taste or feelings, deja vu, excitement Ictal - main seizure Postictal - seizure ends; confusion, drowsiness, headache, muscle soreness, memory loss, weakness Generalized Seizures - affects both hemispheres of the brain Tonic-Clonic (Grand Mal) - LOC, muscle rigidity (tonic), rhythmic jerking (clonic), postictal confusion Absence (Petit Mal) - brief loss of awareness, blank stare, eye blinking or lip smacking, common in children Myoclonic - (myo=muscle), sudden, brief muscle jerks, no LOC Tonic - toned muscles (muscle contractions/stiffening, causing falls) Clonic - (repetitive = clone) repetitive jerking movements, usually symmetrical, contraction then relaxation Atonic (Drop Attacks) - sudden loss of muscle tone, leads to falls Focal / Partial Seizures - only one brain hemisphere Focal Aware / Simple Partial - no LOC, localized symptoms (twitching, sensory changes Focal Impaired Awareness / Complex Partial - altered consciousness, automatism (lip smacking, picking at clothes), postictal confusion Status Epilicticus medical emergency! seizure lasting >5 minutes ore repeated seizures without recovery may occur with ant type of seizure injury from falls, aspiration, or trauma hypoxia or metabolic disturbances cognitive impairment with recurring seizures EEG (detects abnormal brain activity) - usually after a seizure MRI/CT scan (identifies structural causes) Blood tests (checks for metabolic or toxic triggers) Lumbar puncture (if infection suspected) supportive care: maintain ABC, keep free from injury First line - benzodiazapines (IV, IM, rectal) Recurrent issues: anticonvulsants (12 categories, too many to mention, common=>phenytoin AED) vagal nerve stimulation neurostimulation lesionectomy or lobectomy seizure precautions: call for help, padded side rails, lower bed, O2 & suction at bedside do not restrain client do not put tongue blade in mouth during seizure do not put airway or open jaw during seizure clear area for any hard objects Loosen clothes from around the head, neck, or chest place client in lateral position (left side if possible) - to prevent aspiration Maintain the airways and suction if needed record time of seizure, note duration after seizure, assess ABC: including presence of gag reflex after seizure: provide supplement O2 , check ABC, VS, neuro check, reorient anything that could be dangerous with unexpected seizure climbing tall structures working from heights cooking over fire operating power tools taking baths/swimming WITHOUT supervision driving
#nursing #medsurg #neuro

item.title: TBI
item.description: Types of mechanical forces: Direct - direct blow to the head resulting in bruising of the brain. Rotational - abrupt, rotating impact to the head i.e., an acceleration-deceleration injury. Shear - Happen when the brain shifts and rotates inside the bony skull causing shearing of the axons in the brain i.e., diffuse axonal injury. TBI Classification Primary Injury - skull fracture, contusion, concussion (can be focal, diffuse, or both) Secondary - ischemia, hypoxia, increased ICP, Cerebral Edema Coup - A brain injury site on the same side of the striking force. Contre-Coup - injury site on the opposite side of the striking force caused by the brain impacting the skull.Mild TBI - concussion Closed Head Injuries - blunt impact, MVC, fall Penetrating Head Injuries - exposed to infection Explosive Blast neuropathological brain disease associated with multiple mild to severe TBIs caused by sustained repetitive concussions (contact sports, boxing, wrestling) can only be diagnosed after death => limited understanding of the disease changes related to cognitive function, impaired memory and thinking patterns, behavior with increased aggression and impulsivity, moods with depression and anxiety Loss of consciousness for seconds to minutes Headache Confusion Dizziness Blurred vision Ringing in the ears Tiredness Changes in behavior or mood Sensitivity to light or sound Nausea or vomiting Changes to sleep patterns Loss of consciousness for minutes to hours Persistent headache Seizures Loss of vision, dilated pupils Difficulty understanding, communicating, or concentrating Extremity weakness Coordination and balance challenges Sensory perception changes Aggression Depression CSF Leakage => may lead to meningitis, damage to brain spinal cord Hyperoxia => too much oxygen, leads to arterial vasoconstriction and injury to the brain, lungs, and heart. standard labs: CBC, CMP, urine toxicology screen, blood alcohol level non-contrast head CT, MRI, angiography to identify vascular injuries maintain cerebral perfusion pressure greater than 60 mm Hg maintain ABC Decrease ICP: Mannitol, hypertonic saline, and barbiturates Surgical: decompressive craniectomy or placement of external ventricular drains or cisternostomy to monitor and maintain intracranial pressures Therapeutic hypothermia (TH) - lowering of a client’s body temperature from 32° C (89.6° F) to 35° C (95° F) to protect brain function IVF, pressors PRN HOB 30-45 Maintain alignment of the head, keep transducer at correct levels Sedation & Analgesia Seizure prophylaxis Insulin Sliding Scale Nursing: adequate nutrition, skin integrity, infection prevention, seizure precautions, trend vital signs, GCS, I/Os

item.title: Intro to Critical Care & Emergency Nursing
item.description: Primary Triage - in the field Secondary - at ED, triage nurse assigns 3 or 5 tier categories Tertiary - when the client exits the ED and is moved into the ICU or operating room Emergent - life-threatening illness or injury Urgent - treatment can be delayed, not immediately life-threatening Delayed - minor injuries or illnesses, higher priority patients are dealt with first Patient assessment Primary Survey- ABCDE Secondary Survey - Head to Toe assessment Tertiary Survey - final step to uncover injuries that have been missed => anytime and before hospital discharge External Regulations in Nursing: state laws Internal Regulations in Nursing: organization policy & procedures critical care nurses are except from state nurse practice acts when they work in Federal entities: VA, DOD, Indian Health Service EMTALA Emergency Medical Treatment and Active Labor Act (EMTALA) - law that prevents refusing care to uninsured patients EMTALA: patients need to be stabilized first before transferring to another facility EMTALA - exception during during disasters, patients can be transferred without being stabilized first all documentation should be transferred with the patient SEXUAL ASSAULT fear of being stigmatized => #1 reason why victims do not report Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) should be assigned to the client who has experienced sexual assault: provide support, forensic exams, collect evidence "rape kit" sexual assault victims - collect evidence, test HIV with PEP, emergency contraception Certified Forensic photographer must take photos Consent must be obtained prior to exam Collect evidence ASAP HIV prophylaxis must be given within 72 hours provide contraception ASAP Breaking bad news: provide information in bit and pieces to allow for digestion of information Media relations: do no talk with them, follow protocols Social media: avoid sharing information, follow HIPAA nurse should also be aware of the location of the Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) on all chemicals used in the facility. hazard vulnerability analysis, Emergency Operations Plan - required by joint commission PPE Shortage - reuse them by cleaning, do not conserve: PPE usage is still required Phases: Planning - risk assessment, identifying hazards, creating disaster plan Response = activation of plan, command post, lines of communication, nurse provides triage and care Recovery - continued care, monitor, transport, watch mental health of team and patients, evaluate Green Tag - minor injuries, obeys commands: lacerations, sprains Yellow - delayed: fractures, open wounds, deep lacerations Red - immediate, may survive if treated, neuro injury, shock, major burns, CPR is applied, hemcon Black - deceased or not expected to live provide power to government officials to activate authorities and resources bystander CPR programs - offered by AHA Stop the Bleed program - teach bystanders to stop blood loss #medsurg #criticalcare #nursing
item.guid: Med-Surg/Z - Misc Topics/Intro to Critical Care & Emergency Nursing.md

item.title: Anemia
item.description: abnormally low RBC, Hgb concentration, or HCT indicator of underlying disease or disorder results in diminished o2 carrying capacity and delivery to tissues and organs Little to no manifestations in mild cases Pallor Fatigue, somnolence, and headache Irritability Numbness and tingling of extremities (paresthesia) Dyspnea on exertion Sensitivity to cold Pain and hypoxia with sickle-cell crisis SOB, tachy, dizziness nail deformities when chronic goal of treatment is to restore and maintain adequate tissue oxygenation Iron Supplements: oral, IV for severe cases Iron Oral Supplements => must take on EMPTY stomach to increase absorption do not take with calcium supplements Vitamin C increases iron absorption Erythropoietin: epoetin alfa - ematopoietic growth factor used to increase production of RBCs monitor for increased BP, monitor CBC, monitor for cardiac event B12 supplements - to convert folic acid administer parenterally if lack of intrinsic factors/stomach malabsorption Folic Acid Supplements Blood Transfusions - for severe only due to risk of infections Prevention: pregnant/menstruating = ensure more iron foods, iron supplements iron-deficient and have elevated cholesterol levels => eat more iron-rich foods that are not red or organ meats into their diets eat more folate (spinach, lentils, bananas) and folic acid fortified grains and juices Iron supplements causes constipation = increase FIBER intake CALCIUM (milk) disrupts iron absorption CBC #cbc Mean corpuscular volume (MCV): Size of red blood cells Normocytic: Normal size Microcytic: Small cells Macrocytic: Large cells Mean corpuscular Hgb (MCH): Determines the amount of Hgb per RBC Mean corpuscular Hgb concentration (MCHC): Indicates percentage of Hgb present relative to the size of the cell Iron Studies Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) - an indirect measurement of all proteins that bind with iron and transports it for storage Sickle cell Schilling Test - measure B12 absorption for G6PD blood loss Inadequate RBC production (hypoproliferative) Increased RBC destruction (hemolytic) Deficiency of necessary components (folic acid, iron, erythropoietin, vitamin B12) acute or chronic blood loss (trauma, menorrhagia, GI, chemical or radiation exposure) rapid metabolic activity: pregnancy, adolescence, infection Increased hemolysis: Sickle Cell, Impaired Glycolysis: G6PD deficiency anemia, Immune Disorders, Trauma to RBCs: mechanical heart valve, cardiopulmonary bypass Diet or malabsorption: iron, folic acid Pernicious Anemia - deficiency of intrinsic factor produced by gastric mucosa, which is necessary for absorption of vitamin B12 Pica - persistent eating of substances not normally considered food (nonnutritive substances), such as soil or chalk Bone Marrow Suppression - exposure to radiation or chemicals Aplastic anemia - results in fewer RBCs as well as decreased platelets and WBC Age - Older adult clients are at risk for nutrition-deficient anemias; can be misdiagnosed as depression Complications heart failure due to increased heart demand

item.title: Valvular Dysfunctions
item.description:
abnormal function or structure of heart valve leading to impaired heart blood flow leads the Heart Failure, cardiac arrest, death can either be inability to fully open or close: stenosis - narrowing, valves do not completely open; caused by calcification of the valves regurgitation - backflow; valves do not close completely congenital => born with it rheumatic disease - infection from strep throat that was not treated promptly with antibiotics, leading to scarring of the heart valve
Endocarditis - infection of the inner layer of the heart, is caused by septicemia or intravenous drug use Heart diseases: MI, hypertension, atherosclerosis of aorta, HF Autoimmune: lupus, marfan syndrome (connective tissue disorder), high dose radiation, aging process age (over 75) inactivity high fat/sodium/sugar diet obesity family hx defibrillators/pacemakers
IV Drug use => risk for Endocarditis Comorbidities: HTN, HLD, AFib, DM Medical Procedures: dilation of L ventricle, radiation treatment previous heart surgeries Cardiac: chest pain, arrhythmia, heart murmur Respiratory: dyspnea, PND (paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea) Constitutional: fatigue, weakness Neuro: dizziness heart failure symptoms: lower extremity edema FLASH PUMONARY EDEMA abdominal pain from large liver; ascites note: symptoms present when disease has progressed
Heart Failure AFIB Thromboembolism
Endocarditis Sudden Death echocardiogram - gold standard, measures pressure on each valve, EF note: patients lie on LEFT side normal EF: 50-70% Transthoracic Echocardiogram (TTE) Transesophageal Echocardiogram (TEE) - small transducer is introduced into the throat and passed down the esophagus into the stomach CXR, MRI, ECG - detects enlarged chambers (abrnomal) Cardiac Catherization - aka angiogram, catheter is inserted into either an artery, dye used, then x-ray Stress Test - exercise to determine capacity Drug Therapy: Beta blockers: lower BP/HR CCB - C = calms the heart (low BP, low HR) Digoxin - Increase contractility, decrease HR, cardiac remodeling! Diuretics Vasodilators Surgical Valve repair balloon valvuloplasty minimally invasive procedure that expands the openings of stenosed valves small catheter is threaded into a vessel in the groin and advanced into the heart At the end of the catheter is a balloon, which is guided into the narrowed heart valve balloon is inflated to dilate the valve, and the leaflets of the valve are separated valve replacement - from cow, pig, human, mechanical/artificial Mechanical valves: must be younger than 65; must take Warfarin forever Biological valves: older than 65, kidney disease, warfarin, pregnant, increased risk for bleeding Lifestyle mods Heart Failure Care: daily weights, fluid balance infection prevention - dental hygiene; brush and floss regularly report signs of infection
monitor for bleeding: PTT, INR => Coags Maintain consistent intake of vitamin K
monitor for DVT

item.title: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
item.description:
blood enters space between arachnoid membrane and the pia membrane common cause: ruptured cerebral aneurism neurological emergency that leads to Increased ICP, brain ischemia, death high mortality rate: 10-15% die prior to ED arrival, 25% within 24 hr, 40% within 1 month Aneurysm Rupture
TBI Hypertensive crisis bleeding disorders hypertension smoking alcohol use disorder cocaine use Ehler-Danlos Syndrome Type IV Marfan's Syndrome Ruptured Aneurysm Risk Factors: 40-50+ years old, female EARLY SIGNS Severe “thunderclap” headache – sudden onset “worst headache of my life” Double vision Neck pain Stiffness Altered consciousness Cranial nerve palsy (CN III & VI) => hearing/balance & neck muscles Nausea and vomiting LATE SIGNS: vasospasm cerebral ischemia coma seizures rebleeding hydrocephalus rebleeding - highest risk within 24-48 hours => biggest cause of death vasospasm hydrocephalus seizures
increased ICP death Non-contrast CT scan – first-line; highly sensitive within 72 hours Lumbar Puncture - if CT negative but SAH still suspected => cannot be done on patients with increased ICP; lie on LEFT SIDE; FETAL POSITION CT angiograph or cerebral angiogram - to identify source of bleeding MRI/MRA - follow-up or unclear cases manage blood pressure: keep MAP above 70 mm Hg, 90 mm Hg if vasospasms are present Antihypertensives: Nicardipine (CCB) Anti-hypotensive: Levophed - vasoconstrictor Antifibrinolytics: TXA; prevents rebleeding Antiseizures: Levetiracetam (Keppra) Meds for vasospasm => CCBs: Nimodipine SURGICAL: clipping the aneurysm, coiling the aneurysm Hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) - increased amounts of atmospheric pressure and breathing of increased oxygen amounts to treat conditions such as mild TBIs and, more commonly, acute or chronic wounds seizure precautions strict BP monitoring manage ICP => HOB 30 monitor neuro avoid stimulation, provide calm environment avoid activities that increase ICP => straining, coughing

item.title: Nephrotic Syndrome
item.description:
Kidney disorder with massive proteinuria (> 3 g/24 h) leading to hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia. Results from injury to the glomerular filtration barrier (podocyte / basement‑membrane damage). Primary glomerular: minimal‑change disease (children), FSGS, membranous nephropathy Secondary: diabetes, systemic lupus erythematosus, infections (HIV, hepatitis B/C), malignancies, drugs (NSAIDs, lithium). Diabetes or long‑standing hypertension. Autoimmune disease (e.g., SLE). Chronic infections, Hepatitis, HIV-AIDS. Nephrotoxic medications (NSAIDs). Genetic podocyte defects; family history of renal disease. Generalized pitting edema (periorbital → dependent). Frothy or foamy urine. Weight gain, ascites, anasarca in severe cases. Possible hypertension. Fatigue, loss of appetite. Thromboembolism (loss of antithrombin III). Infections (loss of IgG, edema‑related skin breakdown).
AKI / progressive CKD Hyperlipidemia → atherosclerosis. Hypocalcemia, vitamin D deficiency, malnutrition. Urinalysis: 3+ – 4+ protein, oval fat bodies, lipiduria. 24‑h urine protein or random protein/creatinine ratio. Serum: ↓ albumin / total protein, ↑ cholesterol & triglycerides, possible ↓ Ca²⁺. Kidney biopsy to identify underlying lesion (in adults). Ultrasound to assess kidney size/rule out obstruction. Edema management: sodium (< 2 g/day) & fluid restriction, loop diuretics, IV albumin + furosemide in refractory edema. RAAS blockade: ACE I or ARB to cut proteinuria and protect kidney. Statins for hyperlipidemia. Anticoagulation if high thrombotic risk (e.g., serum albumin < 2 g/dL). Immunosuppressants (steroids, calcineurin inhibitors, cyclophosphamide) for immune‑mediated causes. Tight glycemic and BP control in diabetic or hypertensive patients. Daily weights, strict I&O, edema map. Monitor vital signs, especially BP; watch for orthostatic changes. Assess skin integrity, provide pressure‑relief mattress, elevate edematous limbs. Monitor labs (albumin, electrolytes, lipids, creatinine). Administer diuretics in AM; monitor for hypovolemia/ototoxicity. Implement infection precautions; obtain cultures if fever. Adhere to low‑sodium diet; limit processed foods. Take medications exactly as prescribed; do not stop steroids abruptly. Weigh yourself daily; report sudden gain > 2 lb (1 kg) in 24 h. Recognize signs of infection (fever) and clots (leg pain, chest pain). Avoid NSAIDs and nephrotoxic agents unless approved. Schedule regular follow‑ups and lab checks; keep vaccinations current (pneumococcal, flu).

item.title: Pseudamonas Aerginosa
item.description: Gram-negative, aerobic rod Opportunistic nosocomial (hospital-acquired) pathogen Known for its resistance to many antibiotics Commonly produces a blue-green pigment (pyocyanin) and grape-like odor Infection from **contaminated water, equipment, or hands Affects immunocompromised or critically ill patients Can colonize skin, respiratory tract, and indwelling devices Burns, wounds, surgical sites Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) Indwelling catheters (urinary, central lines) Cystic fibrosis Neutropenia Prolonged antibiotic use Skin: greenish-blue pus, wound infections, burn infections Lungs: pneumonia with thick secretions, dyspnea, fever Urinary tract: dysuria, frequency, foul odor Ear: swimmer’s ear (otitis externa) Sepsis: fever, hypotension, organ dysfunction Sepsis/septic shock Multi-drug resistant (MDR) infections* Endocarditis, osteomyelitis Chronic lung infection (especially in CF patients) High mortality in bloodstream infections Culture and sensitivity from wound, sputum, urine, blood Blue-green colonies on agar PCR testing (in some cases) Requires specific antibiotics due to resistance Common choices: Piperacillin-tazobactam (Zosyn) Cefepime Meropenem or Imipenem Aminoglycosides (e.g., tobramycin) Fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin) Combination therapy may be used Infection control measures essential Implement strict infection control/hand hygiene Monitor for signs of systemic infection Administer antibiotics as ordered and monitor for toxicity Encourage respiratory hygiene (esp. in ventilated patients) Educate about prevention, especially for high-risk groups Isolation precautions as needed

item.title: Dialysis
item.description:
A medical procedure that replaces the function of the kidneys when they are no longer able to filter waste, toxins, and excess fluids from the blood.Function of Dialysis: remove excess fluid + electrolytes acid-base balance remove waste products restore homeostasis thru osmosis, diffusion, ultra-filtration Types of Dialysis: Hemodialysis: Blood is filtered through a machine outside the body to remove waste and excess fluids. Peritoneal Dialysis: Uses the lining of the abdomen (peritoneum) to filter blood inside the body by infusing a dialysis solution into the abdomen.Dialysis Access Sites Hemodialysis: Fistulas, grafts, or central venous catheters (CVC) Peritoneal Dialysis: Catheter inserted into the abdominal cavityDialysis Procedure Hemodialysis: Blood is removed, cleaned, and returned to the body via a machine over a 3-5 hour period, typically 3 times a week. Peritoneal Dialysis: Dialysate fluid is infused into the abdomen, where it absorbs waste and excess fluid, and is then drained out, typically performed daily.Considerations for Fistula assess patency: presence of bruit, palpable thrill, distal pulses, circulation Avoid the fistula sight! do not: measure BP, inject, venipuncture. Elevate site after fistula creation Have protamine sulfate ready to reverse heparin. Renal insufficiency: CKD, AKI, ESRD Medication or illicit drug toxicity Persistent hyperkalemia Pulmonary edema severe Hypertension hypervolemia that does not respond to diuretics Hemodialysis: Infection at the access site, hypotension, muscle cramps, blood clots, anemia
Peritoneal Dialysis: Peritonitis 1, catheter infection, fluid imbalance, inadequate dialysis DDS: Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome patients new to dialysis can develop d/t rapid removal of solutes and changes in blood ph look for: BUN above 175 manifestations: headaches, N/V, decreased LOC, seizures, restlessness severe: confusion, seizures, coma, death Priority: monitor for K! (RBCs are not affected by Dialysis) monitor kidney function values: BUN, creatinine Assess for signs of complications (e.g., infection, fluid overload) Provide education on dietary restrictions, fluid intake, and medication adherence Encourage psychological support due to the chronic nature of dialysis treatment Risk for Infection related to dialysis access site (e.g., fistula, catheter) and immune suppression. Imbalanced Nutrition: Less than Body Requirements related to dietary restrictions and altered metabolism due to kidney dysfunction. Fluid Volume Excess related to impaired renal function and fluid retention. Fatigue related to dialysis procedure and chronic kidney disease. Risk for Electrolyte Imbalance related to dialysis treatment, particularly changes in potassium, calcium, and sodium levels. Fluid restriction Limit Na Limit K (bananas, beans, potatoes, oranges, tomatoes, spinach, avocados)
High protein to prevent muscle loss (dialysis removes protein in blood but for CKD patients that are not undergoing dialysis, limiting protein may be indicate to prevent Uremia) Uremia - buildup of waste products in the blood due to kidney failure

item.title: Vitamin Deficiency Anemia (pernicious)
item.description: Results from fewer healthy RBCs due to the body’s low vitamin B12 and folate levels B12 is essential for DNA synthesis in the production of RBCs, leading to immature, large cells Absorption problem (lack of intrinsic factor) or diet issue Autoimmune: Pernicious Anemia (terminal ileum cannot absorb B12) Malabsorption: lack of intrinsic factor Disease: celiac or Crohn’s Nutritional deficits: vegan diet Antiseizure meds: reduces B12 absorption Gastric surgery Alcohol consumption DM meds PPI Contraceptives Old age Celiac/Crohn’s Sjogren’s Syndrome: dry mucous membranes, including dry mouth and eyes Little to no manifestations in mild cases Signature symptom: BEEFY, smooth, sore TONGUE Pallor Fatigue, somnolence, and headache Irritability Numbness and tingling of extremities (paresthesia) Dyspnea on exertion Sensitivity to cold Pain and hypoxia with sickle-cell crisis SOB, tachy, dizziness nail deformities when chronic Newborns: developmental delay, spine/brain defects Dementia Mood changes, psych issues Neuropathy, ataxia B12: injection, nasal spray, oral Diet changes: include red meat, chicken, fish, milk Vegetables do not naturally contain vitamin B12 Note safety issues due to peripheral neuropathy; ADLs may be impaired Visual problems increase the risk of falls CBC with peripheral smear B12 and folate serum

item.title: Mononucleosis
item.description: “Mono” or “Kissing Disease” Viral infection caused by Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) Common in teens and young adults Transmitted via saliva (kissing, sharing drinks, utensils) Primarily EBV (Herpesvirus family) Occasionally caused by Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Adolescents and young adults Close contact (kissing, shared items) Immunocompromised individuals Fatigue (can last weeks/months) Sore throat (resembles strep) Fever Swollen lymph nodes (especially cervical) Enlarged spleen (splenomegaly) Enlarged liver (sometimes) Headache, body aches Mild rash (especially if given amoxicillin or ampicillin) Splenic rupture (rare but serious) Hepatitis Airway obstruction (severe tonsillar enlargement) Chronic fatigue syndrome Secondary infections (e.g., strep throat) Monospot test (detects heterophile antibodies) EBV antibody panel CBC: shows atypical lymphocytes, possible leukocytosis Rule out strep throat with rapid antigen or culture Supportive care only (since it’s viral) Rest, fluids, antipyretics (acetaminophen, ibuprofen) Avoid contact sports for at least 3–4 weeks if splenomegaly Corticosteroids only if airway obstruction or severe swelling Monitor for airway obstruction and splenic rupture signs (sudden LUQ pain, hypotension) Encourage rest and hydration Educate on avoiding contact sports and overexertion Promote good hygiene to avoid spreading No antibiotics unless secondary bacterial infection present

item.title: Uremia
item.description:
A condition resulting from severe kidney dysfunction, leading to the accumulation of waste products (urea, creatinine) in the blood. Associated with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and acute kidney injury (AKI). Causes multi-system complications due to toxin buildup and electrolyte imbalances.
Chronic kidney disease (CKD) or ESRD
Acute kidney injury (AKI) Severe dehydration leading to kidney failure
Glomerulonephritis Polycystic kidney disease Obstructive uropathy (e.g., kidney stones, tumors) Uncontrolled diabetes or hypertension (leading to nephropathy) Autoimmune diseases affecting the kidneys Long-term diabetes or hypertension Family history of kidney disease Chronic NSAID or nephrotoxic drug use Recurrent urinary tract infections or kidney infections Age-related kidney decline Severe infections or sepsis affecting kidney function Fatigue, weakness, and confusion (due to toxin buildup) Nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite Metallic taste in mouth and uremic breath odor Pruritus (severe itching) due to toxin accumulation in the skin
Peripheral Neuropathy (tingling, burning sensation in limbs) Fluid overload leading to hypertension and pulmonary edema Muscle cramps, restless legs, and bone pain (due to electrolyte imbalances) Decreased urine output or anuria
Pericarditis - ati (chest pain, friction rub) Cardiovascular disease (major cause of death in uremia) Metabolic acidosis due to impaired bicarbonate regulation Hyperkalemia leading to life-threatening arrhythmias Uremic encephalopathy (confusion, seizures, coma) Pericarditis and pericardial effusion Increased risk of bleeding due to platelet dysfunction Bone demineralization and fractures (renal osteodystrophy) Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine Electrolyte imbalances (hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, metabolic acidosis) Decreased glomerular filtration rate (GFR) Urinalysis (proteinuria, hematuria) Echocardiogram/ECG (to assess for pericarditis, arrhythmias)
Dialysis (hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis) to remove toxins Diet: low protein to reduce urea buildup, adequate to prevent muscle wasting, low K, low phosphate, low Na Fluid restriction - prevent edema Correction of electrolyte imbalances (calcium supplements, phosphate binders) Blood pressure control (antihypertensives) Erythropoietin therapy for anemia Renal transplant (definitive treatment for ESRD) Monitor fluid balance, weight, and signs of fluid overload Assess for uremic encephalopathy (confusion, lethargy, asterixis) Manage itching with skin care and antihistamines Administer medications cautiously due to impaired drug excretion Monitor and educate on dialysis access care (AV fistula, peritoneal catheter) Encourage adherence to dietary and fluid restrictions Provide emotional support, especially for patients considering dialysis or transplant Prevent life-threatening complications (hyperkalemia, fluid overload, pericarditis) Ensure adherence to dialysis and medication regimens Educate on dietary restrictions and symptom management Support mental health and quality of life in chronic kidney disease patients

item.title: Raynaud's vs Buerger's Disease
item.description: Raynaud’s = Red, White, Blue (triphasic response) Buerger’s = Bad smoker’s fingers

item.title: Blood Transfusion
item.description: FACH => Transfusion Reactions Pnemonic Febrile Anaphylactic Circulatory Overload Hemolytic mild allergic reaction flushing or redness itchy wheezing hives hypotension a person's immune system destroys red blood cells during a blood transfusion destroyed RBCs release free hemoglobin in blood stream kidneys filter hgb, damaging renal tubules, causing pain and inflammation Manifestations: low back pain hyPOTENSION fever tachycardia mental: apprehension urinalysis: hemolyzed RBP Iron Toxicity - client who has received several blood transfusions is at risk for development of hemosiderosis, which is excess storage of iron in the body. The excessive iron can come from overuse of supplements or from receiving frequent blood transfusions, as in sickle cell anemia

item.title: Sickle Cell Anemia
item.description: affects the shape of the red blood cells in the body by causing hemoglobin to be sticky cause tissues in the body to become hypoxic, leading to many complications sickle-shaped RBCs flowing through the blood vessels of the client’s abdomen, chest, and joints cause severe pain, which can last for hours or days Vaso-Occlusive Crisis (VOC) - a painful complication of sickle cell anemia that occurs when blood vessels are blocked by sickle-shaped red blood cells Symptoms: severe pain, acute chest syndrome (reduced lung perfusion = DEADLY), dactilytis (inflammation of finger, toes), priapism both parents must be carriers of the sickle cell trait for the child to be affected if only one parent is carrier, child will be carrier only genetics severe pain - affects ADLs, damage to joints can cause anxiety, depression, stress, sleep disorder, poor coping fatigue caused by anemia (sickle cells die within 10-20 days, normal life span is 120 days) swelling of hands and feet visual deficits (sickle cells block vessels in eyes) anemia symptoms Acute Chest Syndrome - emergency stroke blindness blood clots during pregnancy and hypertension acute chest syndrome - most serious blood flow can be blocked to the lungs, causing breathing difficulty, fever, and severe chest pain emergency! Damage to organs, pulmonary hypertension, leg ulcerations due to poor circulation, blindness, priapism, DVT, and gallstones are all diseases or disorders that can occur in clients who have sickle cell anemia. newborn screening - serum test Hemoglobin electrophoresis to identify the type of hemoglobin. Complete blood count (CBC) showing anemia and high reticulocyte count. Peripheral blood smear showing sickled cells. pain management IV fluids for hydration blood transfusion Hydroxyurea - reactivates production of fetal hemoglobin prevention: drink 8 glasses water daily to prevent dehydration (dehydration = crisis) avoid extreme temp changes avoid high altitudes affecting O2 intake lookout for iron overload arising from frequent blood transfusions iron deposits in organs = organ damage needs iron chelation therapy encourage support group Drink 3-4L per day Avoid traveling to high altitudes and airplanes => reduced oxygen, can lead to vaso-occlusive crisis Avoid activities that require persistent exposure to cold weather

item.title: Pericarditis
item.description: Inflammation of the pericardium, the sac surrounding the heart Can be acute, chronic, or recurrent Often self-limiting but may lead to serious complications like cardiac tamponade Viral infections (most common – e.g., coxsackievirus) Bacterial infections, TB Post-MI (Dressler's syndrome) Autoimmune diseases (e.g., lupus, RA) Uremia, trauma, cancer, radiation Certain medications (e.g., hydralazine, isoniazid) Recent viral illness MI or cardiac surgery Autoimmune conditions Chronic kidney disease Cancer or radiation therapy Sharp, pleuritic chest pain, worse when lying down, better when sitting up and leaning forward => pericardial layers interact with gravity, when lying down, heart rests against irritated pericardium Pericardial friction rub (high-pitched scratchy sound) Dyspnea with Hiccups => common ATI question Fever, fatigue Dyspnea, especially with exertion Nonproductive cough Pericardial effusion Cardiac tamponade (life-threatening) Constrictive pericarditis (chronic thickening) Recurrence of symptoms ECG: widespread ST elevation and PR depression Echocardiogram: detects effusion or tamponade Chest X-ray: enlarged cardiac silhouette if effusion Labs: elevated WBC, CRP, ESR; troponin may be mildly elevated NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) for pain and inflammation Colchicine to prevent recurrence Corticosteroids (if autoimmune or unresponsive to NSAIDs) Antibiotics if bacterial cause Pericardiocentesis if tamponade develops Monitor for signs of tamponade: hypotension, JVD, muffled heart sounds (Beck’s triad) Position patient sitting up and leaning forward for comfort Administer anti-inflammatories as prescribed Educate on activity restriction during recovery Monitor vital signs, ECG, and for worsening symptoms Supportive care: oxygen if dyspneic, emotional reassurance

item.title: PAD vs PVD
item.description: Umbrella term for diseases affecting blood vessels outside the heart and brain Includes arterial and venous disorders Most common: Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD) and Chronic Venous Insufficiency Subset of PVD Caused by atherosclerosis in peripheral arteries Results in reduced blood flow to limbs (typically legs) PAD: Antiplatelets, statins, smoking cessation, walking programs, revascularization PVD (venous): Compression stockings, leg elevation, avoid standing long, diuretics (if edema), wound care

item.title: DKA vs HHS
item.description:
both hyperglycemic emergencies d/t diabetes severe and life-threatening! DKA - Diabetic Ketoacidosis caused by absolute lack of insulin blood glucose level of greater than 250 mg/dL => leads to hyponatremia and glucosuria polyuria => leads to electrolyte loss, dehydration, hypovolemia, hyperosmolarity, acidosis unique to DKA: acidosis (ph of less than 7.3), ketone production common in Diabetes T1 HHS - Hyperosmolar Hyperglycemic Syndrome relative lack of insulin => pancreas produces insulin but it is not enough blood glucose greater than 600 mg/dL signature feature: serum osmolality of greater than 320 mOsm/kg normal pH more severe fluid loss => LONGER ONSET
common in Diabetes T2 DKAAges 13 to 25 Assigned female at birth Previous episodes of DKA HHSAges 65 and older African American, Native American, and Hispanic heritage Morbid obesity BothLow income, homelessness, and lack of health insurance Elevated HbA1c Taking antipsychotic or antidepressant medications Acute infection or illness Excessive alcohol consumption Use of illicit drugs, especially cocaine Blood glucose levels that are not well managed K can drop very fast Neuro: AMS, lethargy, fatigue, blurred vision, HA, polydipsia Respiratory: tachypnea Cardiovascular: hypotension, tachy, weight loss, dry mucous membranes, poor skin turgor, arrythmias GI: N/V, abdominal pain GU: polyuria Unique DKA features: fruity smelling breath, Kussmaul respirations Anion Gap - need to know how to "close the gap" in terms of hydration (mild to moderate: 10+ to 12+ mEq/L) Ketones in urine - DKA Expected: hyponatremia CXR - r/o respiratory conditions EKG - detect arrhythmias Blood Cultures Urine Culture Check insulin - check every hour if emergency (also if in ICU), medsurg: q2-4 regular insulin - only insulin that can go IVP Insulin has it's own IV line if it's infusion POTASSIUM - insulin can only be given if serum potassium is above 3.3 mEq/L => high risk for hypokalemia IVF Resuscitation => NS (15-20 mg/kg in first hour), continue up to 500ml/H4 for four hours For hypernatremia, switch to 0.45% NaCl after the first bag of NS IV REGULAR Insulin - bolus then continuous infusion (lower blood glucose by 50-70 mg/dl per hour) => landing the plane, can't go too fast transition to sq insulin once patient is alert and oriented (eating) e- replacement PRN HHS severe hydration! super high osmolality IVF first, then administer insulin DKA Treatment Goals: glucose of less than 200, pH greater than 7.3, Anion Gap 12 mEq/L or lessNOTE: hold insulin if K is less than 3.3! => keep IVF until K is corrected Diabetes management Stress, trauma, infection Assessment of equipment

item.title: Chest Tube Care
item.description: 2 Types: WET SUCTION - CLOSED SYSTEM DRY SUCTION - connected to wall suction Drainage Collection Chamber => connected to patient, monitor every 15min first 2 hours (normal: serous, clear, red, ABNORMAL: purulent or yellow, bright red blood (abnormal) Water Seal Chamber => allows removal of volume from pleural space without allowing air in, sterile water only, add if needed (normal: tidaling => rise and fall during ventilation, continuous bubbling: air leak, no bubbling: kink or occluded, lung re-expanded (need re-eval) Suction Control Chamber => can be wet or dry. Dry = Dial on the system (mechanical suction control) Two or three chambers: drainage, water seal, mechanical suction control (no water) Suction set with dial or regulator, often quieter Quieter, portable, easier for ambulation No water evaporation issues Easier setup in emergency or transport Needs sterile water for suction chamber May be noisy due to bubbling Water level must be checked/refilled if evaporated Suction Control Chamber => Continuous bubbling is normal (if bubble too violent = suction too high!) keep drainage below chest level must have two rubber-tipped hemostats in the room (in case of dislodgement)

item.title: AKI
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary interchangeable term: Acute Kidney Failure (ARF) sudden onset and usually reversible decrease in kidney function
can progress to CKD and ESRD if not treated 3 Categories Prerenal - most common, reduced blood flow to kidneys
caused by hypotension, hypovolemia, Heart Failure, Liver failure, renal artery stenosis Vasodilation: sepsis, anaphylaxis
common cause: Cirrhosis meds: NSAIDs, ARBs, ACEi, cyclosporine ATI Tip: aka "Pre-renal Azotemia: - caused by a decrease in blood flow to the kidneys, known as renal hypoperfusion Intrarenal - direct Kidney Damage (renal cortex and renal medulla) caused by nephrotoxic agents: contrast dyes, NSAID, aminoglycosides, vancomycin Acute Tubular Necrosis: deadly, renal tubules become damaged and die, GFT decreases
Glomerulonephritis, lupus nephritis Rhabdomyolysis Hemolysis Postrenal - obstruction of urine flow
Renal Calculi, BPH tumors, strictures, neurogenic bladder other ureteral obstructions sepsis, shock Nephrotoxic drugs: NSAIDs, aminoglycosides, contrast dyes, ACEi) kidney disease, diabetes, HTN major surgery, trauma, burns (fluid loss, rhabdo risk elderly Oliguria (<400 mL/day) or Anuria (<100 mL/day) in severe cases Azotemia (↑ BUN & creatinine) → Causes nausea, confusion, fatigue Fluid overload → Edema, hypertension, pulmonary congestion Hyperkalemia → ECG changes (peaked T waves, arrhythmias) => kidneys unable to excrete potassium, it builds up Metabolic acidosis → Kussmaul respirations Uremic symptoms (pruritus, anorexia, altered mental status)** e- imbalance
pulmonary edema, Heart Failure Metabolic acidosis (kussmaul breathing infection, sepsis
CKD, ESRD Serum creatinine & BUN → Increased (hallmark of AKI) GFR → Decreased Urinalysis → Casts, protein, hematuria (intrarenal causes) Electrolytes → Hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, hypocalcemia Renal ultrasound → Identifies obstruction (postrenal causes) Fractional Excretion of Sodium (FeNa) → Low in prerenal, high in intrarenal AKI Prerenal AKI → IV fluids (if hypovolemic), vasopressors if shock Intrarenal AKI → Avoid nephrotoxins, manage underlying disease Postrenal AKI → Relieve obstruction (catheter, surgery) correct e- imbalance or acidosis
Diuretics for fluid overload Dialysis if severe #1 priority: e- imbalance, fluid overload, hyperkalemia, cardiac output adjust nephrotoxic drugs hydr8 Vancomycin Tetracycline Pantoprazole Omeprazole Methotrexate Lithium Cortisone Cimetidine Aspirin  Allopurinol Acetaminophen

item.title: Pancreatitis
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal inflammation of the pancreas (from autodigestion of pancreas = digestive enzymes eat the pancreas) stems from pancreatic duct obstruction (see causes) acute or chronic enzymes are key to understanding this disease: protease, lipase, amylase
also causes Hepatitis symptoms due to blockage of common bile duct (liver and pancreas shares) Pancreas: produces enzymes to digest food (note carbs, fats, proteins); releases insulin and glucagon to regular blood sugarAcute Pancreatitis - sudden, releases trypsin that causes pancreatic acinar cell death = inflammatory response, usually managed with conservative treatments Chronic Pancreatitis - ongoing, progressive inflammation, may cause irreversible organ damage from fibrosis and scarring
gall stones and alcohol abuse = most common cause
gall stones - obstruct the pancreatic duct (see Cholecystitis); obstruction causes enzymes to autodigest alcohol: constant inflammation occludes the duct diabetes & obesity Post-ERCP abdominal surgery trauma infection alcohol abuse smoking high-fat diet which leads to gallstone formation family hx, obesity, DM, cystic fibrosis old intense pain in epigastric area or left upper abd (radiates to back, worsens after eating) abdominal tenderness with guarding Hypotension - third spacing (fluid shift to interstitial space), SIRS, E- imbalance, sepsis Cullen's Sign - blue grey discoloration sign around belly button (Edward Cullen is blue-grey) Grey-Turner's Sign - ecchymosis on the patient's flank (you turn to the side to see it) Fox's Sign - ecchymosis on groin (fox = fuck area / groin) Infection: fever, chills, tachy, diaphoresis, tachypnea N/V
Jaundice (see Hepatitis) => pancreas and bile duct share a common pathway into duodenum, gallstones can also block the common bile duct Dark Urine - tell-tale sign of elevated bilirubin levels clay-colored stools also: oily stool (steatorrhea) pruritus (from bile salt accumulation) Tetany - involuntary muscle contractions, typically caused by low levels of calcium in the blood (hypocalcemia) dehydration
AKI or CKD necrotizing pancreatitis - tissue death Pancreatic pseudocysts (fluid-filled sacs, can rupture and cause bleeding)
SIRS => MODS - greatest risk for death if unresolved within 48 hrs sepsis malnutrition
Diabetes T2 Pancreatic Cancer Recurrent pancreatitis - once you get it, you will most likely get it again ARDS (yes)
Lipase: elevated, best marker detecting Pancreatitis due to its specificity (lipase is an enzyme that breaks down FATS, secreted by pancreas thru bile salts) lipase levels: 0-160 u/L
Amylase: elevated, also used but can also be elevated in Bowel Obstruction, Gastric Ulcers (Amylase is an enzyme that breaks down CARBS, secreted by pancreas thru bile salts)
WBC = elevated (see CBC)
Bilirubin = elevated (see LFT)
CMP: low Ca Glucose (pancreas can't make insulin) = increased Imaging: US (preferred to detect gallstone), CT, MRCP, ERCP CRP/ESR = elevated reduce inflammation first, then treat the cause strict NPO with I/O recording (rest pancreas, reduce enzyme secretion) IVF for e- correction NGT nutrition or TPN or PRN decompression
Analgesia progress to clear liquid, bland diet, low fat diet as tolerated If blockage is confirmed = ERCP (A scope gets shoved down your throat to check your liver, gallbladder, and pancreas, can also remove gallstones) Cholecystectomy Drainage of pancreas if indicated For chronic pancreatitis: Enzyme supplements Low FAT Low SUGARS provide enzymes with food, if prescribed NOTE: once pancreatitis resolves, amylase will return to normal within 3-6 hours! Lipase will remain elevated for 14 days!

item.title: Diabetes Insipidus
item.description: dry inside - diabetes insipidus same amount of kool aid powder but with too little water = the juice is too concentrated & has too much flavor (hypernatremia, high serum osmolality) low release of antidiuretic hormone (aka vasopressin) => patient keeps peeing nonstop! key e-: Na 2 Types: Central DI - neuro, trauma, less common Nephrogenic DI - kidneys develop resistance to ADH, more common Less common: gestational DI Central DI => brain issue: tumor, bran surgery, infection in CNS => hypothalamus or pituitary gland Nephrogenic => caused by gene mutations, renal diseases, pregnancy, hypercalcemia, hypokalemia, meds (lithium, abx, antifungals, antineoplastics) congenital - rare (affects hypothalamus) autoimmune or vascular diseases sarcoidosis ischemia any condition related to injury of hypothalamus or pituitary: neurosurgery, infection, genetic disorder damage to kidneys (lithium, amphotericin B, demeclocycline) => stop meds right away gestational DI => pregnancy MS - dipsogenic DI (excessive thirst) thirst does not go away => polydipsia polyuria - excessive urinating nocturia HIGH SODIUM > leads to excessive thirst; hypernatremia patients who have no thirst perception have greater risk increased risk for skin impairment due to nocturia nocturia - urination at night, less sleep higher risk for mortality d/t fever, dehydration, hypernatremia, cv complication Serum ADH less than 1, => nephrogenic, more than 5= central (normal is 1 to 5 ng/L) diluted urine - urine osmolality is low (normal average is 500-900; anything under 300 is DI) Urine Specific Gravity confirms DI: Less than 1.005 (normal range is 1.005-1.03) Urine sodium 24 hours - less than 40 mg/day look for UOP of greater than 3L/day water deprivation test differentiates between central and nephrogenic stimulates secretion of ADH DI: urine osmolality does not increase over 300 mosm/kg Nurse task: ensure water is withheld body weight and urine osmolality are measured HOURLY Other Lab Tests considered: Serum sodium, osmolality urine BUN Central DI: desmopressin - an analog of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) and the hormone replacement of choice for diabetes insipidus; REABSORBS WATER IN KIDNEYS most effective route for desmopressin: intranasal 5-10 mcg at bedtime other drugs to increase ADH: carbamazepine, chlorpropamide Thiazide Diuretics: usually with nephrogenic (sometimes in central DI); thiazides induce mild hypovolemia which results in less urine output eventually, thus retain more water renal diet Dextrose or any hypOtonic fluids => 500-750mL/hr infusion rate (NOTE: DO NOT INFUSE HYPERTONIC!) Adverse reactions of desmopressin: hyponatremia, palpitations, tachycardia, headache, rhinitis, nasal congestion, pruritus, edema of the eyes indwelling catheter is usually indicated => strict I/O

item.title: Addison's Disease
item.description: ADD => add the steroids!, added stress will kill! chronic condition caused by insufficient production of cortisol and aldosterone by the adrenal cortex aka primary adrenal insufficiency Leads to problems with fluid balance, glucose regulation, and stress response Autoimmune destruction of adrenal glands (most common in developed countries) Infections (e.g., TB, HIV, fungal infections) Adrenal hemorrhage or metastasis Surgical removal of adrenal glands Genetic disorders Autoimmune diseases (e.g., Diabetes T1, Hashimoto’s) Chronic infections (e.g., TB) History of adrenal surgery Use of anticoagulants (risk of adrenal bleeding) Family history of adrenal insufficiency Fatigue, weakness Weight loss, anorexia Hyperpigmentation (bronze skin, especially in joints, mucosa) Hypotension Hyponatremia HYPERKALEMIA - the only thing that is elevated! Salt craving Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain Low blood glucose Irritability, depression Adrenal crisis (Addisonian crisis): life-threatening drop in BP, glucose, and Na⁺ (anything less than 90 sys) Can be triggered by stress, illness, surgery, trauma, or sudden steroid withdrawal Risk for hypovolemic shock, coma, death if untreated ACTH stimulation test (definitive) Low cortisol levels High ACTH levels in primary Addison’s Electrolyte imbalances: ↓ Na⁺, ↑ K⁺ CT/MRI to evaluate adrenal glands lifelong hormone replacement : steroids! Hydrocortisone or prednisone (cortisol) Fludrocortisone (aldosterone replacement) Increase steroid dose during stress/illness/surgery Treat underlying cause if possible IV hydrocortisone, fluids, and glucose during adrenal crisis Monitor BP, electrolytes, glucose Educate on lifelong steroid use and stress dosing Medical alert bracelet recommended Teach signs of adrenal crisis (severe weakness, confusion, hypotension, vomiting) Encourage salt intake (if no HTN) Monitor for infection or illness as triggers Teach not to stop steroids abruptly

item.title: Cushing's Disease
item.description: CUSH - cortisol up, sugar high => everything is elevated except potassium Cushion - pillow air bag (obesity) Condition caused by prolonged exposure to high cortisol levels Can be endogenous (body overproduces cortisol) or exogenous (from long-term steroid use) Affects metabolism, fluid balance, and immune function Small Cell Lung Cancer => common test question lol Prolonged corticosteroid therapy (most common, usually found in Rheumatoid Arthritis patients or Asthma patients) Pituitary adenoma (Cushing’s disease – ↑ ACTH) Adrenal tumors (↑ cortisol secretion) Long-term use of glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone) Female sex (more common in women) Ages 20–50 Pituitary or adrenal tumors Weight gain, especially in face (“moon face”), trunk, and upper back (“buffalo hump”) Purple striae on abdomen Thin, fragile skin with easy bruising Hirsutism (excess hair growth) Muscle weakness, especially in extremities Osteoporosis Hyperglycemia Hypertension Mood changes (irritability, depression) Decreased immunity Menstrual irregularities Diabetes mellitus Hypertension and cardiovascular disease Osteoporosis and fractures Infections due to suppressed immune response Psychiatric disturbances Adrenal crisis if steroids withdrawn abruptly 24-hour urine cortisol test Dexamethasone suppression test Salivary cortisol levels CT/MRI of pituitary or adrenal glands Gradual tapering of exogenous steroids Surgical removal of tumor (if pituitary or adrenal) Radiation therapy for tumors Medications to suppress cortisol (e.g., ketoconazole, metyrapone) Monitor blood glucose, BP, and electrolytes Protect skin from injury (thin, fragile skin) Prevent infection – immune suppression Support emotional well-being Ensure slow taper of corticosteroids if discontinuing Provide calcium and vitamin D for bone health Educate about symptoms of adrenal insufficiency during treatment adjustment

item.title: Addison vs Cushing
item.description:
Inverse of each other!Cushing's Disease (Excess Cortisol)Everything is elevated except potassium“CUSH” - Cortisol Up, Sugar High • ↑ Cortisol • ↑ Sodium (hypernatremia) • ↑ Glucose (hyperglycemia) • ↑ BP (hypertension) • ↓ Potassium (hypokalemia) • Skin fragile, truncal obesity, moon face, buffalo hump
Addison's Disease (Adrenal Insufficiency) “ADD” - All Down in DeficiencyEverything is decreased except potassium• ↓ Cortisol • ↓ Sodium (hyponatremia) • ↓ Glucose (hypoglycemia) • ↓ BP (hypotension) • ↑ Potassium (hyperkalemia) • Skin pigmentation (bronze tone)

item.title: Thyroid Storm
item.description:
aka thyrotoxic crisis life-threatening emergency in which multiple systems of the body are in a severe hypermetabolic state overstimulation of the entire metabolic system high mortality rate - 25% poorly managed or undiagnosed hyperthyroidism (see Hyperthyroidism "GRAVES DISEASE") abruptly stopping the hypothyroid medication misc causes: injury, surgery, or burns, and other conditions, including COVID-19, diabetic ketoacidosis, pregnancy, infections, or drug reactions other causes: cardiovascular disease, hypertension, tachyarrhythmias, or ischemic heart disease other things to note: Amiodarone can induce thyrotoxicosis high fever - 104-106 with sweating tachycardia 140+ BPM
Heart Failure severe hypertension, arrythmias, exophthalmos enlarged thyroid bulging eyes hand tremors jaundice hyperreflexia GI: abdominal pain, N/V/D, obstruction, liver failure Behavioral: anxiety, confusion, agitation, psychosis, coma
Heart Failure Arrythmias Shock
MODS Death LOW TSH High T3 and T4
Possible abnormalities: LFT, hyperglycemia, hypercalcemia, WBC ECG CXR - r/o HF ICU level of care: vent support, close monitoring, cardiac monitor Pharmacological: propylthiouracil (PTU) and methimazole (MMI) => inhibit thyroid synthesis alternative treatment: LITHIUM Manage fever: cooling blanket, acetaminophen, IVF Manage BP: betablockers; propanolol Lower Thyroid levels: gluccocorticoids Decrease stimulation Thyroidectomy - last resort Plasmapheresis - therapeutic plasma exchange (TPE), is a medical procedure that removes plasma from the blood and replaces it with a substitute fluid. monitor for calcium levels prior to THYROIDECTOMY

item.title: COPD
item.description: persistent respiratory manifestations and airflow limitation airway restriction caused by noxious gas and/or particle exposure can be caused by chronic bronchitis or emphysema COPD is a broad term that includes bronchitis and emphysema Emphysema permanent enlargement of airspaces and destruction of airspace walls affects respiratory bronchioles, alveolar sacs, ducts, alveoli Chronic Bronchitis - inflammation of bronchial tubes, leading to increased mucus production and coughing common: cigarette smoke => more mucus production => cilliary function decreases => inflammation thickened and fibrosed alveoli => damaged macrophages => more infection smoking exposure to noxious gases occupational exposure to dust, fumes environmental pollutants, biomass fuel female allergen sensitivities asthma chronic lung disease dyspnea, chronic cough, sputum production exertional dyspnea = most common early manifestation wheezing, chest tightness barrel chest - severe and late sign late sign and poor prognosis: weight loss decreased breath sounds, crackles at lung bases sit leaning forward slightly = use of accessory muscles of neck Pursed lip expiration Hoover's sign = drawing in of the lower ribs while inhaling Neck vein distention due to intrathoracic pressure during thromboembolic disease lung cancer resp failure increased mortality rate weight loss - too busy coughing to eat skeletal muscle dysfunction - decreased mobility, decreased nutrition, inactivity, hypoxia, inflammation more pronounced on elderly goal: control symptoms, not die, improve QOL SABA , LABA, inhaled corticosteroids, anticholinergics, methylxanthines, LAMA (antimuscarinic agents) methylxanthines -
