relax smooth muscles in airway (Theophylline) Vaccines: influenza, pneumococcal (PVC13), RSV (>60yo) CAPTURE questionnaire (0 or 1 => no risk, 5-6 => severe) weak expiratory flow PFT especially spirometry => gold standard of diagnosing COPD spirometry before and after bronchodilator to determine airflow limitation is reversible Forced Expiratory Volume (FEV1) forced Vital Capacity (FVC) SPO2 CXR - to rule out dyspnea/sputum CT - determine severity of disease increased mortality rate from respiratory failure weight loss, skeletal muscle dysfunction, poor nutrition loss of muscle cells decreased physical activity Cardiac: CHF thromboembolic disease lung cancer respiratory failure female smoking = MOST IMPORTANT responsiveness to allergens exposure to dust/fumes asthma chronic lung disease O2 promote rest breathing exercises do not give anti-anxiety medications with BIPAP => ? encourage vaccination to all diseases hand elevate HOB smoking cessation avoid exposures encourage rehab pursed lip breathing => moves air out of lungs influenza vaccine Pneumococcal - 65 and older, once a year Corticosteroids side effects: trembling, headaches, dry mouth, weight gain, diabetes, osteoporosis#nursing #medsurg #respiratory

item.title: Pneumothorax
item.description: air that collects within pleural cavity d/t leak from lung into parietal and visceral pleura creates pressure causing lung to collapse a life-threatening condition that requires immediate attention. Types: Traumatic Pneumothorax blunt or penetrating trauma creates one-way valve into pleural space air goes in but does not go out common causes: rib fracture, bult trauma, flying or diving, changes in pressure subtypes: Primary Spontaneous Pneumothorax (PSP) - without underlying lung disease but in the presence of asymptomatic bullae or blebs that rupture Secondary Spontaneous Pneumothorax (SSP) - lung disease is present, most commonly, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease Open Pneumo - air entering through an open wound in the chest (sucking sound occurs as air rushes through the chest walls) Iatrogenic - type of traumatic; caused by a medical treatment or procedure (thoracentesis or biopsy) Tension Pneumo - severe form, air enters the chest cavity, becomes trapped, and cannot be expelled (common causes: barotrauma, ventilation tracheostomy injury, occlusive dressing ineffective) subpleural bleb - a small air-filled cyst located on the surface of the lung, close to the pleural lining. They are typically asymptomatic but can rupture, leading to a pneumothorax smoking cigarettes or MJ tall & thin pregnancy Marfan Syndrome - genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissues Atmospheric drops - diving, mountain climbing, or any activity with no time to acclimatize COPD Tuberculosis apical blebs or bullae Cystic Fibrosis Lung Cancer ASthma HIV with pneumonia any lung condition chest pain, SOB hypotension distended neck veins or hypotension from an increased central venous pressure tachypnea, dyspnea, tachycardia, hypoxia pleuritic chest pain radiating to shoulder => common in PSP asymmetric lung expansion Decreased tactile fremitus Hyper resonant percussion notes Decreased breath sounds or absent breath sounds hypoxia, hypercapnia mobility: weakness, physical activity intolerance CXR - definitive CT E-FAST evacuate air in pleural space: needle decompression (14-16g angiocatheter) 2nd ICS after: thoracostomy tube or catheter in 5th ICS MCL ensure drainage system is below catheter chest tube insertion => 5th ICS MCL Chest Tube Suction amount: 10 to -20 cm H2O of water O2 analgesia pleurodesis - for air leaks longer than 7 days, AIDS patients => surgery that occludes lung EARLY MOBILITY IS KEY! => encourages airway clearance educate on chest tube and drainage management semi fowlers (HOB-35-45) O2 and analgesia

item.title: Status Asthmaticus
item.description:
rapid onset of a severe Asthma episode and has the potential for acute ventilatory failure or death extreme form of asthma exacerbation characterized by hypoxemia, hypercarbia, and secondary respiratory failure. requires ventilatory support and ICU care airways close prematurely when the client exhales leading to an increase in the volume that remains in the lung (functional residual capacity) and air trapping. leads to respiratory acidosis (first resp alkalosis then acidosis) Low socio-economic status Low comprehension => poor understanding
Coronary Artery Disease => CAD & MI (d/t adverse effects of meds) previous episodes history of intubation Poor access to care Financial issues r/t missing work Kicked out of school r/t missing school increased risk of obstructive shock hits harder increased sensitivity to meds SOB unable to speak chest tightness accessory muscle use drowsy, decreased LOC cyanotic Diminished or absent lung sounds (possibly no wheezing) patients tend to sit leaning forward to open airway asphyxia (resulting from mucus plug) => life-threatening chest asymmetry Pulsus Paradoxus => systolic blood pressure falls at the height of inspiration Early => Respiratory Alkalosis (because of hyperventilation); eventually turns to acidosis Late => R. Acidosis Note: Hypercarbia - too much CO2 Hypoxemia - too little O2 2nd Respiratory Failure respiratory acidosis rare: rhabdomyolysis => can lead to permanent disability, fatal; caused by excessive use of respiratory muscles Pulmonary Function Test =< when PEFR (peak expiratory flow rate) and FEV are reduced by 50% of the patient's best
increased PaCO2, increased pH => respiratory acidosis (see Acid Base Balance) rule out infection: CBC rule out Hypokalemia prepare to intubate if r. acidosis (late stage) Nebulized Bronchodilator: Albuterol q.20 => SABA oral or IV Steroids => decrease inflammation (i.e. methylprednisolone or Medrol) IV fluids - facilitate secretion and expectoration supplemental I2 Magensium Sulfate - relaxes muscles Monitor: tripod positioning

item.title: Pulmonary Embolism
item.description: A life-threatening condition where a thrombus or emboli blocks blood flow in the pulmonary arteries, reducing oxygen exchange and straining the heart. Medical Emergency! Terms to note: Thrombus - A blood clot that forms within a blood vessel Embolus - moving clot or particle that travels through the bloodstream until it lodges in a smaller vessel; made up of fat, air, or tumorHence, a thrombus can become an emboliREMEMBER: Thrombus = Stays Put Embolus = Moves and Block DVT (most common cause) Fat embolism (from fractures) Air embolism (from IV lines or trauma) Amniotic fluid embolism (during labor) Tumor embolism (from metastatic cancer) Virchow’s triad - increased coagulability, venous stasis, and endothelial tissue injuryVenous Thromboembolism (VTE) - when patient presents with both PE and DVTRisk Factors: females (early and middle adult age groups) males (elderly) age: 40+ Black Americans Family History/Genetics: thrombophilia, protein C or S deficiency, hyperhomocysteinemia Venous Statis: Immobility or prolonged bed rest travel greater than 4 hr by air bedrest greater than three days Surgery (especially orthopedic or abdominal) Hospitalization for HF, A.Fib, A.Flutter, central venous catherization Obesity Pregnancy and postpartum period Smoking Oral contraceptives or hormone replacement therapy (ESTROGEN BASED) Cancer - tumors may dislodge, more immobile Previous DVT or PE Fractures (especially long bones) Poor - increased air pollution exposure sudden onset dyspnea - most common chest pain tachypnea tachycardia hypoxia anxiety & restlessness cough HEMOPTYSIS - not a common presenting manifestation (ATI) blood or blood-tinged sputum from the mouth or trachea that originated in the lungs or the lower respiratory tract. Severe: syncope, hypotension, cyanosis, shock symptoms Less common: arrythmias (AFIB), JVD Low Risk - asymptomatic, hemodynamically stable Intermediate-Risk (or submassive) - right ventricular dysfunction, low BP (corrected with IVF) High-Risk - hemodynamically unstable Pulmonary hypertension Right-sided heart failure (cor pulmonale) Shock Death (if untreated) CTPA - computed tomographic pulmonary angiogram => Gold Standard, uses contrast dye thru arteries, then x-ray. visualizes arteries, locates obstruction ABG => reveals respiratory alkalosis, hypocapnia Troponin => may be elevated in moderate to large PEs D-Dimer - elevated d/t presence of clot Chest X-Ray => may not show PE but can rule out atelectasis, effusion, or other causes for dyspnea Assessment Findings: abnormal lung sounds on auscultation: rales or diminished abnormal heart sounds: gallop Treatment Goals: Maintain Oxygenation, at least 90% SPO2 Maintain Mental Status Prevent Further Emoblism Avoid Complications Interventions Supplemental O2 Mechanical Ventilation if unstable ECMO - extracorporeal membrane oxygenation Thrombolysis (Alteplase) - clot-busting meds Thrombectomy - surgical removal of clot using endovascular device Anticoagulants (e.g., heparin, warfarin, enoxaparin) - does not dissolve clots but prevents new ones from forming Anticoagulation therapy for a minimum of three months Evaluate Risk Factors for a VTE: examine lower extremities; note swelling, warmth, tender or hard veins in calves Prevention is Easier Than Treatment! - ensure VTE prophylaxis (pharmacological or mechanical-SCDs), encourage ambulation, hydration Note bleeding risk R/T anticoagulant therapy Educate: anticoagulation medications, increased chance of recurrence, medical tag/bracelet, bleeding precautions, avoid risky activities, mobility, lifestyle, nutrition

item.title: Dumping Syndrome
item.description: A condition where food moves too quickly from the stomach into the small intestine, causing fluid shifts and hormonal responses. Common after gastric surgery (e.g., gastrectomy, gastric bypass). Gastric surgery (partial or total gastrectomy, gastric bypass, vagotomy). Rapid gastric emptying due to loss of normal pyloric control. High-sugar meals, which pull fluid into the intestine, worsening symptoms. => AVOID HIGH CARB History of gastric surgery. High-carbohydrate diet. Small stomach size or altered digestion due to surgery. Early Dumping Syndrome (Within 30 Minutes of Eating) Abdominal cramping, bloating, nausea. Diarrhea (due to rapid fluid shift into intestines). Tachycardia, palpitations, dizziness (from fluid loss and vasodilation). Diaphoresis (sweating). Late Dumping Syndrome (1-3 Hours After Eating) Rebound hypoglycemia due to excessive insulin release. Weakness, dizziness, confusion. Sweating, shakiness, palpitations. Severe dehydration from diarrhea. Malnutrition and weight loss due to food avoidance. Hypoglycemia from late-phase insulin surge. Glucose tolerance test – Identifies late dumping syndrome. Gastric emptying study – Confirms rapid emptying. Clinical history and symptom pattern. Dietary modifications: Eat small, frequent meals. Avoid high-carb foods (especially simple sugars). Increase protein and healthy fats to slow digestion. Drink fluids between meals, not with meals. Lie down after eating to slow gastric emptying. Medications: Acarbose (delays carbohydrate absorption, prevents hypoglycemia). Octreotide (reduces gastric motility). Surgical options (rarely needed): Reconstructive surgery to slow gastric emptying. Monitor for dehydration (tachycardia, hypotension). Educate on dietary changes to prevent symptoms. Assess blood sugar levels for hypoglycemia. Encourage rest after meals to reduce rapid dumping.

item.title: Cancer Treatment
item.description: is a type of radiation therapy during which the radiation source is in direct contact with the client's tumor. DIFFERENT FROM CHEMO - chemo is directed throughout the whole body MORE precise therapy - directly into cancer cells During the therapy, the client emits radiation and is potentially hazardous to others. The client should be in a private room with a private bathroom, and the nurse should keep the door to the client's room closed. PER ATI: 2-5 treatment, one or twice a week no restriction on proximity - no excreted radiation between treatments (you can stand close to them) there should be no blood - report immediately if there is! patient will stay still Systemic treatment using cytotoxic drugs to destroy or inhibit cancer cell growth Administered orally, intravenously, intramuscularly, subcutaneously, or intrathecally Contraindications: Severe immunosuppression Active infection Organ dysfunction (e.g., liver or kidney failure) Pregnancy (specific agents may be contraindicated) Nursing Tasks Administer chemotherapy safely following protocols and PPE guidelines Monitor for immediate reactions (e.g., anaphylaxis, infusion site issues) Assess for side effects such as nausea, vomiting, fatigue, or myelosuppression Provide patient education on side effect management and treatment schedule Ensure proper handling, disposal, and spill management of cytotoxic agents Nursing Considerations Monitor CBC, renal, and liver function before and during treatment Assess for signs of infection, bleeding, or anemia Implement supportive care measures (e.g., antiemetics, hydration, pain control) Educate on neutropenic precautions and infection prevention AVOID DIRECT SUNLIGHT! - skin on radiation path is sensitive to sun damage Provide emotional support and address psychosocial concerns Chemotherapy Combination Meds - Different chemotherapeutic agents act at various stages of cellular mitosis (division). By combining agents, medication therapy is more effective in stopping or slowing the growth of cancerous cells by interfering with their ability to multiply. Do NOT remove the markings - they are guides for treatment - important for accuracy! use hands instead of wash cloth in doing skin care - skin is sensitive during therapy avoid direct sunlight for at least 6 months skin is more sensitive to burns

item.title: NIH Stroke Scale
item.description: 0 = No stroke symptoms 1–4 = Minor stroke 5–15 = Moderate stroke 16–20 = Moderate to severe 21–42 = Severe stroke 1a. LOC (Level of Consciousness) 0 = Alert 1 = Not alert, but arousable 2 = Requires repeated stimulation 3 = Unresponsive1b. LOC Questions (Month & Age) 0 = Both correct 1 = One correct 2 = Neither correct1c. LOC Commands (Open eyes, grip hand) 0 = Both correct 1 = One correct 2 = Neither correct2. Best Gaze (Horizontal eye movement) 0 = Normal 1 = Partial gaze palsy 2 = Forced deviation or no movement3. Visual Fields (Confrontation test) 0 = No loss 1 = Partial hemianopia 2 = Complete hemianopia 3 = Bilateral blindness4. Facial Palsy 0 = Normal 1 = Minor paralysis 2 = Partial (lower face only) 3 = Complete (one or both sides)5. Motor Arm (L & R – 10 sec hold) 0 = No drift 1 = Drift, doesn’t hit bed 2 = Some effort, can't hold up 3 = No effort against gravity 4 = No movement UN = Amputation or joint fusion6. Motor Leg (L & R – 5 sec hold) 0 = No drift 1 = Drift, doesn't hit bed 2 = Some effort, can't hold up 3 = No effort against gravity 4 = No movement UN = Amputation or joint fusion7. Limb Ataxia 0 = Absent 1 = Present in 1 limb 2 = Present in 2 limbs UN = Paralysis prevents test8. Sensory 0 = Normal 1 = Mild to moderate loss 2 = Severe or total loss9. Best Language (Naming, repetition, picture description) 0 = No aphasia 1 = Mild to moderate aphasia 2 = Severe aphasia 3 = Mute or global aphasia10. Dysarthria 0 = Normal 1 = Mild to moderate slurring 2 = Unintelligible or mute UN = Intubated or physical barrier11. Extinction & Inattention (Neglect) 0 = No neglect 1 = Mild neglect 2 = Severe neglect1a. Level of Consciousness (LOC Responsiveness) How: Observe patient when you walk in. If needed, call name, tap, or use painful stimulus (sternal rub). Look For: Spontaneous activity, alertness, arousability. 1b. LOC Questions Say: “What month is it?” “How old are you?” Score: 1 point for each incorrect or no answer. 1c. LOC Commands Say: “Open and close your eyes.” Then “Grip and release my hand.” Look For: Correct performance of both tasks. 2. Best Gaze How: Ask them to follow your finger horizontally (not vertical). Look For: Symmetric movement of both eyes; forced deviation or inability to track. 3. Visual Fields How: Cover one eye at a time. Wiggle fingers in upper/lower quadrants. Ask: “How many fingers do you see?” or “Point to the side where you see movement.” Look For: Field cuts or blindness. 4. Facial Palsy Say: “Show me your teeth.” “Close your eyes tight.” “Raise your eyebrows.” Look For: Symmetry, droop, weakness. 5. Motor Arm (Left & Right) How: Hold arm up 90° (sitting) or 45° (lying). Say: “Keep your arm up — don’t let it drift.” Watch: For 10 seconds. Look For: Drift, falling, or no movement. 6. Motor Leg (Left & Right) How: Hold leg up 30° while lying down. Say: “Keep your leg up — don’t let it fall.” Watch: For 5 seconds. Look For: Drift, effort, or no movement 7. Limb Ataxia How: Finger-to-nose and heel-to-shin tests (eyes open). Look For: Overshooting, jerky or uncoordinated movement. Note: Score only if weakness isn’t the cause. 8. Sensory How: Lightly touch arms/legs with your fingers or a pin. Ask: “Does this feel the same on both sides?” Look For: Numbness, decreased feeling, no response. 9. Best Language How: Show picture cards, name objects, repeat phrases, describe a scene. Look For: Word-finding difficulty, gibberish, comprehension issues. 10. Dysarthria How: Ask patient to say “The sky is blue in Cincinnati” or repeat words. Look For: Slurred or garbled speech (not aphasia). Note: Use writing or gestures if intubated. 11. Extinction & Inattention (Neglect) How: Do double simultaneous touch or ask them to describe picture details. Ask: “Do you feel me touching both sides?” or “What do you see in this picture?” Look For: Ignoring one side, inattention, denial of weakness.

item.title: Hypothyroidism
item.description:
Underactive thyroid gland causing low thyroid hormone levels Leads to slowed metabolism and systemic effects Common in middle-aged/older adults, more in females HypO = HashimotO = lOw n slOw T3/T4 is LOW = HypO T3/T4 causes increased expression of B-adrenergic receptors (causing increased FIGHT OR FLIGHT response => opposite for hyPO) Hashimoto’s thyroiditis (autoimmune destruction) - immune system mistakenly attacks your thyroid, slowly killing it off and making you feel tired, cold, and sluggish Iodine deficiency or excess Thyroidectomy or radioactive iodine therapy Pituitary or hypothalamic dysfunction (↓ TSH or TRH) Medications (lithium, amiodarone) Overdose of Hyperthyroidism meds like: PTU, Methimazole Female, > 60 years Family history of thyroid disease
Autoimmune disorders (Diabetes T1, RA) History of radiation to neck Postpartum period Fatigue, lethargy, depression Cold intolerance (do not use electric blankets due to decreased sensitivity to temperature, they may not notice if it's too hot) weight gain Cardio: Bradycardia, hypotension GI: Constipation, ascites Skin: dry skin, brittle hair, alopecia (not hirsutism = excessive hair growth in women) Neuro: Hoarseness, slow speech, memory impairment Resp: pleural effusion Myxedema (puffy face, periorbital edema) Goiter - swollen thyroid (fat neck) Menstrual changes/irregular, amenorrhea low seggs drive Myxedema coma (severe hypothyroidism crisis) => PREPARE FOR INTUBATION ↓ LOC, hypothermia, respiratory failure, bradycardia, hypotension Emergency: IV levothyroxine, mechanical ventilation, warming
Cardiovascular complications (Heart Failure, atherosclerosis) Infertility, miscarriage - can affect neuro health of baby Elevated: TSH (if primary hypothyroidism) -_Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH) is ELEVATED because body is trying to activate the thyroid Decreased: T3, T4 - these hormones are responsible for metabolism, HR, BP, temp, growth, muscle/bone health Other labs: ↑ cholesterol, anemia Levothyroxine (Synthroid): Lifelong replacement; iv or oral Take on empty stomach in morning, 30–60 min before food takes 3-4 weeks to take effect; DO NOT ABRUPTLY STOP (titrated to TSH levels) Start low, increase gradually to prevent cardiac stress Monitor for hyperthyroidism signs (palpitations, weight loss, high BP, agitation, confusion, thyroid storm) baby safe avoid narcotics & sedatives DO NOT TAKE CALCIUM Monitor VS (risk for bradycardia, hypotension, hypothermia) Weight Changes => monitor Encourage fiber, fluids for constipation prevention Educate on need for lifelong medication adherence Avoid sedatives (↑ risk of myxedema coma) Assess for depression, cognitive changes NCLEX/ATI: Monitor for myxedema coma, reinforce medication timing (morning, empty stomach), avoid abrupt discontinuation

item.title: Anticoagulants
item.description:
#pharmacology #nursing Note Difference between anticoags vs antiplatelets
Anticoagulants - interfere with clotting cascade
Antiplatelets - inhibit activation of platelets Anticoags from NurseintheMaking Anticoagulants prevent new clots from forming, prevent current clots from getting bigger; not blood thinners! Uses: DVT, PE, A-Fib, post-op patients Heparin (LMWH - Low Molecular Weight Heparin: Lovenox - generic enoxaparin) IV or SQ Rapid onset, Heparins Happens Fast - great for short term therapy Monitor: aPTT (heparin has “P” in it) - Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time - how fast blood clots “If numbers are high, the patient will die”, if low - clots will grow - must be therapeutic range Antidote: Protamine Sulfate Educate: subq 2” from umbilicus, 90deg, do not massage site, bruising/pain is common Warfarin (Coumadin) Commonly PO Slow - hours-day / “Warfarin you have to Wait” Can be given with Heparin together Monitor: INR - International Normalized Ratio - how fast blood clots “If numbers are high, the patient will die”, if low - clots will grow - must be therapeutic range Antidote: Vitamin K (during War, Vitamin K KILLS Warfarin!) Educate: Be consistent with Vit K intake - green leafy, liver Know the Difference! Anticoagulants - interfere with the body's clotting factors (proteins) in the coagulation cascade to prevent clot formation Uses: prevention of venous thromboembolisms (VTE), deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism, stroke, afib Antiplatelets - inhibit platelet aggregation (clumping) to prevent the formation of clots in arteries Uses: prevent heart attacks strokes, and other cardiovascular events related to atherosclerosisHemostasis - delicate balance regulated by substances in blood: procoagulants vs anticoagulants Thromboembolic Disorder - too much clotting (leads to thrombi or emboli) Coagulation Disorder - too little clotting, leads to excessive bleeding Thrombocytopenia - decreased platelet production or super platelet destruction Labs to diagnose bleeding disorder: prothrombin time (PT) thrombin time activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) in some instances, a bleeding time.Prefilled Subcutaneous Injection - Enoxaparin do not expel air bubbles - they make sure that full dose is given inject med into anterolateral abdominal wall DO NOT MASSAGE site after injection => can cause bruising & tissue damage with anticoagulants

item.title: Fishbones
item.description: Na | Cl | BUN ---|----|---- K | CO2 | Cr Glu Nuckle BUNS - COCO crunch! Na (Sodium): 135-145 mEq/L Cl (Chloride): 96-106 mEq/L BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen): 7-20 mg/dL K (Potassium): 3.5-5.0 mEq/L CO2 (Bicarbonate): 22-29 mEq/L Cr (Creatinine): 0.6-1.2 mg/dL Glu (Glucose): 70-100 mg/dL (fasting) WBC Hgb | Hct Plt WBC (White Blood Cells): 4,500-11,000 cells/µL Hgb (Hemoglobin): 13.5-17.5 g/dL (male), 12-15.5 g/dL (female) Hct (Hematocrit): 38-50% (male), 34-44% (female) Plt (Platelets): 150,000-450,000 cells/µL

item.title: Herpes Zoster or Shingles
item.description: a painful rash caused by the varicella-zoster virus same virus that causes chicken pox Caused by reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus (VZV), which causes chickenpox Virus stays dormant in nerve ganglia and reactivates later, typically due to immune suppression Results in painful, blistering skin rash along a dermatomal pattern
item.guid: Med-Surg/X - Other Systems/Infectious Diseases/Herpes Zoster or Shingles.md

item.title: Rheumatoid Arthritis
item.description:
Chronic autoimmune disease causing systemic inflammation and progressive joint destruction Patho: synovium is inflamed, immune system attacks tissue surrounding joint, causing damage (including eyes, mouth, heart, lungs) Symmetrical polyarthritis, primarily affecting small joints (hands, wrists, feet) Leads to pain, swelling, stiffness, and deformities Can also affect organs (heart, lungs, eyes, skin) Autoimmune response triggering synovial inflammation Genetic predisposition (HLA-DR4 and HLA-DR1 genes) Environmental triggers (e.g., smoking, infections) Female sex (3:1 female-to-male ratio) Ages 30-50 (peak onset) Family history of RA Smoking (strongest modifiable risk factor) Obesity (linked to disease severity) Infections (may trigger immune response) Symmetric joint pain and stiffness (lasting >1 hour in the morning) Swollen, warm, and tender joints Most commonly affects: fingers, wrists, elbows, knees, ankles Joint deformities over time (swan neck, boutonnière, ulnar deviation) Fatigue, low-grade fever, weight loss AFFECTS THE WHOLE BODY Mouth - gum disease, dry, tooth decay Limbs - deformities, swelling, locking, weakening, ruptured tendons, bunions Skin: rash, ulcers, Rheumatoid nodules (subcutaneous lumps), neuropathy Lungs: COPD, (interstitial fibrosis, pleuritis) Kidneys: impaired function d/t buildup of proteins (amyloidosis) Eye inflammation (scleritis, keratoconjunctivitis sicca) Joint deformities and disability Osteoporosis (due to chronic inflammation and steroid use) Cardiovascular disease (increased risk of heart attack/stroke) Lung disease (fibrosis, pleural effusions) Anemia of chronic disease Infections (due to immunosuppressive therapy) clinical assessment Rheumatoid factor (RF) (positive in 70-80% of cases) Anti-CCP antibodies (more specific for RA) Elevated ESR & CRP (indicate inflammation) XR: shows joint erosion, osteopenia, narrowing of joint space MRI/US: early synovitis detection Culture from Synovial Fluid - r/o bacteria (yes, it can be aspirated) no cure; only management of symptomsPharmacologic:
DMARDs (disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs) – first-line, Methotrexate (MTX) (gold standard) Biologic DMARDs (if unresponsive to traditional DMARDs) - TNF inhibitors NSAIDs and corticosteroids (for symptom relief, but not disease progression) CELECOXIB - cox-2 inhibitor, pain relief for RA, NSAID Non-Pharmacologic: PT - joint mobility, increase muscle strength assistive devices (splints, braces) Immobility will further hinder joint movement and should be avoided Gentle exercise of the affected extremities should be performed, even when joints are painful and inflamed
Monitor for side effects of DMARDs (e.g., liver toxicity, bone marrow suppression, Thrombocytopenia - platelet under 100k) Educate on medication adherence (early treatment prevents joint damage) Encourage joint protection techniques (avoid prolonged gripping, use adaptive tools) Promote balanced rest and exercise Apply warm/cold therapy (warm packs for stiffness, cold packs for inflammation) Monitor for extra-articular complications (lung, heart, skin issues) Encourage smoking cessation (reduces disease progression) Regularly test for TB (DMARDs)
DMARDs - MTX: causes immunosuppression, not for pregnant, bleeding risk, photosensitivity, sun exposure sensitivity Chronic pain related to joint inflammation Impaired physical mobility due to joint stiffness and deformities Self-care deficit related to decreased hand function Risk for falls due to joint instability Fatigue related to systemic inflammation Risk for infection due to immunosuppressive therapy

item.title: Phsyical Ass
item.description: #physical #assessment #headtotoe #nursing #foundationsRinne - placed on ear; normal: AC>BC, "rinne under the pine (pineal)" Webber - placed on head: BC>ACLordosis - lumbar (L for L) Kyphosis - thoracic Stereognosis is the ability to identify the shape and form of a three-dimensional object and, therefore, its identity with tactile manipulation of that object in the absence of visual and auditory stimuli.** Gustation: A chemical sense that responds to molecules in food.  Proprioception: The sense of body position, weight, and resistance in relation to the body. It's also known as kinesthetic sense.  Kinesthesia: The sense of movement and speed of the body. It's also known as motion sense. Grade 1+ (Mild): Depth: Slight indentation (2 mm or less). Rebound: Indentation disappears quickly (less than 5 seconds). Grade 2+ (Moderate): Depth: Moderate indentation (3-4 mm) Rebound: Indentation lasts for 10-15 seconds. Grade 3+ (Severe): Depth: Deep indentation (5-6 mm). Rebound: Indentation remains for 1-2 minutes. Grade 4+ (Very Severe): Depth: Very deep indentation (greater than 6 mm) Rebound: Indentation persists for more than 2 minutes. Olfactory (I): Sensory - Smell. Optic (II): Sensory - Vision. Oculomotor (III): Motor - Eye movement, pupil constriction. Trochlear (IV): Motor - Eye movement (superior oblique). Trigeminal (V): Both - Facial sensation; mastication. Abducens (VI): Motor - Lateral eye movement. Facial (VII): Both - Taste; facial expressions. Vestibulocochlear (VIII): Sensory - Hearing, balance. Glossopharyngeal (IX): Both - "ah," and assess swallowing and voice quality Vagus (X): Both - Visceral sensation; parasympathetic control. Accessory (XI): Motor - Head, shoulder movement. Hypoglossal (XII): Motor - Tongue movement. Stethoscope: Diaphragm = high pitch sounds; lung sounds and bowel sounds Bell = low pitched sounds (smaller); heart sounds and murmurs.

item.title: Polycythemia
item.description: Blood disorder with increased red blood cell (RBC) mass Can be primary (Polycythemia Vera) or secondary to chronic hypoxia or tumors Increases blood viscosity, causing sluggish blood flow Primary: Myeloproliferative disorder (Polycythemia Vera – JAK2 mutation) Secondary: Chronic hypoxia (COPD, high altitude), tumors producing erythropoietin (renal cell carcinoma) Relative: Dehydration (hemoconcentration without true RBC increase) Smoking Living at high altitudes Chronic lung disease Genetic mutations (JAK2) Renal tumors or cysts Ruddy complexion, facial plethora Headache, dizziness, blurred vision Pruritus (especially after hot shower) Splenomegaly Hypertension Thrombosis or bleeding episodes CBC: Elevated RBC, hemoglobin, hematocrit Erythropoietin level (↓ in PV, ↑ in secondary) JAK2 mutation testing Bone marrow biopsy Oxygen saturation, ABG (in secondary causes) Phlebotomy (mainstay for PV to reduce Hct <45%) Hydroxyurea (myelosuppression) for high-risk PV Low-dose aspirin to prevent thrombosis Treat underlying cause in secondary polycythemia Oxygen therapy for hypoxic patients Monitor for signs of thrombosis or bleeding => elevate legs when sitting down to prevent blood pooling Educate on hydration and avoiding iron supplements Assist with phlebotomy procedures Manage pruritus and skin integrity Monitor CBC, clotting profile Ensure safety during dizziness or vision changes Cardiovascular strain from hyperviscosity Increased risk of stroke, MI, DVT Possible progression to myelofibrosis or acute leukemia (in PV)Thromboembolic events (DVT, PE, stroke) Hemorrhagic complications Splenomegaly or splenic rupture Gout (due to increased cell turnover) Progression to malignancy (myelofibrosis, leukemia)

item.title: Alcoholic Liver Disease
item.description: A progressive liver disorder caused by chronic alcohol consumption, leading to liver inflammation, fatty liver, fibrosis, and cirrhosis. Early Stage (Fatty Liver/Steatosis): Often asymptomatic, hepatomegaly, mild elevation in liver enzymes Alcoholic Hepatitis: Jaundice, RUQ pain, nausea, vomiting, anorexia, fever, hepatomegaly, ascites Cirrhosis (Late Stage): Portal hypertension, ascites, varices, hepatic encephalopathy, coagulopathy, muscle wasting Portal Hypertension - causes ascites; blood pressure in the liver’s veins gets so high, it starts causing swollen belly and bleeding LFT (AST, ALT) → AST > ALT (usually 2:1 ratio)** Elevated GGT, Bilirubin, INR (if liver dysfunction severe) Low Albumin (liver can't synthesize proteins) Abdominal Ultrasound/CT (fatty infiltration, cirrhosis signs) Liver Biopsy (definitive diagnosis if needed) GGT => most specific market that indicates extent of drug toxicity or excessive alcohol use (elevated is bad) Chronic excessive alcohol intake (typically > 40g/day for men, > 20g/day for women) Genetic predisposition Malnutrition (common in heavy drinkers) Heavy, prolonged alcohol use Female sex (higher susceptibility to alcohol-induced damage) Genetic polymorphisms affecting alcohol metabolism Hepatitis C coinfection Obesity (worsens liver damage) Poor nutrition (low protein, vitamin deficiencies) Jaundice (yellow skin/eyes) Fatigue Abdominal pain or discomfort Nausea and vomiting Ascites (swelling in the abdomen) Easy bruising or bleeding Hepatic encephalopathy (confusion, altered mental state) Spider veins on the skin Enlarged liver (hepatomegaly) Dark urine and pale stools CNS: Hepatic encephalopathy (confusion, asterixis, coma) GI: Esophageal varices, GI bleeding, pancreatitis Cardiovascular: Cardiomyopathy, hypertension Renal: Hepatorenal syndrome (kidney failure due to liver dysfunction) Liver failure (irreversible damage) Hepatic encephalopathy (toxin buildup, confusion, coma) Esophageal varices (rupture → massive GI bleed) Hepatocellular carcinoma (increased risk with cirrhosis) Alcohol cessation (most important intervention) Nutritional support (high-protein diet, vitamin supplementation, especially thiamine to prevent Wernicke’s encephalopathy) Corticosteroids (for severe alcoholic hepatitis) Pentoxifylline (may reduce inflammation, used in severe cases) Liver transplant (for end-stage cirrhosis in select patients) Monitor liver function tests, coagulation studies Assess for withdrawal symptoms (tremors, agitation, seizures, delirium tremens) Encourage alcohol rehabilitation programs Manage ascites (fluid restriction, diuretics, paracentesis if needed) Monitor for GI bleeding (black stools, hematemesis) Educate on alcohol abstinence, nutrition, and follow-up care

item.title: BPH
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary non-cancerous enlargement of prostate gland; Benign Prostate Hyperplasia common in aging males
Leads to various urinary disorders: Retention, bladder outflow obstruction, urethra constriction hormonal changes (DHT or dihydrotestosterone, estrogen imbalance) aging men over 50 family history
obesity, Metabolic Syndrome, HTN, DM increased urinary frequency and urgency weak urine stream hesitancy straining dysuria nocturia - frequent night time urination decreased QOL/sef-esteem urinary retention UTI, urisepsis bladder stones hydronephrosis - kidney damage from backlflow PSA - prostate specific antigen test screen for prostate cancer Alpha blockers: Cardura Tamsulosin (flomax) - relax smooth muscles in prostate and bladder neck
5-Alpha Reductase Inhibitors Surgery: prostatectomy for super large prostates over 100g Transurethral Resection of the Prostate (TURP) = gold standard TURP - a surgeon inserts a thin tube called a resectoscope through the urethra and into the prostate. The resectoscope has a camera and an electrical loop that cuts away excess prostate tissue. The tissue is removed in small pieces, which are flushed out of the bladder indwelling cather needed postop to monitor UOP and bleeding cloudy urine = infection expected: temporary dribbling and leakage postop (ALL NORMAL) expected: urge to urinate following procedure (ATI), poor sphincter control expected: blood tinged urine postop (a few days) expected: burning & pain Monitor for urinary retention, bladder distention Educate on medication side effects (dizziness, hypotension) Encourage timed voiding, fluid management (avoid evening fluids) Post-TURP: monitor for bleeding, continuous bladder irrigation (CBI) Teach patients to avoid bladder irritants (caffeine, alcohol) Reinforce importance of follow-ups for PSA and symptom monitoring sterile saline fluids to flush clots from the bladder after surgery

item.title: Renal Calculi
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary kidney stones, nephrolithiasis, or urolithiasis caused by accumulation of minerals and salts that lodge in the kidney or urinary tract = pain, hematuria Dehydration: most common Calcium Oxalate (most common) in urine => too much vitamin C! Calcium Phosphate uric acid (look out for gout) struvite cystine stones: genetic Hyperparathyroidism diet: high sodium, high oxalate( spinach, nuts, chocolate), high purine (red meat, alcohol, shellfishh) environmental: extreme heat and sun exposure = e- imbalance lifestyle genetic: family hx gout (uric aid stone) age: 43 and older male: twice as likely obesity frequent UTI
Diabetes T2
CKD HTN severe flank pain with acute oset N/V infection: fever, malaise, etc
If presents with Pylonephritis, surgery may be required Urinary Obstruction => hydronephrosis (kidney swelling) => HIGH PRIORITY
Pylonephritis, sepsis
AKI UA: check RBC, WBC, crystals Non-contrast CT = gold standard Renal US: useful for pregnant patients, children KUB X-ray (Kidney, Ureter, Bladder) observation: if stones are small (<5mm) Tamsulosin (alpha blockers): relax ureter muscles for easier stone passage CCB: for vasodilation (do not use if hypotensive)
Analgesia Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL) → Breaks stones using sound waves Ureteroscopy with stone removal → For larger or impacted stones Percutaneous nephrolithotomy → For large or complex stones risk for obstruction( dec UOP, pain, hematuria) risk for infection strain urine to collect stone

item.title: Venous Access Port
item.description: should be flushed after each use, and at least once a month => prevents blood clots flush with 5 mL heparin with 100 units use non coring needle, 22 guage does not require dressing
item.guid: Med-Surg/Z - Misc Topics/Lines Drains/Venous Access Port.md

item.title: Parathyroid
item.description: Four small glands located behind the thyroid in the neck Despite the name, not part of the thyroid — totally separate job! Releases parathyroid hormone (PTH) PTH’s job = regulate calcium and phosphate levels in the blood Increases calcium in blood by: Breaking down bone (releasing calcium) Telling kidneys to keep calcium (reabsorption) Helping intestines absorb more calcium (by activating vitamin D) Lowers phosphate levels (via kidney excretion) Too much PTH → high calcium (hypercalcemia) Symptoms: "bones, stones, groans, moans" Bone pain, kidney stones, GI upset, fatigue/confusion Too little PTH → low calcium (hypocalcemia) Symptoms: muscle cramps, tetany, Chvostek’s & Trousseau’s signs PTH = Pulls The calcium Higher HypOcalcemia = twitchy/Overactive nerves HypErcalcemia = sluggish (moans, stones, bones)

item.title: Cast Care
item.description: Assess neurovascular status regularly: check circulation, movement, sensation (CMS), color, temperature, pulses, cap refill. Elevate the casted limb above heart level for the first 24–48 hours to reduce swelling. Turn the patient every 2 hours if in a body cast to prevent skin breakdown. Keep the cast dry if it’s not waterproof — cover with plastic when bathing. Use the palm of your hands (not fingers) to handle a wet plaster cast to prevent indentations. Report signs of complications: numbness, tingling, severe pain, swelling, foul odor, drainage, or cool/pale skin. Encourage movement of fingers/toes distal to the cast to maintain circulation. Apply ice packs to the cast over a towel for the first 24–48 hrs to reduce swelling (if approved). Don’t insert objects (like pens or coat hangers) into the cast to relieve itching — risk of injury and infection. Don't insert cotton wipe to dry inside cast - use blow dryer on COOL setting instead Don’t get the cast wet, unless it's made of water-resistant material. Don’t cover a wet cast with plastic — it traps heat and moisture and may cause skin damage. Don’t ignore foul smells or drainage — these could be signs of infection or pressure ulcers under the cast. Don’t bear weight on the cast unless it’s a walking cast and the doctor says it’s okay. Don’t trim or pull apart edges of the cast — always consult a provider if the cast is uncomfortable or damaged.

item.title: Colostomy
item.description: empty bag when it is one-third to one-half full => too much can cause leakage DO NOT: use antimicrobial ointment on peristomal skin - these disrupt adhesion unless prescribed by provided (usually with infection) apply skin barrier while skin is moist => dry first

item.title: Meniere’s Disease
item.description: Chronic inner ear disorder affecting balance and hearing Characterized by episodes of vertigo, tinnitus, fluctuating hearing loss, and aural fullness Caused by excess endolymphatic fluid in the inner ear Exact cause unknown Theories include abnormal fluid drainage, immune response, viral infections, genetic predisposition Age 40–60 years Family history Head injury Viral infections affecting the inner ear Allergies or autoimmune diseases Recurrent episodes of vertigo (lasting 20 min to several hours) Tinnitus (ringing or roaring in the ears) Fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, especially low-frequency Aural fullness (pressure or fullness in the ear) Nausea, vomiting, imbalance during attacks Progressive, permanent hearing loss Risk of falls or accidents due to vertigo Anxiety, depression due to chronic symptoms Difficulty driving or working Based on history and clinical presentation Audiometric tests: sensorineural hearing loss Electronystagmography (ENG) for balance assessment MRI to rule out other causes (e.g., tumors) No cure, focus on symptom management Low-sodium diet, fluid restriction to reduce inner ear fluid Diuretics (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide) Antivertigo medications (e.g., meclizine, diazepam) during acute attacks Antiemetics for nausea (e.g., promethazine) Hearing aids for hearing loss Severe cases: intratympanic injections (e.g., gentamicin), vestibular nerve section, labyrinthectomy Teach fall precautions during vertigo episodes Encourage low-sodium diet and fluid management Instruct on taking meds at onset of symptoms Reduce environmental stimuli during attacks (dim lights, quiet) Provide emotional support for chronic symptoms Educate on avoiding alcohol, caffeine, and smoking

item.title: Osteoarthritis
item.description: Degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage and underlying bone Most common form of arthritis, affecting weight-bearing joints (knees, hips, spine, hands) Progressive (irreversible) and non-inflammatory, leading to pain, stiffness, and reduced mobility osteo = bone Bone Spurs - occurs because of changes in bone; small pieces of bone that form at joints with arthritis leading to further breakdown of joints and cartilageComparison vs Rheumatoid Arthritis Osteoarthritis - caused by joint mechanical stress, affects big joints, more common Rheumatoid - autoimmune, inflammatory, affects all joints, less common Cartilage deterioration due to mechanical stress and aging Chronic joint overuse (e.g., repetitive movements, high-impact activities) Joint misalignment or instability Obesity-related increased joint load Previous joint injuries or surgeries Aging (most common in adults over 50) Obesity (increased stress on weight-bearing joints) Joint injuries or trauma Repetitive stress from occupation or sports Genetic predisposition Muscle weakness and poor joint support joint pain (worsens with activity, relieved by rest) Morning stiffness (lasting <30 minutes) Crepitus (grating sound) with movement Decreased range of motion and flexibility Joint swelling (mild, non-inflammatory) Bony enlargements (Heberden’s nodes on distal fingers, Bouchard’s nodes on proximal fingers) HEBERDEN's NODES - hard lumps over the joints of the fingers Chronic pain and disability Joint deformity and stiffness Decreased mobility leading to muscle atrophy Increased risk of falls due to instability Depression and reduced quality of life clinical assessment XR, MRI erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) to show inflammation (ref: 0-15 for male 0-20, female => higher if older) synovial fluid analysis - to rule out inflammatory arthritis no permanent treatment; supportive unless severe Non-pharmacologic: weight loss (reduce joint stress), PT & exercise (improve strength), assistive device & better shoes (comfort), hot/cold therapy (pain relief) Pharmacologic: acetaminophen, NSAIDs, capsaicin, lidocaine, hyaluronic acid injection (lubricates joints), steroid shots Surgical (severe): joint replacement (aka arthroplasty) Encourage regular exercise (low-impact like swimming, walking) Teach joint protection techniques (assistive devices, ergonomic adjustments) Promote weight management (reduces joint strain) Administer and monitor pain medications (watch for NSAID-related GI side effects) Encourage warm showers or heat therapy to relieve stiffness Monitor for complications like decreased mobility and fall risk For recent knee replacements: do not put pillow under joint (impairs circulation, risk of flexion contracture) Chronic pain related to joint degeneration Impaired physical mobility due to joint stiffness and pain Self-care deficit related to limited joint function Activity intolerance related to fatigue and discomfort Risk for falls due to joint instability and muscle weakness

item.title: Lupus
item.description: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic autoimmune disease where the immune system attacks its own tissues, leading to inflammation and damage. Affects multiple organs, including skin, joints, kidneys, and the heart. More common in women (especially those of childbearing age) and can be triggered by genetic, environmental, and hormonal factors. unknown genetic, hormonal (PREGNANT), and environmental factors Genetic predisposition: Family history of lupus or other autoimmune diseases increases risk. Environmental triggers: Infections, medications, UV light exposure, and smoking. Hormonal influence: Estrogen plays a role, making lupus more common in women. Gender: More common in women, particularly those of childbearing age. Ethnicity: More prevalent in African American, Hispanic, and Asian populations. Family history of lupus or other autoimmune diseases. Environmental triggers: UV light, infections, and certain medications. Systemic: Fatigue, fever, weight loss, malaise. Skin: Butterfly-shaped rash across the cheeks and nose, photosensitivity, discoid lupus. Joint: Pain, stiffness, and swelling, commonly affecting small joints. Kidneys: Lupus nephritis (inflammation of the kidneys) can cause edema, proteinuria, and kidney failure. Neuro: Headaches, seizures, and memory loss. Cardiovascular: Increased risk of pericarditis and stroke. Respiratory: Pleuritis, pleural effusion, and interstitial lung disease. Lupus nephritis: Kidney failure due to glomerulonephritis. Cardiovascular disease: Increased risk of heart attacks, strokes, and pericarditis. Infections: Due to immunosuppressive treatments and the disease itself. Osteoporosis: Long-term use of corticosteroids can lead to bone thinning. Psychosocial impact: Chronic pain, fatigue, and cosmetic issues (skin rashes) can affect quality of life. Antinuclear antibody (ANA) test: Positive in most patients with lupus. Anti-dsDNA: Specific to lupus, high titers correlate with kidney involvement. Anti-Smith antibodies: Specific but less common. Complete blood count (CBC): May show anemia, leukopenia, or thrombocytopenia. Complement levels (C3, C4): Low levels suggest active disease. Urinalysis: Detects proteinuria, hematuria, and casts indicating kidney involvement. Skin biopsy: To confirm lupus-induced skin lesions. Kidney biopsy: In suspected lupus nephritis. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for pain and inflammation. Antimalarial drugs (e.g., hydroxychloroquine) for skin and joint symptoms. Corticosteroids for acute flare-ups and inflammation. Immunosuppressive drugs (e.g., azathioprine, methotrexate) for severe disease or organ involvement. Biologic agents (e.g., belimumab) for refractory cases. Monitor for flare-ups: Assess for signs of active disease, such as fever, joint swelling, and rash. Patient education: Importance of sun protection, medication adherence, and avoiding triggers. Kidney function monitoring: Regular urinalysis and serum creatinine levels. Psychosocial support: Address the emotional and psychological impact of chronic disease. Bone health: Monitor for osteoporosis, especially in patients on long-term corticosteroid therapy. Infection control: Educate patients about the increased risk of infections due to immunosuppressive treatment. pain management prevent flare-ups maintain skin integrity decrease joint stiffness, increase ROM educate

item.title: Cancer
item.description:
Uncontrolled growth and spread of abnormal cells that can invade nearby tissues and metastasize to other parts of the body. Can originate in any organ or tissue and is classified based on cell type and location (e.g., carcinoma, sarcoma, leukemia, lymphoma). Stages: Ranges from localized (Stage 1) to widespread metastasis (Stage 4) Cell Changes: Normal hyperplasia - increased # of cells, appear normal dysplasia - abnormal cells present carcinoma in situ - abnormal cells that stay in one location without spreading malignant - mutated, changed, replicate faster, spread to other areas Genetic mutations: Inherited or acquired DNA changes that lead to uncontrolled cell growth. Environmental factors: Exposure to carcinogens like tobacco, radiation, and chemicals. Lifestyle factors: Poor diet, obesity, and lack of physical activity increase risk. Infections: Certain viruses (e.g., HPV => cervical cancer, hepatitis B, Epstein-Barr) contribute to cancer development. Genetic predisposition: Family history of cancer increases risk. Age: Risk increases with age due to accumulated genetic mutations, body unable to remove damaged cells Smoking and tobacco use: Major cause of lung and other cancers. Alcohol consumption: Associated with liver, esophageal, and breast cancer. Obesity and poor diet: Linked to colorectal, breast, and pancreatic cancer. Radiation exposure: UV rays cause skin cancer, while ionizing radiation increases risk for leukemia and thyroid cancer C: Change in bowel or bladder habits => may indicate obstruction or tumors in GI tract A: A sore that does not heal => indicates poor immune response or skin cancers U: Unusual bleeding or discharge => tumors eroding blood vessels T: Thickening or lump in the breast or elsewhere => tumor growth I: Indigestion or difficulty swallowing => esophageal, gastric, or throat cancers O: Obvious changes in warts or moles = > skin cancers N: Nagging cough or hoarseness => Lung, laryngeal, or thyroid cancers irritate airways Other manifestations: pain from cancer tumors and treatment (radiation, chemotherapy) Neutropenic Precautions => decreased WBC, high risk for sepsis unintentional weight loss Lymphedema: swelling of the interstitial tissues as a result of increased lymph fluid (example: one arm may be swollen while other one is not)
Peripheral Neuropathy: can be sensory (numbness), motor (weakness, loss of balance), autonomic (constipation, diarrhea, sexual function impairment, etc.) infertility sleep disturbance, insomnia, anxiety
Delirium in advanced cancer fatigue Chemotherapy/Radiation Therapy Side Effects: Neutropenia (lowered WBC), may lead to sepsis N/V => increased risk of dehydration, metabolic abnormalities, etc dry mouth, mouth ulcers decreased taste sensation fatigue: chemo-anemia or from stress alopecia flaky skin Pancytopenia (a deficiency of WBCs, RBCs, and platelet count) is an expected adverse effect of chemotherapy.
Bone Marrow Suppression: chemotherapy or metastasis, causing Anemia, leukopenia (low WBC), and Thrombocytopenia. hypercalcemia - usually from myeloma (blood cancer) and breast cancers spinal cord compression - breast cancer Superior Vena Cava Syndrome (SVC) - structural complication caused by a tumor compressing the SVC Malignant Pericardial Effusion - cancerous fluid accumulates around the heart Tumor Lysis Syndrome - metabolic emergency that is triggered by cancer treatment
Med-Surg/GU/SIADH death Imaging: X-rays, CT scans, MRI, PET scans to detect tumors. Biopsy: Gold standard for confirming cancer type and grading. Blood tests: Tumor markers (e.g., CA-125 for ovarian cancer, PSA for prostate cancer). Genetic testing: Identifies inherited cancer syndromes (e.g., BRCA1/2 mutations). Surgery: Removal of tumors when localized. Chemotherapy: Systemic drug therapy to kill or slow cancer cells. Radiation therapy: High-energy radiation to target and destroy cancer cells. Immunotherapy: Boosts immune system to recognize and attack cancer. Targeted therapy: Drugs that block specific cancer cell growth pathways. Hormone therapy: Used for hormone-sensitive cancers like breast and prostate cancer. Palliative care: Focus on symptom management and improving quality of life in advanced stages. Pain Management
Manage Side Effects: N/V, mucositis, Peripheral Neuropathy, bone marrow suppression Support: emotional, nutritional
Infection prevention: Neutropenic Precautions a lot of stuff is radioactive: their bodily wastes, sheets, clothes, etc patient must have separate everything: towels, utensils, dishes no seggs, kissing 6 feet apart from others avoid pregnant, infants, children

item.title: Lyme's Disease
item.description: A tick-borne bacterial infection caused by Borrelia burgdorferi Transmitted through the bite of infected black-legged (deer) ticks Most common vector-borne illness in the U.S. Can affect skin, joints, heart, and nervous system Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, a spirochete bacterium Transmitted through the bite of infected Ixodes ticks (must be attached for 36–48 hrs) Outdoor activities in grassy, wooded areas Living in or visiting endemic regions (e.g., Northeast, Midwest U.S.) Having pets that bring ticks indoors Warmer months (late spring to early fall) Early localized (3–30 days): Erythema migrans ("bull’s-eye rash") Fever, chills, headache, muscle and joint aches Early disseminated (weeks to months): Multiple rashes, facial palsy, meningitis Carditis (AV block) Late disseminated (months to years): Arthritis, especially in large joints Neurological symptoms (memory issues, neuropathy) per ATI: Early Lyme disease is characterized by: fever influenza-like manifestations - erythema migrans - a distinct, progressive, circular or bullseye rash that often develops at the bite site but can also develop at other sites such as the thighs and knees. Chronic arthritis Cardiac complications (e.g., heart block) Neurologic deficits Post-treatment Lyme disease syndrome (PTLDS) Clinical signs (esp. bull’s-eye rash) Serologic testing: ELISA, followed by Western blot May take weeks for antibodies to appear Early disease: oral antibiotics (e.g., doxycycline, amoxicillin) Neurologic or cardiac involvement: IV antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone) Pain management for arthritis No current vaccine (as of now) Teach tick prevention: use repellents, wear long sleeves/pants, check skin/pets Instruct to remove ticks properly (tweezers, steady upward pull) Monitor for signs of systemic involvement Stress importance of completing antibiotic regimen Supportive care for joint pain or neurologic symptoms

item.title: Aplastic Anemia
item.description: A rare condition where the bone marrow fails to produce enough blood cells Leads to pancytopenia: decreased RBCs, WBCs, and platelets Can be acquired or inherited Idiopathic (most common) Autoimmune destruction of hematopoietic stem cells Exposure to toxins (e.g., benzene), radiation, or chemotherapy Certain medications (e.g., chloramphenicol, NSAIDs) Viral infections (e.g., hepatitis, EBV, HIV, parvovirus B19) Inherited disorders (e.g., Fanconi anemia) History of toxic chemical exposure Autoimmune disorders Use of specific medications Previous cancer treatment Viral infections Fatigue, pallor, weakness (due to anemia) Frequent infections, fever (due to neutropenia) Easy bruising, petechiae, bleeding gums, epistaxis (due to thrombocytopenia) Tachycardia, dyspnea Life-threatening infections Severe bleeding Heart failure from chronic anemia Death if untreated CBC: pancytopenia Bone marrow biopsy: hypocellular marrow with fatty infiltration Rule out other causes of pancytopenia (e.g., leukemia, myelodysplastic syndrome) Identify and remove causative agent if possible Blood transfusions (RBCs, platelets) Immunosuppressive therapy (e.g., ATG, cyclosporine) Bone marrow or stem cell transplant (curative for severe cases) Antibiotics for infections Monitor for signs of infection and bleeding Use neutropenic and bleeding precautions Educate on avoiding crowds and injury Administer transfusions and medications as ordered Provide emotional support for long treatment course and potential isolation

item.title: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
item.description: Acute autoimmune disorder where the immune system attacks the peripheral nervous system Leads to demyelination of peripheral nerves, causing ascending weakness and paralysis Often follows infection or vaccination Often triggered by infections: Campylobacter jejuni (most common), cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, influenza Occasionally follows vaccination or surgery Immune system mistakenly targets peripheral myelin Recent viral or bacterial infection Recent immunization or surgery Male sex Age over 50 Symmetrical, ascending muscle weakness starting in legs Paresthesia (tingling, numbness) Loss of reflexes (areflexia) Facial weakness, difficulty speaking or swallowing Respiratory muscle weakness or failure Autonomic dysfunction: fluctuating BP, arrhythmias Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) from immobility Autonomic instability Aspiration pneumonia Permanent neurologic deficits (rare) Clinical presentation and history of recent illness Lumbar puncture: elevated protein in CSF with normal WBC Nerve conduction studies and EMG: slowed conduction MRI to rule out other causes Hospitalization and supportive care Plasmapheresis or IV immunoglobulin (IVIG) to reduce immune attack Mechanical ventilation if respiratory muscles involved Pain control and DVT prophylaxis Physical therapy during recovery Monitor respiratory status and prepare for intubation if needed Assess motor strength, cranial nerves, and reflexes regularly Prevent complications from immobility (pressure ulcers, DVT) Support nutrition, communication, and emotional needs Educate on slow recovery process and provide rehab support

item.title: Scleroderma
item.description: Chronic autoimmune connective tissue disorder causing hardening and tightening of the skin and internal organs the body produces and deposits too much collagen, causing thickening and hardening Divided into two types: Localized Scleroderma – Limited to skin and underlying tissues. Systemic Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis) – Involves skin, blood vessels, and internal organs. Exact cause unknown; involves immune system dysfunction, genetic factors, and environmental triggers. Female sex (most common in women aged 30-50). Family history of autoimmune diseases. Exposure to silica dust, solvents, or industrial chemicals. Viral infections may play a role. Skin thickening and hardening (fingers, face, and extremities). contractures - tissues around joints become stiff and tight, limiting the range of motion and potentially causing the joint to become fixed in a bent position (fingers - most common, wrists, elbows, shoulders, knees, ankles) - all extremities basically Raynaud’s Disease (cold-induced color changes in extremities). Tight, shiny skin over affected areas. Joint pain and stiffness. Esophageal dysmotility (difficulty swallowing, acid reflux). Telangiectasia (visible blood vessels on the skin). Organ involvement may lead to lung fibrosis, heart issues, or kidney dysfunction. Pulmonary hypertension. Heart failure from myocardial fibrosis. Scleroderma renal crisis (acute kidney failure and severe hypertension). Digital ulcers and gangrene from poor circulation. Malnutrition from GI involvement. Antinuclear antibody (ANA) test – Often positive. Anti-Scl-70 antibody – Specific for systemic scleroderma. Anti-centromere antibody – Common in limited scleroderma. Skin biopsy confirms fibrosis. Imaging (e.g., CT scan, echocardiogram) assesses organ damage. Immunosuppressants (e.g., methotrexate, cyclophosphamide). Calcium channel blockers for Raynaud’s. Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) for acid reflux. ACE inhibitors for renal crisis prevention. Vasodilators for pulmonary hypertension. Promote skin care with moisturizers to reduce dryness and irritation. Encourage warm clothing and lifestyle adjustments to manage Raynaud’s. Monitor for hypertension, renal function, and respiratory changes. Provide small, frequent meals to reduce GI discomfort. Educate about the chronic nature of the disease and coping strategies. Impaired Skin Integrity related to fibrosis and tight skin. Ineffective Airway Clearance related to pulmonary fibrosis. Chronic Pain related to joint stiffness and inflammation. Risk for Impaired Tissue Perfusion related to vascular involvement.

item.title: Raynaud’s Disease
item.description: A vasospastic disorder that causes intermittent constriction of small arteries, usually in fingers and toes. Triggered by cold exposure or stress, leading to reduced blood flow and color changes. Primary Raynaud’s: Idiopathic with no underlying disease. Secondary Raynaud’s: Associated with autoimmune conditions (e.g., Scleroderma, Lupus, Rheumatoid Arthritis). Female sex (more common in women ages 15–40). Cold environments. Family history of Raynaud’s or autoimmune disease. Occupational triggers (e.g., vibration tools). Smoking (vasoconstriction). Triphasic color changes in digits: White (pallor) from vasoconstriction. Blue (cyanosis) from poor oxygenation. Red (rubor) from reperfusion. Numbness, tingling, burning pain during or after attacks. Cold, pale, or blue fingers/toes, often symmetrical. Ulcers or sores on fingers in severe cases. Tissue necrosis if blood flow is severely compromised. Functional impairment with frequent attacks. Clinical history and symptoms during cold/stress exposure. Nailfold capillaroscopy to examine capillary structure (esp. in secondary). Antibody testing (ANA, anti-centromere) for autoimmune association. Lifestyle modifications: Avoid cold, wear gloves, keep core warm. Manage stress. Stop smoking. Medications: Calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine) – relax vessels. Vasodilators (e.g., topical nitroglycerin). In secondary cases, treat underlying condition. Severe cases: Sympathectomy (nerve surgery to reduce spasms). Teach cold avoidance strategies and layering clothing. Encourage smoking cessation. Educate on early symptom recognition and attack prevention. Monitor for skin breakdown or signs of ulceration/ischemia. In secondary Raynaud’s, coordinate care for underlying autoimmune disease.

item.title: Wounds
item.description: Incision – Clean, straight cut (e.g., surgical wound). Laceration – Irregular, torn wound (e.g., from trauma). Abrasion – Superficial wound caused by friction (e.g., scraped nee). Puncture – Deep, narrow wound caused by a sharp object (e.g., needle stick). Avulsion – Tissue torn away from its normal location (e.g., degloving injury). Ulcer – Open sore due to prolonged pressure or circulation issues (e.g., pressure ulcer). Burn – Tissue damage from heat, chemicals, electricity, or radiation. Primary Intention Edges are approximated (closed) with sutures, staples, or glue. Minimal scarring and healing occurs quickly. Example: Surgical incision. Secondary Intention Wound heals from the inside out; left open to heal naturally. Granulation tissue forms, followed by epithelialization. Higher risk of infection and more scarring. Example: Pressure ulcers, burns, large wounds with tissue loss. Tertiary Intention (Delayed Primary Closure) Wound left open initially, then later closed surgically. Used when there is a high risk of infection or contamination. Example: Infected surgical wound, abdominal wound with dehiscence.

item.title: HIV-AIDS
item.description:
Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) => a retrovirus that is transmitted through blood and body fluids (semen, vaginal secretions) also found in feces, urine, tears, saliva, cerebrospinal fluid, cervical cells, lymph nodes, corneal tissue, and brain tissue attacks CD4+ T cells, weakening the immune system CD4 protein found on the surface of certain immune cells, known as helper T cells crucial in recognizing and responding to infections CD4 range: 500-1,500 cells/mm3 (average adult, lower for younger or elderly) Stage 1 - Acute HIV Infection Occurs 2-4 weeks after exposure Rapid viral replication and spread Symptoms: Flu-like symptoms (fever, sore throat, rash, swollen lymph nodes, headache) Highly infectious phase CD4+ T-Lymphocyte Count: 500 cells/mm3 or more Stage 2 - Chronic HIV, latent Virus continues to replicate at low levels Can last for several years (longer with ART) Symptoms: Few or no symptoms Gradual decline in CD4+ T-cell count CD4+ T-Lymphocyte Count: 200 to 499 cells/mm3 Stage 3 - AIDS Final stage, severe immune system damage Vulnerable to opportunistic infections and cancers Symptoms: Severe immunosuppression, opportunistic infections (e.g., tuberculosis, pneumonia, candidiasis), cancers (Kaposi’s sarcoma, lymphoma) CD4+ count below 200 cells/mm³ (less than 14% of lymphocytes) Unprotected seggs (vaginal, anal, oral) Multiple seggs partners Occupational exposure (health care workers) Perinatal exposure Blood transfusions (not a significant source of infection in the U.S.) IV drug use with a contaminated needle asymptomatic initially Chills, fever Rash swollen lymph nodes Anorexia, nausea, weight loss Weakness and fatigue Headache and sore throat Night sweats Kaposi Sarcoma (cancer) - manifests as hyperpigmented multicentric lesions that can be firm, flat, raised, or nodular. Following a biopsy, the lesions are treated with radiation and/or chemotherapy Opportunistic infections cancers (Kaposi’s sarcoma, lymphoma) neurological issues (HIV-associated dementia) wasting syndrome - significant unintentional weight loss, muscle wasting, and fatigue organ failure. CD4+ T-cell count: Normal: 500-1,500 cells/mm³; AIDS diagnosis: <200 cells/mm³ Viral Load: below 40 to 75 copies/mL of blood CBC and differential: Abnormal (anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia) Platelet count: Decreased less than 150,000/mm3 HIV antibody screening test (ELISA, Western blot, IFA, home test kit) Test viral load before beginning treatment HIV Drug resistant testing - guides medication therapy Brain or lung MRI/CT antiretroviral therapy (ART) - suppress viral replication and restore immune function; lowers viral load postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) medication - for accidental exposure, must be taken within 72 hours, daily for 28 days All women who are pregnant should be screened for HIV DO NOT administer live virus vaccines (especially for CD4+ count below 200 cells/mm³ due to the risk of uncontrolled viral replication) positive Western blot or IFA test => client has been exposed to and has the AIDS virus in their body BUT does not mean the client has clinical AIDS. Promote medication adherence monitor for side effects of ART educate on transmission prevention provide emotional support encourage routine screening encourage high protein diet - at least six small feedings with high protein value
manage symptoms of opportunistic infections: TB, Pneumonia, septicemia, kaposis sarcoma, lymphoma report indications of infection immediately to the provider

item.title: Peripherally Inserted Central Catheter (PICC)
item.description: A long-term intravenous (IV) access device inserted into a peripheral vein (usually the basilic, cephalic, or brachial vein) and advanced to the superior vena cava. Used for long-term medication administration, total parenteral nutrition (TPN), and frequent blood draws. Long-term IV therapy (e.g., antibiotics, chemotherapy). Parenteral nutrition when enteral feeding is not possible. Frequent blood sampling to minimize vein trauma. Central venous pressure (CVP) monitoring in some cases. Local infection or vascular abnormalities at the insertion site. Thrombosis or occlusion in target veins. End-stage renal disease (preferably preserving veins for future dialysis access). Dressing Changes: Use aseptic technique (sterile gloves, chlorhexidine prep). Change transparent dressing every 7 days (or if soiled). Flushing Protocol: Use 10 mL saline before and after use to prevent occlusion. Heparin flush per facility policy (often for non-valved catheters). Blood Draws: Discard 5 mL blood before sampling. - Flush with 20 mL normal saline post-draw. Assessment: Check for redness, swelling, drainage, or pain at the site. Measure and document external catheter length to detect migration. Patient Education: Avoid heavy lifting with the affected arm. Do not submerge in water (cover during showers). Infection Prevention: Monitor for signs of local (redness, swelling) and systemic infection (fever, chills). Clot Prevention: Flush regularly and assess for sluggish flow or resistance. Catheter Migration: Sudden difficulty flushing or aspiration may indicate dislodgment. Air Embolism Prevention: Clamp the catheter when not in use, and place the patient in Trendelenburg if air embolism is suspected. Regular monitoring and proper care reduce the risk of complications such as infection, thrombosis, or catheter migration.
item.guid: Med-Surg/Z - Misc Topics/Lines Drains/Peripherally Inserted Central Catheter (PICC).md

item.title: Cholecystitis
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal #cholecystitisWhat is it: Inflammation of the gallbladder; can be calculous (gallstone) or acalculous CALCULOUS most common; gallbladder becomes inflamed due to an obstruction caused by a gallstone that may prevent the bile from being expelled ACALCULOUS sudden inflammation of the gallbladder w/o gallstones more life threatening! high risk of perforation and necrosis that occurs more often in critically ill clients dysfunction of the gallbladder emptying mechanism related to prolonged periods without oral feeding usually accompanied by severe trauma, burns, sepsis or other major complication Causes: gallstones (calculous cholecystitis) obstructing the cystic duct, leading to bile stasis and infection bacterial infection, ischemia, trauma, prolonged fasting, critical illness. Risk Factors: Female, obesity, high-fat diet, rapid weight loss, pregnancy, hormone therapy, older age, diabetes, prolonged TPN use.Clinical Manifestations: RUQ pain, radiates to right shoulder, worsens after fatty meals, N/V, fever, tachycardia, Murphy’s sign positive, possible jaundice if bile duct obstructed.Blumberg's sign - sharp pain that occurs when pressure is released from the abdomen during a physical examination (ATI)Diagnosis: Ultrasound (first-line), HIDA scan, CT scan, elevated WBC, LFTs (bilirubin, ALP), amylase/lipase if pancreatic involvement.Treatment: NPO IV fluids
Analgesia abx cholecystectomy (laparoscopic preferred) - The surgical excision of the gallbladder. ERCP if bile duct obstruction present. Nursing Considerations: Monitor for infection pain control NPO status IV hydration post-op care after cholecystectomy (early ambulation, wound care educate on diet modifications (low-fat, small meals). Things to note: Murphy's Sign - when you press on the RUQ and the patient experiences pain ERCP - Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography; a medical procedure that combines endoscopy and X-rays to diagnose and treat conditions affecting the bile ducts ERCP is used to remove gallstones MRCP - Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography, another imaging procedure Estrogen - fucks up the gallbladder resulting in decreased production of bile salts => clumping of bile => blockage HIDA scan - dye is injected to trace movement in bile ducts, Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid Scan, uses special cameraWhat is it: gallstones formed from cholesterol, bilirubin, or mixed substances in the gallbladder, can be asymptomatic or cause obstruction leading to cholecystitis. Causes: Imbalance in bile composition (excess cholesterol, bilirubin, or decreased bile salts), bile stasis, gallbladder motility issues. Risk Factors: Female, obesity, high-fat/low-fiber diet, rapid weight loss, pregnancy, hormone therapy, older age, diabetes, liver disease, prolonged TPN. Clinical Manifestations: Asymptomatic or biliary colic (RUQ pain, radiates to right shoulder, postprandial, especially after fatty meals), nausea, vomiting, bloating, dyspepsia. Diagnosis: Ultrasound (first-line), CT scan, MRCP, elevated LFTs if bile duct obstruction, ERCP if common bile duct stones suspected. Treatment: Asymptomatic—no treatment needed; symptomatic—cholecystectomy (laparoscopic preferred), bile acid dissolution therapy (ursodiol) if surgery contraindicated, ERCP for bile duct stones. Nursing Considerations: Pain management, monitor for signs of obstruction or infection, educate on diet changes (low-fat, small meals), post-op care after cholecystectomy, assess for complications like pancreatitis or cholangitis.

item.title: ESRD
item.description:
End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) Final stage of CKD where kidneys can no longer maintain fluid, electrolyte, and waste balance GFR < 15 mL/min, requiring dialysis or kidney transplant for survival Leads to multisystem complications due to accumulation of toxins, fluid overload, and hormonal imbalances RIFLE Criteria for AKI (from mild to very bad) Risk: Increased creatinine x1.5 or GFR decrease >25% with urine output <0.5 mL/kg/hr for 6 hrs Injury: Increased creatinine x2 or GFR decrease >50% with urine output <0.5 mL/kg/hr for 12 hrs Failure: Increased creatinine x3 or GFR decrease >75% or creatinine ≥4 mg/dL with urine output <0.3 mL/kg/hr for 24 hrs or anuria for 12 hrs Loss: Persistent AKI requiring dialysis for >4 weeks End-stage kidney disease: Dialysis dependence for >3 months Diabetes mellitus (Diabetic nephropathy) → Leading cause Hypertension → Chronic high BP damages glomeruli
Polycystic Kidney Disease
Glomerulonephritis (chronic inflammation damaging nephrons) Autoimmune diseases (Lupus, IgA nephropathy) Obstructive uropathy (chronic kidney stones, BPH, reflux nephropathy) Uncontrolled diabetes & hypertension Family history of kidney disease Obesity, smoking, high-sodium diet Nephrotoxic medications (NSAIDs, aminoglycosides) African American, Hispanic, Native American ethnicity (higher prevalence of diabetes & HTN) Fluid overload → Edema, pulmonary congestion, hypertension Uremia (toxin buildup) → Fatigue, confusion, pruritus, nausea, metallic taste Electrolyte imbalances → Hyperkalemia (dysrhythmias), metabolic acidosis, hypocalcemia Anemia → Pallor, weakness (decreased erythropoietin production) Bone disease (renal osteodystrophy) → Bone pain, fractures (due to calcium/phosphorus imbalance) Cardiovascular complications → Heart failure, pericarditis, arrhythmias Cardiovascular disease (leading cause of death in ESRD patients) Hyperkalemia-induced cardiac arrest Pulmonary edema from fluid overload Infections (weakened immune system, dialysis access site infections) Uremic encephalopathy (neurological dysfunction from toxin buildup) Malnutrition (protein-energy wasting common in dialysis patients)
Serum creatinine & BUN → Significantly elevated, see CMP GFR < 15 mL/min → Diagnostic of ESRD Electrolytes (↑K+, ↓Ca2+, ↑Phosphate, metabolic acidosis) Hemoglobin & hematocrit (↓ due to erythropoietin deficiency) Renal ultrasound → Small, atrophied kidneys (except in PKD) Dialysis (Hemodialysis or Peritoneal Dialysis) Kidney transplant (preferred long-term solution) Fluid & dietary restrictions (low sodium, potassium, phosphorus, and protein moderation) Erythropoietin-stimulating agents (epoetin alfa) for anemia Phosphate binders (calcium acetate, sevelamer) to prevent bone disease Vitamin D & calcium supplements to manage hypocalcemia Blood pressure & glucose control to slow progression in early CKD Monitor fluid status (daily weights, edema, lung sounds, BP) Assess for dialysis complications (hypotension, infection, disequilibrium syndrome) Monitor potassium levels & cardiac rhythm (risk of hyperkalemia-induced arrhythmias) Educate on dietary restrictions (low sodium, potassium, phosphorus, and controlled protein intake) Administer medications safely (adjust dosages for renal impairment, avoid nephrotoxic drugs) Assess for uremic symptoms (pruritus, confusion, nausea) Encourage adherence to treatment plan (dialysis schedule, medications, diet)

item.title: NIHSS Stroke Scale
item.description: Overview: Standardized tool for assessing stroke severity evaluates neurological impairment based on specific criteria commonly used in acute stroke care and research Scoring: 0 = No stroke symptoms 1-4 = Minor stroke 5-15 = Moderate stroke 16-20 = Moderate to severe stroke 21-42 = Severe stroke Assessment Components: Level of Consciousness (LOC): Alertness response to questions/commands Best Gaze: Horizontal eye movement Visual Fields: Visual field deficits Facial Palsy: Facial muscle weakness Motor Arm (L/R): Arm strength and drift Motor Leg (L/R): Leg strength and drift Limb Ataxia: Coordination assessment Sensory: Sensation loss Best Language: Ability to name objects follow commands Dysarthria: Clarity of speech Extinction/Inattention (Neglect): Awareness of stimuli on both sides Scoring Tips: Each item scored individually then totaled higher scores indicate greater impairment used to guide treatment decisions like thrombolytic therapy and predict outcomes

item.title: Herpes
item.description: Acyclovir

item.title: Eye Disorders
item.description: Macular degeneration, often called age-related macular degeneration (AMD), is the central loss of vision that affects the macula of the eye. There is no cure for macular degeneration. AMD is a common cause of vision loss in older adults. G Dry macular degeneration is the most common and is caused by a gradual blockage in retinal capillary arteries, which results in the macula becoming ischemic and necrotic due to the lack of retinal cells.Wet macular degeneration is a less common form and is caused by the new growth of blood vessels that have thin walls that leak blood and fluid.A cataract is an opacity in the lens of an eye that impairs vision.Postoperative care should focus on the following. Preventing an increase in intraocular pressure (straining, bending over the waist, sneezing, blowing nose, coughing, etc) Preventing infection. Administering ophthalmic medications. Providing pain relief. Teaching the client about self-care at home and fall prevention NO READING POSTOP to repair DETACHED RETINA

item.title: Nephrostomy
