item.description: Percutaneous tube placed directly into renal pelvis to drain urine Used when normal urinary flow is obstructed Ureteral obstruction (e.g., stones, tumors) Postoperative urinary diversion Infection with impaired drainage Trauma causing urinary tract damage Uncorrected coagulopathy Severe infection at insertion site Anatomical abnormalities preventing safe placement Assess and document urine output, color, and consistency Perform site care with sterile technique Ensure tubing is free from kinks and secured properly Flush the tube only if prescribed and trained to do so Educate patient on care, infection signs, and activity restrictions Monitor for infection (e.g., fever, site redness, purulent drainage) Ensure drainage bag remains below kidney level Avoid excessive manipulation to prevent dislodgement Encourage fluid intake unless contraindicated Assess for signs of urine leakage or skin irritation

item.title: Pneumonia
item.description:
#respiratory #nursing #medsurg
Acid Base Balance => for ABG ValuesWhat is it?
umbrella term used to refer infection of lung parenchyma caused by bacteria, fungi, and viruses #pneumonia inflammation => exudate/secretions= > occlusion of bronchi => airway compromise consolidation = air in small airways is replaced by fluid in lungs Clinical Presentation fever, chills, malaise, loss of appetite, myalgia cough (w/ or w/out sputum), tachypnea, dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain SOB, adventitious breath sounds (crackles and rhonchi) dull percussion, tactile fremitus Hypoxemia = impaired alveolar gas exchange CXR: opacity tachy Labs: WBC, ESR, CRP, procalcitonin =>all elevated severe: sepsis, hypotension, altered mental status, organ dysfunction Treatment bronchodilators & analgesia treat cause: antibiotics (depends on culture) MRSA = vancomycin encourage early mobility but need rest and avoid overexertion semi fowler remove secretions: coughing exercises, increased fluid intake O2 with humidifier to minimize dry secretions incentive spirometer - RT, PT, nutrition consult CURB-65 Scale (Confusion Urea, RR, BP, 65 or older) Score of 0-5: 0=outpatient, 4 or greater=ICU modalities: confusion, BUN, RR, SBP, age Nursing Considerations & Interventions infection control encourage conserving of energy, less stress, educate smoking cessation Complications & Other Systemic Effects poor nutrition sepsis atelectasis = inability of lungs to inflate properly MI, stroke, arrythmia, pulmonary embolism impaired mobility Causes Subtypes: Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP) s. pneumonia, s. aureus, mycoplasma pneumoniae s. pneumoniae = most common influenza Hospital Acquired Pneumonia (HAP) s. aureus, MRSA. pseudomonas aeruginosa Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP) s. aureus, MRSA. pseudomonas aeruginosa Risk Factors over 65 COPD, cystic fibrosis heart disease, lung cancer previous viral respiratory infection or pneumonia bronchiectasis asthma Co-morbidities: stroke, DM, malnutrition immunocompromised: HIV Diagnosis CXR, CT blood culture, sputum, CBC/WBC CRP, ESR, procalcitonin

item.title: Lipid Panel
item.description: #nursingGoal: everything must be less than 200, 150, 100 200 or less: total cholesterol 150 or less: trigly 50 or less: LDL (lousy)

item.title: Lab Values to Know
item.description: Glucose (Fasting): 70 - 99 mg/dLHemoglobin A1c (HbA1c): < 5.7% (normal), 5.7% - 6.4% (pre-diabetes), ≥ 6.5% (diabetes)Serum Osmolality Normal Range: 275 - 295 mOsm/kg TSH (Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone): 0.5 - 5.0 mU/L T3 (Triiodothyronine): 80 - 200 ng/dL T4 (Thyroxine): 4.5 - 12.5 µg/dL Free T4: 0.8 - 2.0 ng/dL

item.title: DIC
item.description:
A life-threatening hematologic disorder characterized by simultaneous clotting and bleeding due to widespread activation of the coagulation cascade Leads to microvascular thrombosis, ischemia, and organ failure, followed by excessive bleeding due to depletion of clotting factors and platelets usually found in patients who are already in critical condition => DIC worsens their outcomes Can be acute (life-threatening) or chronic (low-grade, seen in cancer patients) DIC = Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation Sepsis (most common cause, especially Gram-negative infections) Severe trauma or burns Obstetric complications (placental abruption, amniotic fluid embolism, preeclampsia) Malignancies (leukemia, metastatic cancer) Major surgery or massive blood transfusion Severe liver disease (liver produces clotting factors) Snake venom poisoning Cyanosis or gangrene (due to microthrombi in extremities) Altered mental status (cerebral ischemia) Acute kidney injury (renal ischemia) Respiratory distress (pulmonary embolism, ARDS) Petechiae, ecchymosis, and purpura bleeding from existing wounds: IV sites, surgical wounds, mucous membranes Hematuria, hematemesis, melena Epistaxis (nosebleeds), gingival bleeding Intracranial hemorrhage (severe cases) MODS
hypovolemic Shock ishcemic limb loss d/t clotting intracranial bleeding => coma, death D-Dimer: elevated, indicates clot Prolonged PT, aPTT, INR Thrombocytopenia - low platelet count Low Fibrinogen - converted into clots Schistocytes (fragmented RBCs) on blood smear Treat cause: abx for sepsis, deliver baby Blood product replacement (if severe): platelets, FFP, cryoprecupitate for fibrinogen replacement
Heparin for chronic DIC => if clotting predominant supportive care: o2, IVF, vasopressors monitor for bleeding and thrombosis
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing

item.title: Shock
item.description:
Shock life-threatening condition that occurs as a result of circulatory failure causes decreased SVR and perfusion leads to tissue hypoxia, cellular death, and organ dysfunction 4 Main Types: Distributive (septic, anaphylactic, neurogenic, toxic) => vasodilation Cardiogenic Hypovolemic Obstructive Common Manifestations: tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, abnormal mental status, mottled skin, cold and clammy extremities, oliguria, hyperlactatemia, and metabolic acidosis Systemic vasodilation results in decreased perfusion the heart, brain, and kidneys => eventually organ damage Capillary fluid leaks into the surrounding tissue causing further clinical deterioration with decreased systemic vascular resistance and abnormal oxygen utilization. decreased CO, hypotension Subtypes: septic, anaphylactic, neurogenic, toxic risk factors: CKD, lots of lines, immunosuppression, recent surgery, old, cancer release of inflammatory cytokines in the presence of sepsis cytokines damage blood vessel walls, triggering clotting and forming tiny clots fluid leaks! Causes: pancreatitis, burns, HAI Treatment: abx within 1 hour, IVF (crystalloid - Salt solutions used for fluid replacement that can easily move around the body), norepi to manage BP Resus: 3-mL/kg first 3 hours of resus severe hypersensitivity reaction that is mediated by IgE results in the release of chemical mediators such as histamines, prostaglandins, leukotrienes increases vascular permeability and subsequent decreased SVR, vasodilation, decreased perfusion to vital organs, and bronchoconstriction Causes: exposure to an allergen (foods, latex, medications, animal venom, insect stings) signature cue: exposure to an allergen such as medication, food, or insect sting Manifestations: flushing, edema of the face and mouth, urticaria, hypotension, hoarseness, facial and oral edema, tachypnea, wheezing or stridor FIRST LINE TX: IM EPI (give first before anything else), keep repeating until symptoms resolve => hold epi in muscle for 10 sec remove cause of allergic rxn, IVF (crystalloids), corticosteroids, antihistamines, albuterol Scenario: if giving abx & patient complains of itchiness and difficulty breathing, do the ff: 1. stop meds, 2. auscultate lungs, 3. epi due to autonomic dysregulation caused by a primary and secondary spinal cord injury above the level of T6, often associated with trauma to the cervical or thoracic vertebrae. Primary injury: damage to axons, grey mater, and the anterior root Secondary injury: causes electrolyte shifts, edema, and a vascular insult that leads to necrosis of the grey matter. Causes: trauma, Guillain-Barre Syndrome, spinal anesthesia Manifestations: brady cardia = unique symptom, flushed and warm skin, autonomic dysreflexia, temperature dysregulation, orthostatic hypotension, and bradyarrhythmias Tx: IV NS ASAP involves infection from Staphylococcus aureus and endotoxins from group A streptococcus often resulting from the use of nasal or vaginal tampons Other causes: burns, soft tissue or post-surgical infections, and dialysis catheters manifestations: hypotension, rash resembling a sunburn, fever, and ultimately organ-failure related to vascular permeability. intravascular volume is decreased, resulting in poor CO result of blood loss or extracellular fluid loss 25-30% loss of volume Hemorrhagic shock - insufficient perfusion of blood inadequate O2 demands => anaerobic metabolism, by-product: lactic acid (leads to lactic acidosis => decreased cardiac contractility) Coagulopathy: impaired coagulation as a result of blood loss Signature cue: flattened neck veins and orthostatic hypotension low central venous pressure (normal is 2-6 mmHg)
risk factors: trauma, Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm, PUD, maternal clients with bleeding risk Nursing intervention: lower HOB (more perfusion to brain and core) Note: infuse NS first before vasopressors (do not infuse vasopressors first!) Put SPO2 on forehead instead of extremities for more accurate Volume Loss Manifestations by % <20% loss - anxiety, restlessness 20-40% loss - tachycardia, tachypnea, oliguria (dec. UOP), and orthostatic hypotension 40%+ loss: hypotension, severe tachycardia, and deteriorating mental statusOther manifestations: muscle cramps, thirst, abdominal or chest pain, lethargy, agitation, or confusion, decreased skin turgor, dry mucous membranes, tachycardia, cyanosisInternal bleeding symptoms: hematemesis, bloody stool, and abdominal distentionHemorrhagic Causes: trauma, rupture of esophageal varices GI bleed, aneurysm rupture, anticoags Non-Hemorrhagic causes: excessive diuresis, burns, GI fluid loss, third spacing (ascites, edema, pleural effusion, interstitial shift)Treatment: determine if hemorrhagic or not ASAP Hemorrhagic: stop the bleed, administer blood products (PRBCs), FFP, plasma, large bor IV Non-hemo: rapid infusion of warm isotonic crystalloids for a total of 30 mL/kgdo not give vasopressors in hypovolemic shock => it can worsen tissue perfusion (if given, infuse NS first) Cardiac dysfunction causes myocardial ischemia => less CO => hypoperfusion Compensatory mechanisms: peripheral vasoconstriction, tachycardia Signature cues: chest pain and cardiac arrhythmias, narrowed pulse pressure, rhonchi, and distended jugular veins with elevated pulsations. Causes: PE, metabolic acidosis, e- imbalance, cardiac nature risk factors: 75 older, asian, pacific islander, female, DM, CVD, sepsis, obese Signature manifestations: chest pain, arrhythmias, narrowed pulse pressure, ronchi, distented JV with pulsations tx: goal is to restore optimal CO; vasopressors (norepi), inotropes (dobutamine, milrinone), IVF, treat cause or mechanical support Positive Inotropic = more forceful beats, Double D's = Digoxin & Dopamine Note: Dopamine can cause Tachycardia and Arrythmias (lower dose if this happens) MCS: mechanical circulatory support. Examples: LVAD, balloon pump (IABP), ECMO, cardiac transplant blood flow is blocked and circulation to the major organs is disrupted examples: pulmonary embolism, tension pneumo, mechanical ventilation with high levels of PEEP other examples: aortic dissection, pericardiac tamponade, pericardiac effusion, mass within heart other Causes: tension pneumo, ventilation high VEEP, PE Risk factors: atherosclerotic disease, uncontrolled HTN, coagulopathies resulting in increased clotting, cancer, AIDS, pulmonary HTN, respiratory diseases or surgeries requiring the use of mechanical ventilation, and thoracic trauma. Sx for Tension pneumo: diminished or absent breath sounds, tracheal deviation, or neck vein distention
sx for Cardiac Tamponade: Beck’s triad (muffled heart sounds, hypotension, increase jugular venous pressure) in addition to experiencing dyspnea.
sx for Pulmonary Embolism: pulsus paradoxus, hemoptysis sx for Pericarditis, p. effusion: pulsus paradoxus sx Aortic Dissection: pulse deficit tx - remove obstruction, vasopressors Pulmonary Embolism: signature sign: hymoptysis, pulsus paradoxus Initial Stage Patho: Cellular hypoxia leads to anaerobic metabolism and lactic acid buildup S/S: Often subtle; possible mild tachycardia and cool extremities Compensatory Stage Patho: Body activates compensatory mechanisms (SNS activation, RAAS system) to maintain perfusion, "FIGHT OR FLIGHT", peripheral vasoconstriction S/S: Tachycardia, increased respiratory rate, cool/clammy skin, decreased urine output, altered mental status. Progressive Stage Patho: Compensatory mechanisms fail, resulting in worsening hypoxia and cellular dysfunction S/S: Hypotension, weak pulses, severe confusion, anuria, metabolic acidosis, cold and clammy skin is priority in this stage Refractory Stage - irreversible Patho: Widespread organ failure with severe hypoxia and cellular death, S/S: Profound hypotension, unresponsive state, multiple organ dysfunction, death imminent Modified Early Warning Score (MEWS) - employed to identify risk of mortality and clinical deterioration based on SBP, RR, HR, mental status, and temperature.Continuous Renal Replacement Therapy (CRRT) A dialysis method used in critically ill patients who are unable to tolerate traditional intermittent hemodialysis. provides continuous, slow filtration of waste products and fluids from the blood. may cause pneumothorax Intra-Aortic Balloon Pump (IABP) ballon inflates during diastole with aortic valve closure causing blood from aorta to flow into circulation better treatment for cardiogenic shock requires informed consent inserted into femoral artery Lactate Levels: elevated indicates hypoxia (normal is 0.5 to 2.0 mmol/L) Monitor BP: must be at least 90 sys, 65 MAP, oliguria (dec. UOP), anuria (no UOP) insert central lines, art lines, etc IVF, PRBC, blood trend HD Manage IV drips: pressors (norepi), inotropes (dobutamine, milrinone) nutrition or TPN abx indwelling urinary catheter
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing

item.title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm
item.description:
dilation of the aorta greater than 30mm if greater than 55mm => large, requires urgent treatment very deadly if it ruptures infrarenal aorta = most common location of AAA Patho: aortic wall weakens; thinning of the media & adventitia with the loss of vascular muscle ATHEROSCLEROSIS - buildup of plaque high BP infection trauma smoking => biggest risk factor other major risks: male, history renal insufficiency Cardiac: HTN, CAD, PAD, Heart Failure COPD recommended screening: abd US, 65-75 yo, smoking hx Geriatric Considerations: polypharmacy, comorbidities, NOTE: DIABETES DECREASES RISK early signs: N/V, satiety, pain: lower back, flank, & groin, audible bruit, pulsating mass (nontender), abdominal pain late signs: intense pain with distention, abdominal distension, Cullen's sign (umbilical), turner sign (flank) 90% mortality related to blood loss abdominal US CT => surgery PET scan - determines size manage BP: maintain SYS 90-120 check VS: as much as possible assess pedal pulses, bruits monitor for mottling => turns into ecchymosis sudden pain Education: stop smoking, low fat, low NA diet, exercise, manage BP, routines of ICU Assess regularly: mass, bruits, abdomen Trending of VS, labs, UOP Insertion of: arterial lines, central lines, foley CBC: shows rupturing - hematocrit is decreased if it ruptured DraW: CMP, coags, blood type 2 large bore IV crentral pressure devices fluids, PRBCs, meds (pressors, inotropes) consent, ADs vitals type & screen for blood turn q2 IS deep breathing clear liquid diet, advance as tolerated ambulation education: follow-up prn, advance activity as tolerated monitor: graft complications Cardiac meds: BP, statin abx Glucose control antiplatelet Lifestyle: exercise, balanced diet repeat CT: 1month, 6 month,12 month EVAR: endovascular aneurysm repair - stent placement; less invasive Open Repair
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing

item.title: SIRS
item.description:
A widespread inflammatory response triggered by infection, trauma, or other severe stressors. Often a precursor to sepsis, Shock, or multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS). Diagnosed when two or more criteria are met cytokine storm - a life-threatening condition characterized by an excessive and uncontrolled release of inflammatory proteins (cytokines) from immune cells SIRS + infection = SEPSIS #1 organ affected: LIVER Liver Failure results in: cerebral edema, blood clotting issues, renal failure Toxic Shock syndrome - biggest source is TAMPONS (if they are in the hospital)SIRS Criteria: must meet two or more Temperature: > 38°C (100.4°F) or < 36°C (96.8°F) Heart rate: > 90 beats per minute Respiratory rate: > 20 breaths per minute (and PaCO2 less than 32 mm Hg) White blood cell count: > 12,000/mL or < 4,000/mL or > 10% bands Terms: Severe Sepsis - one or more organ failures Septic Shock - hemodynamic instability despite volume replenishment acute stress from infections and noninfectious stimuli infections: bacterial, viral, fungal (esp with abx use) trauma/burns
Pancreatitis => huge one major surgery ischemia or tissue injury autoimmune disorders, cancers illicit drugs heart valve abnormalities artificial joints Elderly or immunocompromised individuals Severe injury, burns, or surgery pregnant cirrhosis ABX or corticosteroid use artificial organs: heart valves, joints Prolonged hospitalization or invasive procedures; long ICU stays Malignancy or chronic illness IV Drug use Diabetes - do not notice wounds, do not feel pain with UTI or other infections
Comorbidities: dm, MI, HF, cancer, lung disease, CKD, dialysis Liver Dysfunction => can cause cerebral edema, blood clotting issues, renal failure Altered mental status Hypotension Decreased urine output Sepsis (if caused by infection) Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
MODS
DIC Shock (septic, hypovolemic, or cardiogenic) see SIRS criteria blood cultures => draw before ABX treatment
Coags => because of impaired liver function => impaired Vitamin K synthesis => bleeding issues
LFT UA and culture Sputum culture => basically anything that can indicate microorganism growth ABG/VBG imaging: CXR, CT, MRI, US, ECG lactate levels: assess for tissue hypoxia (ref <2.0 mmol/L) procalcitonin or PCT (elevated in bacterial infections) (ref. below 0.1 ng/mL) treat underlying cause: abx, antiviral, trauma, corrective surgery (incision/drainage) supportive measures (see below) IVF resus (isotonic) => bolus of 30 mL/kg Pressors: norepinephrine => maintain at least 90 mmHg systolic Corticosteroids O2 => maintain 92% or greater SPO2 Control glucose 80-110 mg/dL (or follow facility protocol) antipyretics for fever
main goal: disrupt progression into MODS SIRS patients will require ICU level of treatment
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing

item.title: Cardiac Arrest
item.description:
cessation of heart and respiratory function which results in death death occurs in minutes Ventricular fibrillation => most common cause asystole, PEA CAD & MI that includes unstable lesions, ruptured plaques of atherosclerosis and/or thrombosis. loss of consciousness and loss of pulse and respiration prior to the arrest: heavy chest pain with possible radiation to other areas such as the jaw, abdomen, or back, tachypnea and diaphoresis Post-Cardiac Arrest Syndrome cascade of events including neurologic injury, cardiac, and microcirculatory dysfunctions following ROSC
e.g. ARDs, DIC, adrenal dysfunction, hepatitis, AKI neuro: seizures, coma, or brain death elevated Troponin levels (elevated as soon as 2-3 hr following incident) Reference Cardiac Troponin T: < 0.1 ng/mL Reference Cardiac Troponin I: < 0.03 ng/mL Elevated CK - indicates muscle injury (CK-MB is specific to cardiac muscle) => ref,: CK (total): 20-200 U/L, ​​​​​​​CK-MB: 5–25 IU/L
BNP - elevated indicates Heart Failure, BNP: < 100 ng/L D-Dimer - elevated indicative of clotting; ref: < 500 ng/mL ESR - elevated indicates infarction, infection, inflammation; ref Male: up to 15 mm/hr CAB algorithmGoals: PaCO2 range of 35 to 45 mm Hg SPO2 92-98% maintain >90 mm Hg systolic and > 65 mm Hg diastolicFirst Responder Tasks: Call for help CPR – Initiate compressions to the client Crash cart – Instruct an assistive personnel or other team members to obtain the crash cart “ati_engage_ams_2022_L24_adult_ca_400.svg” could not be found. Cardioversion - performed on clients who have a pulse but are not stable hemodynamically; a low energy, synchronous shock that is delivered at the exact point of the QRS complexDefibrillation - asynchronous shock that is delivered without delayimplantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) - treats VT and VT, for patients with high risk Emergency meds: LEAN (Lidocaine, epi, atropine, narcan)Epinephrine - vasopressor, maintain HR & BP, 1 mg q3-5min Amiodarone - Antiarrhythmic (VFIB, PVT), IV 150mg over 10 min Lidocaine - Antiarrhythmic (ventricular rhythms) Atropine - Antiarrhythmic, increase HR, decrease resp & GI secretions, IV 0.5-1 mg q3-5 (max 2mg)Treatment post-ROSC monitor everything including EEG (for comatose patients) TTM 24 hrs: 32° and 36° C (89.6° and 96.7° F) => minimize brain injury and neuro impairment if comatose Vent support with ETCO monitor EEG blood glucose monitoring Critical Findings (increased risk of arrest) An increase in normal chest pain or unrelenting chest pain, chest pain at rest or chest pain not relieved by nitroglycerine BP 60 mm Hg or less systolic BP greater than 180 mm Hg systolic and/or mm Hg diastolic BP change from lying to standing of greater than 20 mm Hg systolic or 10 mm Hg diastolic Pulse rate greater than 100 bpm or less than 60 bpm Pulse deficit Presence of crackles in lungs bilaterally Diminished or absent peripheral pulses Chest pain - 12 lead, check cardiac enzymes, prepare for catherization BP<60 sys - central line monitor, 12-lead ecg, portable x-ray, CMP, chem, vasopressors Pulse deficit/arrhythmias - 12 lead, e-, thyroid function blood test, cardiovert Lung Crackles - 12 lead, BNP, e-, chem Pulse > 100 bpm or < 60 bpm - e-, assess confusion or restlessness
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing

item.title: MODS
item.description:
A progressive, life-threatening condition where two or more organ systems fail due to an uncontrolled systemic inflammatory response reversible but deadly => higher # of organs affected = higher chance of death leads to longer ICU stay, higher mortality Often results from sepsis, trauma, burns, or severe illness, leading to widespread tissue hypoxia and organ failure. Can be primary (direct organ injury) or secondary (resulting from systemic inflammation and shock). Sepsis & septic shock: Most common cause due to overwhelming infection. Severe trauma: Major burns, crush injuries, or hemorrhagic shock. Pancreatitis: Triggers systemic inflammation. Major surgery: Postoperative complications and ischemia-reperfusion injury. Respiratory failure (ARDS): Leads to oxygen deprivation affecting multiple organs. Toxic drug reactions: Overdose or chemotherapy-induced toxicity. Advanced age: Poor physiologic reserve. Chronic illnesses: Diabetes, chronic kidney disease, heart failure. Immunosuppression: Cancer, chemotherapy, organ transplantation. Prolonged ICU stay: Mechanical ventilation, multiple invasive devices. Severe hypotension: Prolonged shock states leading to ischemia. Respiratory failure: ARDS, hypoxia, need for mechanical ventilation. Cardiovascular dysfunction: Hypotension, tachycardia, poor perfusion. Renal failure: Oliguria, increased creatinine, electrolyte imbalances. Hepatic dysfunction: Jaundice, elevated liver enzymes, coagulopathy. Neurological changes: Confusion, agitation, decreased LOC, coma. Metabolic derangements: Lactic acidosis, hyperglycemia, electrolyte disturbances. Coagulopathy: Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), increased bleeding risk Severe hypotension & shock: Progresses to cardiovascular collapse. Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC): Widespread clotting and bleeding. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): Worsening hypoxia and ventilatory failure.
Acute kidney injury (AKI): Requires dialysis in severe cases. Liver failure: Increased ammonia, encephalopathy, coagulopathy. Death: MODS has a high mortality rate, especially if more than three organs are involved SOFA Scoring (sequential organ failure assessment) = assess risk morality related to MODS Elevated lactate levels (tissue hypoxia). Coagulation tests (DIC screening). Renal function tests (BUN, creatinine). Liver enzymes (AST, ALT, bilirubin). Arterial blood gases (ABGs) (hypoxia, acidosis) CTI, MRI, US Supportive care & organ support Mechanical vent Vasopressors (Norepinephrine, dopamine)
Dialysis for AKI Sepsis Management: abx, IVF, blood products Nutritional Support: enteral or parenteral nutrition Monitor for early signs of organ failure (urine output, oxygenation, mental status). Maintain hemodynamic stability: Monitor BP, HR, CVP, and fluid balance. Assess for infection: Frequent cultures, temperature monitoring. Manage mechanical ventilation: Prevent ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). Prevent complications: DVT prophylaxis, repositioning to prevent pressure ulcers. Provide emotional support: For patient and family regarding prognosis and treatment decisions Early recognition of MODS to prevent progression. Maintain adequate oxygenation and perfusion. Prevent & treat infections aggressively. Support failing organ systems with appropriate interventions. Coordinate multidisciplinary care for comprehensive treatment. Educate family members on prognosis and treatment options.
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing

item.title: Hemodynamic Monitoring
item.description: insertion of catheter in peripheral art (usually radial, femoral, brachial), see trends or abrupt changes in BP, frequent lab draws transducer must be positioned at the level of the midaxillary line at the level of the right atrium when lying in bed too low: high pressure, too high - low pressure => all wrong manual blood pressures can be unsafe due to sudden hemodynamic changes catheter is inserted through the brachial, antecubital, jugular, or femoral vein to connect with the right side of the heart and then proceed to the pulmonary artery for patients who have cardiogenic shock, pulmonary hypertension, and unexplained dyspnea Pulmonary Capillary Wedge Pressure (PCWP) - measure of the pressure in the small blood vessels (capillaries) that lie between the lungs and the left atrium. Reflects left atrial pressure and left ventricular end-diastolic pressure (LVEDP); indicates left heart function and fluid status. Normal Range: 6-12 mmHg. Normal Range: 6-12 mmHg pressure in the superior vena cava or right atrium; reflects right ventricular preload and fluid status. Normal Range: 8 and 12 mm Hg. central venous access device (CVAP), generally inserted in the internal jugular or subclavian vein and advanced into the superior vena cava at the entrance to the right atrium. Decreases in CVP can be an indication of hypovolemia, blood loss greater than 10%, dilation of the vena cava, or a decrease in intrathoracic pressure Elevations in CVP can indicate decreased cardiac contractility, dysrhythmias, or abnormal functioning of the cardiac valves, all of which may indicate heart failure #medsurg #criticalcare #nursing

item.title: Cardiac Surgeries
item.description:
A surgical intervention that uses a graft vessel to bypass obstructed vessels in the coronary arteries obstruction usually caused by constricted or clogged due to plaque donor vein from leg (saphenous vein or artery in chest (internal mamary), radial artery cardiobypass machine used while heart is stopped Off-pump CABg - option to keep heart beating rather than using bypass machine during surgery usually required by patients with CAD & MI Mitral Valve Regurgitation - MR blood flow is reversed from LV to LA, usually during systolic aka mitral valve insufficiency
causes: Endocarditis Aortic Regurgitation - AR inadequate closure of aorrtic valve during diastole leads to back flow of blood through aortic valve
causes: calcified aortic valve disease, tear or laceration, Endocarditis Aortic Stenosis - AS common valve disorder that causes LV obstruction through valve stenosis and calcification increases valve LV systolic pressure, leading to increase in LV ejection time, ultimate leading to decreased aortic pressure leads to LV hypertrophy, dysfunction, and failure
causes: congenital or d/t rheumatic valve disease, Lupus, METS, ESRD Common manifestations: fluid retention => rapid weight gain edema of abdomen, ankles, feet palpitations SOB, chest pain dizziness
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing

item.title: EKG
item.description: #nursing #medsurg #cardiovascular #ekg P Wave: Represents atrial depolarization; should be upright and precede each QRS. PR Interval: Time from atrial depolarization to ventricular depolarization (normal: 0.12–0.20 seconds). QRS Complex: Represents ventricular depolarization; normal duration <0.12 seconds. T Wave: Represents ventricular repolarization; upright in most leads. ST Segment: Should be isoelectric; elevation or depression indicates ischemia or injury. QT Interval: Represents total ventricular activity (depolarization + repolarization); prolonged QT may indicate risk for arrhythmias. Strip Timing small square - .04 second large square (5 smalls) = .20 seconds 1 strip = 6 seconds (that means multiply QRS's by 10 = heart rate per minute) ECG Description: Regular rhythm, rate <60 bpm, normal P wave before each QRS. Causes: Athletes, medications (beta-blockers, digoxin), hypothyroidism, vagal stimulation. Clinical Presentation: Dizziness, fatigue, syncope, or asymptomatic. Treatment: None if asymptomatic, atropine or pacing if symptomatic. ECG Description: Regular rhythm, rate >100 bpm, normal P wave before each QRS. Causes: Fever, anxiety, pain, dehydration, anemia, hyperthyroidism. Clinical Presentation: Palpitations, dyspnea, dizziness, or asymptomatic. Treatment: Treat underlying cause (e.g., fluids for dehydration, antipyretics for fever). Mnemonic/Description: A heartbeat that starts in the wrong part of the heart, causing a random extra thud. Rate: Depends on underlying rhythm. Rhythm: Irregular. P Wave: present with every QRS except it is absent with PVC. PR Interval: Not measurable for PVC. QRS Complex: >0.12 seconds (wide). Causes: Electrolyte imbalance, ischemia, stimulants. Clinical Presentation: Palpitations or asymptomatic. Treatment: Treat cause, beta-blockers if frequent. Mnemonic/Description: Early P wave, normal QRS, An early, out-of-sync beat from the top chambers of the heart Rate: Depends on underlying rhythm. Rhythm: Irregular due to premature beat. P Wave: Abnormal shape, early. PR Interval: Normal or shortened. QRS Complex: <0.12 seconds. Causes: Stress, caffeine, electrolyte imbalance. Clinical Presentation: Palpitations or asymptomatic. Treatment: Avoid triggers, rarely needed. Mnemonic/Description: Prolonged PR interval. Rate: Usually normal. Rhythm: Regular. P Wave: Normal, one per QRS. PR Interval: >0.20 seconds (prolonged). QRS Complex: <0.12 seconds. Causes: Aging, medications (beta-blockers, digoxin). Clinical Presentation: Asymptomatic. Treatment: None unless symptomatic. Mnemonic/Description: Irregularly irregular, no P waves. atria quiver instead of contracting effectively, causing irregular heartbeats and impaired blood flow Rate: Variable (ventricular rate). Rhythm: Irregularly irregular. P Wave: Absent, fibrillatory waves. PR Interval: Not measurable. QRS Complex: <0.12 seconds. Causes: Hypertension, coronary artery disease, valvular heart disease, heart failure, hyperthyroidism, alcohol use, obesity, sleep apnea, post-surgery, or idiopathic Clinical Presentation: Cardiac: Irregular pulse, palpitations, pulse deficit (apical vs peripheral pulse are different), chest pain General: fatigue, dizziness, shortness of breath Can be asymptomatic. Risk of thromboembolism (e.g., stroke) due to blood stasis in atria. Treatment: Rate Control - beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, digoxin Rhythm Control - antiarrhythmic drugs, cardioversion Anticoagulation - warfarin, DOACS (apixaban, etc) Interventional - ablation, pacemaker “AdobeStock_385717687-1.webp” could not be found. Mnemonic/Description: Sawtooth flutter waves. Rate: Atrial 250-350 bpm; ventricular varies. Rhythm: Regular or irregular. P Wave: Sawtooth appearance. PR Interval: Not measurable. QRS Complex: <0.12 seconds. Causes: Similar to AFib (hypertension, CAD). Clinical Presentation: Palpitations, fatigue. Treatment: Rate control, cardioversion, anticoagulation. Mnemonic/Description: Narrow, rapid QRS, hidden P waves. Rate: >150 bpm. Rhythm: Regular. P Wave: Often hidden in QRS. PR Interval: Not measurable. QRS Complex: <0.12 seconds. Causes: Re-entry circuits, stress, stimulants. Clinical Presentation: Palpitations, dizziness, chest discomfort. Treatment: Vagal maneuvers, adenosine, beta-blockers, cardioversion if unstable.

item.title: PCT
item.description: What is it: A precursor of calcitonin released in response to bacterial infections; useful for detecting systemic inflammation and sepsis. Normal Range: <0.1 ng/mL (may vary slightly by lab). Out of Normal: 0.1 - 0.5 ng/mL: Possible mild infection or inflammation. 0.5 - 2 ng/mL: Suggestive of localized infection; increased risk of sepsis. >2 ng/mL: Strongly indicates systemic bacterial infection or sepsis; higher levels correlate with severe infection and poor prognosis.

item.title: Lactate Levels
item.description: What is it: Byproduct of anaerobic metabolism produced when oxygen delivery to tissues is insufficient; elevated levels indicate hypoxia or impaired cellular respiration. Normal Range: 0.5 - 2.2 mmol/L (may vary slightly by lab). Out of Normal: Mild Elevation (2.2 - 4 mmol/L): Possible early tissue hypoxia, sepsis, or shock. Severe Elevation (>4 mmol/L): Suggests significant hypoxia, sepsis, organ dysfunction, or metabolic crisis; often linked to poor prognosis.

item.title: Hemothorax
item.description: What is it? collection of blood in pleural space: between visceral and parietal pleura often associated with traumatic thoracic injuries from blunt or penetrating injury life-threatening due to hemodynamic and respiratory compromise blood limits airway functioning, increases vascular resistance = leads to cardiac arrest, death Clinical Presentation similar to pneumothorax respiratory distress, tachycardia, tachypnea, decreased or absent breath sounds, dull percussion asymmetrical chest movement, hypoxia, hypotension JVD - late sign, but maybe absent in hemothorax subcutaneous emphysema Treatment tube thoracostomy (aka "chest tube") semi-fowler analgesia and O2 splinting Nursing Considerations & Interventions educate on seat belt, driving impairment, road safety note that SPO2 of aging adult is usually 93-94% encourage early mobility prevent anxiety Complications & Other Systemic Effects usually accompanied by chest wall injury, rib fx, flail chest, cardiovascular injury hypoxia and hypecapnia Causes motor vehicle collision - most common cause blunt chest trauma less common: iatrogenic, vascular, infectious diseases, spontaneous iatrogenic: anticoagulation treatment for pulmonary emboli with warfarin, thoracentesis, CVC most common: chest tube insertion all involve: major arteries: intercostal arteries and aorta Risk Factors comorbidities: congenital diseases (hemophilia, thrombocytopenia) Diagnosis CXR - 1st line tool ultrasound or FAST ECG ABG CBC - HGB

item.title: Pericarditis - ati
item.description: Inflammation of the pericardium, the sac surrounding the heart Can be acute (sudden onset) or chronic (lasting more than three months) Leads to chest pain, pericardial effusion, and possible cardiac tamponade if untreated Infections (viral, bacterial, fungal, tuberculosis) Post-myocardial infarction (Dressler’s syndrome) Autoimmune diseases (lupus, rheumatoid arthritis) Uremia (kidney failure-related pericarditis) Cancer (metastatic spread to pericardium) Chest trauma or post-cardiac surgery Radiation therapy to the chest Medications (hydralazine, procainamide, isoniazid) Recent viral infection (e.g., influenza, HIV, Coxsackievirus) History of heart attack or cardiac surgery Chronic kidney disease or dialysis Autoimmune conditions Malignancy with metastasis to the heart Tuberculosis exposure Sharp, pleuritic chest pain (worse with deep breathing, relieved by sitting up and leaning forward) Pericardial friction rub (high-pitched, scratchy sound over the left sternal border) Fever and chills if infection is present Dyspnea due to pain and pericardial effusion Tachycardia from cardiac stress Beck’s Triad (if cardiac tamponade develops): hypotension, muffled heart sounds, jugular venous distension (JVD) Pericardial effusion (fluid buildup in the pericardial sac) Cardiac tamponade (life-threatening compression of the heart) Constrictive pericarditis (chronic scarring and thickening of the pericardium, restricting heart movement) Electrocardiogram (ECG) – ST-segment elevation in multiple leads, PR depression Echocardiogram – Detects pericardial effusion and heart compression Chest X-ray – Enlarged cardiac silhouette (if effusion is large) Cardiac biomarkers (troponins, CK-MB) – Normal or mildly elevated (rules out myocardial infarction) Inflammatory markers – Elevated ESR, CRP, leukocytosis Pericardiocentesis (if effusion is suspected) – Fluid analysis for infection or malignancy NSAIDs (ibuprofen, aspirin, indomethacin) for inflammation and pain Colchicine to prevent recurrence Corticosteroids (prednisone) for autoimmune or refractory cases Antibiotics or antifungals if infectious cause suspected Dialysis if uremic pericarditis is present Pericardiocentesis for large pericardial effusions or tamponade Pericardiectomy (surgical removal of the pericardium) for chronic constrictive pericarditis Monitor for signs of cardiac tamponade (hypotension, muffled heart sounds, JVD, pulsus paradoxus) Position patient upright and leaning forward to relieve pain Administer prescribed anti-inflammatory medications and monitor for side effects Assess for worsening dyspnea, tachycardia, or hypotension (signs of pericardial effusion) Monitor ECG for ST-segment changes and dysrhythmias Educate patient on medication adherence and recurrence prevention Recognize and manage acute pericarditis early to prevent complications Monitor for and intervene in cardiac tamponade Ensure adequate pain management to promote comfort Educate on lifestyle modifications and follow-up care

item.title: Incontinence
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary involuntary loss of urine Types: Stress - caused by weakness of the urethral sphincter or the pelvic floor muscles, involuntarily urine leakage with sneezing, coughing, or physical exertion. Urge - detrusor muscle overactivity that causes bladder contraction, or; loss of neurologic control or by irritation of the bladder.
Overflow - urine leakage of an overdistended bladder, which is caused by a bladder obstruction that blocks urine excretion or impaired contractility of the detrusor muscle. Bladder obstruction causes of the distended bladder include pelvic organ prolapse, abdominal or pelvic masses, or BPH.
Iatrogenic - caused by medical treatments or interventions like Diuretics, sedatives, surgeries that affect bladder function Mixed - combination of urge and stress usually temporary; usually d/t food irritants: alcohol, spicy, sugary, caffeine, carbonated. Meds: diuretics, BP meds, Doxazosin (cardura), antidepressantsm CCB, ACEi coughing - stress incontinence
Heart Failure - fluid overload Neurologic conditions: MS MSK disorders, mobility issues stress test: cough Check for UTI: UA bladder scan to check post-void residual volume (result of greater than 200mL = overflow incontinence) Urinary antispasmodics, such as oxybutynin (Ditropan XL) bladder relaxants, such as Mirabegron (myrbetriq) Bladder Training - urinating at set time intervals Pelvic Floor Muscle Training - kegels
Catheters - use judiciously to minimize UTI, can help avoid skin breakdown Alternative urine collection: condom cath, purewick falls precautions

item.title: Glomerulonephritis
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary inflammation of the glomeruli, impairs kidney function => more waste in blood steam, e- imbalance, loss of blood RBC and protein can be acute or chronic results in proteinuria, azotemia, hematuria proteinuria => elevated cholesterol, HTN, edema severity is classified based on proteinuria of greater than 3.5g/day and edema Azotemia - elevated N2 waste products such as urea and creatinineAcute - primary renal cause or by an illness that impairs renal function
Chronic - progressive, leads to ESRD streptococcal infection - most common; usually after a strep throat (Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus) Endocarditis - also linked to gn (watch out for cardiac valve replacement) Autoimmune diseases (Lupus, IgA nephropathy, Goodpasture’s syndrome) Vasculitis (Wegener’s granulomatosis, polyarteritis nodosa) Diabetes mellitus (Diabetic nephropathy leading to glomerular damage) Bacterial endocarditis, viral infections (Hepatitis B, C, HIV) see causes family history of kidney disease Drug toxicity: NSAID, abx, illegal drugs periorbital edema: hallmark symptom decreased eGFR (normal is greater than 60/ml/min) dark and frothy urine decreased UOP elevated BP - from fluid overload and RAAS activation infection: fever, malaise, weakness abdominal discomfort
CKD that can lead to ESRD Acute Kidney Injury Nephrotic Syndrome - severe protein loss, high cholesterol, edema
Pulmonary edema, Heart Failure, due to fluid overload Hypertensive crisis from uncontrolled BP
CMP - check e-, elevated K, BUN, creatinine GFR: down UA: RBC, WBC, protein, casts => indicates glomerular damage Kidney Biopsy CXR: pulmonary edema US
goal: manage cause, avoid CKD and ESRD Corticosteroids: prednisone for anti-inflammation and immune suppression Abx if caused by stre[ Diuretics: manage edema ACEi/ARBs - control BP, reduce proteinuria
Dialysis: for AKI or ESRD Diet restriction: low Na, K, protein, fluid restriction #1 Priority: manage BP as this can lead to further kidney damage Second level priority: decreased UOP salt restriction more severe: Na, K, protein restriction to slow progression Lifestyle: smoking, DM, HTN

item.title: Cerebral Aneurysms
item.description:
weakening or bulging area in the wall of a cerebral artery typically asymptomatic but can rupture causing life-threatening subarachnoid hemorrhage commonly located at arterial bifurcations in the Circle of Willis most aneurysms do not rupture hypertension => increased vessel wall stress Atherosclerosis (weakens vessel walls) Congenital arterial defects (e.g. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)) Head trauma Infections (mycotic aneurysms) Connective tissue disorders (Ehlers-Danlos, Marfan syndrome) family hx smoking - damaged blood vessels alcohol or drug abuse age >40 sudden severe headache Stroke presentation N/V visual disturbances stiff neck confusion seizure LOC Cardiac Arrest Death Unruptured CA: sometimes none, double vision, pain behind eye, dilated pupil, numbness on one side of face Cerebral Angiogram - gold standard; small catheter is inserted in vessel in leg all the way to brain, guided by x-ray MRI, CT, CTA Lumbar Puncture - presence of blood in CSF (+) ruptured: need surgical intervention ASAP, life-threatening unruptured or no manifestations: no treatment required, monitor unruptured but large and symptomatic: surgical intervention or endovascular therapy surgical clipping - metal clip punches the aneurysm Endovascular therapy: stent or mesh barrier is inserted to induce a clot, diverting blood from aneurysm Monitor neurological status (LOC, pupils, motor function) Maintain BP within target range (avoid hypotension/hypertension) Keep HOB elevated 30 degrees to reduce ICP Minimize stimulation (quiet environment, limit visitors) Implement seizure precautions Educate on lifestyle modifications (BP control, smoking cessation, avoiding stimulants)
#nursing #medsurg #neuro

item.title: Stroke
item.description:
sudden loss of brain function due to interrupted blood flow causing neuro dysfunction brain cells experience hypoxia (unlike TIA where it is temporary) can cause lifelong disability or death Ischemic - sudden loss of circulation; embolism or plaques block brain arteries (carioembolic = embolism from heart)
Hemorrhagic - blood vessel in brain ruptures (Cerebral Aneurysms) causing increased pressure, increased ICP = decreased brain blood flow => cerebral ischemia HTN - most common; increased pressure can cause vessels to rupture leading to hemorrhagic stroke diabetes - most common severe OSA heart valve disease MI Aneurysm smoking, vaping sedentary oral contraceptives, coagulopathies, migraines, trauma, drug use Right Hemisphere Stroke - left side paralysis and sensory loss, right visual field loss, aphasia (look straight, but move opposite) Left Hemisphere Stroke - r side paralysis and sensory loss, L visual field loss BE FAST B - loss of balance, dizziness E - vision loss in one or both eyes F - facial drooping, uneven symmetry (Hemiplegia) A - arms weak, numbness S - slurred speech T - call 911 immediately Hemorrhagic stroke: headache (classic tell-tale sign of hemorrhagic vs ischemic), N/V, seizures Other Effects: Aphasia {Expressive = you say words you don't intend to say, Receptive = cannot understand words} Hemiplegia - paralysis or weakness on one side of body Hemiparesis - paralysis of one side of body Hemianopsia - loss of vision in half of visual field Ataxia - poor muscle control causing clumsy movements Dysarthria - difficulty speaking Dysphagia - difficulty swallowing
Increased ICP falls depression UTI pneumonia
r/o glucose or e- imbalance! (similar manifestations with stroke/TIA)
CBC, Coags => r/o hypercoagulability Fibrinolysis & aspirin - if embolic (alteplase) => monitor for bleeding, angioedema
Respiratory - supplemental O2; intubation d/t to increased ICP and compression of brainstem Antiepileptics Physical Therapy - mobility, strength Occupational Therapy - ADLs, regain independence Speech Therapy - swallowing thrombectomy - blood clot (thrombus) is removed from a blood vessel. decompressive hemicraniectomy (partial removal of skull to relieve ICP) reversal agent for anticoagulants (if applicable)
Osmotic Diuretics d/t increased ICP
Respiratory - supplemental O2; intubation d/t to increased ICP and compression of brainstem Antiepileptics Physical Therapy - mobility, strength Occupational Therapy - ADLs, regain independence Speech Therapy - swallowing evaluate swallowing ability for choking or aspiration risk falls risk
bleeding precautions in patients receiving thrombolytics or Anticoagulants, Antiplatelets
#nursing #medsurg #neuro

item.title: GCS
item.description: EYES for the eye test VOICE for the verbal test OLD BEN for the motor test Mild TBI (13-15): Possible concussion, brief loss of consciousness, confusion, or headache. Moderate TBI (9-12): More significant injury with possible prolonged confusion and neurological deficits. Severe TBI (≤8): High risk of mortality or long-term disability; often requires intubation and intensive care.

item.title: Osteoporosis
item.description: chronic metabolic bone disorder resulting low bone density the rate of bone resorption (osteoclast cells) exceeds the rate of bone formation (osteoblast cells) results in fragile bone tissue and can lead to fractures progressive deterioration of bone tissue Often asymptomatic until a fracture occurs (common fracture site: wrist, hips, spine) Osteopenia - precursor to osteoporosis; low bone mineral density relative to the client’s age and sex; bone density peaks at 18-30, decreases gradually, significant decrease in postmenopausal women Aging (natural loss of bone mass over time) Hormonal changes (especially estrogen deficiency in postmenopausal women) Males: loss of testosterone => decreased bone mass Nutritional deficiencies (calcium, vitamin D) Non-Modifiable: Female sex (higher risk than males) Aging (risk increases after 50) Family history of osteoporosis or fractures Caucasian or Asian ethnicity History of malabsorption disorders (celiac disease, anorexia, bariatric surgery) male with decreased T levels Modifiable: Low calcium and vitamin D intake Sedentary lifestyle (lack of weight-bearing exercise) Excess alcohol (decreased bone formation and increased bone absorption) Excess Caffeine consumption => increased excretion of calcium in the urine. Smoking (reduces bone mass) Long-term corticosteroid use (e.g., prednisone) Low body weight or eating disorders High protein or low protein diet frequent sodas or carbonated drinks - High phosphorus intake increases the rate of calcium loss Often asymptomatic until a fracture occurs Loss of height over time (due to vertebral compression fractures) Kyphosis (hunched back, "dowager’s hump") Back pain from vertebral fractures Fragility fractures (hip, wrist, vertebrae) from minimal trauma Fractures (hip, spine, and wrist most common) Chronic pain and disability from fractures Loss of independence (due to mobility issues) Increased mortality (hip fractures linked to higher mortality rates) Bone Mineral Density (BMD) Testing (via DEXA scan); T-score ≤ -2.5 confirms osteoporosis Serum calcium, vitamin D levels (to assess deficiencies) X-rays (for fractures) 24 hr urine = check Lifestyle Modifications: Increase calcium intake (1200 mg/day postmenopausal women) Vitamin D supplements (800-1000 IU/day) => increases calcium absorption Weight-bearing exercises (walking, resistance training) Smoking cessation & limiting alcohol intake limit caffeine Medications: Bisphosphonates (first-line): Alendronate, risedronate, zoledronic acid (inhibit bone resorption) => take before breakfast with 8oz water, remain upright for 30 min Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulators (SERMs) (e.g., raloxifene) => replace estrogen due to menopause (note: high risk of breast, endo cancer, DVT) Denosumab (monoclonal antibody) for high-risk patients Calcitonin (less commonly used) Parathyroid hormone analogs (teriparatide) (stimulates bone formation) Orthotic Devices - immobilization of the spine immediately after a compression fracture of the spine Surgery: joint repair, vertebroplasty, kyphoplasty Educate on fall prevention (home safety modifications, proper footwear, clear walkways, adequate lighting, etc) Encourage weight-bearing and resistance exercises Monitor for signs of fractures (sudden pain, loss of function) Ensure adequate calcium and vitamin D intake Teach correct administration of bisphosphonates (take on an empty stomach with water, stay upright for 30-60 min) Foods rich in vitamin D are most fish, egg yolks, fortified milk, and cereal. Foods rich in calcium are milk products, green leafy vegetables, fortified orange juice and cereals, red and white beans, and figs. Some soy and rice products are fortified with vitamin D and calcium. Risk for injury related to fragile bones Impaired physical mobility due to pain or fractures Chronic pain related to vertebral fractures Deficient knowledge related to disease management and prevention

item.title: Peritonitis
item.description:
Inflammation of the peritoneum, often due to infection, perforation, or trauma, leading to potential sepsis if untreated medical emergency! peritoneum - thin, serous membrane that lines the abdominal cavity and covers most of the abdominal organsBased on two types: Spontaneous - no identifiable source, complication of liver failure or AKI/CKD Secondary - caused by perforation, internal bleeding, etc Portal hypertension - cirrhosis of liver causes blood obstruction in liver => fluid buildup in abdoment (ascites) => peritonitis
Cirrhosis
Ulcerative Colitis (Irritable Bowel Diseases)
Bowel perforation (Gastric Ulcers, Diverticulitis, appendicitis, Bowel Obstruction)
Peritoneal Dialysis Abdominal trauma Surgical complications Infection spreading from intra-abdominal organs Abdominal surgery Perforated peptic ulcer Diverticulitis Ruptured appendix Peritoneal dialysis Cirrhosis with ascites Immunosuppression Severe abdominal pain (worse with movement) Rigid, board-like abdomen (because of fluid-filled belly) Rebound tenderness Fever Tachycardia Hypotension Nausea, vomiting Decreased bowel sounds Possible signs of sepsis (altered mental status, respiratory distress) cloudy dialysis fluid (if on peritoneal dialysis) Septicemia - spread of bacteria and toxins in blood stream Sepsis - body's systemic response to an infection; leading cause of death from peritonitis Clinical assessment (rigid abdomen, rebound tenderness)
CMP - elevated CK, BUN (d/t ) CBC (leukocytosis) Blood cultures Abdominal X-ray (check for free air from perforation) CT scan (source of infection) Peritoneal fluid analysis (bacteria, WBCs) => abdominal tap or paracentesis IV antibiotics Fluid resuscitation NG tube for decompression PRN Pain management Surgery for perforation or abscess drainage Peritoneal lavage if severe infection NPO, progress accordingly Avoid gas producing foods: carbonated Avoid Irritating foods: spicy, high-fat Once recovered: high protein/high calorie diet to support recovery, high fiber meals Monitor vital signs for sepsis (fever, tachycardia, hypotension) Assess for worsening pain or rigidity Maintain NPO status Administer IV fluids and antibiotics Manage NG tube if present Provide pain relief Prepare for possible surgical intervention Educate on infection prevention and post-op care

item.title: Osmotic Diuretics
item.description: Osmotic diuretics increase urine output by drawing water into renal tubules Primarily used for conditions requiring rapid fluid reduction Do not significantly affect electrolyte balance compared to other diuretics Increased intracranial pressure (ICP) Increased intraocular pressure (IOP) (e.g., glaucoma) Acute renal failure (to prevent tubular necrosis) Drug toxicity (enhances renal excretion) Increases plasma osmolality, pulling water from tissues into bloodstream Freely filtered in glomerulus, not reabsorbed, increasing urine volume Reduces cerebral edema and intraocular pressure by shifting fluid Mannitol (most commonly used osmotic diuretic) Fluid and electrolyte imbalances Dehydration, hypotension Pulmonary edema (fluid shift into vasculature) Headache, nausea, vomiting Active intracranial hemorrhage (risk of worsening bleeding) Severe dehydration or hypovolemia Pulmonary edema or heart failure Anuria (ineffective if kidneys cannot produce urine) Hypernatremia Monitor fluid status, urine output, and electrolytes Assess for signs of dehydration (dry mucous membranes, hypotension) Use filter when administering mannitol (crystallization risk) Monitor neurological status in ICP patients Avoid use in heart failure due to risk of pulmonary edema

item.title: Aspiration Risk
item.description: Assessment: Evaluate swallowing ability using bedside swallow screening, noting coughing, drooling, or difficulty managing secretions. Diet Modification: Implement NPO status if aspiration risk is high, then progress to appropriate texture-modified diets (e.g., pureed, mechanical soft) and thickened liquids as ordered. no thin liquids Positioning: Keep the patient upright at 90° during meals and for 30-60 minutes after eating to reduce aspiration risk. Swallowing Techniques: Encourage chin tuck, small bites, slow chewing, and alternate solids with liquids to aid swallowing. Aspiration Precautions: Monitor for coughing, wet voice, increased secretions, or respiratory distress, and implement suctioning if needed. Oral Care: Provide frequent oral hygiene to reduce bacterial aspiration pneumonia risk. Collaboration: Work with speech-language pathology (SLP) for swallowing therapy and further evaluation. Enteral Nutrition Consideration: If oral intake is unsafe, initiate NG or PEG tube feeding per provider order.

item.title: Neutropenic Precautions
item.description:
Infection prevention measures for patients with low neutrophil counts (neutropenia) Neutropenia: Absolute Neutrophil Count (ANC) <1,500 cells/mm³, with severe neutropenia at <500 cells/mm³ Common in chemotherapy patients, bone marrow transplant recipients, and immunocompromised individuals WBC Reference Ranges: 4,000–11,000 cells/µL Cancer treatments (chemotherapy, radiation) Bone marrow suppression (leukemia, lymphoma, aplastic anemia) Autoimmune disorders (Lupus, Rheumatoid Arthritis)
Severe infections (HIV-AIDS, sepsis) Certain medications (immunosuppressants, corticosteroids) Congenital neutropenia (rare genetic conditions) Prolonged hospitalization (increased exposure to infections) Invasive procedures (IV lines, catheters, surgeries) Poor nutrition (malnutrition weakens the immune system) Age (older adults and infants have weaker immune responses) Chronic illnesses (diabetes, kidney disease) Hand hygiene: Frequent and proper handwashing for patients, visitors, and staff Protective isolation: Private room with HEPA filtration if severe neutropenia No fresh flowers, plants, or standing water (reduce exposure to mold and bacteria) No raw or undercooked foods (risk of bacterial contamination) Limit visitors: Avoid sick individuals, ensure visitors follow hygiene protocols Strict aseptic technique for IV lines, catheters, and dressings Daily assessment for infection signs (fever, chills, redness, swelling) Avoid invasive procedures if possible (IM injections, rectal exams, urinary catheters) Encourage good oral hygiene (soft toothbrush, avoid flossing if thrombocytopenic) Sepsis (life-threatening infection) Pneumonia Opportunistic infections (fungal, viral, bacterial) Mucositis (oral ulcers, GI inflammation) Complete Blood Count (CBC) with differential (low neutrophil count) Blood cultures, urine cultures (to detect infections) Chest X-ray (to check for pneumonia) Broad-spectrum antibiotics (immediately for fever) Colony-stimulating factors (filgrastim, pegfilgrastim) to stimulate neutrophil production Antifungal or antiviral medications (if infection suspected) IV fluids and supportive care Monitor temperature closely (report fever ≥100.4°F (38°C) immediately) Assess for infection symptoms (may be subtle in neutropenic patients) Educate patients on infection prevention at home (avoid crowds, wear a mask, maintain hygiene) Encourage adequate hydration and nutrition Monitor CBC results to track neutrophil recovery Risk for infection related to neutropenia Impaired oral mucous membrane related to chemotherapy-induced mucositis Risk for imbalanced nutrition due to dietary restrictions and mucosal damage Fear/anxiety related to risk of infection and isolation

item.title: CBC
item.description:
Fluid Electrolyte Cheat Sheets
#nursing

item.title: Antiplatelets
item.description:
Note Difference between anticoags vs antiplatelets Anticoagulants - interfere with clotting cascade
Antiplatelets - inhibit activation of platelets Prevent platelet aggregation to reduce clot formation Used for stroke, myocardial infarction (MI) prevention, peripheral artery disease (PAD), and after stent placement Do not dissolve existing clots but prevent new ones from forming Inhibit platelet activation and aggregation by blocking specific pathways Common targets: thromboxane A₂, ADP receptors, or glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptors Aspirin – Irreversibly inhibits COX-1 and COX-2, reducing thromboxane A₂ production Clopidogrel (Plavix) – Blocks P2Y₁₂ ADP receptors on platelets, preventing aggregation Ticagrelor (Brilinta) – Reversible P2Y₁₂ ADP receptor blocker, faster onset than clopidogrel Abciximab, Eptifibatide, Tirofiban – Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors, used in acute coronary syndromes Bleeding (GI bleeding, intracranial hemorrhage) Bruising, easy bleeding (nosebleeds, prolonged bleeding from cuts) Gastrointestinal irritation, ulcers (aspirin) Thrombocytopenia (rare but serious) Active bleeding disorders (e.g., GI ulcers, hemorrhagic stroke) Severe liver disease Aspirin allergy (especially in asthma patients) Recent surgery (risk of excessive bleeding) Pregnancy (some agents contraindicated, especially in the third trimester) Monitor for signs of bleeding (bruising, black stools, hematuria) Educate on avoiding NSAIDs and alcohol (increases bleeding risk) Assess platelet count and coagulation labs if prolonged therapy Encourage adherence, especially post-stroke or post-MI Advise patients to inform healthcare providers before surgery or dental procedures

item.title: Peripheral Neuropathy
item.description:
Damage to the peripheral nerves, leading to sensory, motor, and autonomic dysfunction generally described as a symptom of something else Types: Sensory - numbness, tingling, and decreased ability to sense hot, cold, or pain Motor - weakness, loss of balance, and difficulty breathing or swallowing Autonomic - constipation, diarrhea, changes with urination, dizziness, issues with sexual function, or sweating problems Diabetes T1, Diabetes T2 (most common cause)
Chemotherapy-induced neuropathy (common in Cancer treatment)
Autoimmune diseases (Guillain-Barré syndrome, lupus, Rheumatoid Arthritis) Chronic alcoholism (nutritional deficiencies) Vitamin deficiencies (B12, B6, E, niacin)
Infections (HIV-AIDS, Lyme disease, leprosy) Toxins (heavy metals, pesticides) Kidney disease (uremic neuropathy)
Hypothyroidism Nerve compression (carpal tunnel syndrome, herniated discs) Hereditary conditions (Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease) Uncontrolled diabetes Excessive alcohol use Poor nutrition Autoimmune disorders Chronic kidney or liver disease Exposure to toxins or certain medications Genetic predisposition Sensory Symptoms: Numbness, tingling, or burning sensation (often in hands and feet) Increased or decreased pain sensitivity (hyperesthesia or hypoesthesia) Loss of ability to feel temperature changes or pain "Stocking-glove" distribution (symptoms begin in feet and hands) Motor Symptoms: Muscle weakness or atrophy Difficulty walking, coordination issues, foot drop Muscle cramps or twitching Autonomic Symptoms: Orthostatic hypotension (dizziness upon standing) Bowel and bladder dysfunction Excessive sweating or inability to sweat Sexual dysfunction Falls and injuries (due to impaired sensation and muscle weakness) Chronic pain Infections, ulcers, and poor wound healing (especially in diabetic patients) Loss of limb (in severe diabetic neuropathy cases) Autonomic dysfunction complications (hypotension, cardiac issues) Clinical assessment (history, symptom pattern) Nerve conduction studies (NCS) & electromyography (EMG) (assess nerve damage) Blood tests (check for diabetes, vitamin deficiencies, infections, kidney/liver function) Skin or nerve biopsy (for small fiber neuropathy) MRI or CT scan (to rule out nerve compression) Treat underlying cause (e.g., blood sugar control in diabetes, correcting deficiencies) Medications for neuropathic pain: Anticonvulsants (gabapentin, pregabalin) Tricyclic antidepressants (amitriptyline, nortriptyline) SNRIs (duloxetine, venlafaxine) Topical treatments (capsaicin cream, lidocaine patches) Opioids rarely used (except for severe cases) Physical therapy (to improve strength, balance, and mobility) Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) (pain relief) Plasma exchange or IVIG (for autoimmune neuropathies) Monitor for worsening symptoms (progressive weakness, autonomic dysfunction) Educate on foot care (especially for diabetic patients): Inspect feet daily for ulcers or injuries Wear properly fitted shoes Avoid extreme temperatures (due to decreased sensation) Encourage safety precautions: Fall prevention (assistive devices, adequate lighting) Avoid burns (use gloves for hot surfaces, check water temp before bathing) Promote medication adherence Encourage lifestyle modifications: Smoking cessation (improves circulation) Regular exercise (enhances nerve function) Well-balanced diet (rich in B vitamins, healthy fats) Chronic pain related to nerve damage Impaired physical mobility related to muscle weakness and sensory deficits Risk for injury related to decreased sensation and balance issues Self-care deficit related to loss of fine motor skills
#nursing #medsurg #neuro

item.title: Gout
item.description: A type of inflammatory arthritis caused by the accumulation of uric acid crystals Uric acid crystals form and deposit in the joints, causing inflammation and pain Often affects the big toe (podagra), but can involve other joints such as the knees, wrists, and elbows. Acute episodes of gout may last a few days to weeks and can be triggered by dietary factors, alcohol, dehydration, or trauma. Hyperuricemia (high levels of uric acid in the blood) due to: excessive production OR reduced excretion Genetic predisposition (family history of gout) High purine foods (red meats, shellfish, organ meats) Alcohol consumption (beer and liquor) Sugary drinks (high fructose corn syrup) Excessive intake of processed foods Obesity, diabetes, hypertension, and kidney disease increase risk. Medications (e.g., diuretics, low-dose aspirin) can elevate uric acid levels. Male gender (more common in men, especially age 30-50) Obesity (increased uric acid production) Chronic kidney disease (decreased excretion of uric acid) Family history of gout Medications (diuretics, immunosuppressive drugs) Hypertension and metabolic syndrome Severe, sudden pain in a joint, most commonly the big toe (podagra) Swelling, redness, warmth in the affected joint Pain may be excruciating to touch, with symptoms often occurring at night Tophi (hard nodules) may form in chronic gout, typically around the joints or ears Fever in severe cases Long-term: Tophi formation in joints, tendons, or skin, joint deformities Joint damage and deformities due to long-term uric acid crystal deposition Kidney stones (due to uric acid buildup in kidneys) Chronic pain and decreased mobility Cardiovascular issues (increased risk of hypertension and heart disease) Tophi formation in soft tissues Joint aspiration (synovial fluid analysis): Identifies uric acid crystals under a microscope. Blood tests: Elevated serum uric acid levels (although may not be elevated during acute attack). X-rays: May show joint damage in chronic gout cases or presence of tophi. Ultrasound: Detects urate crystals in joints and soft tissues. Acute attack management: NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) to reduce pain and inflammation Colchicine (reduces inflammation and pain, especially within the first 24 hours) Corticosteroids (oral or injected into the joint) for severe cases Uric acid-lowering drugs: Allopurinol (reduces uric acid production) Febuxostat (alternative to allopurinol) Probenecid (increases uric acid excretion by kidneys) Lifestyle modifications: Low-purine diet: Avoid red meats, shellfish, and organ meats Limit alcohol (especially beer and liquor) Weight loss (reduces uric acid levels) Adequate hydration (helps prevent uric acid crystals from forming) Pain management: Administer NSAIDs, colchicine, or corticosteroids as prescribed. Encourage proper hydration: Fluids help in reducing uric acid concentration in the blood. Monitor serum uric acid levels during treatment. Education on lifestyle changes Prevent future attacks: Ensure patient adheres to long-term medications (e.g., allopurinol) and dietary modifications. Monitor for signs of kidney stones (severe pain, hematuria). Acute pain related to inflammation from uric acid crystals Impaired physical mobility related to joint pain and swelling Ineffective health maintenance related to poor dietary habits or medication adherence Risk for injury related to decreased mobility from joint inflammation

item.title: Meningitis
item.description:
inflammation of the meninges (protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord) viral or bacterial (sometimes parasitic => rare) causes disruption in neuro functions d/t inflammation Bacterial - medical emergency due to rapid progression & high mortality Viral - resolves on its own, less serious Viral: HSV, enteroviruses (common in warm places/tropical), HIV, measles, mumps, West Nile virus Bacterial: Hib, Listeria monocytogenes (common in elderly/newborns), Strep pneumoniae, Enteroviruses (common among 5 below) Funga (rare) Parasitic (rare) Immunocompromised - HIV, very old, very young living in group setting travel Direct Bacterial entry - head trauma, skull fractures, neurosurgery unvaccinated Recent Surgery: spine, lack of spleen, CSF leak Classic Triad: Fever, Stiff Neck (nuchal rigidity), altered mental status Severe headache Photophobia (sensitivity to light) Nausea and vomiting Seizures (in severe cases) Confusion, lethargy, irritability Petechial rash (meningococcal meningitis) Positive Brudzinski’s sign (neck flexion causes knee flexion) Positive Kernig’s sign (pain with knee extension when hip is flexed) Sepsis (meningococcemia, life-threatening) Seizures and epilepsy Hearing loss (common long-term effect) Hydrocephalus (CSF buildup in brain) Cognitive impairments, learning disabilities Brain damage, coma, or death (if untreated or severe cases) lumbar puncture (LP): Bacterial => cloudy CSF, ↑ protein, ↓ glucose (bacteria is eating the glucose) Blood cultures** (to identify bacterial source) CT/MRI scan (rule out brain abscess, increased ICP before LP) Nasal/throat swabs (detect viral or bacterial organisms) Viral; supportive care, Acyclovir (if HSV) Bacterial: ABX (Ceftriaxone or cefotaxime + vancomycin,) Reduce brain swell: dexamethasone Seizure Precautions ICP management => manage BP, avoid straining, elevate HOB Prevention: vaccination Monitor neurological status (LOC, pupil response, vital signs) Implement droplet precautions for bacterial meningitis (until 24 hrs after antibiotics) Elevate HOB 30 degrees (reduce ICP) Reduce environmental stimuli (quiet, dim lights for photophobia) Monitor for signs of increased ICP (worsening headache, vomiting, bradycardia, hypertension) Administer pain relievers, fever reducers (acetaminophen) Encourage vaccination (Hib, pneumococcal, meningococcal vaccines prevent bacterial forms)
Contraindications for LP: increased ICP, Thrombocytopenia, suspected spinal epidural abscess maintain or normalize BP manage fever & pain prevent seizures maintain or improve neuro status

item.title: End of Life
item.description: Stages: Early Stage: Loss of mobility, reduced desire/ability to eat or drink, cognitive changes (delirium, increased sleep). Middle Stage: Further mental decline, brief wakefulness, "death rattle" from mucus/saliva pooling due to weak cough reflex. Late Stage: Fever, apnea, mottled skin from peripheral circulation loss; progression varies from 24 hrs to over 14 days. Good Death: Typically pain-free, in a preferred location, surrounded by loved ones. Clinical Death: Heart/lungs stop, but brain remains viable; timely CPR may restore function. Brain damage starts after 4 min without oxygen, death in 4-6 min. Biologic Death (Brain Death): No brain activity or blood flow; diagnosed by apnea, absent brainstem reflexes, coma from known cause. Causes of Biologic Death: Intracranial (subarachnoid hemorrhage, TBI) or extracranial (cardiac arrest, inadequate CPR, trauma, drowning, overdose, stroke, aneurysm). Pathophysiology of Biologic Death: Brain oxygen deprivation → increased edema → raised intracranial pressure → reduced cerebral perfusion → herniation. Organ Donation: Mechanical support can maintain lung/heart function, but brain death is required for organ donation eligibility. General Changes: Profound weakness, fatigue, increased sleep, disorientation, visions of deceased individuals. Food & Fluids: Decreased interest in eating/drinking, weight loss, dehydration, difficulty swallowing (choking/coughing). Urinary Function: Decreased output, urinary incontinence, dark concentrated urine due to low fluid intake. Skin Changes: Mottling (purple/dark pink in lighter skin, brown in darker skin), pressure injuries from immobility and poor perfusion. Cardiac & Circulation Changes: Reduced cerebral perfusion (drowsiness, confusion, terminal delirium), peripheral cyanosis, mottling, hypotension, tachycardia, cooling extremities. Respiratory Changes: Pooling secretions causing "death rattle," weak/absent cough reflex, dyspnea, Cheyne-Stokes respirations (shallow, rapid breathing with apnea periods). Absence of resp, HR, responsiveness, voluntary movement, muscle function, and nervous system activity Complete muscle relaxation Algor mortis causes body cooling, pale skin, and loss of turgor Rigor mortis causes muscle stiffness, beginning within 2-6 hours and peaking at 12 hours Livor mortis causes blood pooling in dependent areas, leading to purple or reddish discoloration, which becomes fixed after 6-12 hours Specialized care for clients with serious illnesses to improve quality of life. Treatment Approach: Can include symptom management alongside or instead of curative treatments. Client Support: Helps clients understand treatment options and make informed choices. Interprofessional Team: Includes nurses, social workers, dietitians, chaplains, and providers; tailored to client needs. Goals: Supports clients in living actively until death, focusing on comfort and symptom control. Common Symptoms Managed: Dyspnea and pain are primary concerns. Early Implementation Benefits: More effective when started early, reducing unnecessary hospitalizations. Palliative Sedation Used for terminally ill or actively dying clients with distressing symptoms Relieves pain, agitation, and anxiety to prevent unnecessary suffering Not intended to hasten death Common medications: opiates, benzodiazepines, antipsychotics Risks: respiratory depression, aspiration, delirium-related agitation Requires informed consent from the client or legal proxy Must align with advanced directives if applicable Definition: Focuses on comfort, quality of life, and support for clients nearing the end of life. Eligibility: For clients with a terminal illness, typically with a prognosis of fewer than six months, though it can be extended. Care Approach: Provides comfort care rather than curative treatment. Settings: Can be provided at home, in hospitals, hospice centers, or nursing homes. Interprofessional Team: Offers medical, emotional, physical, spiritual, and social support. Home Hospice: Primarily managed by family and friends with hospice team support. Respite Care: Temporary relief for caregivers to prevent burnout. Nursing Role: Collaborates with clients, families, and the care team to honor patient wishes and provide education. Palliative vs. Hospice Care Comparison Palliative Care: Provided alongside curative treatments or as symptom management Can begin at any stage of a serious illness Aims to improve quality of life and relieve symptoms Available in hospitals, outpatient clinics, and nursing homes Hospice Care: For clients with a terminal illness, typically with a prognosis of ≤6 months Focuses on comfort rather than curative treatment Provided at home, in hospice centers, hospitals, or nursing homes Primarily managed by family with hospice team support Both: Aim to improve quality of life Use an interprofessional team for medical, emotional, social, and spiritual support Manage symptoms such as pain and dyspnea Respect client autonomy and end-of-life wishes Identifying Potential Donors: Clients must meet brain death criteria (irreversible loss of all brain function). Brain death is confirmed through apnea, known-cause coma, and absent brainstem reflexes. Clients near death (not brain dead) may still be assessed for potential donation. Organs & Tissues Eligible for Donation: Organs: Kidneys, liver, lungs, heart, pancreas, intestines. Tissues: Corneas, middle ear, heart valves, bone, veins, ligaments, tendons, cartilage, skin. Other Donations: Hands, face, bone marrow, cord blood, blood stem cells, blood, platelets. Live Organ Donation: One kidney, one lung, part of the liver, pancreas, or intestine. Assessment & Scoring: CGS: Score of 3 with the absence of at least three brainstem reflexes indicates imminent brain death. FOUR Score: Evaluates respiration, eye response, brainstem response, and motor response (score of 0 suggests brain death). Nurse’s Role in Brain Death & Donation Process: Assess and document brainstem reflexes and neurological status. Maintain circulation and respiratory function with mechanical ventilation and vasopressors. Work closely with the organ donation coordinator to evaluate donor suitability. Shift care focus from treatment of the client to organ preservation. Priorities in Donor Care: Maintain a patent airway and normal body temperature. Ensure adequate oxygenation and perfusion of organs. Maintain fluid and electrolyte balance to prevent complications. Family Communication & Support: Nurses play a key role in discussing organ donation due to their relationship with the family. Use clear, compassionate communication, explaining brain death and prognosis. Respect cultural and spiritual beliefs regarding death and organ donation. Families are more likely to consent when they experience compassion, commitment, and clear information. Education & Training for Nurses: Ongoing training on organ donation, brain death criteria, grief counseling, and facility protocols. Sensitivity to the death and dying process is crucial. Pain & Symptom Management: Assess and manage pain, dyspnea, agitation, and secretions using medications (opioids, benzodiazepines, anticholinergics). Comfort Care: Reposition frequently, provide skin care, and use moisture barriers to prevent breakdown. Keep the client clean, dry, and comfortable. Respiratory Support: Elevate the head of the bed, use oxygen if needed for comfort, and provide suctioning or anticholinergic medications for excessive secretions. Emotional & Psychological Support: Offer reassurance, provide presence, and support the client and family emotionally. Encourage open discussions about end-of-life wishes. Communication: Speak softly, use simple phrases, and ensure the client and family understand changes occurring. Provide honest but compassionate information. Hydration & Nutrition: Do not force food or fluids; provide oral care to prevent dryness and cracking of lips. Use ice chips or moistened swabs for comfort. Urinary & Bowel Care: Monitor for incontinence, use absorbent pads, provide perineal care, and consider catheterization if needed. Skin Integrity: Turn and reposition frequently, use pressure-relieving devices, and assess for skin breakdown. Cultural & Spiritual Considerations: Respect religious or cultural practices related to death and dying; involve chaplains or spiritual leaders as requested. Family Support: Encourage family presence, educate about the dying process, and provide opportunities to say goodbye. Offer grief resources. Postmortem Care: Respect cultural practices, clean the body, remove tubes (unless an autopsy is required), and prepare the body for the family’s final moments.

item.title: Thrombocytopenia
item.description:
