Low platelet count (<150,000 platelets/mm³) leading to increased bleeding risk Mild (100,000–150,000/mm³): Usually asymptomatic Moderate (50,000–100,000/mm³): Risk of prolonged bleeding Severe (<50,000/mm³): High risk for spontaneous bleeding Critical (<20,000/mm³): Risk of life-threatening hemorrhage Decreased platelet production Bone marrow disorders (leukemia, aplastic anemia, myelodysplastic syndrome) Chemotherapy, radiation therapy Viral infections (HIV, hepatitis, Epstein-Barr virus) Nutritional deficiencies (vitamin B12, folate) DMARDs Increased platelet destruction Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) Autoimmune diseases (lupus, rheumatoid arthritis) Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) Increased platelet sequestration - Splenomegaly (due to liver disease, lymphoma) Cancer treatments (chemotherapy, radiation) Autoimmune disorders Chronic infections (HIV, H. pylori) Liver disease (cirrhosis, portal hypertension) Use of blood-thinning medications (heparin, warfarin) Genetic disorders (Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, Fanconi anemia) Easy bruising (ecchymosis) Petechiae (tiny red or purple spots on skin) Prolonged bleeding from minor cuts Gum or nosebleeds (epistaxis) Heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia) Blood in urine (hematuria) or stool (melena) Severe cases: Intracranial hemorrhage, GI bleeding Uncontrolled bleeding (internal or external) Intracranial hemorrhage (life-threatening) Severe anemia due to blood loss Shock if bleeding is extensive
Complete Blood Count (CBC): Low platelet count Peripheral blood smear (assess platelet shape and function) Bone marrow biopsy (if bone marrow failure suspected)
Coags (PT, PTT, INR) (to rule out clotting disorders) HIT antibody test (if heparin-induced thrombocytopenia suspected) Treat underlying cause (infection, bone marrow suppression, autoimmune disease) Platelet transfusions (for severe thrombocytopenia or active bleeding) Corticosteroids or IV immunoglobulin (IVIG) (for immune-related thrombocytopenia) Discontinuation of causative drugs (e.g., heparin in HIT) Plasmapheresis (for TTP) Splenectomy (if refractory ITP) Avoid NSAIDs, aspirin, and anticoagulants Monitor platelet count trends and bleeding symptoms Implement bleeding precautions: Use soft toothbrush, avoid flossing Avoid IM injections and invasive procedures Use electric razor instead of a blade Prevent falls and injuries Apply prolonged pressure to any bleeding sites Monitor for signs of internal bleeding (hypotension, tachycardia, pallor, dizziness) Educate patient on bleeding risk and safety measures Risk for bleeding related to low platelet count Impaired oral mucous membrane related to gum bleeding Risk for injury related to fall risk and potential bleeding Deficient knowledge related to thrombocytopenia management

item.title: DMARDs
item.description:
Disease-Modifying Antirheumatic Drugs (DMARDs) slow disease progression in autoimmune conditions Reduce inflammation, prevent joint and tissue damage Classified into conventional synthetic (csDMARDs), biologic (bDMARDs), and targeted synthetic (tsDMARDs) Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) Psoriatic arthritis (PsA) Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) Ankylosing spondylitis Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) (e.g., Crohn’s, ulcerative colitis) Suppress immune system to reduce inflammatory response csDMARDs: inhibit cell replication, alter immune pathways (e.g., methotrexate inhibits folate metabolism) => RA, some cancers, dissolve ectopic pregnancies bDMARDs: target specific immune mediators (e.g., TNF inhibitors block tumor necrosis factor) tsDMARDs: inhibit intracellular signaling pathways (e.g., Janus kinase inhibitors) Methotrexate (csDMARD) Adalimumab (TNF inhibitor, bDMARD) Tofacitinib (JAK inhibitor, tsDMARD) Immunosuppression increases infection risk Hepatotoxicity, nephrotoxicity (methotrexate)
Bone marrow suppression (anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia) => monitor CBC GI upset, nausea, diarrhea Pulmonary fibrosis (methotrexate) Injection site reactions (biologics) Active infections (TB, hepatitis, sepsis) Pregnancy (methotrexate is teratogenic) Severe liver or kidney disease Live vaccines while on biologics Monitor infection: temp, fever avoid live vaccines limit visitors avoid large crowds no fresh flowers no fresh fruits/veggies visitor masks cook food thoroughly Educate on infection precautions MTX: Very high risk for bleeding (d/t thrombocytopenia) Monitor CBC, liver, and kidney function tests => due to risk of bone marrow suppression Screen for TB, hepatitis before biologic therapy Folic acid supplementation with methotrexate to reduce toxicity Assess for signs of bone marrow suppression (bruising, fatigue, infection) Monitor respiratory function for methotrexate-induced lung toxicity Rotate injection sites for biologics, monitor for hypersensitivity reactions

item.title: Opioids
item.description: Opioids are potent analgesics that act on the central nervous system (CNS) Used for moderate to severe pain management High risk for dependence, tolerance, and addiction Acute pain (postoperative, trauma) Chronic pain (cancer, palliative care) Severe cough (codeine) Diarrhea (loperamide) Bind to opioid receptors (mu, kappa, delta) in the CNS and peripheral nervous system Inhibit pain signal transmission and alter pain perception Cause CNS depression, leading to sedation and euphoria Morphine (strong opioid agonist) Fentanyl (synthetic opioid, highly potent) Oxycodone (moderate to strong opioid) Codeine (mild opioid, antitussive) Respiratory depression (dose-dependent) Sedation, dizziness, confusion Nausea, vomiting, constipation Urinary retention Hypotension, bradycardia Tolerance, dependence, withdrawal symptoms Pruritus (histamine release) Respiratory depression, severe asthma or COPD Head injury (risk of increased intracranial pressure) Hypotension or shock Severe liver or kidney impairment History of substance use disorder Monitor respiratory rate, hold if RR <12/min Assess pain level before and after administration Encourage hydration and fiber intake to prevent constipation Implement fall precautions due to sedation and dizziness Educate on proper use, risk of dependence, and avoiding alcohol Use naloxone (opioid antagonist) for overdose reversal Gradually taper long-term use to prevent withdrawal symptoms

item.title: TIA
item.description:
aka ministroke blood flow to brain is temporarily blocked resolves complete and does not cause residual neuro manifestations (unlike a stroke) can last for a few minutes or up to 24 hours major warning sign to seek medical attention ASAP stenosis - reduced blood flow embolic occlusion - clot of blood vessel, can vary in size, disintegrate and block a smaller vessel in brain Carotid Artery Stenosis emboli from heart (e.g. A.Fib, valve disease) Atherosclerosis Clotting Disorders - too much clotting hypertension - major one Diabetes cardiovascular disease hyperlipidemia smoking obesity alcohol poor previous TIA slurred speech dizziness headache blurred vision or double vision one-sided weakness aphasia FAST - stroke may resremble hypoglycemia or e- imbalance: test glucose and CBC Coags => PT/INR to determine hypercoagulability toxicology Cardiac Enzymes Lipid Profile CT/MRI ECG & CXR - determine a-fib or cardiac abnormaility Holter Monitor - detect A.Fib Carotid Ultrasound - assess stenosis
Antiplatelets: CAD (clopidogrel, aspirin, dipyridamole) if embolic
Anticoagulants if with A.Fib: apixaban, warfarin Surgical: stent or carotid endarectomy (remove buildup of plaque)
#nursing #medsurg #neuro

item.title: Multiple Sclerosis
item.description: #nursing #medsurg #neuro

item.title: Head Injuries
item.description:
broad term that refers to any damage to the head due to trauma can cause TBI => alteration in neuro function
Types (for other types, go to Critical Care section: TBI) Concussion - mild head injury that may or may not cause a temporary loss of consciousness Subdural Hematoma - collection of blood between the brain and dura
Monro-Kellie Doctrine - cranial vault is composed blood, brain tissue, CSF (if one of these swells, the other must decrease, otherwise, will result in increased ICP)Total Score: 3 (lowest) to 15 (highest) 13-15 = Mild brain injury 9-12 = Moderate brain injury ≤8 = Severe brain injury (coma) MVA Falls: d/t old age, visual acuity, weakness, chronic hypertension, meds physical assault Type of trauma: blunt, penetrating, blast Concussion Manifestations - may appear abruptly or within days headache confusion difficulty concentrating N/V dizziness blurred vision fatigue amnesia of the event that caused injury Acute Subdural Hematoma (SDH) Manifestations change in consciousness; memory loss, disorientation altered pupil response hemiparesis severe: HTN, bradycardia, bradypnea, comatose Chronic SDH can manifest weeks to months after initial injury PCS - Post Concussive Syndrome when manifestations persists for more than 3 months such as headache, photosensitivity, dizziness, and fatigue
increased ICP brain herniation seizures Hydrocephalus - CSF accumulation permanent disability death full neuro exam: check reflexes, sensation, strength, visual acuity Affective/emotional: changes in mood, irritability Cognitive: difficulty concentrating, amnesia, confusion, brain fog Physical/Somatic: visual disturbances, headaches, dizziness Sleep: trouble, drowsiness, sleep alteration Imaging: CT (most common), MRI, XR
CMP, Coags (check PT/INR, PTT) Mild Head Injury: supportive care only, discontinue activities, analgesia, observation if at risk (e.g. bleeding disorder, anticoagulants) Small SDH: few or no neuro concerns: rest and observation, clot will be absorbed in months, no long-term complications Large SDH: surgical to remove hematoma, ICP monitoring Rehab fall precautions
#nursing #medsurg #neuro

item.title: ALS
item.description: #nursing #medsurg #neuro

item.title: Dementia
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro Progressive decline in cognitive function, affecting memory, reasoning, language, and problem-solving Types: Vascular Dementia - reduced oxygen to brain from altered vasculature Lewy Body Dementia (LBD) - protein deposits in brain block neuron connections Fronto-Temporal dementia (FTD) - affects frontal lobe causing changes in behavior Mixed Dementia - self-explanatory
Alzheimers - most common cause advanced age brain injury
Alzheimers cardiovascular disease neurodegenerative diseases: Huntington's, Wernicke-Korsakoff poor diet, lack of physical activity smoking, alcohol memory loss changes in judgement, problem solving confusion wandering getting lost changes in speaking & language inability to express or understand thots & words difficulty performing daily tasks hallucinations or delusions Malnutrition and dehydration (due to forgetting to eat or drink) Increased fall risk (due to impaired coordination and judgment) Infections (e.g., pneumonia, urinary tract infections) Wandering and getting lost Loss of ability to perform self-care (requiring full-time assistance) Aspiration pneumonia (due to swallowing difficulties) depression, anxiety, social isolation Clinical assessment and history-taking (evaluating cognitive decline) Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) or Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) Neuroimaging (MRI, CT scan to rule out other causes) Blood tests (to check for reversible causes like vitamin deficiencies, infections, or thyroid disorders) CSF analysis (for suspected neurodegenerative conditions) goal: maintain independence (work with ST=swallowing, OT = ADL, PT=mobility, Psych=feels) no cure but meds can slow progression or manage symptoms Cholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., donepezil, rivastigmine, galantamine) for mild-to-moderate dementia NMDA receptor antagonists (e.g., memantine) for moderate-to-severe cases Antipsychotics, antidepressants, and mood stabilizers (for behavioral symptoms if necessary) Cognitive therapy and memory training Lifestyle modifications (healthy diet, exercise, social engagement) provide calm and positive environment remove hazards, use alarms for wandering prevention maintain structured routines (avoid confusion and anxiety speak slowly monitor: depression, agitation, aggression ensure nutrition and hydration

item.title: Delirium
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro Acute, reversible cognitive disturbance characterized by confusion, disorientation, and impaired attention Develops suddenly over hours to days Fluctuating course with periods of lucidity and confusion Often secondary to an underlying medical condition
Compared to Dementia: Dementia: gradual onset, worsens over time Delirium: sudden, sporadic manifestations (on and off) Hypoxia (e.g., respiratory failure, cardiac conditions)
Infections (e.g., UTI, Pneumonia, sepsis)
Metabolic imbalances (e.g., Fluid & Electrolyte ATI, electrolyte disturbances, Hypoglycemia) Medications (e.g., opioids, benzodiazepines, anticholinergics) Substance withdrawal (e.g., alcohol, benzodiazepines) Head trauma or surgery (especially in older adults) Sleep deprivation and sensory deprivation prolonged heat or sun exposure Older adults (especially those with dementia) Hospitalization, ICU stays Polypharmacy History of substance use Severe illness or chronic conditions Visual or hearing impairment Acute onset of confusion and disorientation Fluctuating levels of consciousness (periods of alertness alternating with drowsiness) Impaired attention and concentration Disorganized thinking and incoherent speech Hallucinations or delusions (often visual) Agitation, restlessness, or lethargy Sleep-wake cycle disturbances (e.g., nighttime confusion, daytime drowsiness) Increased fall risk (due to confusion and agitation) Aspiration pneumonia (from decreased swallowing ability) Longer hospital stays and functional decline Progression to dementia in vulnerable individuals Clinical assessment (based on sudden onset and fluctuating symptoms) Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) (screens for delirium)
Blood glucose: rule out Hyperglycemia/Hypoglycemia Drug screen
Urinalysis: rule out UTI
Rue out e-/fluid imbalance: CMP Neuroimaging (MRI, CT scan) (if head trauma or stroke is suspected) Identify and treat underlying cause (e.g., antibiotics for infection, fluids for dehydration) Medications (only if severe agitation; e.g., low-dose haloperidol or atypical antipsychotics) Environmental modifications (quiet, well-lit room, familiar objects, reorientation cues) Adequate hydration, nutrition, and oxygenation Promote regular sleep-wake cycle Monitor for sudden changes in mental status Reorient frequently (provide clocks, calendars, family photos) Ensure safety (fall precautions, avoid restraints) Encourage family presence (reduces anxiety and confusion) Minimize use of sedatives and anticholinergic medications Promote mobility and engagement (helps prevent worsening symptoms)

item.title: Alzheimers
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro progressive neurodegenerative disorder affecting memory, thinking, behavior
most common cause of Dementia amyloid plaque buildup and neurofibrillary tangles in brain leads to gradual loss of cognitive and functional abilities Age (most cases occur after age 65) Family history and genetics Cardiovascular disease (hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia) Head trauma and traumatic brain injury (TBI) Chronic stress and depression Sedentary lifestyle and poor diet
same as Dementia depends on the stage: Early stage: Mild Alzheimer's Short-term memory loss (misplacing items, forgetting names) Difficulty finding words and making decisions Mild confusion and disorientation Middle/Moderate stage: Increased memory loss and difficulty recognizing loved ones Behavioral changes (agitation, aggression, mood swings) Wandering and getting lost Difficulty with complex tasks (managing finances, cooking) Late/Severe stage: Severe cognitive decline and loss of communication body begins to completely shut down Inability to perform self-care (feeding, dressing, toileting) Loss of mobility, swallowing difficulties, and incontinence Mini-Mental State Exam (MMSE) shorter, longer: Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) - first-line neuro exam, administer several times across time amyloid beta protein precursor (soluble) - identifies gene mutations causing early-onset MRI/CT - rule out other conditions PET scan - detect amyloid plaque buildup maintain quiet environment Ensure a safe environment (fall prevention, door alarms for wandering)** Use simple communication (speak slowly, use short sentences) Provide structured routines (minimizes confusion and anxiety) Assist with activities of daily living (ADLs) as disease progresses Encourage social interaction and cognitive activities Monitor for signs of infection, dehydration, and malnutrition Support and educate caregivers on disease progression

item.title: DVT
item.description: type of blood clot that forms in large veins of extremities or pelvis usually occurs in lower extremities 3rd most common cause of death among cardiovascular disorders DVT will go unnoticed but can dislodge and result in a pulmonary embolus, a life-threatening event Types: provoked: from an acquired cause (obesity, cancer, immobility) unprovoked: from an endogenous cause such as recurrence Proximal: above the knee, and this type is more likely to cause complications leading to PE Distal: below the knee (most common) pain, redness, swelling, warmth at affected extremity** edema no longer recommended: DVT filters on inferior vena cava Prophylaxis: SCD, Xa inhibitors (Eliquis, newer class) ambulate early anticoags administer Lovenox - low molecular weight heparin injection conduct "wells criteria test" - establish DVT risk venous doppler - detects bloow flow venography - invasive procedure involving contrast dye and xray d-dimer MRI caused by damage to the wall of a blood vessel turbulence to blood flow, such as with atrial fibrillation, a heart arrhythmia hypercoagulability, meaning the blood is increasingly coagulating or clotting decreased blood flow due to immobility, surgery, catheter dehydration due to increased blood viscosity genetics - factor V Leiden (FVL) mutation CHF, COPD hospital stay immobility: bedrest, airplane right, anesthesia hormonal: pregnant, contraceptive therapy or hormone replacement therapy with estrogen smoking family hx, previous hx old age tumors sepsis chronic health conditions: HTN, DM Usual comorbidities: cellulitis, thrombophlebitis, eczema, vasculitis, cancer, CHF, IBS obesity: pressure on the lower extremities SSC DVT can dislodge and travel = becomes a PE Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) - profoundly serious health condition clotting and anticlotting mechanisms occur at the same time. hypovolemic shock

item.title: Hematological everything else
item.description:
#hematologic #anemia #nursing #medsurg
#bloodclot What is it Blood clots are made up of platelets and fibrin and are a gel-like consistency thrombus - when blocks vein or artery arterial thrombosis - occurs in artery venous Embolus/embolism - if it moves throughout the body; can cause serious harm Subtypes Pulmonary Embolism Myocardial Infarction (MI) Ischemic Stroke - occurs in artery to the brain caused by plaque (fatty deposits) Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) Clinical Presentation chest pain that worsens with deep breathing tachycardia, SOB, lightheadedness, hemoptysis MI: chest pain radiating left arm, SOB, diaphoresis Stroke: facial weakness, difficulty speaking, visual deficit, L/R sided weakness, seizures Treatment Thrombolytics - class of meds that dissolve clots Tissue Plasminogen Activator - give within 3 hours for stroke, do not use with hemorrhagic stroke, verify with CT Thrombectomy - specialized instruments to surgically remove a blood clot Prevention: Coumadin/Warfarin - avoid diet changes, monitor INR, high K diet contradicts this medication Factor Xa Inhibitors - Eliquis, monitoring not required, oral Lovenox/Enoxaparin Heparin - Hold heparin if the platelet count is less than 100,000/mm, monitor aPTT Plavix/Clopidogrel Antiplatelets - ensures platelets do not stick together most common: aspirin, clopidogrel (Plavix), usually prescribed with ACS Nursing Interventions ambulate diet note aging adults challenges
be on alert with anticoagulants #anticoagulant higher risk for bleeding Warfarin - needs INR, diet restrictions Causes/Risk Factors injury or damage to vein surgery exacerbated by bed rest hormonal: oral contraceptives, pregnancy, hormone replacement, estrogen (menopause, prostate cancer) child birth after first 3 months smoking cancers: lungs, brain, pancreas, uterus, ovaries, blood cancers, chemotherapy family history Atrial Fibrillation Infection mechanical heart valves SSC - systemic sclerosis, aka "scleroderma": also provides increased risk for clots Diagnosis D-dimer test: blood test, high = clot. can also be present during pregnancy or postop small fragment of protein is detected from blood clot not definitive, more testing needed if positive CT, US, MRA (magnetic resonance angiography) MRA = more specific to blood vessels V/Q scan - ventilation/perfusion test aided by radioactive and imaging techniques Systemic Effects Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) - profoundly serious health condition clotting and anticlotting mechanisms occur at the same time What is it Hemorrhage: Loss of blood from damaged vessels, inside or outside the body. Severity impacts treatment and prognosis. Blood loss classess: Class I - 0-15% Class II - 15-30% (shock symptoms apparent) Class III - 30-40% (delayed cap refill, SBP<90, tachy) Class IV - 40% or more, no UOP, peripheral pulses absent, shock Types of Hemorrhages: Intracranial - brain bleeds Pulmonary - hemothorax; caused by trauma, cancer, or clotting Stroke - hemorrhagic; vessels rupture and blood leaks into brain Clinical Presentation Symptoms vary: nausea, dizziness, cool skin, shortness of breath, weakness, tachycardia, confusion. Internal bleeding signs: hemoptysis, hematemesis, clammy skin, abdominal rigidity, altered consciousness.
intracranial hemorrhage: #stroke headaches, slurred speech or difficulty speaking, facial numbness, upper and lower extremity weakness or numbness, decreased level of consciousness, seizures, or difficulty with ambulating Treatment IV fluids, blood transfusion, oxygen therapy, warming blankets, emotional support. Type and cross-match for blood products. Physical and occupational therapy for rehabilitation. Nursing Interventions Goal: stop the bleed Assess and identify bleeding source, apply pressure, ensure IV access, administer fluids. Monitor vital signs, oxygen saturation, and mental status. Educate on gradual activity increase and rest. MAP > 65 mm Hg indicates adequate cardiac perfusion. MAP = (DBP×2) + SBP /3Diagnostic Tools CBC, platelet count, PT, PTT. CT scans, x-rays, ultrasounds endoscopy for suspected GI bleeds. Causes Traumatic injuries, cancer, clotting disorders, elevated BP leading to ruptured aneurysm. Risk Factors Trauma, accidents, cancer blood clotting disorders: hemophillia (genetic mutation) poor people = higher risk postpartum hemorrhage = atony (flaccid fetus due to significant blood loss during childbirth or postpartum period) Systemic Effects Hypovolemic shock: decreased cardiac output, circulatory insufficiency, hypoxemia. Cognitive impairments, fatigue, depression, anxiety, PTSD. Orthostatic hypotension increases fall risk.

item.title: Triptans
item.description: Class of drugs used to treat acute migraine attacks and cluster headaches Not for preventive use; taken at migraine onset Sumatriptan (Imitrex) – first and most common triptan Others: Rizatriptan, Zolmitriptan, Eletriptan, Naratriptan, Almotriptan, Frovatriptan Selective serotonin (5-HT1B/1D) receptor agonists Causes vasoconstriction of cranial blood vessels Reduces inflamation and inhibits pain pathways in the brain Acute migraine attacks (with or without aura) Cluster headaches History of cardiovascular disease (MI, stroke, uncontrolled HTN) Peripheral vascular disease Hemiplegic or basilar migraines Use of MAO inhibitors within the past 2 weeks Severe hepatic or renal impairment Chest tightness/pressure, palpitations Hypertension Dizziness, drowsiness Paresthesia (tingling, numbness) Serotonin syndrome (if combined with SSRIs, SNRIs) Rebound headaches with overuse Assess for cardiovascular history before administration Monitor BP due to risk of hypertension Educate on proper use: Take at migraine onset, not for daily use Warn about chest tightness—common but usually not serious Advise against combining with SSRIs, SNRIs, or other triptans within 24 hours Limit use to 2 days per week to avoid medication-overuse headaches

item.title: GERD
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal stomach acids travels up esophagus, irritates lining common chronic disease that affects daily life lower esophageal sphincter (LES) is weakened and fails to close tightly to prevent backflow of stomach contents diet: spicy, caffeine, high fat irritants from smoking obesity = increased intra-abdominal pressure ; promotes reflux decreased physical activity 50 years or older or low socioeconomic status excessive alcohol or caffeine consumption lying down after eating
Hiatal Hernia pregnant Helicobacter pylori - bacterial infection that attacks the lining of the stomach and duodenum stress connective tissue disorders medications: NSAIDS, anticholinergics, aspirin irritation of the throat, or chest pain contributes to heart burn = discomfort regurgitation; sour taste in mouth frequent belching, bloating, regurgitation tooth decay: if it's chronic Barrett’s esophagus - leads to esophageal cancer; lining of the esophagus changes from normal tissue to tissue that resembles the lining of the small intestine dysphagia - difficulty swallowing dyspepsia - epigastric pain odynophagia - Painful swallowing. tooth decay - acid erodes enamel of teeth rule out chest pain from GI vs cardiac etiology; check comorbidities: hx, HTN, HLD, CAD, HF EGD - esophagogastroduodenoscopy; tube with camera that goes down the throat check pH in esophagus: ambulatory pH monitoring or an esophageal pH monitoring test capsule test: capsule is left in esophagus to check pH content
PPI and H2 Blockers H2 Blockers: cimetidine or famotidine PPI: pantoprazole or omeprazole Antacids: treat symptoms, neutralize acid Surgery: endoscopic dilation, reinforce LES possible NGT placement: for parenteral nutrition (liquid only) spicy food - irritant caffeine - increases stomach acid alcohol - irritant high acid foods: tomatoes, citrus, vinegar, pickled chocolate fatty: fried, fatty meat, full-fat dairy peppermint: relaxes LES carbonated beverages educate on lifestyle changes: weight, exercise avoid tight fitting clothes stop smoking avoid food triggers meals 3 hrs before bedtime raise head of bed 6-9 inches maintain good oral hygiene

item.title: Hiatal Hernia
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal upper part of the stomach pushes up through the diaphragm into the chest increased intra-abdominal pressure pushes the stomach up very common among 50+ 2 types: sliding and paraesophageal hernias Sliding - most common occur when the upper section of the stomach occasionally slides up or protrudes into the chest area through the hiatus Paraesophageal (PEH) - more advanced; can become an emergency a greater portion of the stomach, a part of the esophagus, or perhaps the intestines have migrated up into the chest cavity through the hiatus. anything that elevates intra-abdominal pressure multiple pregnancies skeletal disorders with bone decalcification and degeneration constant bearing down: constipation or COPD old age, 50+ (d/t weakened abdominal muscles) GERD obesity pregnant smoker
All GERD symptoms: heartburn, regurgitation, sour taste, etc Water brash: excessive salivation, acidic taste Post-prandial fullness - uncomfortable feeling of fullness in the stomach that persists after eating bloating, early satiety dysphagia Severe: GI bleed = black tarry stool (melena) Very severe: pulmonary symptoms if stomach presses on lungs: dyspnea and possibly atelectasis esophageal compression intestinal obstruction
GI Bleed= hematochezia (red blood stool), melena (black stool) Anemia from bleeds: fatigue, SOB gastric strangulation = tangled intestines (gastric volvulus) X-ray EGD - esophagogastroduodenoscopy - tube with camera; most common =>sedated procedure; biopsy samples taken esophageal motility study - measures the strength and maneuverability of the muscles by inserting a catheter in esophagus
ambulatory esophageal reflux monitoring test (see GERD )
PPI and H2 Blockers H2 Blockers: cimetidine or famotidine PPI: pantoprazole or omeprazole Antacids: treat symptoms, neutralize acid surgical: laparoscopic Nissen fundoplication => wrapping the upper part of the stomach around the lower esophagus Risk for Aspiration – Due to gastric contents refluxing into the esophagus, increasing the risk of aspiration pneumonia. Acute Pain – Related to esophageal irritation from acid reflux, often presenting as heartburn or chest discomfort. Impaired Swallowing – Due to esophageal compression or inflammation from chronic reflux. Imbalanced Nutrition: Less than Body Requirements – Related to discomfort while eating or avoidance of food due to symptoms. Ineffective Breathing Pattern – If the hernia is large, it may press on the diaphragm, causing shortness of breath. Deficient Knowledge – Related to lack of understanding about lifestyle modifications, dietary changes, and medication adherence. Risk for Gastrointestinal Bleeding – If chronic irritation leads to esophagitis, ulcers, or Barrett’s esophagus.

item.title: Fatty Liver - Steatotic Liver Disease
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal fat accumulation in liver due to metabolic dysfunction
usually a benign, reversible condition curable with lifestyle mods but can progress to Cirrhosis
2 Types: NAFLD, Alcoholic Liver Disease => (only difference is alcohol) Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD): Metabolic dysfunction (e.g., obesity, insulin resistance, type 2 diabetes, high cholesterol, hypertension) Poor diet (high-fat, high-sugar foods) Sedentary lifestyle Genetic factors Certain medications (e.g., corticosteroids, methotrexate, tamoxifen)
Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (ALD): see Alcoholic Liver Disease Chronic alcohol consumption Toxic effects of alcohol on liver metabolism Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD): Obesity Type 2 diabetes High cholesterol or triglycerides High blood pressure Metabolic syndrome Older age Family history of liver disease Poor diet (high in processed foods, sugar, or fats) Sedentary lifestyle Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (ALD): Excessive alcohol consumption Heavy drinking over long periods Male gender (more common in men, though women can develop ALD at lower alcohol levels) Early stages may be asymptomatic. Possible symptoms include: Fatigue Weight loss or difficulty losing weight Abdominal discomfort (especially in the right upper quadrant) Jaundice (in advanced stages) Swelling in the abdomen or legs (in cases with liver damage) Dark urine Nausea or loss of appetite Physical examination (may reveal hepatomegaly, or liver enlargement) Blood tests: Elevated liver enzymes (AST, ALT) Lipid profile (elevated cholesterol or triglycerides) Fasting blood glucose (to assess for insulin resistance) Ultrasound: Most common test to identify fatty liver CT scan or MRI: Can provide a more detailed view of the liver Liver biopsy: May be needed in cases of Non-Alcoholic Steatohepatitis (NASH) to assess liver damage Elastography: Measures liver stiffness to evaluate for fibrosis or cirrhosis Lifestyle changes: Weight loss (gradual, about 1-2 lbs per week) Dietary modifications (low-fat, low-sugar, and nutrient-dense diet) Exercise (at least 30 minutes of moderate activity, 5 days a week) Avoid alcohol (for ALD and NAFLD patients) Medications (mainly for managing underlying conditions): Insulin sensitizers (e.g., metformin for insulin resistance) Statins for high cholesterol Vitamin E (in some cases of NASH) Liver transplant: In severe cases of cirrhosis due to fatty liver Manage comorbidities: Control diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia Avoid hepatotoxic medications (e.g., acetaminophen in high doses) Monitor liver function: Regularly check liver enzymes (AST, ALT) and bilirubin levels. Monitor blood glucose and lipid profile for associated metabolic conditions. Diet and weight management: Provide education on a low-fat, low-sugar diet and the importance of gradual weight loss. Encourage physical activity and healthy eating habits. Patient education: Alcohol cessation for those with ALD. Educate about the long-term effects of untreated fatty liver (risk for cirrhosis). Supportive care: Manage fatigue and any discomfort associated with the liver enlargement. Provide emotional support for weight loss challenges and lifestyle changes. Monitor for complications: Watch for signs of progression to cirrhosis (e.g., jaundice, ascites, easy bruising). Watch for signs of hepatic encephalopathy in advanced stages (confusion, altered mental status).

item.title: Hyperthyroidism
item.description:
Overactive thyroid producing excessive thyroid hormones Speeds up metabolism, affecting multiple body systems Common in younger adults, especially females Graves = Gains (active and spends a lot of energy) T3/T4 is HIGH = HYperthyroidism T3/T4 causes increased expression of B-adrenergic receptors (causing increased FIGHT OR FLIGHT response) Graves' disease (autoimmune, most common) - immune system gets confused and tells thyroid to go wild, making you jittery, sweaty, and giving you bulging eyes (grave's ophthalmopathy) Toxic multinodular goiter - lumps (nodules) on your thyroid start making too much thyroid hormone Thyroid adenoma (benign tumor) Excess iodine intake (contrast dyes, medications, seaweed) Overuse of levothyroxine Female, ages 20–40 (sexist!) Family history of thyroid disease Autoimmune disorders (Diabetes T1, Rheumatoid Arthritis) High iodine intake Recent pregnancy (Postpartum thyroiditis) - can increase the risk DURING pregnancy and could affect neuro health of baby extreme stress
Pernicious Anemia (see Vitamin Deficiency Anemia (pernicious)) Weight loss despite increased appetite (Hypermetabolic state) Heat intolerance, sweating Tachycardia, hypertension, palpitations, pedal edema Nervousness, anxiety, insomnia Tremors, hyperreflexia Goiter - term for enlarged thyroid exophthalmos (Graves' disease) - protruding eyeballs, bulging eyes (grape eyes) Diarrhea, increased bowel movements menstrual changes Thyroid storm (life-threatening crisis) - aka thyrotoxicosis Fever, extreme tachycardia, hypertensive crisis (180/100) AMS (big one) Delirium, seizures, dysrhythmias, shock, aneurysm Requires ICU care: IV beta-blockers, cooling, PTU or methimazole Atrial fibrillation, heart failure => blood clots, stroke, or heart failure menstrual cycle disruption (fertility problems) Osteoporosis from increased bone turnover Elevated: T3, T4 - thyroid produces excess amounts; these hormones are responsible for metabolism, HR, BP, temp, growth, muscle/bone health Decreased: TSH (if primary hyperthyroidism) Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH) is reduced because of negative feedback, thyroid is already overstimulated Other labs: Radioactive iodine uptake scan (↑ uptake in Graves’)
EKG for dysrhythmias Antithyroid medications (Methimazole, Propylthiouracil/PTU) - inhibit thyroid hormone synthesis by blocking thyroid peroxidase, reducing T3 and T4 production Methimazole - can cause liver toxicity, hypothyroidism if overmedicated SSKI - Potassium Ioidide, shrinks the thyroid Beta-blockers (Propranolol for symptom control) Radioactive iodine therapy (destroys thyroid tissue in one dose) - very toxic, ensure (-) pregnancy, remove jewelry/dentures, no anesthesia, NPO
Thyroidectomy (for severe cases, requires lifelong levothyroxine) - removal of part or entire thyroid, high risk for hypocalcemia Fluid Electrolyte Cheat Sheets Monitor for thyroid storm (high fever, extreme tachycardia) PTU is contraindicated for pregnant Provide a cool, quiet environment to reduce stimulation (e.g. cooling blankets) Grape eyes = use eye patches or tape the eyelids Educate on taking antithyroid meds at same time daily Monitor for signs of hypothyroidism after treatment High-calorie, high-protein diet due to increased metabolism (4000-500 cal per day) Frequent meals Avoid: caffeine, fiber, spicy food, iodine NCLEX/ATI: Post-thyroidectomy care includes monitoring for airway swelling, keeping a trach kit at bedside, and assessing for hypocalcemia (Chvostek’s, Trousseau’s signs) due to accidental parathyroid removal

item.title: Diverticulitis
item.description: What is it: little pockets in your gut that get inflamed (diverticula) that form in the walls of the colon, typically in the sigmoid colon, occur in areas of weakness along the intestinal tract Causes: Fecal matter or bacteria becoming trapped in the diverticula, leading to inflammation or infection Risk Factors: constant straining (chronic constipation) => more pressure, age, obesity, smoking, lack of exercise, low fiber diet, steroids, opioids, NSAIDS Clinical Manifestations: abdominal pain, fever, N/V, bloating, tenderness, possible rectal bleeding Diagnosis: CT, CBC (infection), colonoscopy (r/o other conditions) Treatment: abx, NPO (bowel rest) followed by clear liquid diet, Analgesia but no NSAIDS, surgery for complications (perforations, abscess, fistulas) avoid NSAIDS assess bowel sounds hydrate avoid enemas and laxatives during inflammation avoid seeds, nuts, popcorn if no inflammation, high fiber diet is encouraged Nuts and Seeds: These can get trapped in the diverticula and cause irritation or infection (though current research suggests this may not always be true for everyone). Popcorn: Similar to nuts and seeds, popcorn kernels can irritate diverticula. Corn: Whole kernels can potentially get stuck in diverticula and cause issues. Fruits and Vegetables with Small Seeds: Such as strawberries, raspberries, and tomatoes, which might irritate the diverticula. Spicy Foods: Can irritate the digestive tract and increase inflammation. High-Fat Foods: Fried foods, fatty meats, and full-fat dairy can slow digestion and worsen symptoms. Refined Grains: White bread, pasta, and rice lack fiber and may worsen constipation, increasing pressure on the colon. Processed Meats: Bacon, sausage, and other high-fat, processed meats can contribute to inflammation.

item.title: Gastric Ulcers
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinalnote: Ulcerative Colitis is different from Gastric Ulcers
see Irritable Bowel Diseases for Ulcerative Colitis Location: Gastric ulcer affects the stomach; ulcerative colitis affects the colon and rectum. Cause: Gastric ulcer is mainly due to acid damage; ulcerative colitis is an autoimmune condition. Symptoms: Gastric ulcer pain is meal-related; ulcerative colitis presents with chronic diarrhea and blood in stool. Treatment Approach: Gastric ulcer focuses on acid suppression; ulcerative colitis requires immune modulation. open sores that occur in the inner lining of the stomach ATI says they are synonymous with PEPTIC ULCERS or PUD damaged protective mucosa is exposed to gastric juices => stomach tissue is dissolved (severe pain) H. pylori colonizes mucosa causing inflammation and increased acidity H.Pylori Infection NSAID use lifestyle: smoking, alcohol cystic fibrosis, hyperparathyroidism, Zollinger Ellison rare: viral infections chemo, cronhs, gastric/lung cancers, vascular insufficiencies family history liver, kidney or lung disease Blood type O rheumatoid arthritis abdominal pain: burning sensation, gnawing = after meals or at night (due to acid irritating the ulcer) weight loss, nausea, vomiting, feeling bloated, and early satiety perforation - biggest concern as it can cause bleeding and infection bleeding late signs: hypotension, tachycardia, dizziness, lightheadedness, weakness, SOB, bloody emesis or stool, anemia fever from infection
CBC, LFT EGD: gold standard, sedated procedure to obtain tissue biopsy, scope down your throat test for H. Pylori = breath test or rapid urease test (biopsies placed in solution) fecal antigen test blood culture - also detects h.pylori Detect perforation: CXR, contrast dye
PPI and H2 Blockers change NSAID meds prostaglandin analog (misoprostol) - reduce gastric acid secretion, increase mucus production For H.Pylori infections: abx + PPI Vagotomy = for severe cases partial gastrectomy spicy food - irritant caffeine - increases stomach acid alcohol - irritant high acid foods: tomatoes, citrus, vinegar, pickled chocolate fatty: fried, fatty meat, full-fat dairy peppermint: relaxes LES carbonated beverages educate NSAID use monitor bloody stool or emesis auscultate/inspect/palpate abdomen

item.title: Irritable Bowel Diseases
item.description:
What is it: classified under the umbrella term known as an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) may demonstrate patches of inflammation followed by patches of healthy tissue Causes: Exact cause unknown; likely involves immune system dysfunction, genetic predisposition, and environmental triggers. Risk Factors: Family history, smoking, high-fat diet, NSAID use, stress, and exposure to Westernized diet/lifestyle. Clinical Manifestations: Abdominal pain (usually RLQ), chronic diarrhea (sometimes bloody), weight loss, fatigue, malnutrition, fever, oral ulcers, and perianal disease (fissures, abscesses, fistulas). Diagnosis: colonoscopy with biopsy, CT, MRI, fecal calprotectin (inflammation marker), blood tests (elevated CRP, anemia, vitamin deficiencies). Treatment: Anti-inflammatory meds (5-ASA, corticosteroids), immunosuppressants (azathioprine, methotrexate), biologics (TNF inhibitors like infliximab), antibiotics for infections, surgery if complications arise (resections, fistula repair). Nursing Considerations: Monitor for malnutrition, dehydration, electrolyte imbalances; provide dietary support (low-fiber during flares, high-calorie/protein intake); assess for medication side effects (infection risk with immunosuppressants); encourage smoking cessation and stress management. Watch for complications like strictures, perforation, and abscesses. What is it: also under IBD, continuous inflammation and ulcers in the colon and rectum. Causes: Unknown; thought to involve genetic, immune, and environmental factors. Risk Factors: Family history, autoimmune disorders, high-fat diet, smoking (increased risk in non-smokers). Clinical Manifestations: cramping, urgency, tenesmus, weight loss, fatigue, fever, anemia, sores can bleed = bloody diarrhea Diagnosis: Colonoscopy with biopsy (shows continuous inflammation, ulcers), stool tests, blood tests (elevated CRP, anemia).
Treatment: Anti-inflammatory meds (5-ASA), corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, biologics (TNF inhibitors), surgery (colectomy if severe). Nursing Considerations: Monitor for dehydration, malnutrition, electrolyte imbalances. Assess for complications (toxic megacolon, perforation).

item.title: Celiac's Disease
item.description: What is it: Autoimmune disorder where eating gluten (found in wheat, barley, and rye) damages the small intestine, leading to nutrient malabsorption. Causes: genetics, triggered by gluten Risk Factors: genetics, autoimmune diseases (Diabetes T1, thyroid), european descent, hx of digestive issues Clinical Manifestations: Diarrhea, weight loss (d/t inability to absorb nutrients), bloating, abdominal pain, fatigue, iron-deficiency anemia, delayed growth in children, skin rashes (dermatitis herpetiformis). Diagnosis: Blood tests (anti-tissue transglutaminase antibody), endoscopy with biopsy showing villous atrophy in the small intestine. Treatment: strict gluten-free diet (lifelong) Nursing Considerations: educate on food labels and meal planning, monitor for malnutrition, emotional support Complications: osteoporosis, infertility

item.title: Bowel Obstruction
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal What is it: Blockage in the intestines preventing normal passage of food, gas, and fluid can be partial, complete, occurring in SMALL or LARGE intestine Causes: Mechanical: Tumors, adhesions (scar tissue), hernias, volvulus (twisted bowel), impacted stool, diverticulitis Non-mechanical (paralytic ileus): Loss of normal bowel movement due to nerve or muscle problems (e.g., after surgery, electrolyte imbalances). Risk Factors: Previous abdominal surgery (adhesions), cancer/tumors, Crohn's, hernias, constipation, old Clinical Manifestations: abdominal pain, bloating/distention, NO BOWEL SOUNDS, vomiting (can smell like shit), constipation, dehydration, e- imbalance Diagnosis: CXR/CT, CBC to r/o infection, BMP for e- imbalances, U/S for peds
Treatment: NPO, IVF, NGT decompression, Analgesia, antiemetics, surgery if severe or caused by tumor Nursing Considerations: always check bowel sounds, blockage of LARGE intestine prevents normal passage of stool and gas leads to bowel distention, fluid shifts, and ischemia can be mechanical or functional (see causes) mechanical: tumors, diverticulitis, volvulus, hernias, strictures, adhesions, impacted feces
functional: paralytic ileus, neurogenic disorders, post-op complications (see Gastroparesis) hx of abdominal surgery colorectal cancer diverticular disease chronic constipation narcotic use old age neuro deficit affecting motility distension cramping pain (intermittent if mechanical, constant if ischemic) N/V constipation high pitched bowel sounds (early) absent bowel sounds (late) XR, CT, contrast enema colonoscopy of not acutely obstructed NPO IVF, e- correction NGT decompression
Analgesia surgery if severe: stent, tumor resection, colostomy always assess bowel sounds, distention, pain NGT decompression pain control without opioids if possible same as large bowel but for SMALL (lol) mechanical: adhesions (most common), hernias, tumors, vovulus, intussusception, strictures, foreign bodies functional: paralytic ileus, postop complications, infections, nuro adhesions - bands of scar tissue that form between intestines and other organs intussusception - one part of the intestine telescopes into another, similar to a collapsed telescope strictures - narrowing of gi tract volvulus - twisted intestines previous abdominal surgeries hernias, hx of tumors IBD radiation therapy, opioid use old same as LBO same as LBO same as LBO adhesiolysis hernia repair same as LBO

item.title: Hepatitis
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal inflammation of the liver Viral hepatitis: Caused by Hep ABCDE Autoimmune hepatitis: Immune system attacks liver cells (less common) Toxic hepatitis: Due to alcohol, drugs, or toxins. (less common) Metabolic hepatitis: Related to fatty liver diseases (e.g., MASLD).
constant irritation causes cells to necrotize and eventually form scar tissues => Cirrhosis(complication) Hepatitis Virus - ABCDE most common: ABC A = ass to mouth (oral-fecal) B & C = blood and cum (bloodborne & sexual transmission) D = double dip (needs B infection first) E = exit through the ass (oral-fecal) vary depending on type A & E- poor sanitation, oral-fecal route, close contact, drug use, seggs, travel to endemic areas, contaminated food B - unprotected seggs, multiple partners (ho life), needles, mother to child, healthcare workers, tattoos, close proximity C = same as B, lower risk from seggs Common risk factors: older adults, immunocompromised, alcohol abuse, preexisting liver conditions jaundice of eyes and skin = buildup of bilirubin N/V abdominal pain, swelling fever, fatigue, loss of appetite dark urine = bilirubin in urine clay-colored stool (white or gray shit => lack of bile = no bilirubin as it is normally excreted in stool) pruritus - buildup of bile salts in skin muscle/joint pain = B/C SEVERE: significant weight loss, uncontrolled N/V, confusion/drowsiness, bruising easily, severe abdominal pain
Cirrhosis => read this as these two are related Liver Failure fulminant liver failure - hepatic encephalopathy, occurs abruptly Bleeding disorders - coagulopathy (Vitamin K is stored and activated in liver) liver cancer hepatic encephalopathy - severe; toxins cannot be excreted by liver Portal Hypertension a lot more
LFT = elevated serum antibodies to specify which type => guides treatment decisions Imaging: US, CT, MRI Liver biopsy Elastography - noninvasive alternative to biopsy that measures liver stiffness (stiff = fibrosis)
Coags = liver is responsible for clotting factors Hepatitis A = no treatment; supportive care only; resolves on its own B & C = interferon for 6 months (proteins produced naturally by immune system for viruses) Direct Acting Antivirals = Hep C not allowed: alcohol, tylenol risk for malnutrition (sarcopenia = loss of muscle from low protein intake) encourage smaller more frequent meals to reduce upset stomach Ascites = compute caloric calculations with ideal weight instead of including ascites weight risk for hyponatremia = very common risk for thrombocytopenia = low platelets, BLEEDING PRECAUTIONS, no shaving, no hard-bristle toothbrush or dental floss, no aspirin/NSAID, check for signs of bleeding, falls precautions Educate on diet encourage vaccination encourage handwashing no seggs use needleless systems if possible report all cases of virus to health department Chronic Liver Disease - umbrella term that includes hepatitis, steatotic liver disease (SLD), cirrhosis, carcinoma, liver failure
Steatotic Liver Disease - aka Fatty Liver - Steatotic Liver Disease, also includes alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD), metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD), and MetALD (a combination of MASLD and ALD).​​​​​​​ Risk for Bleeding: Impaired liver function reduces clotting factors, increasing bleeding risk. Fluid Volume Excess: Ascites and edema from portal hypertension and decreased albumin. Imbalanced Nutrition: Less than Body Requirements: Inadequate intake and malabsorption due to liver dysfunction. Risk for Infection: Impaired immune function and potential for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) in cirrhosis. Acute Pain: Abdominal discomfort from liver inflammation, ascites, or liver capsule distension. Disturbed Thought Processes: Hepatic encephalopathy from toxin buildup affecting brain function. Fatigue: Decreased liver function and metabolic changes cause physical exhaustion. Impaired Skin Integrity: Risk of skin breakdown from edema, pruritus, or jaundice. Risk for Impaired Liver Function: Further liver damage due to ongoing inflammation, alcohol, or medication use. Anxiety: Psychological stress from chronic illness, uncertainty, and potential complications.

item.title: Diabetes T2
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #endocrine #diabetes insulin resistance - cells don't respond properly to insulin
leads to Hyperglycemia there is insulin produced by pancreas but it is not enough to maintain blood glucose (in addition to resistance)
more common than Diabetes T1 reversible, unlike DM1 Insulin resistance (muscle, liver, fat cells fail to respond to insulin). Beta-cell dysfunction (decreased insulin secretion over time). Excess hepatic glucose production (due to unregulated gluconeogenesis). FAT: obesity, sedentary lifestyle, unbalanced diet 45 and older gestational diabetes or PCOS giving birth to a baby heavier than 9 lbs genetics/family hx prediabetes unhealthy sleep habits (blood glucose naturally rises/falls during sleep, poor sleep limits control) slower onset than DM1 fatigue visual changes brownish skin thickening on NECK & ARMPIT delayed wound healing, infection, gangrene in extremities, dry skin 3 Ps: Polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia weight changes Hyperosmolar Hyperglycemic Syndrome (HHS) – severe hyperglycemia, extreme dehydration, altered mental status; usually 600 mg/dL, no acidosis, slow onsetChronic complications: nerve damage: blindness (diabetic retinopathy) & peripheral neuropathy (can't feel toes) abnormal electrical conduction in heart =>arrhythmia patches on skin renal impairment: diabetic nephropathy (kidneys get damaged from filtering sugary blood) bowel dysfunction CAD: MI, stroke Peripheral artery disease: amputation risk rare: DKA non-fasting blood glucose level will be 200 mg/dL or higher fasting blood glucose level will be 126 mg/dL or higher HbA1c is 7% or higher (some parts of ATI says 6.5%) Glucose over 200 with an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) Urinalysis: elevated glucose and acetone
Biguanides - Metformin (first line drug) diet: low glycemic index, Mediterranean diet exercise - aerobic & resistance, walk 8-9 miles a week
Canagliflozin (see GLP-1)
newer meds: SGLT2 Inhibitors
Insulin on some patients bariatric surgery below 70 blood sugar is EMERGENCY = give sugar ASAP (IV D50 or oral if able), do not assess, just give sugar hold metformin before contrast dye procedures inspect feet daily for ulcers, cuts, infections (d/t neuropathy) encourage proper foot hygiene, consider podiatry consult

item.title: Diabetes T1
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #endocrine #diabetes
Check the Insulin note in Pharmacology section insulin dependent (pancreas doesn't produce insulin) autoimmune disease that involves the destruction of the beta cells in the pancreatic islets of Langerhans in the pancreas HbA1c between 5.7% and 6.4% too much glucose in blood but no insulin => can cause hyperglycemia and DKA if left untreated Muscles and organs cannot use glucose without insulin Autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells (most common). Genetic predisposition Environmental triggers (viral infections like Coxsackievirus, rubella, or toxins). genetics, family hx of autoimmune diseases (Hashimoto's, celiac) age - usually between 4-6 years old, or 10-14 possible to occur at any age 3 Ps: Polyuria (peeing nonstop), Polydipsia (extreme thirst), Polyphagia (extreme hunger) fatigue unintentional weight loss visual changes (Diabetic retinopathy) delayed wound healing dry skin Paresthesia: tingling in feet and hands Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) - see below cardiovascular disease: MI, stroke
kidney disease => failure (CKD), dialysis, transplant Nerve and vascular problem (from constant hyperglycemia) => may lead to amputation Diabetic neuropathy (numbness, burning pain, foot ulcers). Diabetic retinopathy => affects nerves in eyes = blindness long term: weight loss and muscle wasting (from breakdown of bodyfat and muscles) Vitiligo - autoimmune condition that affects skin coloration DKA life-threatening condition body burns fat for fuel, results in buildup of acidic ketones => dehydration, weakness, e- imbalance other symptoms: fruity odor breath, confusion
most common in Diabetes T1 blood glucose typically above 250 mg/dL Blood ketones and β-hydroxybutyrate present non-fasting blood glucose level will be 200 mg/dL or higher fasting blood glucose level will be 126 mg/dL or higher HbA1c is 7% or higher Glucose over 200 with an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) Urinalysis: elevated glucose and acetone no permanent cure - must be managed forever
Injectable Insulin (forever) CGM - Continuous Glucose Monitoring insulin pumps and glucose sensors that send alerts to a smartphone or other electronic devices to help avoid hypoglycemia events Regular eye exams - annual Regular Foot exams, possible podiatry consult Lifestyle and nutrition below 70 blood sugar is A PRIORITY = give sugar ASAP (IV D50 or oral if able), do not assess or recheck sugar, just give sugar heat and humidity can exacerbate DM management (affects metabolism) => avoid dehydration Be vigilant with patients presenting with other illnesses => blood glucose becomes more difficult Teach sick-day management (continue insulin, monitor ketones, stay hydrated).

item.title: GFR
item.description: GFR measures how well the kidneys are filtering blood, specifically the volume of blood that passes through the glomeruli (kidney's filtering units) per minute. Normal GFR for a healthy adult is typically around 90–120 mL/min/1.73m², and it can vary based on age, gender, and body size. A decrease in GFR indicates impaired kidney function, which is crucial in diagnosing and staging Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD). Just note that normal GFR is ≥ 90 Guiding Treatment Decisions: Changes in GFR guide adjustments in medication (e.g., dosages of renally cleared drugs) and lifestyle modifications. Monitoring Complications: Low GFR can lead to complications like fluid retention, electrolyte imbalances, and uremia, all of which require close monitoring and management. Preventing Progression: Nurses use GFR to track kidney function over time and assess the effectiveness of interventions (e.g., blood pressure control, blood sugar management) in preventing further damage.

item.title: Insulin
item.description: note: give food when insulin peaks (glucose less than 70)Rapid-acting insulin (e.g., Lispro/Humalog, Aspart/NovoLog) Onset: 15-30 minutes Peak: 1–2 hours Duration: 3–5 hours Given before meals to control postprandial blood sugar spikes ASSPART = move you ass, this is fast REGULAR or SHORT-acting insulin (e.g., Regular insulin, Humulin R, Novolin R) Onset: 30–60 minutes Peak: 2–4 hours Duration: 4-12 hours Often used in hospital settings for acute control. Intermediate-acting insulin (e.g., NPH - aka CLOUDY insulin) => N = not fast Onset: 1–2 hours Peak: 4–12 hours Duration: 14-24 hours slower release, kind of like regular gas, but with a longer burn time => basal control usually taken twice a day never IV Long-acting insulin (e.g., Glargine/Lantus, Detemir) Onset: 1–2 hours Peak: No pronounced peak Duration: Up to 24 hours Provides basal insulin coverage, typically administered once daily. Premixed insulin A combination of short or rapid-acting and intermediate-acting insulins. Given for those who require both rapid and basal control with fewer injections. commonly mixed: NPH (intermediate) and Regular (short acting) ROLL THE VIAL for CLOUDY - do not shake clean with alcohol swab Lantus cannot be mixed with anything NR-RN: I am NOT RETIRED, I am an R-N insert AIR ONLY in order : NPH first, then Regular (not-retired) once air is inside on both vials, proceed to draw from pressurized vials Draw in order R-N: Regular first, NPH last Alternative way of remembering: Cloudy to clear, clear to cloudy (air then draw) Subcutaneous injection (most common) - rotate sites regularly (abdomen, upper arms, thighs, or buttocks) Insulin pump (continuous infusion) Rotation of injection sites (avoid lipodystrophy) Check blood sugar levels before administration (to adjust dose accordingly). Vials vs. pens (insulin pens are easier for patients and caregivers to use). Correct storage (refrigerate unused insulin, do not freeze). Blood glucose monitoring before meals and at bedtime (typically 4 times a day, but can vary). A1C levels (target: <7% for most patients). Signs of hypoglycemia (shakiness, sweating, confusion, dizziness, headache). Signs of hyperglycemia (increased thirst, frequent urination, fatigue, blurred vision). Monitor for signs of insulin resistance (requiring dose adjustment). Mild hypoglycemia (BG <70 mg/dL): Consume 15-20g of quick-acting carbohydrate (e.g., 4 oz fruit juice, 3–4 glucose tablets). Severe hypoglycemia: Administer glucagon (IM) or 25–50mL of D50 (IV) if unconscious or unable to ingest oral glucose. Recheck BG after 15 minutes and repeat treatment if needed. Signs of hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia and how to respond to each. Insulin self-administration technique (rotation of injection sites, proper needle disposal). Dietary management (counting carbs, meal timing). Exercise considerations (adjusting insulin doses based on activity levels). Stress management (stress can raise blood sugar). Glucagon use (for patients at risk of severe hypoglycemia). Importance of regular follow-up (A1C checks, eye exams, kidney function). Adjust insulin doses based on current blood glucose levels, meal plans, and physical activity. Ensure proper patient education on the correct insulin use, lifestyle changes, and recognizing symptoms of hypo/hyperglycemia. Monitor for complications such as infection at injection sites or delayed wound healing. Assist with managing insulin pumps (ensure proper site placement, troubleshoot equipment). Coordinate care with dietitians and endocrinologists for individualized care plans.

item.title: Metabolic Syndrome
item.description: Cluster of conditions increasing risk for heart disease, stroke, and diabetes Includes hypertension, high blood sugar, excess abdominal fat, and abnormal cholesterol levels Diagnosis requires at least three of the five criteria: Large waist circumference (≥40 inches men, ≥35 inches women) Hypertension (≥130/85 mmHg) Hyperglycemia (fasting glucose ≥100 mg/dL) Elevated triglycerides (≥150 mg/dL) Low HDL (<40 mg/dL men, <50 mg/dL women) Insulin resistance (body doesn’t respond to insulin properly) Chronic inflammation Sedentary lifestyle and poor diet Genetic predisposition Obesity, especially central/abdominal obesity Sedentary lifestyle High-fat, high-sugar diet Family history of diabetes or cardiovascular disease Age > 45 years Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) Smoking and excessive alcohol use Often asymptomatic until complications arise Type 2 diabetes (progressive insulin resistance) Cardiovascular disease (MI, stroke, atherosclerosis) Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease Chronic kidney disease Increased risk of dementia and cognitive decline Elevated: Fasting glucose, triglycerides, BP, waist circumference Decreased: HDL cholesterol Other tests: A1C, lipid panel, fasting insulin levels Weight loss (5–10% reduction can improve outcomes) Regular exercise (150 min/week moderate-intensity) Heart-healthy diet (low sugar, low saturated fats, high fiber) Medications as needed: Metformin (for insulin resistance) Statins (for high cholesterol) Antihypertensives (for high BP) Educate on lifestyle modifications (diet, exercise, smoking cessation) Monitor blood glucose, BP, and lipid levels regularly Encourage medication adherence for BP, cholesterol, and diabetes control Assess for signs of cardiovascular complications (chest pain, SOB) NCLEX/ATI: Emphasize waist circumference as a key indicator, reinforce importance of gradual weight loss, and educate on reducing processed carbs and saturated fats

item.title: Hypoglycemia
item.description: Hypoglycemia occurs when blood glucose drops below 70 mg/dL, leading to neurological and autonomic symptoms. It is a medical emergency if untreated, as it can cause seizures, coma, or death. Excess insulin or diabetes medications (sulfonylureas, insulin overdose). Skipping meals or prolonged fasting. Excessive exercise without carbohydrate intake. Alcohol consumption (suppresses gluconeogenesis). Critical illness (sepsis, adrenal insufficiency, liver failure). Diabetes (Diabetes T1, Diabetes T2, on insulin or sulfonylureas). Malnutrition or inconsistent eating patterns. Intense physical activity without proper carb intake. History of hypoglycemia unawareness (common in long-term diabetics). Autonomic Symptoms (early): Sweating. Tachycardia, palpitations. Shakiness/tremors. Hunger. Neuroglycopenic Symptoms (late): Confusion, dizziness. Slurred speech. Blurred vision. Seizures or loss of consciousness (severe cases). Seizures, coma, or death if untreated. Increased risk of falls, accidents, and cognitive impairment. Blood glucose <70 mg/dL. Response to carbohydrate intake (symptoms improve). Conscious patient: "Rule of 15": Give 15g fast-acting carbs (juice, glucose tabs). Recheck glucose in 15 minutes. Repeat if still <70 mg/dL. Follow with a protein/carbohydrate snack to maintain glucose levels. Unconscious patient: Administer glucagon (IM or subQ). If in hospital, give IV dextrose (D50W). Monitor airway, vitals, and glucose levels. Monitor blood glucose frequently, especially for insulin-dependent patients. Educate on early signs of hypoglycemia and prevention strategies. Ensure meal consistency to prevent glucose drops. Encourage carrying a fast-acting glucose source (glucose tabs, candy). Educate family on glucagon use for emergencies.

item.title: Hyperglycemia
item.description:
Hyperglycemia is a condition of elevated blood glucose levels (>180 mg/dL postprandial or >126 mg/dL fasting) due to insufficient insulin action. It occurs in Diabetes T1, Diabetes T2, and other metabolic disorders. Insufficient insulin or medication noncompliance. Infection, illness, or stress (increases cortisol, raising glucose). Excess carbohydrate intake. Physical inactivity (reduces glucose uptake by muscles). Steroid medications (glucocorticoids). Uncontrolled diabetes (DM1, DM2, gestational diabetes). Infections, illness, or surgery. Stress, injury, or trauma. Use of hyperglycemia-inducing drugs (steroids, beta-blockers). Polyuria (excessive urination). Polydipsia (excessive thirst). Polyphagia (excessive hunger). Blurred vision. Fatigue & weakness. Dry skin & dehydration. Slow wound healing. Fruity breath odor, deep rapid breathing (Kussmaul respirations) in DKA. Acute: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) – occurs in DM1, characterized by hyperglycemia, ketosis, acidosis. Hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS) – occurs in DM2, severe hyperglycemia without ketosis but with dehydration and altered mental status. Chronic: Microvascular damage (retinopathy, nephropathy, neuropathy). Macrovascular disease (stroke, MI, PAD). Fasting blood glucose >126 mg/dL. Random blood glucose >200 mg/dL with symptoms. Hemoglobin A1c >6.5%. Urine ketones (present in DKA).
Insulin (rapid-acting for acute correction). Encourage hydration (prevents dehydration, flushes excess glucose). Monitor blood glucose frequently. Address underlying cause (infection, medication noncompliance, stress). Electrolyte replacement (especially potassium in DKA). Monitor blood glucose and ketones regularly. Assess for dehydration (dry mucous membranes, low BP, tachycardia). Encourage medication adherence (insulin, oral hypoglycemics). Educate on recognizing early signs of hyperglycemia. Monitor for complications (neuropathy, retinopathy, nephropathy).

item.title: Pylonephritis
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary kidney infection Ascending infection: develops from lower UTI where bacteria travels from urethra=>bladder=>ureters=>kidney 2 Types: Acute - abrupt swelling Chronic - aka reflux nephropathy, is much rarer than the acute condition and is diagnosed when repeated bouts of acute pyelonephritis occur usually in clients with urinary obstructions e.coli other bacteria (klebsiella, etc)
obstruction: BPH, stones, strictures (narrowing of urinary tract) Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) (backward urine flow from bladder to kidneys) prolonged catheterization females renal stones kidney or bladder disorders immunosuppression enlarged prostate urinary catheters Diabetes => can lead to emphysematous pyelonephritis, which is a necrotizing infection that destroys the kidney tissues fever over 102F pain in side, back, or groin dysuria cloudy or bloody urine fishy odor urine General infection sx: chills, N/V, fatigue mental confusion Emphysematous Pyelonephritis Renal Abscesses => pus in kidney Thrombosis in Renal Vein Acute Renal Failure Hypertension d/t kidney damage UA with culture
CBC Renal US DMSA - dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) test would show any scarring in the urinary tract due to pyelonephritis using a radioactive material injected into the arm then images are taken during the material’s passage through the kidneys. abx, levofloxacin, ampicillin educate: wipe from front to back Assess CVA tenderness monitor BUN, creatinine, UOP

item.title: UTI
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary broad term indicating infection in bladder, kidneys, ureters/urethra females more at risk d/t anatomy Based on Severity Uncomplicated UTI - or cystitis occurs when the bladder becomes infected with bacteria but there are no comorbidities present. Complicated UTI - clients who have comorbidities, such as diabetes, who are pregnant, or immunocompromised Based on Location Lower UTI: Cystitis - inflammation of the bladder Lower UTI: Urethritis - inflammation of the urethra
Upper UTI: Pylonephritis - infection of the renal pelvis and kidney Upper UTI: Ureteritis - less Based on Source of Infection Community-Acquired UTI → Occurs in individuals outside healthcare settings Nosocomial (Hospital-Acquired) UTI → Acquired in a healthcare setting, often associated with urinary catheters (Catheter-Associated UTI or CAUTI) e.coli - #1 cause; bacteria travels up urethra into the bladder indwelling catheters sexual intercourse pregnancy poor hygiene female frequent pelvic exams diaphragms condoms with spermicidal foam
Comorbidities: Diabetes T1, Diabetes T2, immunocompromised Old fucks: CONFUSION, agitation Lower UTI: dysuria, urinary frequency/urgency, suprapubic pain, cloudy, foul urine, hematuria
Upper UTI: fever, chills, flank pain (kidney pain), N/V, fatigue, malaise (see Pylonephritis) Urosepsis - systemic infection that starts in urogenital tract
CKD Retention Clean Catch Urinalysis - clean labia three times with sterile wipes, front to back, catch midstream dipstick urine testing Urine culture - also midstream
BUN - CMP antibiotics (Bactrim) - based on culture results
Analgesia cranberry juice hydration encourage hydration educate proper hygiene void before/after intercourse Avoid bladder irritants: caffeine, alcohol, spicy

item.title: Retention
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary unable to empty bladder Obstruction: prostate enlargement, urethral structure, renal stone, pelvic mass, stenosis of bladder neck Underactive Bladder - weak bladder muscles from aging or neuro problems (MS, Parkinsons, stroke, DM, meds) Medications: anticholinergics, opioids, anesthesia, antihistamines Postop: anesthesia, prolonged catherization BPH cervical cancer old age - underactive bladder pregnant - underactive bladder pelvic organ prolapse recent surgery Diabetes history of pelvic injury slow urine stream feeling of full bladder urge to void bladder discomfort distended bladder 200 mL post void residual (PVR) = inadequate emptying 400 mL = urinary retention Normal PVR: <20mL, 50-100mL for elderly UTI from urine stasis Bladder overdistention - loss of bladder tone Hydronephrosis: kidney damage from backflow Renal Failure UA culture for UTI Bladder scan: check post void residual scan (PVR)
PSA for BPH
Check for infection: CBC
Check for renal dysfunction/electrolyte imbalance: CMP
treat cause: BPH => 5-Alpha Reductase Inhibitors, Tamsulosin, TURP urinary strictures: endoscopy urethral dilation catheterization Monitor urinary output and bladder distention Teach catheter care if self-catheterization is required Educate on medication effects and side effects Encourage scheduled voiding to prevent overdistention Assess for UTI symptoms and complications Provide post-op care if surgical intervention is done

item.title: 5-Alpha Reductase Inhibitors
item.description: Finasteride (Proscar) Dutasteride (Avodart) Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) → reduces prostate size, improves urinary flow Androgenic alopecia (male pattern baldness) Inhibits 5-alpha reductase enzyme → prevents conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) Decreases prostate size by reducing DHT levels Slows disease progression but takes months for full effect Pregnancy (Category X) → teratogenic, can cause fetal male genital abnormalities Women of childbearing age should avoid handling crushed or broken tablets Hypersensitivity to drug components Caution in liver impairment Decreased libido, erectile dysfunction Gynecomastia (breast enlargement, tenderness) Orthostatic hypotension Ejaculatory dysfunction Depression, mood changes Assess urinary function and symptom improvement (may take 3–6 months) Monitor PSA levels (drug decreases PSA; continued elevation may indicate prostate cancer) Educate patients about sexual dysfunction risk Warn pregnant women to avoid handling medication Encourage regular follow-ups to assess response and screen for complications Teach patients to rise slowly from sitting/lying positions due to hypotension risk

item.title: IBS
item.description: What is it: Chronic functional GI disorder causing abdominal pain and altered bowel habits without structural damage. Causes: organic cause cannot be found (aka, functional disorder), Gut-brain axis dysfunction, altered motility, visceral hypersensitivity, microbiome imbalance. Risk Factors: Female gender, stress, anxiety, depression, GI infections, high-FODMAP diet Clinical Manifestations: cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, diarrhea, or constipation Diagnosis: no specific way to diagnose, Rome IV criteria (pain 1+ day/week for 3 months with stool changes), r/o other diseases (lactose tolerance, etc) Treatment: low FODMAP diet, probiotics, stress management, antispasmodics, laxatives, anti-diarrheas, SSRIs. Nursing Considerations: educate on triggers, diet, stress management, food journal FODMAP - fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols. examples: garlic, onions, wheat bread, apples, most beans, cherries, cauliflower, watermelon, high fructose corn syrup, and some dairy products like full-fat milk

item.title: Biguanides - Metformin
item.description: Metformin is an oral biguanide hypoglycemic agent primarily used for Diabetes T2 management. It lowers blood glucose levels without causing significant hypoglycemia.MMM Mini chance of low sugar Massive weight gain Major liver + kidney = toxic Decreases hepatic glucose production (inhibits gluconeogenesis). Increases insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues (muscles and fat). Decreases intestinal glucose absorption. First-line therapy for type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). Used in polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) to improve insulin resistance. May be used off-label for prediabetes to delay progression to T2DM. Severe renal impairment (eGFR <30 mL/min/1.73m²). Metabolic acidosis (including diabetic ketoacidosis). Severe liver disease (risk of lactic acidosis). Heart failure with hypoperfusion. Alcoholism (increased risk of lactic acidosis). Use of iodinated contrast dye (hold before and after procedures). Gastrointestinal distress (nausea, diarrhea, abdominal pain). Lactic acidosis (rare but serious, increased risk in renal/liver impairment). Vitamin B12 deficiency (long-term use). Metallic taste (occasionally reported). Monitor renal function (check eGFR before starting and periodically). Take with food to reduce GI side effects. Assess for lactic acidosis (muscle pain, weakness, fatigue, difficulty breathing). Hold 48 hours before and after contrast dye procedures to prevent acute kidney injury. Monitor vitamin B12 levels in long-term use to prevent deficiency. Avoid excessive alcohol intake due to increased risk of lactic acidosis.

item.title: CMP
item.description:
Fluid Electrolyte Cheat Sheets
#nursing creatinine over 1.3 = no more pee pee (kidney injury)

item.title: GLP-1
item.description: Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonists are injectable (some oral) antidiabetic agents that mimic incretin hormones, enhancing insulin secretion and lowering blood glucose. Exenatide (Byetta, Bydureon) Liraglutide (Victoza, Saxenda – for weight loss) Semaglutide (Ozempic, Rybelsus – oral form available) Dulaglutide (Trulicity) Tirzepatide (Mounjaro – dual GLP-1/GIP agonist, not strictly GLP-1) Stimulate insulin release from pancreatic beta cells (glucose-dependent). Inhibit glucagon secretion, reducing hepatic glucose production. Slow gastric emptying, increasing satiety and promoting weight loss offer improved efficacy, longer duration of action, and additional benefits like weight loss and cardiovascular protection some are once a week Diabetes T2 (T2DM)** (improves glycemic control). Obesity or overweight with comorbidities (certain GLP-1 agonists approved for weight loss). Cardiovascular risk reduction (for high-risk T2DM patients). Personal or family history of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). Multiple endocrine neoplasia syndrome type 2 (MEN2). Severe gastrointestinal disease (e.g., gastroparesis). History of pancreatitis (use with caution). Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea (most common, usually improves over time). Delayed gastric emptying (may affect drug absorption). Pancreatitis (rare but serious). Thyroid tumors (animal studies) (black box warning). Hypoglycemia (when combined with insulin or sulfonylureas). Monitor GI symptoms, especially nausea and weight loss. Assess for pancreatitis (severe abdominal pain, vomiting). Educate on slow eating habits to minimize nausea. Monitor renal function (some formulations affect hydration status). Caution with other gastric-emptying drugs (may affect absorption of oral meds).

item.title: SGLT2 Inhibitors
item.description: Sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitors are oral antidiabetic agents that lower blood glucose by increasing urinary glucose excretion.Prototype: Canagliflozin (Invokana) Inhibit SGLT2 in the proximal renal tubules, preventing glucose reabsorption. Increase glucose excretion in urine (glycosuria), lowering blood glucose. Induce osmotic diuresis, leading to mild BP reduction and weight loss. Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) (as monotherapy or adjunct). Heart failure (HFrEF & HFpEF) (reduces hospitalizations & mortality). Chronic kidney disease (CKD) (slows progression and reduces cardiovascular risk). Severe renal impairment (eGFR <30 mL/min/1.73m² for most drugs). Type 1 diabetes (increased risk of diabetic ketoacidosis). Recurrent UTIs or genital infections (due to glycosuria). Pregnancy & breastfeeding (insufficient safety data). Genitourinary infections (UTIs, fungal infections). Dehydration & hypotension (from osmotic diuresis). Euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) (rare but serious). Lower limb amputation risk (seen with canagliflozin). Acute kidney injury (especially in volume-depleted patients). Monitor renal function (assess eGFR before starting). Educate on hydration (prevent dehydration & hypotension). Assess for signs of infection (UTIs, genital infections). Monitor for ketoacidosis (even if blood glucose is normal). Caution in elderly & hypotensive patients (risk of falls from volume loss).

item.title: Pulmonary Edema
